headline: Qwest Said to Oust Its Chief Executive
abstract: Joseph P. Nacchio, the chairman and chief executive of Qwest Communications  International, was forced to resign last night by the company's board, executives involved in the decision said.

headline: OECD's cautionary tale of porn and cyberspace
abstract: PARIS:—  The trouble at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development began when its French-language Web site was replaced by an "adults only" page offering links to "puritan sex" and "porn tryout."

headline: Just T-Bills, Thanks, For a Lady Who Saves
abstract: Interview with Elaine Stritch, now starring in one-woman Broadway show, Elaine Stritch at Liberty, on subject of money, which she says she cares about very much; she keeps large portion of her assets in real estate and has put bulk of her investments for last 30 years in Treasury bills; photos (L)

headline: Osaka Journal; Oh-So-Sober Japan, Suddenly Drunk on Soccer
abstract: Osaka explodes in frenzy when Japan beats Russia for its first ever World Cup soccer victory, scene that was repeated all over Japan; almost no one had predicted that normally subdued populace would be swept up in wild revelry, but Japan's affection for soccer, which began tentatively decade ago, has turned into head-over-heels love affair that reflects deep-seated generational changes; map; photos (Osaka Journal) (M)

headline: The Economics of Ink
abstract: Peter J Wilson letter on Apr 25 article about inkjet photo printers disputes manufacturers' claim that having individual color cartridges is more convenient and cheaper

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Policing The Police
abstract: Nigeria creates 550-unit to root out corruption in country's police force of 180,000 officers (S)

headline: A New Condition for Palestinians Is Set by Bush
abstract: President Bush told the Palestinian people today that they must replace Yasir Arafat as their leader before the U.S. will support an independent Palestinian state.

headline: Israel Continues Sweep of Cities, Taking Hebron
abstract: Israeli tanks and armored vehicles rolled into Hebron on Thursday evening, while heavy fighting was reported in other parts of the West Bank.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Foreign Minister Cracks Down
abstract: Min Yoriko Kawaguchi dismisses Japan's ambassador to Netherlands, Kazuhiko Togo, and punishes 36 other foreign ministry employees in major reform effort after series of scandals; she replaces Makiko Tanaka in office (S)

headline: ISRAEL ACTS TO SEIZE ARAB LAND AFTER BLAST; BUSH DELAYS TALK
abstract: Israel says it will shortly begin seizing land held by Palestinian Authority in response to Palestinian suicide bombing on Jerusalem bus that killed 19 people and hold it as long as terror continues; Israeli military moves into West Bank areas, with tanks and troops briefly entering Nablus, arresting three suspects and withdrawing; soldiers also seize six Palestinians in Hebron and two nearby villages, raid Jenin and its refugee camp and enter Qalqilya; it is not clear whether moves are part of new policy; Palestinian Authority condemns bombing; holds Israel has left it powerless to stop attacks; map; graph of rise in suicide bombings; photos (M)

headline: Chess Match Starts in Trial Of Andersen
abstract: Lawyers and jury consultants say picking jury to hear obstruction of justice charge against Arthur Andersen in Enron case will be harder for Andersen than for Justice Department, even though it needs only one true believer to prevent guilty verdict; note people tend to have less sympathy for big, powerful accounting firm than for individual charged with crime (M)

headline: Rolling Stone, Struggling for Readers, Names Briton as Editor
abstract: Rolling Stone names Ed Needham as managing editor; he is Briton schooled in racy ways of contemporary English men's magazines; appointment signals end of Rolling Stone's history as publisher of epic narratives and literary journalism, in part because owner Jann Wenner believes that today's younger reader has little patience for long articles (M)

headline: Royal Dutch/Shell Will Buy Enterprise Oil of Britain
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group will buy Enterprise Oil of Britain for 3.5 billion pounds, or $5 billion, in cash; acquisition allows Royal Dutch/Shell to increase production in North Sea by 30 percent and nearly double Norwegian output; some analysts say Royal Dutch/Shell is paying too much because company, which has sat on sidelines through wave of consolidation among nimbler competitors, was under pressure to do a deal (M)

headline: Judge Allows States to Present New Evidence Against Microsoft
abstract: Federal Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly, who is presiding over Microsoft Corp antitrust case, says she will overlook procedural errors by states pursuing sanctions against company and allow them to present new evidence about restriction they have proposed; Kollar-Kotelly, over Microsoft's objections, agrees to allow states to present expert witness James Bach in attempt to show that company's Windows operating system can be broken into different components; decision is first indication that Kollar-Kotelly, who rarely asks questions and has little background in technology, has been paying close attention to conflicting testimony over states' demand for 'modular' version of Windows; version would allow computer makers to substitute rival software for programs like Microsoft's Web browser (M)

headline: Offer for TRW Is Extended
abstract: Northrop Grumman extends its $11.9 billion tender offer for TRW Inc to June 14 (S)

headline: 2nd Day of Antigovernment Protests Slows Venezuela
abstract: Thousands of antigovernment protesters take to streets in Venezuela in second day of general strike by labor and business leaders incensed by Pres Hugo Chavez's left-leaning policies; clash sporadically with demonstrators backing Chavez; protest leaders extend strike indefinitely; government admits for first time that strike has hurt oil output, as exports sag; plays down disruptions; Brig Gen Nestor Gonzalez, army commander, scores Chavez and suggests military might oust him, news conference; Gen Rafael Damiani urges military not to use force against protesters, confusing message since government has not resorted to violence; photo (M)

headline: Photofinishers Go the Silicon Route, Too
abstract: Digital photofinishing gains wider acceptance and can produce acceptable prints even from inferior photos; most customers do not realize their prints are being made electronically; photo (M)

headline: S.E.C. Plans a Forum On Investor Confidence
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission plans public session for investors who want to comment on agency's response to crisis in public confidence in stock market; chairman, Harvey L Pitt, says SEC is moving aggressively to restore investor confidence on every front (S)

headline: Falling Consumer Confidence Helps Send the Dow Lower
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average declines 28.59, to close at 9,474.21; Standard & Poor's 500 index falls 2.29, to 1,007.27; Nasdaq composite index finishes up 7.88, at 1,504.74; 10-year Treasury note's yield drops to 4.80 percent from 4.90 percent as its price rises 24/32, to 100 18/32; graph; tables of stock prices and key rates (M)

headline: Party Organ In Cuba Prints Speech By Carter
abstract: Newspaper of Cuba's Communist Party, in highly unusual gesture of openness, publishes uncensored text of former Pres Jimmy Carter's speech in which he bluntly criticized Cuba's government for denying basic freedoms and endorsed referendum to improve rights; referendum campaign itself has been subjected to news blackout in state-run media, even after supporters garnered more than 10,000 signatures on petitions; newspaper Granma devotes five pages to Carter's speech and to his detailed responses to audience members who denounced referendum campaign, known as Project Varela, as foreign creation; Granma does not act on Carter's suggestion that it also print demands of project: for electoral law reform, amnesty for political prisoners, freedom of expression and right to own small businesses (M)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: BRAZIL: Election Law Prompts Shake-up; Dominican REPUBLIC: Human Rights Plea.

headline: USA Interactive Bids for 3 Web Affiliates
abstract: USA Interactive offers to buy all outstanding shares of Expedia, Hotels.com and Ticketmaster, Internet companies it already controls, for $4.5 billion of its stock; USA shares fall and shares of 3 companies rise, indicating investors expect USA to raise bids; USA head Barry Diller comments (M)

headline: SHARON SAYS ISRAEL IS IN A WAR AFTER SUICIDE BOMBING KILLS 14; MORE TANKS MOVE IN WEST BANK
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon, calling Palestinians leader Yasir Arafat 'enemy of the entire free world,' declares Israel to be at war; issues statement after suicide bomber detonates charge in restaurant in Haifa, killing himself and at least 14 others and as Israel tightens military cordon around Arafat's compound in Ramallah; terse remarks seem aimed at preparing Israel and world for major new assault on West Bank, and possibly Arafat's office itself; Israeli forces take up positions on outskirts of Tulkarm in West Bank; tanks and armored vehicles reportedly advance closer to Bethlehem; enter Palestinian-controlled territory in Qalqilya, northeast of Tel Aviv; Palestinian and other Arab leaders increasingly blame US for Palestinians' predicament, after Pres Bush gave qualified blessing for Israeli assault on Arafat's compound; American diplomacy has remained largely silent since then; Pope John Paul II issues call for cease-fire in Easter Sunday message; group of 40 members of pro-Palestinian group walk through Israeli lines to Arafat's office; most remain inside, apparently intending to act as human shield; cause consternation at top levels of Israeli government; Arab leaders call attack on Arafat's compound as threat to regional stability; photos; maps (M)

headline: White House Feels Its Way as Crisis Deepens
abstract: Bush administration, confronting toughest diplomatic crisis yet, struggles to forge effective Middle East policy as escalating violence rapidly shifts ground; issue is whether administration should hold to longstanding proposals to first cement cease-fire and then begin talks; experts say US has three basic choices; first is giving Israelis green light to evict Yasir Arafat and dismantle Palestinian Authority on assumption that he will never be reliable negotiating partner and Israel must act alone to constrain terrorism; second is current one of watching from sidelines in hope that two sides, exhausted and bloodied, will eventually sit down with envoy Anthony Zinni; third approach would insist that political and security issues be addressed at same time; former envoy Dennis Ross has proposed US set schedule for Palestinians to end terrorism and Israel to withdraw troops, set timetable for starting talks on final settlement, and outline agenda, asking Mideast ministers to visit Washington to push effort (M)

headline: Down to Raucous Wire, Osbournes in MTV Deal
abstract: Negotiations over a new contract for at least 20 more episodes of "The Osbournes," MTV's biggest hit series ever, turned out to be every bit as bizarre as the series itself.

headline: Gays in Jerusalem Parade Their Pride
abstract: First gay pride parade is held in Jerusalem over loud protests from Orthodox Jewish politicians and some demonstrators, who condemn it as celebration of sin; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Juniper Ships High-End Switch
abstract: Juniper Networks begins shipping world's fastest Internet router, T640, which can handle four times Internet traffic of competing products (S)

headline: F.T.C. Is Urged to Take a Hard Line on Snuff
abstract: Antismoking advocates Rep Henry A Waxman and Sen Richard J Durbin urge Federal Trade Commission to derail snuff industry's bid to promote chewing tobacco as safer alternative to cigarettes, letter to FTC head Donald S Clark; charge UST Inc, largest snuff company, unfairly focuses its advertising on children in violation of 1998 settlement with over 40 states, letter to National Association of Attorneys General; hold FTC lacks authority to let companies say snuff poses fewer health risks than smoking (M)

headline: Bahrain Tries to Fill In Potholes on Road to New Government
abstract: Focus on politics of Persian Gulf island state of Bahrain, where potential for instability runs high; tensions between ruling Sunni minority, who have most of wealth, and Shiite majority, which is largely poor discussed; efforts of Khalifa monarchy to still anger of poor by easing away from one-man rule with municipal elections and vote for national Parliament noted; maps (M)

headline: Enron Partners Argue for Removal of Law Firm
abstract: A group of Enron's business partners argued Wednesday for the removal of Milbank Tweed Hadley & McCloy as counsel to the Enron creditors committee.

headline: At World Cup Time, The Web Never Sleeps
abstract: For those who cannot see World Cup Soccer matches because games are broadcast from host countries South Korea and Japan very early in United States, ESPNSoccernet provides continuous updates, written commentary and rough approximation of ball's position on field for up-to-minute coverage; discussion groups allow fans to swap analysis and opinion; photo (M)

headline: Article 2002042290836651978 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Business Text Version         function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                            International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics             Business           -      Media & Advertising            -      World Business            -      Your Money            -      Markets            -      Company Research            -      Mutual Funds            -      Stock Portfolio            -      Columns               Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Vietnamese Refugees Leave Camps
abstract: United Nations moves 905 ethnic minority Vietnamese refugees from two camps just inside Cambodia to Phnom Penh in preparation for their resettlement in United States; Cambodia plans to close camps and seal borders to new asylum seekers, hill tribe members formerly known as Montagnards, who have been fleeing violent land disputes and government crackdown on their unauthorized Protestant Christian groups (S)

headline: A Top Andersen Partner Details Shredding Policy
abstract: Arthur Andersen partner Richard Corgel, under strong cross-examination by Asst US Atty Andrew Weissmann in obstruction case involving Enron Corp, testifies firm maintained policy to destroy extraneous documents in part so records could not be used against firm in litigation; Corgel's testimony is damaging to Andersen, which has argued records destroyed under firm's policies were largely irrelevant and contained no information that it would have wanted to keep from government or plaintiffs; Chad DeJohn, member of computer consulting team with Andersen, testifies about e-mail messages he sent out last fall instructing members of his team to get in compliance with firm's document retention policy, which required destruction of certain records; those messages have been introduced by government; DeJohn testifies that he put pressure on his team to come in compliance with rules, to ensure that they finished other projects on time; Andersen announces deal for transfer of its employees, this time affecting more than 300 people, including 40 partners, in firm's New York office; they will join Ernst & Young (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Primedia Makes a Change at Its Consumer Magazines
abstract: Primedia asks John Loughlin to step down as consumer group chief executive; David Ferm, business-to-business group head, will succeed him; chief executive Tom Rogers comments; photo (M)

headline: In Venezuela, Chávez Starts Shuffling Disloyal Officers
abstract: President Hugo Chávez, after being forced out of power for two days last week by military officers, is reorganizing the armed forces and making appointments to ensure that he is surrounded by loyal commanders.    But active and retired military officers say that the military remains deeply divided and perhaps prone to participating in a popular uprising like the one last Thursday that temporarily removed Mr. Chávez.

headline: Palestinians Sow Confusion And Doubt On Bombing
abstract: Palestinian Authority's intelligence service head Amin al-Hendi says recent suicide bombing in pool hall in Tel Aviv, Israel, does not appear to be work of Palestinian terrorists, but rather was conducted by Israeli criminals against illegal gambling club; Israel dismisses remarks as baseless and irresponsible; says bombing was conducted by Hamas, radical Islamic group (M)

headline: Two Reports Show a Faltering Recovery
abstract: University of Michigan consumer sentiment index falls to 90.8 in June from 96.9 in May; Federal Reserve reports production at factories, mines and utilities rose 0.2 percent in May after gaining 0.3 percent in April; reports demonstrate faltering US economic recovery; graphs (M)

headline: Shares Rally After Unexpectedly Healthy Retail Sales
abstract: Nasdaq composite index is up 66.51 points, or just over 4 percent, to 1,719.05; Dow Jones industrial average gains 188.48 points, or 1.9 percent, to 10,298.14; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 22.72 points, or 2.1 percent, to 1,097.28; US Treasury's benchmark 10-year note falls 16/32, to price of 96 27/32; yield rises to 5.29 percent from 5.23 percent; 30-year bond drops 25/32, to 94 25/32; yield climbs to 5.75 percent from 5.69 percent; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Investing; Hotels Are Adjusting to a Travel Slump. Are Their Stocks?
abstract: Analysts of hotel industry hold varying opinions concerning current valuations and future prices of stocks of hotel operators; all agree that slump in occupancy rates persists despite recovery in stock prices of lodging companies; graph (M)

headline: On Eve of Sharon's U.S. Visit, 2 Settlers Are Killed in Raid
abstract: At least three people die, including attacker, and four more are wounded when two Palestinian gunmen attack heavily guarded Karmei Tzur Jewish settlement in West Bank; attack comes on eve of US visit by Prime Min Ariel Sharon and day after Israeli forces swept into Palestinian-controlled towns in search of wanted militants; Israeli government steps up diplomatic and public relations offensive against Yasir Arafat; charge him with failing to stop terrorist attacks; Arafat urges Bush administration to move quickly toward international peace conference for Middle East (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cisco Buys Two Companies
abstract: Cisco Systems acquires Hammerhead Networks and Navarro Networks for as much as $258 million in stock (S)

headline: KIMCO REALTY RENTS SOME OF ITS CLOSED KMART STORES
abstract: Kimco Realty Corp says it leased 6 of 14 Kmart Corp locations that Kmart closed after filing for bankruptcy protection from creditors (S)

headline: Officials Say Qaeda Suspect Has Given Useful Information
abstract: American officials say they have verified accuracy of some of information provided by Abu Zubaydah, captured senior leader of Al Qaeda, and express cautious optimism that he will eventually divulge more detailed information about terrorist network and whereabouts of surviving leaders, including Osama bin Laden; interrogations of Zubaydah are being carried out by CIA and FBI at undisclosed location overseas; Zubaydah was principal recruiter for Al Qaeda terrorist camps in Afghanistan and is believed to know identity of members who are in hiding around world in so-called sleeper cells (M)

headline: Accounting Change Gets Fresh Support
abstract: PricewaterhouseCoopers chief executive Samuel DiPiazza says worldwide accounting standards should be based on brand principles instead of specific rules to restore investors' confidence (S)

headline: ABB Plans to Sell Part of Its Financial Unit
abstract: ABB Ltd is negotiating to sell part of its financial services division, a galling reversal for company but one analysts say is crucial to rehabilitating company's frayed finances; obtains commitments from three lenders to underwrite its $3 billion credit line; plans to raise $2 billion through bond issue to shore up its cash position as it struggles to reduce its $4 billion in debts; corporate diagram (M)

headline: South African Breweries Said to Be Near $5 Billion Miller Deal
abstract: South African Breweries is close to completing deal to acquire majority stake in Miller Brewing Co from Philip Morris Companies for about $5 billion in cash and stock; South African Breweries is expected to pay about $2 billion in cash and $3 billion in stock for 67 percent stake in Miller (M)

headline: Hindu Right Goes to School to Build a Nation
abstract: Sewa Dham school in Mandoli, India, where 300 young boys follow rigorous curriculum promoting Hindu nationalism, is central project of Hindu revivalist campaign, following years in which nationalists were banned and reviled because of connection to assassin of Mahatma Ghandi; is run by charity affiliated with Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, or National Voluntary Service, oldest and most prominent of Hindu nationalist groups which was founded in 1925 by men who made no secret of admiration for German and Italian fascists; is substantially bankrolled by Indians in US; Hindu nationalist network's political wing, Bharatiya Janata Party, leads coalition government in New Delhi; Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee was once full-time worker for voluntary service; map; photo (M)

headline: A Death and a Breach by Activists as Bethlehem Siege Persists
abstract: Palestinian negotiators offer compromise to end monthlong standoff between Israeli soldiers and Palestinian gunmen inside Church of Nativity in Bethlehem; proposal is modeled after American-brokered agreement that freed Yasir Arafat from house arrest in Ramallah; it would end siege at church by transferring men wanted by Israel as terrorists from inside church to Palestinian jail guarded by foreign wardens; Israel sends mixed signals through news media on Palestinian suggestion, but high-ranking defense official doubts proposal would be accepted because Israel classifies 25 of men inside church as most dangerous of terrorists, and wants them either tried in Israel or exiled on their exit; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Bank Declines Offer For Branches
abstract: National Australia Bank declines bid from rival, Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, to buy 56 regional bank branches being closed by National Australia to cut costs (S)

headline: Methods Used For Marketing Arthritis Drug Are Under Fire
abstract: Centocor, subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson, has been providing doctors with marketing materials that describe how they can make extra money by prescribing expensive rheumatoid arthritis drug called Remicade, practice that health care fraud experts say may be illegal; document once available to doctors on Centocor's Web site stated that included worksheet where physicians could calculate their 'estimated revenue per patient' from prescribing drug; worksheet stated 'revenue' was primarily difference between what Medicare pays doctors for drug and lower amount that Centocor charged doctors for drug; drug is one of few rheumatoid arthritis treatments that Medicare covers; Centocor says company does not talk about profitability and how physicians can make money; Dr Paul April says other doctors have told him that Centocor representatives invited them to meeting where they could learn about how they could profit from Remicade (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: TURKMENISTAN: Caspian Meeting Fails; NEPAL: Rebels Destroy A Home Of The Premier; MYANMAR: Bid To Free Opposition Leader; Sri LANKA: Drug Pirates Need Spelling Enhancer

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Death Sentence For Cult Leader; INDIA: Investigators Raid Muckrakers; CHINA: Floods And Landslides Kill Hundreds; INDONESIA: Suharto Son Denies Murder Charge

headline: Koizumi's Visit to War Shrine Angers Japan's Neighbors
abstract: Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi's surprise visit to war-related Yasukuni Shrine reignites strong tensions between Japan and its neighbors, China and South Korea; both nations denounce visit to shrine they see as symbol of Japan's past militarism; Beijing has long reproached Japan for failing to apologize for its brutal invasion of China in 1930's; South Korea's citizens were pressed into forced labor by tens of thousands of Japan during 35 years of colonial rule that ended in 1945; only three prime ministers have visited shrine since 1978; question of whether Japanese leader should visit shrine has become nationalist litmus test; photo (M)

headline: POLYMEDICA SHARES SURGE ON END OF S.E.C. INVESTIGATION
abstract: PolyMedica Corp, seller of diabetes test kits, says Securities and Exchange Commission has ended investigation of company without taking enforcement action, setting off rally in its stock price; PolyMedica acknowledged in August that it was being investigated by FBI for possible fraud at its Florida units, Liberty Medical Supply and Liberty Home Pharmacy; investigation, now being conducted by Justice Department, continues, and PolyMedica says it is cooperating (S)

headline: INCREASED SALES LIFT PROCTER & GAMBLE'S PROFITS
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co says quarterly earnings rose 16 percent; net income rose to $1.04 billion from $893 million year earlier; sales rose 4.1 percent, to $9.9 billion, biggest gain in two years (S)

headline: Market Place; For financial firms, proposed new rules on analysts are the least of their problems.
abstract: Big investment banks and brokerage firms have done plenty of complaining about new regulations that are intended to reduce influence their investment bankers have over their stock analysts; firms know that proposed rules are least of their problems; Wall Street research has come in for harsh criticism about its objectivity from investors, members of Congress and law enforcement officials; plaintiffs' lawyers are lining up to sue big banks and their well-known analysts for having recommeded stocks that crashed aftere boom of 1990's (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Private Sector; Helping the Poor, Phone by Phone
abstract: helping the poor, phone by

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Matsushita Merging Factories
abstract: Matsushita Electric Industrial Co, leading maker of consumer electronics, will merge some of its 41 plants in China to cut overlapping production (S)

headline: INVESTMENT FIRM IN DEAL WITH CONAGRA
abstract: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst agrees to acquire fresh beef and pork processing business of ConAgra Foods for about $950 million; Hicks Muse will control 54 percent of company, to be renamed Swift and Co, with its partner Booth Creek Management; ConAgra will retain 46 percent (S)

headline: Variations on an Office With Windows
abstract: In today’s Circuits, I looked at a fascinating challenger to the 800-pound gorilla of productivity software (Microsoft Office for Windows): something called OpenOffice.org.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Motorola Wins Round In Turkish Dispute
abstract: Federal Judge Jed S Rakoff orders members of wealthy Uzan family in Turkey to turn over stock in Telsim Mobil, Turkey's second-largest mobile phone company, and imposes freeze on related assets; ruling is hailed by Motorola and Nokia, which had sought order after filing lawsuit charging members of family and codefendants with illegally appropriating about $3 billion that had been lent to family, with Telsim stock as collateral; shares amounted to 66 percent stake in Telsim for Motorola and 7 percent for Nokia; Uzans arranged for Telsim to triple outstanding shares and then stripped foreign companies' shrunken holdings of voting rights; no trial date has been set (S)

headline: Andersen Partner Says He Came to Accept Guilt
abstract: David B Duncan, former partner with Arthur Andersen who pleaded guilty last month to obstruction of justice, testifies about months of anguish he experienced during his gradual shift from certainty in his own innocence to his eventual belief that he committed crime by destroying thousands of records related to Enron; Duncan, in his testimony given at criminal trial of Andersen on single charge of obstruction of justice, portrays himself as man tormented by scandal swirling around him, who repeatedly reexamined his own motivations and actions until he finally became convinced of his guilt; Duncan, in first day of cross-examination by Andersen's lead lawyer Rusty Hardin, describes events leading up to his decision to plead guilty; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rail Crash Cause
abstract: Train derailment at Potters Bar north of London that killed seven people and injured 70 was caused by problems in track repaired last year and inspected day before accident; transportation secretary Stephen Byers explains details to Parliament (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Russian Soldiers, Uninvited, Arrive
abstract: Russia sends 78 heavily armed soldiers into lawless Kodori Gorge in Georgia, ostensibly to provide security for United Nations and Russian monitors on border between Georgia and its separatist-controlled province, Abkhazia; Pres Eduard Shevardnadze denounces deployment as incursion, and his defense minister orders troops to leave or face attack (S)

headline: Looking to Suburbs to Map 9/11's Reach
abstract: ONE of the many mysteries left in the wake of Sept. 11 is just how hard the attack on the World Trade Center hit New York City's economy. Really hard, obviously.    But how hard, exactly? And how much of the past year's economic carnage came from the national recession, rather than from the disaster in Lower Manhattan?

headline: War Crimes Tribunal Becomes Reality, Without U.S. Role
abstract: World's first permanent court for prosecution of war criminals and dictators becomes reality as United States stands on sidelines in strong opposition; treaty that establishes International Criminal Court goes into effect now that it has been ratified by more than required minimum of 60 nations; total has reached 66, but Bush administration appears to be on verge of not only renouncing tribunal, but also removing signature of United States from treaty; it was signed during Clinton administration; Bush administration argues that court will open American officials and military personnel in operations abroad to unjustified, frivolous or politically motivated suits; Congress has passed law to forbid Americans at all levels of government to cooperate with new court (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Airport Deal Canceled
abstract: Malaysia and Schiphol International, Dutch airport operator, calls off plans for Schiphol to buy stake in Malaysia's airport management company; two signed memorandum of understanding in August for Schiphol to pay undisclosed sum for 30 percent of Malaysia Airport Holdings; Malaysian government owns about 70 percent of Malaysia Airport, which operates 37 airports around Malaysia (S)

headline: Article 2002042093677642929 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                       International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business             Technology           -      E-Business            -      Circuits            -    Columns             Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: A Line Etched by Fate
abstract: i3Mobile chief executive John A Lack The Boss column on his priorities; photo (M)

headline: SHOEMAKER SAYS PROFIT WILL BEAT EXPECTATIONS BY 25%
abstract: Skechers USA, maker of contemporary shoes, says its first-quarter profit will top analysts' estimates by at least 25 percent, setting off rise of $2.73 in its stock, to $21.64 per share (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Strategy Rebuffed
abstract: Federal Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly, who is presiding over Microsoft Corp antitrust trial, appears unreceptive to Microsoft's efforts to convince her that nine states have no right to seek antitrust penalties on company beyond settlement already reached with Justice Department; Microsoft argues that states do not have standing to ask for restrictions that would apply to Microsoft's business practices nationwide; Kollar-Kotelly notes that appeals court that upheld Microsoft's antitrust violations last year was well aware that original suit was brought by federal government along with coalition of states (M)

headline: DeVry University Chooses Draft
abstract: DeVry University names Draft Worldwide to handle its branding and direct marketing, with spending estimated at $35 million to $40 million; account had been previously handled by Brown Marketing Communications (S)

headline: Ivy League Or Also-Ran? Does It Matter?
abstract: Tom Redburn column on debate over whether attending highly-selective and expensive colleges confers any real economic benefit in later life; cites study showing students who chose school with lower admissions standards over more competitive school earned incomes just as high as those who attended elite schools; study found even students rejected by highly selective college did as well at those who attended it (M)

headline: 7,000 Jobs Expected to Be Cut at WorldCom
abstract: WorldCom, nation's second-largest long-distance company, is expected to cut about 7,000 jobs as it seeks to recover from slowdown in sales and federal inquiry into its accounting (S)

headline: 50 D'Arcy Workers to Lose Their Jobs
abstract: 50 D'Arcy Workers To Lose Their Jobs D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles is laying off about 50 employees, or 10 percent of the staff in its New York office. Diana McSweeney, a spokeswoman for D'Arcy, confirmed an Adweek report, that about 50 jobs were being eliminated from the New York agency, saying,

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Yellow Pages Publishers Assn is renamed Yellow Pages Integrated Media Assn; Torre Lazur-McCann Healthcare Worldwide acquires Target Research Associates; financial terms undisclosed; Media Planning Group acquires Schmitter Media Agentur for undisclosed sum (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mitsubishi's Profit Falls
abstract: Mitsubishi Corp says profit fell 35 percent in year ended in March; earned 60 billion yen ($466.9 million) as sales fell 5.5 percent; graph (S)

headline: Bush and Putin to Sign Nuclear Pact
abstract: President Bush said today that he would sign a treaty with President Vladimir V. Putin next week committing both nations to cut their nuclear arsenals by two-thirds.

headline: Investors Start to Take New Look at Vivendi
abstract: Some investors are suggesting that it may be time to get into Vivendi Universal SA's stock with Vivendi's share price down to point where who is worth less than sum of its parts; AXP European Equity fund manager Richard C Falle accuses Vivendi chief executive Jean-Marie Messier of confusing investors by mishandling change of management at Canal Plus, Vivendi's pay television operation in France, then by belittling French authorities when they defended their restrictions on Canal Plus as way to protect French cultural diversity; photo (M)

headline: Security Council Tries to Ease Tensions Between U.S. and Iraq
abstract: Diplomats on United Nations Security Council work quietly but persistently to head off American military action against Iraq by trying to persuade Saddam Hussein's government to reopen country to arms inspectors; diplomats fear that failure to persuade Iraqis to allow inspectors back will only strengthen hand of those within Bush administration who favor war, led by Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld (M)

headline: New Confidence U.S. Has a Qaeda Leader
abstract: American officials say man believed to be Abu Zubaydah, chief of operations of Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda terrorist network, was seriously wounded when captured recently in Pakistan and is in US custody; say US is more certain than ever of his identity; capture would represent major accomplishment in American campaign against terrorism, especially since Zubaydah is believed to have taken control of effort to rebuild Al Qaeda network (M)

headline: Pakistan, With U.S. Help, Vigorously Pursues Taliban
abstract: United States presses Pakistan to pursue more aggressively Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters who crossed border from Afghanistan and then went on to urban areas; as result, there are almost daily raids conducted by Pakistani agents, and at least 75 people have been detained; American agents played lead role in raid that resulted in biggest catch, Abu Zubaydah, top lieutenant of Osama bin Laden; government officials say Zubaydah has been in Pakistan since Dec--an embarrassment to local Pakistani intelligence agencies (M)

headline: With No Deal in Sight, Kirch Prepares to Declare Bankruptcy
abstract: The Kirch Group is preparing to declare that its core business is bankrupt, as the company's founder assumes the role of a passive bystander in a bailout argument.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Crowded Field For Parliament Race
abstract: French Interior Ministry reports 8,633 people declared candidacy in elections for 577 seats in National Assembly, one-third more than in legislative elections in 1997 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Restructuring Plan Advances
abstract: Parliaments of Serbia and Montenegro approve plan to remodel Yugoslavia as new state called Serbia and Montenegro (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Liberty Buys OpenTV Stake
abstract: Liberty Media agrees to buy controlling interest in interactive television company OpenTV from MIH Holdings for $185 million in cash and stock; photo (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ad Slump at AOL to Cause Parent to Miss 2002 Goals  AOL Time Warner said it would not achieve its original financial goals for 2002 because of a slump in advertising at America Online.    The company announced first-quarter results that exceeded Wall Street's expectations, even though it posted a $54.2 billion net loss, the result of an expected charge reflecting a decline in the company's value. [Page C6.]

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: More Authority For Chief Executive
abstract: Hong Kong Legislative Council approves government reorganization that transfers power from civil servants to personal appointees of Tung Chee-hwa, territory's chief executive (S)

headline: Iceland Bars American Falun Gong Followers
abstract: State Department asks Iceland's government why it ordered state airline, Icelandair, to refuse passage to American citizens who appear on list of followers of Falun Gong spiritual movement; Amb Jon Baldvin Hannibalsson of Iceland, in Washington, says his government does not want protests to interfere with visit this week of Pres Jiang Zemin of China, country that has branded Falun Gong as 'evil cult' (M)

headline: Private Sector; Entering a 'Community of Pain'
abstract: Bryan Marshal, restructuring specialist hired to help Arthur Andersen survive in business, has warned accounting firm members that they now belong to 'community of pain' and must prepare for difficult belt-tightening; interview; photo (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Slate Picks a Successor to Michael Kinsley
abstract: Slate, online magazine owned by Microsoft, names Jacob Weisberg editor; he beat out deputy editor Jack Shafer after each took turn as editor once Michael Kinsley announced he was stepping down; Kinsley and MSN News and Information general manager Scott Moore comment; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Pacific: Samoa: New Zealand Regrets Abuses
abstract: Prime Min Helen Clark of New Zealand, former semicolonial ruler of Western Somoa, visits Apia to apologize for New Zealand's negligence in influenza epidemic in 1918, which killed 8,000 islanders, and police suppression in 1929 of independence movement and later banishment of island chiefs; photo (S)

headline: Taliban Killed in New Operation in Afghanistan Mountains
abstract: Nearly 1,000 British commandos were airlifted to eastern Afghanistan today after an Australian patrol came under fire.

headline: Hotelevision Hires Nielsen for Ratings
abstract: Hotelevision in New York, which offers cable television via satellite to hotels, hires Nielsen Media Research to provide ratings that will measure viewership of 10 ad-supported cable networks it carries (S)

headline: Abitibi Faces Rating Cut
abstract: Moody's Investor

headline: On Quiet Jerusalem Streets, Few Back Arafat-Powell Talks
abstract: Few Israelis in Jerusalem back Sec of State Colin Powell's meeting with Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat; say Arafat is terrorist who is responsible for suicide bombings; see little sense in engaging in diplomatic sessions with him (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: First Virtual May Face S.E.C. Action
abstract: First Virtual Communications Inc, which makes video-conferencing software, says Securities and Exchange Commission might bring civil action against company; SEC says it intends to recommend civil enforcement proceedings against company, its executive chairman and two former officers; proceedings relate to April 1999 revision of company's financial results for previous year (S)

headline: Security Company Reconsidering Takeover
abstract: Securitas AB, Swedish maker of security systems, will decide this week whether to proceed with $3 billion takeover of British rival Chubb; Chubb has no relation to American insurance compay by same name (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico City: Delay On Two-Level Highways
abstract: Mexico City postpones plans to turn busiest roads into double-decker highways; proposal will be put to popular vote later this year (S)

headline: British Drug Industry Group Criticizes Pfizer
abstract: Association of British Pharmaceutical Industry's managing board, in rare move, publicly reprimands Pfizer Inc, saying it promoted several medicines for unapproved uses and marketed another drug before it received government approval; group ruled in February that Pfizer breached industry's code of conduct and discredited industry by using team of employees known as medical liaisons to promote its products to doctors improperly; Pfizer spokeswoman Mariann Caprino says company did not think medical liaisons in Britain had inappropriate discussions with doctors; says company failed to maintain proper documentation to prove it was following British rules (M)

headline: New Violence Over Rights Raises Fear In Guatemala
abstract: Rising threats and deadly violence against rights workers in Guatemala prompt fears of new crisis of political violence as country tries to recover from decades of civil war; accountant for prominent human rights foundation is shot dead, and four forensic anthropologists who unearthed skeletons of thousands of victims of civil war leave country after they and their families are threatened with death; officials say they do not know who is responsible for threats; rights groups suspect former military and intelligence officers involved in mass killings during civil war, which ended in 1996; Pres Alfonso Portillo's vow to prosecute those responsible for threats is of little confort to rights workers, given his government's scarce resources and ample domestic political problems (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Latvia: Language Law Dropped
abstract: Latvia's Parliament votes to drop language requirement that hinders ethnic Russians from running for political office; NATO and European Union had demanded change, which lawmakers hope will lead to invitation to join defense alliance; law had required candidates to prove fluency in Latvian; now they will only be required to give self-evaluation of language skills (S)

headline: The Words Of Bush On Treaty
abstract: Text of remarks by Pres Bush on new nuclear weapons treaty with Russia (S)

headline: Generational Shift: Brokaw Announces He'll Retire in '04
abstract: NBC signals start of generational shift among television network news anchors, naming Brian Williams, 43-year-old cable newscaster, to succeed to Tom Brokaw as anchor of Nightly News broadcast beginning at end of 2004; Brokaw's tenure as sole Nightly News anchor since 1983 and with network since late 1960's discussed; photos (M)

headline: Priceline Cuts Ties With Hill, Holliday
abstract: Priceline Cuts Ties With Hill, Holliday.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: F.B.I. Searches Software Maker
abstract: FBI agents search Speedera; company is uncertain about reasons for search, given that affidavit supporting search is sealed; Speedera has received civil complaint from competitor Akamai contending there was trade secret theft by Speedera's co-founder-chief technology officer Richard Day; Akamai says its proprietary information about customer Web site performance was stolen by Speedera from computers of Keynote Systems, company that tracks Web site performance (S)

headline: Battling Burnout, And Making a Difference
abstract: Robert N Sellar letter comments on April 14 article on executive 'burnout;' drawing

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Mixed Economic Signals; INDIA: Economic Growth;.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Big Board Weighs Changes For Corporate Directors  The New York Stock Exchange is considering taking steps to help shore up investor confidence in corporate governance in the aftermath of Enron's collapse.    One change would require companies whose shares trade on the Big Board to limit participation on their audit and compensation committees to independent directors. The exchange is also discussing a requirement that would force companies to separate the job of chairman from chief executive. [Page C5.]

headline: Qwest Said to Oust Its Chief Executive
abstract: Joseph P. Nacchio, the chairman and chief executive of Qwest Communications  International, was forced to resign last night by the company's board, executives involved in the decision said.

headline: OECD's cautionary tale of porn and cyberspace
abstract: PARIS:—  The trouble at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development began when its French-language Web site was replaced by an "adults only" page offering links to "puritan sex" and "porn tryout."

headline: Just T-Bills, Thanks, For a Lady Who Saves
abstract: Interview with Elaine Stritch, now starring in one-woman Broadway show, Elaine Stritch at Liberty, on subject of money, which she says she cares about very much; she keeps large portion of her assets in real estate and has put bulk of her investments for last 30 years in Treasury bills; photos (L)

headline: Osaka Journal; Oh-So-Sober Japan, Suddenly Drunk on Soccer
abstract: Osaka explodes in frenzy when Japan beats Russia for its first ever World Cup soccer victory, scene that was repeated all over Japan; almost no one had predicted that normally subdued populace would be swept up in wild revelry, but Japan's affection for soccer, which began tentatively decade ago, has turned into head-over-heels love affair that reflects deep-seated generational changes; map; photos (Osaka Journal) (M)

headline: The Economics of Ink
abstract: Peter J Wilson letter on Apr 25 article about inkjet photo printers disputes manufacturers' claim that having individual color cartridges is more convenient and cheaper

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Policing The Police
abstract: Nigeria creates 550-unit to root out corruption in country's police force of 180,000 officers (S)

headline: A New Condition for Palestinians Is Set by Bush
abstract: President Bush told the Palestinian people today that they must replace Yasir Arafat as their leader before the U.S. will support an independent Palestinian state.

headline: Israel Continues Sweep of Cities, Taking Hebron
abstract: Israeli tanks and armored vehicles rolled into Hebron on Thursday evening, while heavy fighting was reported in other parts of the West Bank.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Foreign Minister Cracks Down
abstract: Min Yoriko Kawaguchi dismisses Japan's ambassador to Netherlands, Kazuhiko Togo, and punishes 36 other foreign ministry employees in major reform effort after series of scandals; she replaces Makiko Tanaka in office (S)

headline: ISRAEL ACTS TO SEIZE ARAB LAND AFTER BLAST; BUSH DELAYS TALK
abstract: Israel says it will shortly begin seizing land held by Palestinian Authority in response to Palestinian suicide bombing on Jerusalem bus that killed 19 people and hold it as long as terror continues; Israeli military moves into West Bank areas, with tanks and troops briefly entering Nablus, arresting three suspects and withdrawing; soldiers also seize six Palestinians in Hebron and two nearby villages, raid Jenin and its refugee camp and enter Qalqilya; it is not clear whether moves are part of new policy; Palestinian Authority condemns bombing; holds Israel has left it powerless to stop attacks; map; graph of rise in suicide bombings; photos (M)

headline: A Cheerleader, for a Company in a Midlife Funk
abstract: Interview with Cisco Systems chief executive John T Chambers, who built company by buying technology from start-up enterprises and recruiting key workers through company acquisitions; he has slowed pace of acquisitions as Cisco's fortunes fell mercurially with Internet bubble; is reorganizing company, cutting costs and focusing on new markets; photo; chart (M)

headline: Venezuela's 2 Fateful Days: Leader Is Out, and In Again
abstract: Article reviews two days in which Venezuelan Pres Hugo Chavez was ousted by business and military leaders, and then restored when pro-Chavez crowds demand return and uprising collapses; photos; chronology (M)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Annan Opens Food Conference
abstract: Secretary General Kofi Annan opened a United Nations conference on hunger by urging a fairer distribution of food supplies and support for farmers. ''While some countries produce more than they need to feed their people,'' he said in Rome, ''others do not, and many of these cannot afford to import enough to make up the gap.'' Most speakers on the first day were African heads of state who called for removal of barriers to farm trade with developed countries and greater access by farmers in poorer nations to land, cheap loans, and technology for producing hardier crops. Mr. Annan, who is from Ghana, said that almost 200 million people in Africa, or 28 percent of the population, are chronically hungry, and that several countries in southern Africa face ''outright famine'' in coming months.   John Tagliabue (NYT)

headline: Dan Doerner
abstract: ART photographers have long fooled the eye with burning and dodging, effects that make portions of photos lighter or darker during the film development process. But with the advent of digital image editing, the 1990's produced a cottage industry of photo retouchers and compositors who altered photos for artistic or illustrative effect. Among the new crop of digital manipulators was Dan Doerner, 41, who studied photography at the State University of New York at Albany, learned literally to cut and paste images in a darkroom to create collages, and eventually worked with an early version of Adobe Photoshop in 1989 while living in Los Angeles.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Doubt About Tyco's Ability To Raise $6.5 Billion in Sale  A day after Tyco International said that it planned to spin off CIT, its financing division, investors and even Tyco's bankers questioned whether Tyco would be able to raise as much as it had pledged. Tyco, which has $23 billion in debt, hopes to raise $6.5 billion in the move.    The sale is crucial for Tyco, whose shares have plunged on concerns about its accounting and the credibility of its management. For CIT, the sale is crucial because it needs to regain access to the commercial paper market, the cheapest source of financing. [Page C3.]

headline: Sears to Buy Lands' End for $1.9 Billion
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest department store company, agreed to buy Lands' End the biggest specialty catalog and Internet retailer, for $1.9 billion in cash.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Rebound At BASF
abstract: BASF says first-quarter net income rose to $502 million, 72 percent higher than in first quarter year earlier; chairman Jurgen Strube comments; graph (S)

headline: F.D.A. Panel Recommends Approval for Psoriasis Drug
abstract: Advisory panel to Food and Drug Administration recommends approval of Biogen's psoriasis drug Amevive, clearing way for marketing of first new type of treatment in years for skin condition; Biogen executive vice president Dr Burt A Adelman welcomes approval (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Loss Widens As Sales Tumble At Ciena
abstract: Ciena says revenue in quarter ended April 30 fell to $87.05 million, down 80 percent from period in 2001; net loss rose to $612.2 million from $50.7 million; chief executive Gary B Smith comments; graph (S)

headline: U.S. Messages to Arab Youth, Wrapped in Song
abstract: Radio Sawa, new radio station established by US government, beams news and music to youth throughout Arab world to counteract anti-American diatribes on Middle East airwaves (M)

headline: Miller Beer Expected to Be Sold to South African Breweries
abstract: South African Breweries and Philip Morris came to an agreement that would enable South African Breweries to buy two-thirds of the Miller Brewing Company.

headline: When Still Meets Video, Can One Camera Do All?
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column explores whether one piece of equipment can capture both movies and still pictures; short movies taken with still cameras are 'painful to watch,' tiny image surrounded by sea of black that runs maximum of 8-10 seconds; camcorders are equally ineffective at taking snapshots; problem lies with light sensor inside camera, which currently cannot serve both technologies; review of several hybrids; drawbacks; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   8.00       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   4.50       Federal funds   2.00   1.74   5.30       3-month T-bills   1.79   1.74   4.12       6-month T-bills   2.11   2.04   4.02       10-yr. T-infl.   3.29   3.29   3.29       10-yr. T-note   5.42   5.39   4.97       30-yr. T-bond   5.82   5.80   5.49       Telephone bd.   7.88   7.84   7.75       Municipal bds.   5.44   5.44   5.30          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Other Advertising Items
abstract: Accounts • STIPhonecard Inc., New York, part of the Telco Group, to Cox Advertising, New York, to handle the first campaign for STIPhoneCard.com, a Web site for retail and wholesale phone-card transactions. Billings were estimated at $10 million. People • Thomas Moore, president and chief executive at Nelson Communications Worldwide, New York, the medical marketing unit of the Publicis Groupe, is resigning to become president and chief executive at the Biopure Corporation, Cambridge, Mass., a biotechnology company. Roger Haupt, chairman and chief executive at the Bcom3 Group, Chicago, will head Nelson temporarily as a successor to Mr. Moore is sought. Publicis is acquiring Bcom3, which operates a health care agency, Medicus Group International.

headline: Another Tumble Gives Stocks Their Fifth Week of Losses
abstract: Stock prices skid for third consecutive day and fifth sequential week; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 1.7 percent, or 17.15, closing at 989.14, below 1,000 for first time since its Sept 21, 2001 bottom following Sept 11 terrorist attacks; Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq composite index also drop sharply, Dow falling 177.98, or 1.9 percent, to 9,253.79 and Nasdaq losing 23.79, or 1.6 percent, to close at 1,440.96; flight-to-safety buying causes 5/32 gain in 10-year Treasury note, to 100 26/32, its yield falling to 4.77 percent from 4.79 percent; 30-year Treasury bond rises 12/32, to 99 20/32, driving its yield down to 5.40 percent, from 5.43 percent; photo; graphs; table of key rates (M)

headline: Micron Says It Will Buy Biggest Part Of Hynix
abstract: Micron Technology agrees in principle to buy most of Hynix Semiconductor of South Korea--taking all of its main business, manufacture of memory chips, and 15 percent stake in rest--for about $4 billion in cash and stock; memorandum of understanding opens way for Micron to look at Hynix's books and determine exactly how much Hynix owes (M)

headline: Premier Plays to Hungarian Pride, and Far Right
abstract: Prime Min Viktor Orban presents himself as only true patriot in Hungary's parliamentary elections, the most polarized since end of Communist rule; critics, along with Hungary's neighbors and some Western governments, worry that Orban's appeal to national pride is more than mere electioneering, especially since he refuses to rule out forming governing coalition between his center-right party, Fidesz, and extreme-right Freedom and Justice Party; photo (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Euro RSCG Worldwide acquires Dorfer Relationship Communications, marketing services agency; financial terms undisclosed; agency will be renamed Euro RSCG Dorfer (S)

headline: Palestinians Say They Are Too Angry to Celebrate the Israeli Withdrawal
abstract: Palestinians in Ramallah, liberated of Israeli tanks, take to streets, seething after 23 days of occupation; Israeli officials say they were hunting for wanted terrorists and collecting documents linking Palestinian Authority to attacks on Israeli civilians, but Palestinians see goal of operation as humiliation; they predict continuation of cycle of retaliation and retribution of last 18 months; some call for continued suicide bombings; photo (M)

headline: Joseph L. Steiner, 95, a Founder Of a Well-Known Toy Maker
abstract: Joseph Lowenbach Steiner, co-founder of company that made toys like Bubble Rocket and Easy-Bake Oven, dies at age 95 (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Gazprom Endorses Auditor
abstract: Gazprom's board recommends PricewaterhouseCoopers continue as auditor, ignoring shareholder criticism that accounting firm failed to reveal billions of dollars of losses at Gazprom; photo (S)

headline: Disney Dusts Off an Heirloom; Reviving the Family Film to Reverse a Lackluster Box Office
abstract: Walt Disney Studio, seeking to reverse box office slump, is putting renewed stress on making modestly budgeted wholesome family movies; Nina Jacobson, president of Buena Vista Motion Picture Group, Disney unit that makes live-action films, comments; Disney, which invented family film, faces stiff competition in field; graph of Buena Vista's market share; photos (M)

headline: G.E. AGREES TO PAY $120 MILLION FOR A COMDISCO UNIT
abstract: General Electric agrees to buy health care equipment leasing unit from Comdisco, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, for $120 million; also agrees to assume about $45 million of debt (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: South KOREA: Securities Stake To Be Acquired; South KOREA: Daewoo Workers To Keep Jobs; THAILAND: Pipeline Decision Is Delayed; JAPAN: Steel Concern Expects A Loss.

headline: Happy, After the Fact
abstract: Prof Felicia Ackerman letter on taxing smokers (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Weapons Found Near Vnukovo Airport
abstract: Police in Moscow report finding cache of rockets buried near major airport southwest of capital; spokesman says rockets might have been stolen from military unit for sale to criminals or terrorists (S)

headline: Churning Out the Laser Pages Without Churning Out the Money
abstract: Samsung Electronics upgrades entry-level laser printer and prices it attractively for users looking to move away from older inkjet technology; photo (M)

headline: Bush Offers Plan to Help Mothers Avoid Passing H.I.V. to Babies
abstract: Pres Bush announces $500 million plan to prevent pregnant women from passing AIDS virus to their babies and reduce number of infected babies by 40 percent in dozen African nations and Caribbean; new money, which includes $200 million already set aside by Congress, will provide treatment to million women a year over five years; reaction among advocates for people with AIDS is mixed, with some praising Bush and others holding plan falls short of global needs (M)

headline: ImClone's Loss Narrows
abstract: ImClone Systems' fourth-quarter loss narrows to $30.5 million from $33.7 million a year earlier; revenue rises to $2.31 million from $153,000 (S)

headline: Pension Folly: How Losses Become Profits
abstract: Floyd Norris column on how companies are turning pension losses into profits; says Milliman USA study found that in 2001 reported results of 50 large companies included $54.4 billion of profits from pension fund investments, while pension funds lost $35.8 billion; Norris says loses were buried in annual report disclosures that few can understand; says Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Harvey L Pitt has promised to make annual reports more understandable; holds theory of current rule is that over time, all this will balance out--that pension income will be understated in good years, as it was for companies in late 1990's, and overstated in bad ones; says investors would do well to study pension disclosures in this year's annual reports; they show that many plans that seemed to be overfinanced couple of years ago no longer are; chart (M)

headline: In New Tack, iVillage Looks Beyond Ad Revenue
abstract: IVillage, network of Web sites for women, is introducing own brands of vitamins and so-called nutraceutical supplements; plans to offer range of other products aimed at women; chief executive Douglas W McCormick comments on plans to supplement lagging ad revenues with sales; photo (M)

headline: JETBLUE STOCK FALLS AFTER ANALYSTS CALL IT OVERVALUED
abstract: Shares of JetBlue Airways drop after analysts working for companies that underwrote company's initial public offering release mixed reviews; stock closes at $49.60, down $4.90, or 8.99 percent; UBS Warburg analyst Samuel Buttrick and analysts for Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley comment (S)

headline: Report Cites a Rise In Spending on Ads
abstract: CMR report shows advertising in major media increased 0.4 percent in first quarter of 2002, compared with period year earlier; says increase, to $23.5 billion from $23.4 billion, is attributed partly to ad spending in connection with Winter Olympics in February as well as Easter's falling in March (S)

headline: Sri Lanka Rebel Voices Hope for End to 18-Year War
abstract: Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam leader Velupillai Prabhakaran, in first news conference since 1990, calls for political solution to his 18-year war against Sri Lankan government; reserves right to continue armed struggle; news conference, in rebel-held area, comes as Tamil Tigers and Sri Lanka are poised to hold first direct peace talks in eight years, to be mediated by Norway; map; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Australia
abstract: AUSTRALIA: Gold Miner Considers Options; AUSTRALIA: Directors Penalized.

headline: Japan Reports 1.4% Growth, Signaling End To Recession
abstract: Japan emerges from recession as its economy expands by 1.4 percent during first quarter; exports rise 6.4 percent, and consumer spending rises 1.6 percent; corporate capital spending, however, drops by 3.2 percent, holding overall growth below level forecast by analysts; figures give minor lift to Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi, whose disapproval rating in public opinion polls is now higher than his approval rating; World Cup soccer championship is attracting about 400,000 foreign visitors to watch game, but skeptics doubt if tournament wil give more than temporary boost to economy (M)

headline: An American Coffeehouse (or 4) in Vienna
abstract: Starbucks has opened four successful coffeehouses in Vienna, despite dire predictions and ban on smoking; cafes cater mainly to Europeans, not Americans, in one of world's densest and most competitive coffee markets; Franz Holzschuh, who leads Starbucks joint venture in Austria, says reaction to nonsmoking policy, promoted as way to protect coffee aroma, has been positive; map; photos (M)

headline: Mubarak Says Settlements Are 'a Time Bomb'
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said Sunday that he considered Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza to be a "time bomb."

headline: Compressed Data; Rant Inappropriately. Multiply by 20,000. Duck.
abstract: Fleishman-Hillard, public relations firm, apologizes to Declan McCullagh, editor of Wired News Web site, after one of Fleishman's computer administrators sends him a warning about sending unsolicited e-mail to a Fleishman employee; Fleishman assigned that employee the e-mail address of former employee who was active in Politech, e-mail list maintained by McCullagh, but did not inform her; Politech e-mails are about electronic security, free speech and privacy; photo (M)

headline: MediaTalk; E-Books: An Idea Whose Time Hasn't Come
abstract: International eBook Award Foundation discontinues Frankfurt eBook Awards and suspends its activities after Microsoft Corp withdraws financing; Microsoft forms International e-Book Association, which will give smaller awards and focus on regulatory and technical issues; Thomson Multimedia stops making hand-held e-book reading devices because of low sales (M)

headline: S.& P. Tries a Hedge-Fund Gauge
abstract: Standard and Poor's plans to start its own hedge fund index early this summer, and says it will provide a transparency now absent from the industry.

headline: Week's Equity Offerings
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Aaron Rents, Atlanta, 2 million shares. Wachovia.

headline: White House Hints Powell May Cancel Meeting With Arafat
abstract: The Bush administration signaled that Colin L. Powell might cancel his meeting with Yasir Arafat unless he denounced terrorism.

headline: Ex-King Steps Away From Role in Afghanistan's Government
abstract: The former king of Afghanistan announced today that he would not be a candidate for any executive position in the government taking shape in that country.

headline: In Trip to Kabul, Pakistan Leader Spurns U.S. Aid in Hunting Qaeda
abstract: Pakistan Pres Pervez Musharraf makes surprise visit to Afghanistan, trying to mend fences after years of Pakistani support for Taliban, but also rejecting future US military operations against Taliban or Al Qaeda forces who have fled over border to Pakistani tribal areas; says Pakistani troops can do job alone; Musharraf meets with interim President Hamid Karzai, embraces Northern Alliance leaders and says Pakistan's only wish now is to make sure neither country again becomes sanctuary for terrorists; insists he now controls Pakistan's military intelligence agency, which Afghans consider Taliban's alter ego; he also gives Karzai $10-million aid check; photo (M)

headline: Lehman Simplifies Its Stock Ratings
abstract: Lehman Brothers Holdings simplifies its stock rating system to three tiers: 'overweight,' 'equal weight' and 'underweight' (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Mobile Phone Expansion
abstract: China Mobile will pay $10.2 billion to China's state-owned national phone company to buy cellular phone operations in eight provinces in central and western China; China Mobile will raise part of money for deal by selling $750 million worth of its shares to Vodafone Group, which increases its stake in China Mobile to 3.27 percent from 2.18 percent (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Andersen Agrees to Admit Wrongdoing in Enron Case  Pushed by the decision of a former partner to plead guilty to obstruction of justice in the Enron investigation, Arthur Andersen has reached the outlines of a settlement with the government for both criminal and civil charges stemming from the collapse of its former client, people involved in the case said.    Andersen has agreed to a government condition that it admit it committed a crime by destroying documents related to Enron last fall. The tentative agreements amount to a turnabout for Andersen, which has loudly proclaimed its innocence since it was indicted last month. [Page A1.]    Web Sites Mine Data as Ads Dry Up  Pressed for profits, Internet companies like Yahoo are increasingly selling access to their users' postal mail addresses and telephone numbers, in addition to flooding their e-mail boxes with junk mail. [A1.]

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: Deflecting the Marketing Offensive
abstract: It's springtime, and you know what that means: E-Mail Abuse Season. (Of course, summer, fall and winter are also E-Mail Abuse Seasons, but humor me.)

headline: In Bahrain, Women Run, Women Vote, Women Lose
abstract: Bahrain holds municipal elections in which women participate for first time in nation's history as both candidates and voters, but all 31 women running in field of more than 300 candidates lose; all 50 seats on five councils are won by candidates affilated with Islamic organizatons; voting for a man was turned into religious duty in many neighborhoods; female candidates had difficulty meeting voters in country still largely segregated by sex; photos; map (M)

headline: MERCK TO REVISE LABEL INFORMATION FOR VIOXX
abstract: Merck & Co will revise prescribing information for its Vioxx painkiller to show both cardiovascular risks and benefit in reducing side effects like ulcers in arthritis patients; will include information on higher risks of heart attacks in Vioxx patients, compared with risk in patients taking older painkiller, naproxen; will also note results from study showing that Vioxx patients have fewer gastrointestinal side effects than patients on naproxen (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cruise Deal Approved
abstract: British antitrust regulators approve merger of P&O Princess Cruises and Royal Caribbean Cruises (S)

headline: A Mission To Save Money, A Record Of Otherwise
abstract: Premier Inc, one of nation's most powerful hospital-owned buying groups, which has mandate to help nearly 1,500 nonprofit hospitals hold down costs, posts rise of 84 percent in its own spending over last three years; has dismayed some hospitals by expanding into areas that have little to do with its core mission of finding best products at best prices; some hospital executives question group's practice of holding conferences and business meetings at luxury resorts, where Premier spends tens of thousands of dollars for speeches by world leaders and diplomats who are not directly involved in hospital care issues in US; are now working together to examine Premier's books and learn whether group's rising costs are justified; photo; graph (M)

headline: COLONIAL BANCGROUP TO PURCHASE PALM BEACH NATIONAL
abstract: Colonial BancGroup Inc agrees to buy Palm Beach National Holding Co for about $105.5 million in stock (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Two executives are joining Dittus Communications, Washington.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Eclipsys Hires New Chief Executive
abstract: Eclipsys Corp says Paul Ruflin will become chief executive in mid-July, replacing founder Harvey J Wilson, who will remain chairman (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Network Operator's Woes
abstract: KPNQwest NV will run out of cash this year unless it can lower its debt, sell assets or find buyer (S)

headline: Basque Separatists Set Off Car Bomb Near Site of Big Soccer Game
abstract: Basque separatist group ETA detonates car bomb close to stadium in Madrid, hours before start of important European soccer game; 17 people are hurt, none seriously; second bomb, 30 minutes later, may have destroyed bombers' getaway car; ETA has killed one person this year and been linked to several other attacks; Spanish Government has increased pressure on group since Sept 11 and arrested 11 members of Batasuna, political party linked to ETA (M)

headline: Israeli Military Advances Into More of the West Bank; Plans a 'Crushing' Response
abstract: Israeli ground forces move into West Bank village of Dura after Israeli security cabinent endorses plan to seize and hold Palestinian-controlled territory in response to Palestinian attacks that have killed 33 Israelis in past week; army is now holding positions in at least five of eight major Palestinian cities and towns in West Bank; photo; map (M)

headline: Warnings Added To Diabetes Drugs
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline and Eli Lilly & Co add warnings about heart and liver risks to their diabetes drugs; FDA posts information about risks in Glaxo's drug, Avandia, and in Actos from Lilly (S)

headline: I.B.M. Net Off 32% as Customers Balk
abstract: IBM says first-quarter profits dropped 32 percent; net income was $1.19 billion, down from $1.75 billion year earlier; revenue was $18.55 billion, decrease of nearly 12 percent from $21.04 billion year ago; president-chief executive Samuel J Palmisano and chief financial officer John R Joyce comment (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: *Roundup of advertising account changes (S)

headline: Mary Poppins Might Like It
abstract: Glenn Kupferman conceived, manufactures and markets Windbrella, umbrella designed to withstand wind gusts on golf course without inverting; his Windbrella Products Corp sells device; diagram; photo (M)

headline: Stephanopoulos Named Anchor Of 'This Week'
abstract: George Stephanopoulos is named sole anchor of ABC public affairs program This Week; George Will, conservative commentator, will remain as panelist; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Politician Seeks Asylum
abstract: Pedro Carmona, Venezuelan businessman who replaced Pres Hugo Chavez during his two-day ouster in April, seeks political asylum at Colombian Embassy in Caracas (S)

headline: Investors Root for the Home Team and Don't Venture Abroad
abstract: Mark Hulbert article notes United States equity mutual fund investors allocate nearly 90 percent of their portfolios to American stocks, which constitute just 53 percent of total value of worldwide equities; notes investors in every major global market favor stocks from own countries; researchers cite psychological factors for home bias; graph of global stock market share (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH/Ronald E. Lindquist; AmSouth Large Cap Fund
abstract: Article discusses investing strategies of Ronald E Lindquist, portfolio manager of AmSouth Large Cap Fund; chart; photo (M)

headline: Explosion at Synagogue Tied to Jihad; Arrest Made
abstract: Tunisian officials, initially reluctant to tie the blast to Islamic militants, now say that the act was planned and orchestrated by a man with suspected links to several cells.

headline: World Business Briefing: Americas
abstract: CANADA: Bell Canada Stake Bought; ARGENTINA: Water Company Write-Off;.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Ex-Army Chief Denies War Crimes
abstract: Gen Dragoljub Ojdanic, who surrendered to United Nations war crimes tribunal, pleads not guilty to charges of crimes against humanity and war crimes; commanded Yugoslav army under Pres Slobodan Milosevic; is charged with role in campaign to force ehtnic Albanians out of Kosovo in 1999; photo (S)

headline: Chief Executive of Fiat Resigns in Streamlining
abstract: Fiat chief executive Paolo Cantarella says he will resign; departure will streamline central management of company; Cantarella's duties will be assumed by chairman Paolo Fresco; resignation is intended to signal Fiat's willingness to make fresh start; graph; photo (M)

headline: Red Cross Steps In to Feed Hundreds in Afghan Prison
abstract: Red Cross takes over feeding of hundreds of severely malnourished Taliban prisoners held by Afghan authorities in Shibarghan; map; officials say Afghans are unable to provide adequate conditions for 2,772 prisoners in overcrowded camp (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Robert S Shulman, longtime marketing executive, is opening Markitecture in Norwalk, Conn (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Alissa Blate, senior vice president at the MWW Group, East Rutherford, N.J., was promoted to executive vice president and director for consumer marketing.

headline: Contrary St. Petersburg in Limelight
abstract: Pres Vladimir Putin takes Pres Bush on tour of his hometown, St Petersburg, Russia, where they visit Hermitage, view ballet, and watch judo tournament; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   8.00       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   4.50       Federal funds   1.75   1.71   4.54       3-month T-bills   1.67   1.68   3.73       6-month T-bills   1.83   1.86   3.72       10-yr.
