headline: Afghan Leader Swears In 5 Deputies With an Eye to Balance
abstract: Afghan Pres Hamid Karzai swears in five vice presidents, including three powerful regional leaders, to strengthen his central government and gain some control over regions and wayward provincial rulers (S)

headline: Private Sector; A Knight Moves Up at Citigroup
abstract: WHEN Sanford I. Weill, the chief executive of Citigroup, broadened the list of his possible successors last week, his promotion of Sir Deryck C. Maughan was the biggest surprise.    The elevation of Sir Deryck to chief executive of Citigroup's international division was portrayed by Mr. Weill and other Citigroup executives as a reward for his fine work. But for some time, Sir Deryck hardly appeared to be Mr. Weill's favorite son.

headline: For Glareless Photos, Bring Your Own Clouds
abstract: Cindy Litchfield develops Cloud Dome, system for photographing jewelry using digital camera; light from flash created unpleasant glare, but dome diffuses glare; system is available from clouddome.com; photo (M)

headline: Indian Air Force Jet Catches Fire And Crashes Into Bank, Killing 7
abstract: Indian Air Force jet catches fire and crashes into three-story bank building in Jalandhar, killing 7 people and injuring 14 in fire that roars for hours; jet, accident-prone MIG-21, is warhorse of Indian Air Force and has been subject of parliamentary investigation that found it was involved in most of 283 air force accidents over last decade, which destroyed 221 aircraft and killed 100 pilots; in latest accident, pilot parachutes to safety (M)

headline: Ralph Shapey, 81, Composer Evoking Conflicting Impulses
abstract: Ralph Shapey, composer known for his idiosyncratic style, dies at age of 81; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Inquiry Said to Focus On Sell Order by Stewart  Prosecutors in the investigation of ImClone Systems are narrowing their focus to the apparent lack of documentation of the sell order that Ms. Stewart says she and her stockbroker, Peter Bacanovic, agreed on weeks before the sale took place, officials said.    Merrill Lynch, where Mr. Bacanovic worked, has delivered documents to the Congressional committee that is investigating ImClone. But a Congressional spokesman would not say whether a sell order for Ms. Stewart's shares was among the files. [Page C2.]    Martha Stewart's problems are starting to spook the marketers and agencies that buy time and space on and in the properties with her name. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C2.]

headline: Sharon’s Speech to the Israeli Parliament
abstract: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's speech to the Israeli parliament on Tuesday

abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                       International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business             Technology           -      E-Business            -    Circuits          -      Columns               Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: Cox Empire Seeks Growth (on Its Own Terms)
abstract: Focus on growth challenges facing Cox Enterprises Inc, one of nation's largest private media companies which reported $8.7 billion in revenue in 2001; photos; charts (L)

headline: 3 Witnesses Questioned In Fatal Karachi Car Bombing
abstract: Three witnesses were taken into protective custody on Saturday and were being questioned about an explosion outside the American Consulate.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Lower Credit Rating
abstract: France Telecom's credit rating is cut to level just above junk status by Moody's Investors Service; downgrade comes over concerns about company's inability to cut its debt, which stands at $68 billion (S)

headline: Signs Enron Bet on Price Increase Before California Power Shortage
abstract: Enron Corp records cited by California State Sen Joseph Dunn show company was making increasingly large bets that electricity prices in state would increase on eve of California energy crisis in middle of 2000; Dunn is scheduled to testify before Senate Commerce Committee hearing that will examine whether Enron manipulated power prices in California in 2000 and 2001, contributing to surge in electricity prices that pushed California into fiscal crisis; soon after crisis began, California officials began accusing Enron and other energy companies of artificially causing shortages; House lawmakers prepare to do battle over legislation to improve pension safeguards in wake of Enron's collapse; Democratic leaders, who plan to introduce their own bill, say Republican proposal offers cosmetic changes and scaled back some current safeguards; Republicans say that they proposed substantial reforms and that Democratic legislation could lead some companies to curb pension coverage by imposing burdensome new rules; photo (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Productivity and profitability: an odd couple in an odd recession.
abstract: Prof Hal R Varian Economic Scene article discusses strong productivity growth of last six months, noting such growth is aberrant in recession; notes such growth, while good news for economy, may not be good news for business profits; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: President Quits
abstract: Pres A Q M Badruddoza Chowdhury quits his largely ceremonial post under pressure from governing Bangladesh National Party, which accused him of showing disrespect to party's founder Ziaur Rahman by not visiting his grave (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Swissair Faces Claims
abstract: Bankruptcy administrator reports Swissair Group, which collapsed in Oct, faces claims of $25 billion; SAirGroup, airline's holding company, plans to contest over 60 percent of claims (S)

headline: MediaTalk; Satire on Patsy Cline Trips Up Columnist
abstract: Lawrence Hall, columnist for The Star-Ledger in Newark, writes scathing column about victimology, citing April 9 item on Web site of Cybercast News Service about new study suggesting that music of country singer Patsy Cline contributes to depression, suicide and violent behavior by women; Hall failed to notice that piece was labeled satire; Star-Ledger editor Jim Willse calls episode 'sloppy and embarrassing'; photo (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Apr 7 article on investment advice for 401(k) retirement plans: Conning & Co study of them was not spurred by Enron's problems and began before problems were publicly known

headline: Microsoft Antitrust Case Goes to Judge for Ruling
abstract: Microsoft and coalition of state attorneys general pursuing antitrust sanctions against company make their closing arguments in case, disregarding Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly's order to identify areas of compromise; she had hoped that company and nine states that have not signed on to settlement reached between company and Justice Department would assist her in arriving at consensus position before she begins her deliberations on whether to approve that settlement or impose more restrictive proposals of holdout states (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Sales Up At Novartis
abstract: Novartis says first-quarter sales rose 10 percent, to $4.7 billion; graph (S)

headline: Fiat Reaches Agreement With Banks On Its Debt
abstract: Fiat and its major creditor banks reach agreement on major financial plan, refinancing short-term debt totaling 3 billion euros ($2.8 billion); Fiat has been trying to sell assets and reorganize its industrial activities to keep its credit rating from deteriorating; deal announced by Fiat and Intesa BCI, San Paolo IMI and Banca di Roma comes in return for pledge by Fiat to dispose of assets worth at least 3 billion euros by end of year (M)

headline: States' Attack On Microsoft May Be Hurt
abstract: Federal Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly indicates that she might not allow nine states challenging Microsoft Corp's antitrust settlement with government to introduce evidence that their lawyer has said is 'central part of our case'; states want to introduce documents outlining complaints from computer makers that proposal to settle case would let Microsoft continue retaliating against them if they do not give in to its demands (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mitsubishi Stock Rises
abstract: Shares of Mitsubishi Motors Corp soar 17 percent on talk that company's largest shareholder, DaimlerChrysler, will try to take it over as early as next year; DaimlerChrysler's chief executive Jurgen Schrempp comments; graph (S)

headline: VIOLENCE IN GAZA AS ISRAEL REDUCES WEST BANK FORCES
abstract: Israel reduces forces in West Bank as troops skirmish with Palestinian gunmen in Gaza Strip and suicide bomber attacks military checkpoint, wounding two soldiers; UN Security Council unanimously approves resolution supporting mission to gather information on Israeli military action against terrorists in Jenin refugee camp; Yasir Arafat reportedly offers Palestinian trial of five men wanted by Israel in murder of cabinet minister last year; five are holed up with Arafat in Ramallah; two Palestinian gunmen are shot while trying to infiltrate Jewish settlement in Gaza; 35 Palestinians who died in Jenin are buried; photo (M)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: MONDAYNone.

headline: AMR EXECUTIVE TO BECOME CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER AT AT&T
abstract: AT&T Corp names Thomas W Horton, chief financial officer of AMR Corp, senior executive vice president and chief financial officer, succeeding Charles H Noski as chief financial officer; AMR names Jeffrey C Campbell chief financial officer and senior vice president for finance, replacing Horton (S)

headline: $1 Billion Settlement Over Faulty Implants
abstract: Sulzer Medica, Europe's leading maker of orthopedic devices, completes deal to settle lawsuits by American patients over faulty hip and knee implants; agrees to pay about $1 billion; will distribute about $200,000 apiece to about 3,300 patients who received faulty implants, most of whom have since had corrective surgery; says that 87 more patients chose not to accept overall settlement and are continuing to use it individually (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Deutsche Telekom Posts Loss
abstract: Deutsche Telekom says it lost 1.8 billion euros ($1.66 billion) in first quarter, up from loss of 358 million euros year earlier; graph (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: U.S. Security Request Rejected
abstract: Greece rejects State Dept request to have American inspectors search cargo vessels traveling in Greek territorial waters and suspected of involvement in terror-related activities; Foreign Min George Papandreou cites constitutional limitations in his rebuff of request (S)

headline: A New Snag for Accounting Legislation
abstract: Senate Banking Committee chairman Paul S Sarbanes, facing enormous opposition from financial services industry and some Republican lawmakers, postpone meeting scheduled for May 21 at which lawmakers would have considered overhaul of accounting industry regulations inspired by collapse of Enron; House Republicans have already passed accounting bill that is favored by accounting industry and business groups (S)

headline: U.S. Says It Will Not Support International Criminal Court
abstract: Bush administration officials said today that the court's prosecutors will not be given any information to help them bring cases against any individuals.

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: 50 Million Children Without A Nationality
abstract: United Nations Children's Fund reports that as many as 50 million babies born in 2000 were never legally registered; says starting life without official nationality puts these children at greater risk of being exploited or trafficked (S)

headline: Fears About Microsoft Return, in Mexico
abstract: A government initiative to bring Internet access within reach of 9 of 10 Mexicans has drawn criticism because to many it smacks of handing Microsoft a de facto monopoly.

headline: The Heavy Lifters Of Raw Computation
abstract: Q. Is a mainframe computer the same thing as a supercomputer?    A. Unlike personal desktop computers designed for use by one person at a time, a mainframe computer can handle thousands of users at a time and is often used in a corporate or financial environment.

headline: A nonprofit group is bringing large advertisers and ethnic newspapers together to benefit both.
abstract: Independent Press Association has begun program called All Communities Advertising Service to help some ethnic newspapers in New York tap into broader advertising market by making it easier for advertisers to buy ads; program permits advertisers to place ads in many ethnic publications with one phone call (M)

headline: Wyndham's Frequent Guests Get Some Vital Services Free
abstract: Wyndham International hotel chain is offering members of its guest-loyalty program free phone calls, other free services to attract business travelers (S)

headline: CBS adds seven new series and tries to make a dent in NBC's dominance at 10 p.m.
abstract: CBS announces fall prime-time schedule tailored to attack some strongholds of ratings leader NBC; CBS Television president Leslie Moonves comments; chart on fall prime-time lineup; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mazda Raises Outlook
abstract: Mazda Motor Corp expects profit to double this year, helped by revived sales in Japan and Europe; forecasts profit of 20 billion yen ($155.6 million) in year ending March 31, 2003, or 127 percent more than this year; expects sales to rise 8 percent (S)

headline: Judge's Ruling On Andersen Hurts Defense
abstract: Federal Judge Melinda F Harmon rules that jurors could find Arthur Andersen accounting firm guilty of criminal obstruction of justice even if they do not agree on which of firm's employees had intent to commit crime; denies defense attorneys' motion for mistrial; photo (M)

headline: Latin America holds both risk and reward : A lively Southern exposure
abstract: CARACAS—  Latin America offers considerable opportunity for the bold offshore investor who is willing to stomach a large dose of risk. But growth forecasts of a respectable 3.8 percent for the region for next year come with some caveats.

headline: Europeans Speak Out Against Rise of Le Pen
abstract: Europeans of widely varying political persuasions today deplored the rise of Jean Le Pen and the National Front in France.

headline: New chairman of trade group calls for improving the value of the product that agencies sell.
abstract: Advertising industry executives discuss problems that confront agencies as they grapple with continued advertising spending downturn, American Association of Advertising Agencies management conference; association chairman Ken Kaess says he will stress improving value of agencies' services (M)

headline: PRIVATE CAPITAL COUNTERS WYLY'S BID FOR BOARD SEATS
abstract: Private Capital Management LP will support, with voting shares it owns, board of directors of Computer Associates International Inc against renewed proxy challenge by investor Sam Wyly (M)

headline: ISRAEL'S MILITARY RETHINKING ACTION IN THE GAZA STRIP
abstract: Israel seems to be moving toward targeted, limited military operation in Gaza Strip, not all-out reoccupation, as its troops pull out of Bethlehem; withdrawal from city, last West Bank city still occupied in Israeli military operation that began March 29, comes after gunmen, civilians and clergy members file out of Church of Nativity; Defense Min Benjamin Ben-Eliezer asks army to re-evaluate plans for Gaza, in part because of leaks about operational details; some newspapers say operation may be canceled because of United States pressure; US officials say they urged Prime Min Ariel Sharon to consider consequences of Gaza move; Lt Gen Shaul Mofaz and other Israeli military leaders are arguing for serious strike on Palestinian militants of Hamas in Gaza; Palestinians in Gaza brace for attack; four Israelis are slightly wounded when two Palestinians detonate blast, Beersheba; bystanders catch and beat one of Palestinians and police catch other; Israeli police arrest two more Jews for planning terror attacks on Palestinians in East Jerusalem; map; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Economic Growth
abstract: Britain's gross domestic product grows 0.1 percent in first three months of 2002, compared with no growth in fourth quarter of 2001 (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Corning Sales Drop 53%
abstract: Corning reports first-quarter loss after sales fell 53 percent; $90 million loss was in contrast to income of $132 million year ago; sales dropped to $898 million from $1.92 billion (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Madrid: Judge Wants Kissinger Questioned
abstract: Baltasar Garzon, Spain's top criminal judge, asks British judicial authorities to question former United States State Sec Henry A Kissinger as possible witness in probe of terrorist acts by Latin American governments in 70's and 80's when Kissinger visits London for planned meeting (S)

headline: Afghanistan to Pay Farmers for Uprooted Poppies
abstract: Afghan officials say they have released nearly half of 300 people arrested in reported plot to topple government; denies trying to stifle political opponents; among those released is Wahidullah Zahbauan, former finance minister of Northern Alliance; Afghan Interior Minister Yunis Qanuni claims police discovered documents outlining plans to attack interim president Hamid Karzai and Mohammad Zahir Shah, former king who is expected to return to Afghanistan soon; he canceled visit last month, reportedly because of assassination threat; photo (M)

headline: WILLIAMS COS. SAYS ITS PRESIDENT WILL ALSO BE CHAIRMAN
abstract: Williams Companies says president Steven J Malcolm has also been named chairman, effective immediately, succeeding Keith E Bailey, who will retire on May 31 (S)

headline: Patents; The government releases its list of Top 10 countries and companies that received its imprimatur for inventions.
abstract: Patent and Trademark Office statistics show California led states with most patents awarded to residents in 2001; foreign-born, noncitizen residents of United States earned nearly half of all patents awarded to applicants with US address; Japan was by far leading nation of residence for foreign patent winners (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: IRELAND: Wireless Merger; The NETHERLANDS: Accounting Issue; GERMANY: Factor Orders Fall.

headline: Daewoo Leaves Foreign Plants Adrift
abstract: Many of Daewoo Corp's foreign plants are facing serious problems; plants in Poland, Romania, Czech Republic, Ukraine, Uzbekistan, India, Iran, Egypt, Libya, China and Philippines are burdened with billions of dollars in debt; they are stuck with agreements with local governments to maintain employment and meet investment and production targets, promises made in exchange for tax breaks and other favors; Daewoo can count on only three more years' worth of key parts and licenses from plants that General Motors Corp is buying; marketing agreements in Europe will eventually bar most of Daewoo's foreign factories from selling under Daewoo name; photo (M)

headline: Jakarta Journal; Boy Kisses Girl: That's Sweet, and Sensational!
abstract: What's With Love, slick American-style movie by Indonesian director Mira Lesmana that shows 16-year-old girl and boyfriend kissing on screen, creates box-office sensation of year in predominantly Muslim country and outgrosses even most successful Hollywood imports; urban drama about students from middle class or above who face quandries similar to those of peers in West is in contrast to most Indonesian movies that center on eternal struggle of rural life; photo (M),

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Ex-General Convicted In Nuclear Case
abstract: Retired Israeli Brig Gen Yitzhak Yaakov, 76, is convicted of disclosing classified data about Israel's nuclear program in unpublished manuscripts of memoir and novel he sent to United States publisher, but he is cleared of charges he intended to harm state security; headed weapons development program for military; photo (S)

headline: Republicans Schedule Vote On Unity With Israel
abstract: House Republicans set vote for next week on resolution of 'solidarity' with Israel that condemns Yasir Arafat for 'ongoing support and coordination of terror'; Secretary of State Colin L Powell had made personal plea to hold off on resolution; senior Republican aides say there is overwhelming impulse among lawmakers to stand with Israel, as well as Republican disillusionment with Powell; some conservatives accuse him of being too inclined to seek middle ground in Middle East, undercutting moral clarity of Pres Bush's stand against terrorism; White House seems resigned to House action, noting that resolution is nonbinding (M)

headline: In New Era, Corporate Security Looks Beyond Guns and Badges
abstract: Businesses have been forced to review their notions of corporate security in months sine Sept 11 terrorist attacks and have come to realization that chief security officer job calls for new kind of corporate security executive--one with breadth of experience, analytic skills, business acumen and leadership qualities; elusive ideal is executive not only familiar with physical security of people and property, but also fluent in digital security of computers and information; executive headhunters are recruiting people who fit description and, with their talents suddenly much in demand, chief security officers can earn more than $400,000 per year; General Motors Corp's chief information security officer James Christiansen, who was hired well before September attacks, comments; chart; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Carmaker Shares Fall
abstract: Shares in Ssangyong Motor fall 8.6 percent, reflecting disappointment that PSA Peugeot Citroen is not interested in company; graph (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Apple Introduces Media Player
abstract: Apple Computer offers first public version of its software media player, QuickTime 6; player supports new international standard for view multimedia; Apple says it will also make its new Emac computer more widely available (S)

headline: N. KOREANS TALK OF BABY KILLINGS
abstract: Increasing number of escapees from North Korea say forced abortions and infanticide are norm in North Korean prisons; say prisoners discovered to be pregnant are routinely forced to have abortions, and if babies are born alive, guards force prisoners to kill them; say prohibition on pregnancy in prisons dates back at least to 1980's, and that forced abortion and infanticide are rule; China's deportations of thousands of illegal migrants from North Korea in recent years has resulted in sharp increase in number of pregnant women ending up in North Korean prisons; defectors, male and female, are reviled as traitors and counterrevolutionaries, and women who become pregnant, especially by Chinese men, face special abuse; official Korean Central News Agency denounces allegations as 'whopping lie;' photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DESA INTERNATIONAL INC., Bowling Green, Ky., a maker of space heaters and security equipment, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and said it planned to sell the company by late September and continue operating with the same workers.    PARKER HANNIFIN CORP., Cleveland, the largest maker of hydraulic equipment, said it had sold its automotive warranty business to Phoenix American Insurance Group Inc., Miami, a provider of extended warranties and service contracts to car dealers. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Accounts Awarded By Two Companies
abstract: AXA Financial selects Martin Agency as its US ad agency of

headline: North Koreans Seek Asylum At Consulates In China
abstract: Seven North Koreans try to barge into consulates in Shenyang, China, in bid for political asylum; two succeed in entering American Consulate and five are interecepted by Chinese guards at Japanese Consulate; 28 North Koreans have gained safe passage to South Korea by forcing their way into Western diplomatic compounds in Beijing in last two months, angering and frustrating Chinese Government; map (M)

headline: Israel Refuses to Recognize Greek Orthodox Patriarch
abstract: Israeli Government again refuses to recognize new Greek Orthodox patriarch of Jerusalem Irineos, who is custodian of most Christian religious sites in region; he was elected by bishops of Jerusalem patriarchate in Aug and enthroned on Sept 15 as leader of oldest and largest church in Holy Land; reason most often stated by Israeli officials is suspicion that Irineos is sympathetic to Palestinian Authority; various Israeli officials say real issue is vast real estate holdings of patriarchate, including land on which Parliament stands and many other important properties in Jerusalem, West Bank and Gaza Strip; photo (M)

headline: Capture of Qaeda Leader Is Confirmed by White House
abstract: The White House said today that the U.S. had indeed captured Abu Zubaydah, a top Al Qaeda leader, and speculation arose that he might face a military tribunal.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Dissident Meets Party Members
abstract: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, Burmese prodemocracy leader, drives through Yangon for first time since being released from house arrest by military government; meets with members of her party in suburb (S)

headline: How Blocking Assets Erased a Wisp of Prosperity
abstract: Bush administration's freezing of assets of Al Barakaat cripples company, Somalia's biggest employer; Al Barakaat is forced to lay off 700 employees; thousands of people lose their deposits, and those awaiting money from relatives in United States are cut off; Al Barakaat, in land devastated by civil war and drought, ran biggest bank, biggest phone system and only water-purification plant (M)

headline: Movado Reports a Profit
abstract: Movado Group says net income was $332,000 in fiscal first quarter ended April 30 in contrast to net loss of $128,000 year earlier; sales in quarter rose about 1.4 percent, to $57.3 million from $56.5 million (S)

headline: After Pausing, Income Gap Is Growing Again
abstract: Louis Uchitelle Economic View column on income inequality, which stopped expanding during late 1990's, but is deeply imbedded in American system and once again getting larger; earners in 90th percentile ($1440 a week) have seen wages steadily rise since early 1980's, while wages of those in middle ($646 a week) or at low end ($307 weekly) of spectrum have stagnated or lost ground to inflation; graph (M)

headline: In a Sad Hotel, Caucasus War Refugees Make Do
abstract: Iveria hotel, once best hotel in Tblisi, Georgian Republic, has become hovel for refugees who fled punishing civil war in 1992-1993 that drove 260,000 ethnic Georgians from Abkhazia, separatist Georgia province; decade of home-improvement experiments by more than 1,000 residents, twice hotel's capacity, have transformed it into half slum and 'remarkable' piece of deconstructionist architecture; photos (M)

headline: Business; An Empire, Yes, but More Serene Than Martha's
abstract: Article profiles Chris Madden Inc, fledgling but successful home furnishings empire that resembles Martha Stewart's, but on much smaller scale; Madden comments; photos (M)

headline: U.N. Forum Stalls on Sex Education and Abortion Rights
abstract: Efforts to draft final declaration following General Assembly Special Session on Children are being complicated by differences between Bush administration's delegates and many other delegates over abortion and sex education; United States delegation, upholding White House stance against abortion, seeks to amend language arrived at in previous UN conferences so that it excludes abortion from menu of reproductive health services offered to teenagers; in this they are joined by Vatican, as well as several Islamic nations; on opposing side are delegates from European Union, as well as countries in Latin America, Africa and Asia (M)

headline: Biotechnology Seeks End to Slump
abstract: Failures of number of once-promising drug trials have soured investors on biotechnology stocks, even those without bad news; analysts are divided on whether stocks have hit bottom and are poised to rise; one question is whether spate of product problems is sign of deep-seated change in industry's fundamentals; graph; photos (M)

headline: Afghan Grave Site Yields Bodies Believed Linked to Bin Laden
abstract: Investigators have exhumed 23 bodies from a grave site that they suspect was used to bury Al Qaeda fighters.

headline: Harry Potter and the Quest For the Unfinished Volume
abstract: British author J K Rowling is late in completing fifth book in popular Harry Potter series, Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, disappointing legions of young fans; turned out four books at rate of one each year through July 2000; says writing it is proving more involved than she initially expected; Scholastic, US publisher, says it expects to publish book before June 2003 (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Implantable Chip Headed For Market
abstract: Applied Digital Solutions says skin-embedded computer chip is not required to undergo testing by Food and Drug Administration and will thus be available soon; Applied Digital has publicized device, called Verichip, as substitute for medical tags, saying wireless readers could be used with it to get information like pacemaker model or drug allergies of person brought to hospital; in reality chips would only contain identification codes that would refer to database of medical information; Applied Digital says because chip will not contain medical information, product is able to avoid FDA review; holds it will begin distributing equipment to read chips to hospitals in Palm Beach and Broward Counties in Florida (S)

headline: Fed Is Content Not to Raise Interest Rates
abstract: Federal Reserve votes unanimously to hold its benchmark interest rate unchanged, saying durability of economic recovery remains uncertain; sees inflation remaining under control; leaves federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks at 40-year low, 1.75 percent, where it has been for nearly five months; Federal Open Market Committee stresses that 5.8 percent economic growth rate in first quarter was largely one-time boost from companies' beginning to rebuild their inventories as recession ended; Bureau of Labor Statistics reports productivity in first quarter rose at 8.6 percent annual rate, its fastest pace since 1983; productivity growth in last year's fourth quarter is revised, to 5.5 percent from 5.2 percent; graph (M)

headline: Top Executive at ABC Television Leaves After One Year in the Job
abstract: Steven M Bornstein is stepping down as president of ABC Television one year after being named to position; no replacement is named; move is second change in senior management in last several months at ABC, which is suffering through one of worst television season's in company's history; Stu Bloomberg, who had been co-chairman of ABC Entertainment, was ousted in January; Walt Disney Co president Robert Iger comments; photo (M)

headline: Police Are Led to Body Said to Be Pearl's
abstract: Pakistani police official says three new suspects in murder of Daniel Pearl, Wall Street Journal reporter, have led police to grave at western edge of Karachi where they say he is buried; if remains are identified as those of Pearl, and if they are admitted as evidence, they could help shore up case against four men now on trial in Hyderabad; witnesses say they saw one defendant, Ahmed Omar Sheikh, meet with Pearl before his kidnapping; others say they heard Sheikh admit to abduction; defense attorney for four suggests that videotape showing execution of Pearl, which FBI agents presented in court, was faked (M)

headline: KPNQwest Lays Off a Third Of Dutch Headquarters Staff
abstract: KPNQwest, moving step closer to collapse, lays off 600 of 2,000 workers at its Netherlands headquarters; talks with potential buyers of firm, which owns Europe's largest fiber optic network, reportedly take on fire sale tone, with assets being sought piecemeal at low prices; company says its bankers seek financing to keep network running until it is sold (M)

headline: DataBank; A Third Week of Declines, and Dejection
abstract: Summary of week's financial markets; charts (S)

headline: WESTERN RESOURCES TO SELL ITS 44.5% STAKE IN ONEOK
abstract: Western Resources, Kansas utility owner, says it has notified Oneok Inc, natural gas utility, of plans to sell its 44.5 percent stake in company, valued at about $1 billion (S)

headline: Freeze on Deposits Is No Holiday, Argentines Find
abstract: Last Friday afternoon, after banks and many businesses closed for the weekend, the Argentine economy entered the financial equivalent of the Twilight Zone.

headline: KMART HAD LOSS IN MAY, BUT BANKRUPTCY COSTS DECLINED
abstract: Kmart Corp reports $96 million loss in May, as sales declined 11 percent; bankruptcy-related costs fell (M)

headline: Ida Milgrom, 94, Dies; Helped Free a Son Held by Soviets
abstract: Ida Milgrom, teacher, economist and musician who helped to lead international campaign to free her son, Soviet dissident Anatoly B. Shcharansky, from prison, dies at age 94; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: GLOBAL TRADE STEEL TARIFF CASE ADVANCES The World Trade Organization has agreed to the European Union's request to set up a panel of experts in the trans-Atlantic dispute over United States steel tariffs. The Bush administration had blocked the union's initial request, as it is allowed to do under trade rules, but the second request automatically leads to the establishment of a panel. The United States also denied requests by Japan and South Korea for a similar panel. Unless an agreement is reached, those requests will be automatically granted later this month.   Elizabeth Olson (NYT) ASIAJAPAN: NASDAQ AT ODDS WITH EXCHANGE Nasdaq Japan threatened to leave the Osaka Securities Exchange for another Japanese stock market if the Osaka exchange continues to delay changes in trading rules that Nasdaq wants. Nasdaq Japan, owned by the Nasdaq market of the United States, the Japanese Internet company Softbank and 13 securities companies, began trading two years ago as a section of the Osaka Securities Exchange. Nasdaq Japan wants the Osaka exchange to adopt a trading system that would allow dealers to act more freely in transactions, but the exchange has been reluctant, a Nasdaq Japan spokeswoman, Naho Yohda, said. The changes are central to Nasdaq's plant to create a global exchange. An Osaka exchange spokesman, Tsutomu Konishi, said the exchange had received no word from Nasdaq.   (AP) CHINA: G.M. BUYS STAKE IN AUTOMAKER General Motors said it would buy a $30 million stake in a Chinese minivan and minitruck maker, moving into the largest sector of China's auto market. General Motors said it would take a 34 percent stake in SAIC-Wuling Automotive, based in the southern province of Guangxi. The original Chinese owners, the Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation and Wuling Automotive, will retain a controlling 66 percent share. Minivans and minitrucks accounted for almost a third of all vehicles sold in China last year, making them the la

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Adelphia Communications To Restate Its Earnings  Adelphia Communications said that it would restate its financial statements for the last three years to include more than $1 billion in loans that it guaranteed to entities controlled by the family of its chairman, John Rigas. The family used some of the money to buy Adelphia stock and bonds.    But analysts said they were confused by tentativeness of Adelphia's statement, with one saying that the market was ''still looking for full disclosure.'' [Page C5.]    Explaining the Departures at Sun  Under pressure to revive Sun Microsystems, Scott G. McNealy, the chairman, recently told senior executives that anyone who was not ready to sign up for the next five years should step aside. So far, five have done so. [C4.]    Abercrombie Sells Ads in Catalog  Abercrombie & Fitch, the retailer known for its sexually provocative catalogs, has started to sell advertising in the publication to other retailers trying to reach consumers ages 18 to 24. Stuart Elliot: Advertising. [C6.]    Talks to Sell Package Company  Madison Dearborn Partners, an equity firm, is in talks to buy the Jefferson Smurfit Group, the Irish paper and packaging company. The talks could flush out other suitors. [C2.]    Court Orders New Vivendi Vote  A French court has ordered Vivendi Universal to hold a new shareholder meeting, ruling that an electronic voting system had malfunctioned. [World Business, Section W.]    Dow Rallies, but Other Gauges Fall  The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 32.24 points, at 10,091.87. But the Nasdaq composite index fell 32.71 points, to 1,644.82, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 1.90 points, to 1,084.56. [C7.]    The government said new orders for factory goods topped expectations in March, but a separate report showed that the unemployed were still having trouble finding work. [C2.]    Merrill Lynch Executive Resigns  Thomas W. Davis, left, who oversaw Merrill Lynch's research department, plans to leave the firm in six months, but he said his departure was unrelated to an investigation by the New York attorney general. In any case, the departure will remove one of the last vestiges of Merrill's previous management and comes as the firm is trying to settle conflict-of-interest allegations. [C7.]    Court Refuses to Dismiss Nike Suit  The California Supreme Court has refused to dismiss a lawsuit accusing Nike of fraud for asserting that its overseas workers received adequate wages and that its working conditions complied with safety regulations. [C6.]    Microsoft's Motive Questioned  The nine states battling Microsoft in court have tried to compare the company's response to competition from RealNetworks to its reaction to Netscape, where its actions were found to have thwarted competition. [C7.]    Report on Internet Pornography  A report discussing how to deal with Internet pornography has concluded that a broad effort combining technical, legal, economic or educational approaches offered the best chance of protecting children. [C6.]    Energy Company Reports a Loss  Calpine, the power producer, reported a first-quarter loss of $74.3 million after scaling back expansion. In the same quarter, the El Paso Corporation, a pipeline operator, reported earnings of $383 million. [C12.]

headline: The Shock of Gadget Glitches
abstract: I had a great time working on "Piloting Palm," which tells the story of how Palm and Handspring began and grew.

headline: For NATO, Little Is Sure Now but Growth
abstract: Serious efforts are under way to transform North Atlantic Treaty Orgn--make it quicker, more mobile, more precise and more effective, even as it enlarges to complete reunification of Europe and develops new relationship with Russia; Secretary of State Colin L Powell has dismissed talk of NATO irrelevance, noting how many countries want to join; Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld is said to have been unimpressed with alliance when he served as ambassador to NATO in 1973-74; there is much cynicism in Washington over whether European allies will ever spend enough money to live up to their commitments and keep NATO relevent to American needs (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: London Synagogue Attacked
abstract: Vandals ransack London synagogue; attack startles nation that has been largely immune to anti-Jewish attacks (S)

headline: Report of Pakistan Raid
abstract: Pakistani officials said that American forces had joined Pakistani troops in raids in that country's tribal areas to hunt down fighters suspected of belonging to the Taliban and Al Qaeda. American military officials declined to comment.      Article, Page 18.

headline: Canada's Finance Chief Ousted, Igniting Crisis
abstract: Canada's Prime Min Jean Chretien dismisses Finance Min Paul Martin in contest for leadership of Liberal Party that has thrown government and party into biggest crisis of nine years in power; Martin's efforts to organize run for leadership post for many years noted; was widely viewed as Chretien's successor; departure was expected following warning by Chretien he would fire any minister organizing and raising funds in preparation for party convention in February to decide on leader; Martin is replaced by Deputy Prime Min John Manley, moderate and loyal Chretian ally; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Vandalism At Dachau
abstract: Police in Germany announce that vandals overturned memorial stones at Dachau, Nazis' first concentration camp, and at nearby Jewish cemetery (S)

headline: PROCTER & GAMBLE SEEKS BUYER FOR SOME CLAIROL BRANDS
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co, which paid $4.95 billion for Clairol hair care business six months ago, is looking for buyers for unit's Sea Breeze facial cleanser and three other brands as it focuses on its main hair color business (S)

headline: Article 2002042493334655943 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology Text Version         function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                            International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business             Technology           -      E-Business            -      Circuits            -      Columns               Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: PORTUGAL: Telecom Write-Down; INFLATION DECLINE EXPECTED;.

headline: What If Investors Won't Join the Party?
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column says economic rebound in US is threatened by continued depression of broad stock market indexes, which generally begin to rise well before evidence of economic recovery; says that if stocks stay in slump, consumers may rein in their spending, hurting recovery, and that prolonged slump would make it harder and most costly for companies to raise capital they need to expand their operations and increase revenue and profits; suggest that fault lies in good part with steady stream of accounting scandals, corporate chicanery and questionable practices at Wall Street firms, which are undermining investors' trust in nation's capital markets and role they play in helping to generate growth and prosperity; photos (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Pub Owner Expands
abstract: Enterprise Inns, Britain's largest pub owner, to buy 1,860 pubs from Laurel Pub Holdings, unit of Deutsche Bank's private equity group, for 875 million pounds ($1.26 billion); plans to sell fresh equity to existing investors to help pay for deal (S)

headline: Ex-Chief of Sotheby's Sentenced to Probation for Price-Fixing
abstract: Diana D. Brooks, the former chief executive of Sotheby's, was sentenced today by a federal judge in Manhattan to three years probation for her role in conducting a price-fixing scheme with the rival auction house Christie's.

headline: Stock Restriction Ends at Gillette
abstract: The Gillette Corporation has lifted restrictions on when its employees can sell company shares and reinvest the proceeds as part of the company's retirement plan.

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: HONG KONG: Auto Executive Dismissed; INDIA: State Bank Posts Profit Rise; THAILAND: Steel Merger;.

headline: Trials Test the Faith of Rwandans
abstract: Five Rwandan clergymen will be tried on charges of genocide by United Nations war crimes tribunal in Arusha, Tanzania; three are Roman Catholic priests, one is Seventh-day Adventist pastor and one is Anglican bishop; prosecutors claim five collaborated with killers in their congregations during Rwanda's 1994 civil war, when more than 500,000 people were slain; each of accused will be prosecuted separately and each judged for their individual responsibility; but human rights groups hope event will force churches to re-examine broader issues, like role of senior members of clergy in Rwandan politics and near passivity of church hierarchy while killing frenzy was going on; court officials note that Catholic Church, which until now has been shielding priests and nuns accused of wrongdoing in Rwanda, has begun to cooperate with tribunal; photo (M)

headline: Initial Offerings Take a Turn to the Traditional
abstract: Types of businesses raising capital through initial public stock offerings form almost reverse image of overheated technology market of 1999 and 2000; technology companies, which accounted for 70 percent of offerings then, comprised less than third in 2002 first quarter; venture capitalists, source of most new offerings few years ago, now have trouble finding companies in their portfolios that will attract public investor interest; leveraged-buyout firms and large companies spinning off units are major sources of new offerings; over 70 companies are now lined up to go public, down from 366 at this time two years ago and up from 56 last year; graphs; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: ARGENTINA: Strike After Death Of Protesters; CUBA: Socialism Forever, Assembly Declares;.

headline: Article 2002042093545921473 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                      International           -    Africa          -      Americas            -      Asia Pacific            -      Europe            -      Middle East               National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business              Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Floods And Landslides Kill Hundreds
abstract: Floods and landslides in central China caused by heavy rains in last two months have killed more than 500 people, with another 300 missing (S)

headline: Judge Rules Iran Hostages Can't Receive Compensation
abstract: Federal Judge Emmet G Sullivan rules that Americans held captive in Iran for 444 days beginning in 1979 cannot receive damages from Tehran because agreement that freed them bars such lawsuits; hostages won their case against Iran last year by default because Iran failed to defend itself; judge's ruling uses particuarly sharp language to criticize White House and Congress, implying that they hypocritically failed to aid former hostages, most of them embassy personnel, whose captivity was seen by many as symbol of American impotence in Carter administration and helped elect Ronald Reagan (M)

headline: PBS is expanding its brand from the television screen to the shopping mall.
abstract: Public Broadcasting System plans to announce it will team up with Mills Corp, fast-growing shopping center developer to bring PBS to mall; PBS Kids, which aims to make its debut at Opry Mills Mall in Nashville, Tenn, as early as this fall, will feature all sorts of attractions for children; PBS is latest nonretailer to put its name above new 'branded destination sites'; Binney & Smith, maker of Crayola crayons, opened Crayola Works, hybrid store and creative arts studio in Baltimore in June; General Mills opened Cereal Town at Mall of America in Minnesota last year; photo (M)

headline: Canada and U.S. to Cooperate in Inquiry on Bombing
abstract: Canadian officials say US has promised full access to American military personnel involved in accidental bombing of Canadian military exercise in Afghanstan; four Canadian soldiers were killed and eight wounded; phto of ceremony at Kandahar airport at which Canadian troops receive combat badges from American airborne unit (M)

headline: Argentine President Unveils Crisis Legislation
abstract: Argentina's financial system is on verge of collapse, as indefinite bank holiday paralyzes country's economic activity; Pres Eduardo Duhalde proposes emergency legislation to reduce pressure on his government by forcibly converting billions of dollars in bank deposits into low-interest bonds to be paid off in 5 to 10 years; he has sharp criticism for foreign banks and International Monetary Fund, even as he seeks to negotiate accord with IMF that would inject billions of dollars into economy starved for cash; bond plan is sure to be unpopular, and almost immediately groups of protesting depositors march on Congress banging pots and pans; photo (M)

headline: Bomber Strikes Jews and Arabs At Rare Refuge
abstract: Suicide bomber from Islamic group Hamas blows self up in restaurant in Haifa, Israel, killing self and 14 others and wounding more than 40; attack is among deadliest of 18-month intifada and shocks both Arabs and Jews; Arab-owned Matza restaurant was one of rare places in Israel where Jews felt they could find refuge in company of Arabs; dead include Israeli Arabs; suicide bomber also strikes station for paramedics in settlement of Efrat, south of Bethlehem; kills self and wounds four medics; photos; maps (M)

headline: Despite Trailing in Ukraine Vote, Leader's Party Sees Final Victory
abstract: President Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine called on opponents today to work with his government in assembling a ruling legislative coalition.

headline: Dispute Ends For Monsanto And DuPont
abstract: Monsanto and DuPont agree to settle all lawsuits between them over genetically modified seeds and give each other licenses for their patents; Pioneer Hi-Bred International, which is owned by DuPont and is largest seed company in world, will pay royalties to Monsanto for access to certain genes and technology (M)

headline: Executive Life; Out of Work, but Not Rushing to Return
abstract: Executive Life column on executives who find themselves out of work for first time, and have used reprieve to take stock of their lives; surprising number say they now appreciate chance to spend more time with families, to return to neglected hobbies and to rejuvenate their lives; former Mattel Inc president Ned Mansour comments; photo (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Oracle Parries Criticism on Database Contracts
abstract: Oracle denies META Group warning that it might try to charge big corporate customers added fees for database software they have already bought; holds META misinterpreted for clients contract provision on how to count number of data streams company feeds into Oracle database; notes it earlier told META that it would not levy added fees based on misunderstanding (M)

headline: Russia Seeking to Dismantle Collective Farms
abstract: Russia is moving to dismantle collectivization of its farmlands; Parliament's lower house, urged by Pres Vladimir V Putin, has approved preliminary bill to create legal system to buy and sell agricultural lands and is expected to adopt slightly amended version; Communist and Agrarian parties, regional leaders and privatization opponents are threatening to block effort; collectives still run over 90 percent of farms; farmers fear repeat of earlier corrupted privatizations that gave control of former state enterprises to richest oligarchs; map; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Rioting In Belfast
abstract: Police officers and British soldiers in northern Belfast come under sustained attack as they try to separate Roman Catholic and Protestant rioters at intersection between Catholic and Protestant neighborhoods (S)

headline: Karzai, Seeking Ethnic Balance, Names Minister to Lead Police
abstract: Pres Hamid Karzai names Taj Muhammad Wardak, a Pashtun, as Afghanistan's new interior minister, putting him in control of nation's police force; he replaces Muhammad Yunus Qanooni, a Tajik, and predominantely Tajaik police force is widely rumored to be unhappy with change of leadership; choice of Wardak is part of Karzai's effort to balance cabinet and to reduce power of Tajiks (M)

headline: Rodney H. Hilton, British Historian, 85
abstract: Rodney Howard Hilton, influential British Marxist historian who was expert on medieval social history, dies at age 85 (S)

headline: An Internet Pioneer of the 90's Looks to a Future in Software
abstract: Loudcloud Inc is moving beyond providing corporate Internet and computing services to become software supplier to big companies; major technology company is expected to commit to buying its software, probably invest in struggling young company and perhaps take over some of services business; chairman Marc Andreessen, Internet pioneer, chief executive Benjamin Horowitz and other executives comment; stock price graph; photo (M)

headline: Major Upheaval at Ericsson
abstract: Ericsson said that it will cut its work force by an additional 20 percent, still probably lose money this year and ask for almost $3 billion in new investment.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Prosecutor In Lawyer's Death Resigns
abstract: Prosecutor in charge of investigating death of Digna Ochoa, well-known Mexican human rights lawyer found dead last October, has resigned; Renato Sales says his belief that Ochoa committed suicide has created criticism of his capacity to continue investigating case (S)

headline: Top 10 Airlines For Customer Service
abstract: Passenger survey published by Skytrax Research lists top 10 airlines for customer service (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Comdisco Sells Pacific Rim Holdings
abstract: Comdisco, technology and financing company that filed last year for bankruptcy protection, has sold its information technology leasing assets in Australia and New Zealand to Australia's Allco for $44 million (S)

headline: Panel Endorses Use of Claritin Over Counter For Some Hives
abstract: Federal advisory panel, in move that could reduce generic competition for Schering-Plough Corp's stable of allergy drugs, recommends that nonprescription Claritin be approved to treat same allergies as prescription versions; if Food and Drug Administration accepts panel's recommendations, which it does most of time, Claritin would be first nonprescription treatment approved for chronic hives; for Schering-Plough, it would mean that rivals developing generic versions of prescription drug would have to sell them over counter at drugstore prices--something that would translate into less profit; claritin, or loratadine, will lose its main patent protection in December, although Schering-Plough says it has effective patents that will cover drug until at least 2004; company decided last month to seek approval for nonprescription version after Johnson & Johnson and Wyeth said they would also market their own over-the-counter versions of loratadine after Claritin's patent protection ends; Schering-Plough is also working to persuade doctors to switch patients to Clarinex, similar prescription drug company hopes wil absorb some of Claritin's multibillion-dollar annual sales; WellPoint Health Networks is asking federal regulators to do same to Clarinex, which was introduced in January; Wall Street analysts are divided on whether regulators will accept WellPoint's petition (M)

headline: Idled Diplomacy
abstract: ISRAEL -- Secretary of State Colin L. Powell left without a hint of the cease-fire he had come for, saying no truce could take hold as long as Israel resisted the Bush administration's call to withdraw from the Palestinian-controlled cities and towns its forces have seized.    EGYPT -- Reflecting Arab anger over the Israeli-Palestinian stalemate, President Hosni Mubarak canceled a meeting with Secretary Powell and sent his foreign minister, Ahmed Maher, instead. Afterward, Mr. Maher suggested that those calling for the condemnation of Palestinian tactics against the Israelis were misguided. ''I believe an appeal should be addressed first to Israel to end its occupation,'' he said.

headline: Credit Suisse First Boston Eliminates 300 Executive Positions
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston eliminates 300 executive jobs, including those of about 50 managing directors, as part of bank's aggressive campaign to trim costs (M)

headline: Son Is Born to Widow of Reporter Killed in Karachi
abstract: Son is born to Mariane Pearl, widow of Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl who was kidnapped and killed by Islamic militants in Pakistan four months ago (S)

headline: Interpublic Official To Step Down
abstract: Sir Frank Lowe, longtime executive at Interpublic Group of Companies, will retire at end of year (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Special Suffix For Tribes
abstract: Interior Department and General Services Administration say federally recognized American Indian tribes will be eligible for special computer domain name suffix that identifies tribe as government entity (S)

headline: BOEING CUTS PRICE FOR SALE OF PLANES TO SOUTH KOREA
abstract: South Korean defense ministry says Boeing Co has cut $203 million from price of 40 F-15K fighter planes that it agreed to sell to South Korea, reducing cost to $4.2 billion from $4.4 billion; adds Boeing agreed to increase percentage of parts for planes that will be produced by Korean companies to more than 80 percent from 65 percent (S)

headline: Iraq Halts Petroleum Exports To Put Pressure on Americans
abstract: Pres Saddam Hussein of Iraq temporarily halts oil exports, saying he will seek to damage American economy because of Washington's support of Israel; repeats demand that other Middle Eastern oil producers follow suit; support from other Arab states held highly unlikely; Hussein says Iraq will review decision after month, or after Israel withdraws unconditionally from Palestinian territory; likely economic effects of decision discussed; King Abdullah II of Jordan warns if Israel refuses to withdraw from Palestinian territory, relations with kingdom will be affected; photo (M)

headline: Merrill Lynch to Pay $100 Million to Settle Analyst Charges
abstract: Merrill Lynch will pay a $100 million penalty under a wide-ranging agreement settling charges that the company misled investors with "tainted" stock research.

headline: A New Set of Questions for Farmer Mac
abstract: Farm Credit Administration has been considering bringing enforcement action against Farmer Mac over company's failure to furnish business plan for its review; memo, dated May 28 and signed by Farm Credit chief Michael M Reyna, asks Carl A Clinefelter, director of agency's Office of Secondary Market Oversight, to accelerate review of Farmer Mac he conducts each summer; memo also asks Clinefelter to answer 33 questions on Farmer Mac's business practices and oversight by July 1 (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: NTT'S Ratings Cut
abstract: Moody's Investors Service cuts debt ratings of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp, world's largest telecommunications company, citing growing competition (S)

headline: Pakistan to Pull Troops From Afghan Front
abstract: Pres Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan says he will begin withdrawing troops from border of Afghanistan and move them to increasingly volatile region of Kashmir; pledges that Pakistan will not initiate war against India; dozens of people on both sides are reported killed in continuing shelling; Pres Vladimir V Putin is trying to broker meeting between Musharraf and Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee of India at multilateral meeting they will attend next week in Kazakhstan; Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says Pentagon has detected no sign that Pakistan has actually moved troops out of tribal areas along border with Afghanistan; such movement could reduce Pakistan's contribution to American-led campaign against terrorism; photo; map (M)

headline: Aleksandr Lebed, 52, Dies; Midwife of Russian Democracy
abstract: Aleksandr I Lebed, blunt-spoken Soviet paratroop commander who later played crucial supporting role in birth of Russian democracy, dies in helicopter crash in Siberia with six other people; was governor of sprawling Krasnoyarsk Province; photo (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Jerry Who? Try Finding AOL Time Warner Chief in New Report
abstract: Gerald M Levin's name is nowhere to be found in AOL Time Warner's letter to shareholders in its recently released annual report, even though he remains chief executive until mid-May; letter is signed by chairman, Stephen M Case, and co-chief operating officers, Richard D Parsons and Robert W Pittman; spurs speculation that board pressured Levin to retire; photo (M)

headline: In a Blinking Modem, A Code of Betrayal
abstract: Joe Loughry and Prof David Umphress discuss implications of their discovery that it is possible to recreate data shuttled across networks by detecting variations in device's light-emitting diodes; were able to intercept data, including passwords, Web addresses and text files, from up to 100 feet away, suggesting complex home or office networks and businesses like Internet service providers may have to rethink siting of their computer hardware; photo (M)

headline: South African Brewer Takes Another Look at Buying Miller
abstract: Analysts say South African Breweries' decision to open negotiations again to buy Miller Brewing may be way for South African Breweries to insulate itself from volatile emerging markets where it sells most of its beer; Philip Morris Companies has put Miller Brewing on block for about $5 billion, $1 billion less than its initial asking price; chart (M)

headline: Auto Parts Makers Grinding to a Halt
abstract: Tool and die workers, who refine and produce tools for machines and cater to US auto industry, are losing work as more of Michigan's contracts are going to larger supply companies; General Motors Corp, Ford Motor Co and Chrysler have stepped up their modernization drive, sent more work overseas, and consolidated other work at huge supply giants like Delphi and Visteon; nationally, tool and die industry, which is important part of overall machine tool industry, peaked in spring of 1998, as bull market production was fully revving; machine tool orders reached $650 billion, but dropped to about $200 billion by middle of 2001; Tom Libera of J&T Tool and Die in Bay City, Mich, says he is facing closing because there is little work; graph; photos

headline: An E-Mail Affliction: The Long Goodbye
abstract: Some e-mail users are finding themselves trapped in unnecessarily long series of confirmations and thanks; e-mail, purportedly so effortless, unintrusive and speedy, tends to drag on, with users unable to send subtle subconscious signals that say it is time to end exchange; drawing (M)

headline: U.S. Provides List for Passengers
abstract: Transportation Security Administration updates its list of things that passengers may and may not bring on board plane (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: SOUTH KOREA: New Currency Issued; CHINA: Exports Rise;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Downgraded
abstract: Standard & Poor's cuts Deutsche Bank's credit rating; also cuts rating on Credit Suisse Group; photo (S)

headline: Stonyfield Farm tries something new: an old-fashioned campaign to sell its yogurt.
abstract: Stonyfield Farm is beginning old-fashioned advertising campaign to sell its yogurt to solidify its position as top player in $2.3 billion national yogurt market; campaign, created by eFlicks Media, is estimated at $3.5 million; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: U.S. Soldier Guilty Of Murder
abstract: United States Army judge in Mannheim, Germany, finds Specialist Lillie Morgan, American soldier, guilty of premeditated murder for drowning her two young children at family's apartment in military housing complex near Frankfurt; experts for defense testified Morgan is schizophrenic (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Verisign Sued By Consumers
abstract: VeriSign, which registers Internet addresses, is accused in suit filed by consumers of misleading competitors' customers by sending them letters suggesting their domain names would expire unless they switched to VeriSign; Marc Luxemberg is seeking class status for customers who paid $29 fee after receiving 'official looking' mailing to transfer their domain names from their current registrar to VeriSign; Bulkregister.com in early May won injunction from federal judge in Maryland barring VeriSign from mailing domain name expiration notices to its customers (S)

headline: 30-Year Low for Money Markets
abstract: Average yield on money market accounts falls to 1.31 percent, lowest in 30 years (S)

headline: Israel Attacks Arafat Compound in Swift Response After Palestinian Suicide Bombing Kills 17 in Bus
abstract: Israeli ground forces attack Yasir Arafat's compound in Ramallah, surrounding his offices with tanks, after 17 Israelis, including 13 soldiers, are killed in Palestinian suicide attack on bus in northern Israel; Palestinian officials in Ramallah report heavy machine-gun fire and at least six Palestinian casualties, including member of security forces who is killed by gunshot to head; say Arafat is unhurt but in danger; say Israeli troops are withdrawing; Prime Min Ariel Sharon's trip to United States for talks with Pres Bush will be delayed for day; he will leave June 8; Israeli raid on Arafat's headquarters throws into doubt ability of Pres Bush's envoy George J Tenet to accomplish much during his mission; Bush and other American officials have said repeatedly that they have received pledge from Sharon not to try to kill or harm Arafat; photo; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Broadcom Will Acquire Mobilink
abstract: Broadcom, maker of communications chips, agrees to buy Mobilink Telecom, privately held maker of computer chips for cellular telephones, for about $190 million in stock (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   7.50        Discount rate   1.25   1.25   4.00        Federal funds   1.75   1.74   4.43        3-month T-bills   1.75   1.73   3.63        6-month T-bills   1.87   1.82   3.64        10-yr. T-infl.   3.07   3.07   3.23        10-yr. T-note   5.23   5.12   5.43        30-yr. headline: Antiterror Fight: Why the Philippines?
abstract: News analysis; partially successful military raid to rescue American missionary couple held hostage for more than year by Abu Sayyaf rebels in Philippines raises questions about American military role there, such as why Bush administration chose Philippines for its first major military foray after Afghanistan; answer ranges from desire for quick victory over terrorism to wish to reassert American power in Southeast Asia; photo (M)

headline: ADELPHIA COMMUNICATIONS WARNS OF POSSIBLE DELISTING
abstract: Adelphia Communications shares fall 11 percent after company says it may be delisted from Nasdaq Stock Market (S)

abstract: The New York Times: Technology Text Version         function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                            International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business             Technology           -      E-Business            -      Circuits            -      Columns               Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: Hard-Drive Magic: Making Data Disappear Forever
abstract: Survey of 10 products that enable consumers to eliminate computer files irretrievably; so-called scrubbers can be handy for consumer who donates PC to charity; drawing (M)

headline: Energy Trader Admits Faking Transactions
abstract: Reliant Resources Inc, one of country's biggest electricity traders, says it conducted fake transactions with four power companies that inflated its revenue by 10 percent over last three years; industry analysts and companies themselves say practice of trading just to build up volume is widespread and well known in industry; investors worry that other companies might make more damaging revelations, suggesting that much of industry that had been trusted might be built on fiction; CMS Energy and Xcel Energy acknowledge they engaged in such trades with Reliant; Reliant also names EnCana and Merchant Energy Group of the Americas as partners in wash trades (M)

headline: Yahoo Gains in Revenue, Aided by Online Dating Service
abstract: Yahoo Inc says revenue in first quarter was $192.7 million, up 7 percent; Internet portal lost $52.6 million in quarter, largely because of $64 million charge related to changes in accounting; excluding charge, company earned $10.5 million, in contrast to loss of $11.5 million in period year earlier; advertising revenue was $121 million, down 15 percent for year; photo (M)

headline: Investing; S.& P. Tries a Hedge-Fund Gauge
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp plans to start its own hedge fund index in order to provide transparency now absent from industry; new index will initially track returns of only 40 funds, but S&P says its research shows that that many funds reliably reporting their performance data can accurately reflect entire universe of hedge funds; that assumption is questioned by hedge fund managers and companies that operate rival indexes and base their data on hundreds of funds; photo; graph (M)

headline: CREDIT CARD THEFT IS THRIVING ONLINE AS GLOBAL MARKET
abstract: Tens of thousands of stolen credit-card numbers are being offered for sale each week on Internet in handful of thriving, membership-only cyberbazaars, operated largely by residents of former Soviet Union who have become central players in credit-card and identity theft; security experts say buyers of card numbers are spread worldwide, but often come from former Soviet Union, Eastern Europe and Asia, particularly Malaysia; buyers use numbers in variety of frauds, including making purchases over Internet, having them fenced in West, or even extracting cash advances directly from credit-card accounts; cost to financial institutions and individual businesses discussed; security experts comment; say people living in former Soviet Union who are operators of marketplaces are typically buying card numbers from so-called black-hat computer hackers, who obtain numbers by breaking into computer systems of online merchants and getting access to thousands of records at a time (M)

headline: Infogrames to McCarthy Mambro Bertino
abstract: Infogrames to McCarthy Mambro Bertino

headline: Bin Laden Falls Off Pakistan's Best-Seller List
abstract: Osama bin Laden, and books about him, fall out of favor in Peshawar, Pakistan, raucous border town that has long been center of men and materiel for wars in next-door Afghanistan; local printers are thriving on change, filling Afghan orders for new textbooks in post-Taliban era; photos; map (M)

headline: Seizing Arms And Leaving An Upset Town
abstract: Battalion of 200 American soldiers descends into tiny village on Afghanistan's eastern border with Pakistan to extract Australian Special Forces troops who had come under rocket and machine-gun fire from gunmen in village; American soldiers find no Qaeda or Taliban fighters, but 40 scared and unhappy villagers, many of them upset when soldiers search their houses and seize weapons there (S)

headline: AT&T LONG-TERM CREDIT RATING IS CUT TWO NOTCHES
abstract: Long-term credit rating of AT&T is cut by two notches by Moody's Investors Service because of what Moody's calls 'weakened revenue prospects for long-distance voice and data industry' (S)

headline: Greenwich Offices, and Rents, Are Sprucing Up
abstract: Owners of number of Greenwich, Conn, office buildings have been investing heavily in refurbishing in bid to achieve or maintain high rents traditional in city; city's vacancy rate reportedly is about 10.5 percent, somewhat lower than elsewhere in Fairfield County; projects described; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Jail Awaits Big Mac Attacker
abstract: French prosecutor rules antiglobalization advocate Jose Bove must return to jail to finish serving three-month sentence for role in ransacking of McDonald's restaurant in Millau in 1999; photo (S)

headline: Viacom Reports $1.1 Billion Loss
abstract: Viacom Inc reports $1.11 billion first-quarter loss, compared with loss of $7.3 million year earlier; revenue slipped 1.4 percent, to $5.67 billion; chief executive Sumner M Redstone and president Mel Karmazin comment (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Rebels Blamed For Bombings
abstract: Russia's chief prosecutor's office says probe found 'definitive proof' that Chechan separatists, not Kremlin intelligence agents, masterminded 1999 apartment-house bombings that led to full-scale war in Chechnya; upholds intelligence agency's stand that so-called bombs agency placed in Ryazan building were sacks of sugar, part of training exercise (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Complaint Filed On Unlicensed CD'S
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics files complaint with International Trade Commission against 19 companies that make blank compact discs, or distribute them, in effort to curb imports of unlicensed discs (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hand-Held Sales Slowing
abstract: Research firm IDC releases figures indicating that worldwide market for hand-held computer devices dropped 12.1 percent, to 3.25 million units, in first quarter from year ago (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Another Bank Loss; JAPAN: Losses From Beef Scare; JAPAN: New Central Bankers; JAPAN: Nissan Raises China Stake; JAPAN: Sharp's Profit To Fall.

headline: Discrimination Isn't Funny, Mexicans Are Slow to Learn
abstract: A growing number of Mexicans are complaining that obvious acts of discrimination have become part of the country's social fabric.

headline: Daniel H. Case III, 44, Banker for Silicon Valley
abstract: Daniel H Case III, investment banker who helped launch many Silicon Valley enterprises, dies at age 44; photo (M)

headline: Powell Presses His Quest For a Hint Of Progress
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell, seeking way to break Israeli-Palestinian stalemate, suggests regional peace conference at ministerial level without Yasir Arafat, whose presence at any such meeting has been rejected by Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon; visits Lebanon and Syria to press leaders to restrain Hezbollah militants firing across Israel's northern frontier (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: AKQA, San Francisco, is losing two top executives who had been among the founders of Citron Haligman Bedecarré, which was absorbed into AKQA last year.

headline: Villagers Flee As Fighting In Kashmir Is Unabated
abstract: Intense Indian-Pakistani artillery barrages persist for fourth day, sending thousands of villagers in Kashmir fleeing for safety as fears of even fiercer fighting grow; militants continue campaign of terror against Indian military (S)

headline: Rumsfeld, at Base Near Iraq, Warns Sponsors of Terror
abstract: US Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld visits American base near Kuwait's border with Iraq; issues pointed warning to any nation that acquires weapons of mass destruction and plans to strike bargain with terrorists for their use in an attack; will also visit Bahrain and Qatar, Persian Gulf states crucial in mounting any military operation against Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Splits Over Palestinian Statehood And Arafat Role Are Unresolved
abstract: Pres and Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon, meeting at White House, remain divided on how quickly to move toward creation of Palestinian state and whether to deal with Yasir Arafat; photo; Sharon visit is abruptly broken off by news of another suicide bombing; Bush will send CIA Dir George Tenet to work on building new Palestinian security force; says he has not changed position supporting Palestinian state; Sharon says it is premature to discuss issue until Palestinian Authority is radically reformed; voices support, despite latest attack, for regional conference and insists Arafat has ability to halt suicide bombings, noting that Israel has recently had to stop two planned attacks from Gaza, where Arafat's power is intact; explains, in interview, that Arafat should be 'symbolic leader' with real power turned over to prime minister as precondition to political settlement; explains his peace plan, based on cessation of violence and terror, interim incremental steps before setting final borders and development of better Israeli-Palestinian relations; hopes peace coalition could include Egypt, Jordan and Saudi Arabia (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   8.00       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   4.50       Federal funds   1.69   1.73   4.41       3-month T-bills   1.68   1.69   3.68       6-month T-bills   1.86   1.88   3.63       10-yr. T-infl.   3.08   3.06   3.29       10-yr. T-note   5.17   5.18   5.21       30-yr. headline: Al Qaeda Offers Bounty for U.S. Soldiers
