abstract: Taliban and Al Qaeda are offering bounties of up for the killing or capture of American soldiers, American officials said today.

headline: Four U.S. Soldiers Killed in Kandahar
abstract: Four American soldiers were killed and one was wounded today when rockets they were disposing of exploded near Kandahar.

headline: North Korean Migrants Pull U.S. Into a Diplomatic Mess
abstract: Diplomat says eight North Koreans who tried to storm into two foreign consulates in Shenyang, China, are seeking asylum in United States, not in South Korea; this pulls United States into messy international debate; it also puts to test Pres Bush's Feb expression of 'great sympathy and empathy' for North Korean people; other North Koreans who have sought refuge and asylum at United States Embassy in Beijing wanted to go to South Korea, which has policy of accepting North Koreans; request for asylum in US pushes Americans to take explicit stand on politically loaded question: should hundreds of thousands of North Koreans illegally in China be given protected political refugee status under United Nations convenants; map (M)

headline: Are Large Caps Back in Style? Ask Again in a Year
abstract: Mark Hulbert column expresses doubts about expectations of market bulls that large-capitalization stocks will show same relative strength in June and July that they showed in May; graphs (M)

headline: Italy Moves to Tighten Immigration Laws After a Stormy Debate
abstract: Conservative majority in Italy's Parliament approves legislation that will require immigrants to show proof of employment, limit their stay to duration of their work contracts and make it easier to expel them for breaking law; bill also makes it more difficult for immigrants to reunite their families, permitting children to join their parents in Italy only if they are under 18; opposition politicians denounces provisions as racist; Italians may chafe under influx of immigrants, but many of country's industries, including steel and leather tanning, rely heavily on their labor to perform arduous tasks that young Italians no longer will (M)

headline: AOL Shifts Key Contract To Google
abstract: America Online has chosen Google to provide Web search results and advertisements that appear next to them; decision will increase Google's already healthy share of search market and give its advertising program stronger foothold; Google is replacing incumbents, search engine Inktomi and ad provider Overture Services, which will continue to place ads on AOL services in Europe; AOL Time Warner incoming chief operating officer Robert W Pittman and Google chief executive-chairman Eric E Schmidt comment (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: CMGI Loss Narrows As Costs Fall
abstract: CMGI says net loss was $125.2 million in fiscal third quarter ended April 30, compared with loss of $986.6 million year earlier; sales declined 35 percent, to $187.4 million; total operating expenses plunged to $321 million from $1.32 billion (S)/

headline: The Busy Life of Being a Lightning Rod for Bush
abstract: Deputy Defense Sec Paul D Wolfowitz, one of Israel's staunchest allies in Bush administration, was dispatched to big pro-Israel rally in Washington, and found himself being booed repeatedly when he spoke, in largely pro-Israel speech, of 'innocent Palestinians' who are suffering, along with Israelis, from bloodshed; says his remarks were intended to capture administration's balancing act in Midle East, and that he was stunned by outbursts; acknowledges that Secretary of State Colin Powell's Mideast peace mission illustrates limits of American power, especially military might; talks about being lightning rod for Pres Bush; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: COCA-COLA CO., Atlanta, the soft drink maker, said it had reached a seven-year agreement to be the exclusive supplier of water and soft drinks to Regal Cinemas Inc., Knoxville, Tenn., a chain of more than 300 movie theaters. Terms were not disclosed.    FEDERAL-MOGUL CORP., Southfield, Mich., an auto parts maker trying to emerge from bankruptcy protection, said it had won a $100 million contract to supply its new Monosteel pistons to an unidentified maker of heavy-truck engines.

headline: Annan Picks Team To Examine Camp Attacked by Israel
abstract: Former Pres Martti Ahtisaari of Finland is appointed to head United Nations fact-finding team to look into Israel's military assault on Palestinian refugee camp in Jenin; Secretary General Kofi Annan also picks Sadako Ogata, former UN high commissioner for refugees, and Cornelio Sommaruga, former head of International Committee of Red Cross, for three-member team; Palestinians have accused Israel of killing civilians and bulldozing houses down on top of them; Israel contends casualties and destruction are result of battles with gunmen entrenched in general population (M)

headline: Senate Takes Up Terrorism Insurance Again
abstract: Senate Democrats and Republicans reach consensus on need to revive federal legislation that would put most of burden of paying for major terrorist attack on government rather than insurance companies; passage is far from certain because parties have yet to resolve differences over limiting damages victims could collect from insurers and other businesses; consumer advocates and some insurance experts contend that with terrorism coverage becoming increasingly available at lower prices, government intervention is no longer needed; Bush administration and some lawmakers say that it is still difficult to get coverage for new construction projects and big cities and that insurance shortage is creating drag on struggling economy; Pres Bush urges passage of bill; insurance legislation was introduced by Sen Phil Gramm; Sen Charles E Schumer comments; photo (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Sounds Optimistic Note as He Arrives in India for Talks
abstract: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld arrived in New Delhi today for meetings with senior Indian officials, sounding a hopeful note about the outlook for reduced tensions between Pakistan and India.

headline: Subject: A Firm Goodbye
abstract: David A Burack letter on May 9 article about signing off e-mails offers his own solution to seemingly never-ending e-mail exchanges

headline: Merrill Chief Is Apologetic Over Analysts; One Dismissed
abstract: Merrill Lynch chmn and chief exec David Komansky, having seen his firm embarrassed and its stock price pummeled, apologizes for behavior of some of brokerage firm's stock analysts and pledges to punish anybody who violates firm's policies, remarks made at firm's annual meeting, Plainsboro, NJ; within hours, firm backs up Komansky's words; Merrill dismisses stock analyst Phua Young because of accusations of repeatedly sending reports about Tyco International to institutional investors without first getting approval from his managers; Komansky photo (M)

headline: Chinese Allow 5 North Koreans to Quietly Make Way to Seoul
abstract: The Chinese government quietly allowed five detained North Korean asylum seekers to leave China today.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Richemont's Profit Falls
abstract: Compagnie Financiere Richemont says its second-half profit fell 13 percent, hurt by higher costs and stagnant sales; graph (S)

headline: Spreading by the Web, Pop's Bootleg Remix
abstract: Amateur mixtures of two or more pop hits, spread mostly by Internet, are becoming explosively popular; songs, called mash-ups or bootlegs, typically match rhythm, melody and underlying spirit of instrumentals of one song with a cappella vocals of another in intentionally odd pairings; music industry response is mixed, with legal action to block illegal mash-ups and industry release of some legal ones; music is particularly popular in Europe; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Privacy Products Released
abstract: IBM and AT&T Corp release free software intended to help companies and consumers manage online privacy (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: U.S. Poultry Still Non Grata
abstract: Russian agriculture ministry does not take expected action to lift ban on imports of US poultry, imposed because of concerns about chemicals and antibiotics (S)

headline: Daydream About This: Lottery Prizes Are Taxed
abstract: Tax experts suggest strategies to cut tax bite for lottery winners (M)0

headline: The World Cup in Spanish
abstract: Jelani Mahiri letter on June 6 article about accessibility of World Cup Soccer information online says Spanish-language broadcasts offer better option for fans than Web sites

headline: Personal Business; The Nanny Is Late. You Have a Speech. What Now?
abstract: Article on increasing number of companies offering employees backup child care as way to improve productivity; photo (M)

headline: New Diplomatic Dance Follows Israel's Military Offensive
abstract: As Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, flew off today to Washington to bolster his position in the U.S., Egypt's foreign minister met with Yasir Arafat.

headline: Article 2002042093396611894 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //              JOB POSITIONS

headline: Jenin Refugee Camp's Dead Can't Be Counted or Claimed
abstract: Israel officially estimates that 100 Palestinians were killed during nine-day assault on Palestinian refugee camp in Jenin, which is viewed by Israeli authorities as place where Palestinian militants plan attacks on Israeli civilians by suicide bombers; some Israeli officials say toll coud reach 200; Palestinians put figure at several hundred, but acknowledge that because many refugees have fled, no one can yet provide precise figure; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sales Drop At European Chip Maker
abstract: European chip maker STMicroelectronics says sales fell 29 percent, to $1.36 billion in first quarter (S)

headline: Broadcasting Your Data While Keeping It Secret
abstract: Q. What is W.E.P. encryption, which is advertised as a feature for wireless networks?    A. W.E.P. stands for Wireless Equivalent Privacy and is a method for encrypting data as it travels across wireless networks.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: MusicNet Hires Internet Analyst
abstract: MusicNet hires Mark Mooradian as senior director of strategic planning and business development; Cindy Charles is named vice president and general counsel; Ayesha Tidwell is named director of human resources (S)

headline: Requiem for an Honorable Profession
abstract: Interviews with former stock analysts and internal evaluation and compensation documents from Wall Street firms show how research analysts were driven in recent years to excel in investment banking and ranking, not to provide best advice for investors; analysts were supposed to generate investment banking fees by producing positive research reports on companies and to attain highest ranking on Institutional Investor magazine's list of top analysts; photos (M)

headline: Moscow Journal; In a Museum's Mauling, One More Disaster of War
abstract: Restorers in Moscow are working to repair paintings from Pyotr Zakharov Fine Arts Museum in Grozny, Chechnya, damaged during Russian assault on capital during 1995 rebellion; artworks are to be exhibited at Moscow museum Tretyakov Gallery; map; photo (Moscow Journal) (M)

headline: Big Accounting Firm's Tax Plans Help the Wealthy Conceal Income
abstract: Some experts say some of techniques Ernst & Young accounting firm sells to wealthy Americans and their financial advisers to eliminate or sharply cut income taxes should not pass muster in audit and may amount to illegal tax evasion, not legal aggressive tax avoidance, because they hide transactions from Internal Revenue Service; techniques bring huge fees to firm and smaller amounts to lawyers who approve them and banks and currency traders who help execute them; other big accounting firms sell own tax avoidance techniques, including some shut down by Treasury as improper; table outlining technique; photo (M)

headline: Worried Pakistanis Wait for Captured Fighters
abstract: Thousands of Pakistanis who slipped across border to fight with Taliban in Afghanistan remain prisoners of Afghan Army or of warlords demanding ransom, or of their own government, which fears disruptive radicalism they may be bringing home with them; pain of their families in Pakistan is universal; photos (M)

headline: Moving and the Art of Civil War
abstract: Ellyn Spragins humorous column offers practice exercises to prepare for emotional havoc of selling house and buying new one; drawing (M)

headline: U.N. and European Union Press for Cease-Fire
abstract: UN Security Council, deflecting Arab request for stronger resolution demanding Israeli withdrawal from Palestinian cities, meets in private sessions with Israeli and Palestinian envoys to urge end to conflict; European Union calls foreign ministers meeting to pressure Israel (S)

headline: Singapore Telecom to Expand Mobile Business in Indonesia
abstract: Singapore Telecommunications says it will pay $429 million to expand its presence in Indonesia's booming market for mobile phone service; Telekomunikasi Indonesia, former domestic telephone monopoly, will sell to Singapore Telecommunications 12.7 percent block of shares in Telekomunikasi Selular, known as Telkomsel, country's largest cellular phone operator; it agrees to fold another cellular subsidiary into Telkomsel, doubling its capacity; combining new block of Telkomsel shares with 22.3 percent stake bought from Royal KPN of Netherlands in December for $601 million will give Singapore Telecommunications 35 percent stake in company (M)

headline: In Mexico, Greed Kills Fish by the Seaful
abstract: Greed and corruption are allowing Mexican fishing fleets to drain Gulf of California, decimating every important species and leaving impoverished local fishermen with meager catches; photos; American and Japanese ships were first to exploit waters as many governments pour subsidies into commercial fishing fleets, causing fisheries to collapse around world; Gulf of California is world's youngest sea, created when San Andreas fault split Mexico millions of years ago and let Pacific pour in; waters are home home to 875 species of fish and 30 species of marine mammal, which have been killed indiscriminately for years (M)

headline: Andersen Auditors Knew About Federal Inquiry, Records at Trial Show
abstract: Records and testimony presented at Arthur Andersen's trial on charge of obstruction of justice show Andersen auditors billed Enron about $720,000 for dealing with federal inquiry into its finances at same time they were destroying boxes of documents related to company; billing records are government's strongest documentary evidence yet demonstrating not only that Andersen knew about informal investigation into Enron by Securities and Exchange Commission but also that accountants who were shredding documents were simultaneously spending large amounts of time working on matters related to inquiry; legal experts say in interviews that records are particularly damaging to Enron because it appears to establish that wide range of people involved in document destruction had direct, personal knowledge of federal inquiry; former Andersen partner David B Duncan testifies about tensions within Andersen as Enron's position worsened; photo (M)

headline: Church of Nativity Damaged And a Monastery Is Scorched
abstract: Gun battle between Israeli and Palestinian fighters damages exterior of Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem and ignites fire in adjoining monastery, scarring one of Christianity's holiest sites as standoff at church continued for sixth day; fire is quickly extinguished but both sides confirm exterior of church suffered damage during exchange of fire that left Palestinian policeman dead and two Israeli soldiers seriously wounded; photo (M)

headline: HSBC Account Goes to Lowe & Partners
abstract: HSBC Account Goes To Lowe & Partners.

headline: U.S. Says Banks' Earnings Are Up 18.6%
abstract: Office of Comptroller of the Currency reports that nation's banks, taking advantage of low interest rates and stronger cost controls, increased earnings 18.6 percent in last year (M)

headline: BellSouth in Big Brazilian Debt Dispute
abstract: BellSouth and Joseph Safra, one of Brazil's wealthiest bankers, are engaged in dispute that may result in big and messy corporate debt renegotiation; dispute touched off default last week on $375 million debt payment by BCP SA, large Brazilian wireless communications company; BellSouth and unit of Safra's financial group, which jointly control BCP, have sharply differed over how to honor BCP's obligations to foreign creditors; Safra's representatives complicate dispute by offering to inject $325 million in cash into BCP immediately and urging BellSouth to do same; offer is essentially met with silence from BellSouth, with spokesman saying company needs time to analyze proposal; decision to miss payment last week was preceded by series of tense negotiations between BellSouth executives and Safra's respresentatives in Sao Paulo; ABN Amro and Citigroup are part of group of 20 banks that risk losses from their exposure to BCP's debt; BellSouth chief executive F Duane Ackerman has insisted on restructuring debt of BCP; photo (M)

headline: Ace Hardware Picks Goodby, Silverstein
abstract: Ace Hardware selects Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco to handle its ad account (S)

headline: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS NAMES CHIEF TO REPLACE FOUNDER
abstract: ICN Pharmaceuticals names Robert W O'Leary chairman and chief executive, replacing Milan Panic, and says it will review plan to spin off two businesses (S)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: ARGENTINA: Congress Defies President; BRAZIL: A Woman On The Ticket ; MEXICO: Arrest In Oil-and-politics Case.

headline: Article 2002042190761471374 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                      International           -      Africa            -      Americas            -      Asia Pacific            -      Europe            -    Middle East             National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business              Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: Rail Projects Are Sign of a Quiet Revolution in Short-Haul Trips
abstract: Ambitious new intercity rail projects are under consideration around nation, largely to serve business people traveling between cities less than 400 miles apart; moves would free up North American airports, where currently 60 percent of flights are under 400 miles, to handle long-distance trips; experts call for airports that are modern transportation and business hubs, where high-speed and commuter rail links converge; drawing (M)

headline: Security Hole Found in KaZaA File-Sharing Service
abstract: Researchers at Hewlett-Packard find that users of KaZaA, Sharman Networks' popular Internet service for sharing music files, frequently misconfigure programs in way that allows private files on their computers, like e-mail and financial documents, to be shared with global Internet (M)

headline: As Egypt Curbs Dissent, Critic Fears His Fate at Trial
abstract: Saad Eddin Ibrahim, Egypt's most prominent democracy activist, who recently spent eight months in prison, is bracing for new trial before judge with reputation for severity; government of Pres Hosni Mubarak has in past several years extended its authoritarian hand, taking on not only Islamist militants but also human rights activists, intellectuals and gays; Ibrahim has been symbol of that shift; Ibrahim's first trial came after he called for open elections, human rights and end to discrimination against Coptic Christian minority; his prison sentence prompted complaints from governments and human rights group abroad, and verdict was overturned by appeal court; preparations for retrial are under way, with no indication that government will soften its approach to case; photo (M)

headline: Accra Journal; No Mosh Pit, This, but Some Enthusiasm for Aid
abstract: Rock star Bono and and Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill visit Accra, Ghana, to start off their two-week fact-finding tour of Africa; pairing of Bono and O'Neill illustrates expanding ideological consensus on need to address poverty, disease, famine and conflict in Africa--as well as remaining gulf between left and right about how best to do it; Bono wants to convince Bush administration that aid to Africa is both moral imperative and good investment of taxpayers' money; O'Neill makes clear that US will be skeptical about providing aid to countries that cannot show how they are improving standards of living; photo of Bono and O'Neill with Pres John A Kufuor; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Internet
abstract: Cmgi Scales Back Its Forecast; Proposed Royalty Rates Rejected; Bill Intended To Shield Children.

headline: In Jerusalem, Bare Streets And Concern for Children
abstract: Article describes mood in and around city of Jerusalem, where life has changed in innumerable ways amid spate of suicide bombings and constant violence between Israelis and Palestinians; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Support From Berlusconi
abstract: Italian Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi backs Russia's 'fullest integration' with Europe; photo with Pres Vladimir Putin in Sochi on Black Sea (S)

headline: Palestinians Say Israelis Sow Hatred In the Raids
abstract: Palestinians in Bethlehem say Israeli raids and curfews brand them all as terrorists, and sow more hatred (M)

headline: Quebec Journal; No Rest for You, Champlain. The Hunt Goes On.
abstract: Article on unrelenting campaign by Rene Levesque, Canadian archeologist, to locate grave of Samuel de Champlain, France's greatest New World explorer and founder of Quebec City who died in 1635; photos (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: MONDAYNone.

headline: Hyundai Joins 2 Automakers In Planning For Engine
abstract: Hyundai Motor, DaimlerChrysler and Mitsubishi Motors agree to form Global Engine Alliance to develop engines all three companies can use in their cars; accord, response by Hyundai to greater competition it faces as result of General Motors Corp's planned take over of Daewoo Motor, calls for Hyundai to provide basic designs for engines of midsize and luxury cars that other companies can tailor to specific needs (M)

headline: Hotels Are Backing Off On Extra Service Fees
abstract: Many hotels have dropped extra fees, from service charges on minibar purchases and room safes to bundled levies for amenities, because of customer backlash and slump in business travel that began early last year; Bjorn Hanson, managing partner of hospitality consulting unit of PricewaterhouseCoopers, says fewer than 10 percent of regular hotels, as opposed to resorts, now levy any such charges, down from about 30 percent less than year ago; Lalia Rach, dean of Tisch Center for Hospitality and Tourism at New York University comments on how she refused to pay hotel's energy surcharge in Chicago; photo (M)

headline: Extension of Benefits Contributes To an Increase in Jobless Claims
abstract: Labor Department says number of Americans who filed initial claims for state unemployment benefits surged last week to highest level in four months; law enacted last month permitted workers whose benefit had expired to apply for extension; department says state unemployment offices received 460,000 new applications last week, up 64,000 in week ended March 30; graph (M)

headline: Private Sector; In Rich Southern California, Art and Money Don't Always Mix
abstract: Orange County, Calif, Performaing Arts Center finds itself in awkward position halfway through $200 million fund-raising campaign after losing support of Henry T Nicholas III and Henry Samueli, billionaire co-founders of Broadcom Corp; both resigned as Arts Center directors after discovering that some of plaintiffs in class-action lawsuit against Broadcom were also on center's board; photo (S)

headline: Bomb Kills 12 at Pakistan Mosque
abstract: A bomb exploded at a mosque in central Pakistan during a religious festival, killing 12 worshippers, officials said today.

headline: Goodbye to Ally and Scully and Mulder at Fox. Hello to Mr. Grubb and John Doe.
abstract: Fox Broadcasting Co unveils fall prime-time schedule that is filled with changes; programs Ally McBeal and The X-Files have been dropped from schedule; changes detailed; Fox Entertainment chairman Sandy Grushow comments; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Government Bans Magazine
abstract: Bangladesh bans issue of Hong Kong-based magazine Far Eastern Economic Review, charging article unfairly maligns country as hotbed of Islamic fundamentalism (S)

headline: Morocco Detainee Linked to Qaeda
abstract: United States officials say Abu Zubayr, Al Qaeda agent with links to Abu Zubaydah, group's former operations chief, was arrested last week in Morocco; are unsure whether he helped plan Sept 11 terrorism (M)

headline: Germany Eases Restrictions On Workers From Abroad
abstract: German Pres Johannes Rau signs immigration law that significantly expands residence permits available to workers from countries outside the European Union, at a time when countries across Continent are moving toward tightening borders (S)

headline: Andersen Said to Be Near a Deal With KPMG Consulting
abstract: Arthur Andersen is nearing deal to sell its consulting business to KPMG Consulting; tentative agreement could be announced by end of week (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Strong Chip Sales In March
abstract: Semiconductor Industry Association says computer chip sales in March fell 25 percent from previous year but reports strongest month-to-month increase since 1986; says global sales were $10.75 billion, rising 7.2 percent from February; sales fell sharply from $14.41 billion reported in March 2001, but 25 percent decline was narrowest in months; revenue increased in all regions (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: US Airways Unions Fail To Agree on Concessions  US Airways and its unions negotiated throughout the week on concessions by workers, but labor leaders said they were dissastisfied.    David N. Siegel, left, the chief executive, is seeking to cut $950 million in annual labor costs for a revamping plan. The airline must submit that plan to the federal government by June 28, the deadline to apply for $1 billion loan guarantees. [Page C2.]

headline: Vivendi Takes More Lumps As Shares Fall
abstract: Vivendi Universal investors, nervous about continuing swirl of negative news, pummel stock, pushing it down 7 percent at one point, to five-year low; stock later recovers somewhat to close at 35.39 euros ($31.99) per share in Paris, off 2.8 percent; it has lost more than two-thirds of its value this year, as investors have questioned strategy of Vivendi's chief executive Jean-Marie Messier (M)

headline: Intel to Offer Some Pieces In a Puzzle
abstract: Intel Corp is planning to detail performance of its second-generation 64-bit Itanium microprocessor at technical meeting in Germany; Intel, in press release, goes to great lengths to compare new Itanium chip with both its previous Itanium, known as McKinley, and to competing chip from Sun Microsystems; 64-bit Itanium processor is aimed at high-performance corporate markets; missing in document is any reference to Intel's industry-leading Pentium family of microprocessors; missing comparison is intriguing because recent versions of Pentium have demonstrated sharp performance increases of their own (M)

headline: New Yorker Is Suspected of Aiding Killers of Anti-Taliban Leader
abstract: Ahmed Abdel Sattar, Staten Island, NYC, resident indicted on charges related to terrorism, is also suspected of helping prepare letter of introduction used in 2001 by two men who killed Ahmed Shah Massoud, commander of anti-Taliban forces in northern Afghanistan; is charged, along with New York lawyer Lynne F Stewart, with helping imprisoned Muslim cleric Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman to continue to direct terrorist operations from prison in Minnesota; Rahman is serving life sentence for plot to blow up New York City landmarks (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Trade Pact Spans Atlantic
abstract: Chile and European Union conclude agreement that will free more than $7 billion in trade between two, first deal of its kind between Europe and South America; Chile's Pres Ricardo Lagos and Spain's Prime Min Jose Maria Aznar hail agreement (S)0

headline: How in a Little British Town Jihad Found Young Converts
abstract: The story of the "Tipton Taliban" shows the psychic journey being taken in immigrant communities across Western Europe.

headline: More Worry Over Loans By Big Banks In China
abstract: Financial experts are expressing grave worries about solvency of China's banking system; head of China's central bank said recently that 25 to 30 percent of all bank loans are not being repaid; Standard & Poor's estimates that situation may be twice that bad, with half of all loans classifiable as nonperforming; warns that Chinese banks appear to be trying to prop themselves up by issuing new loans at furious pace, in many cases financing vaguely described projects with little discernible effect on China's overall economic output; Terry E H Chan, ratings agency's director for Chinese and Southeast Asian financial institutions, says issuing new loans could yield even more bad loans, and may be creating financial bubble of wasteful and mismanaged overspending of kind that led to crises in many other East Asian nations in late 1990's (M)

headline: Bonuses Meant to Retain Talent Now Risk Outrage
abstract: As it moves to lay off thousands of employees to cut costs, WorldCom is also facing the conflicting problem of avoiding an exodus of experienced senior executives needed to help it survive.    The management challenge is heightened by the looming expiration of a retention program that paid 558 top executives roughly $237 million in bonuses two years ago -- an average of nearly $425,000 -- to keep them from leaving the company during a period that will end on July 30. Some of the executives received bonuses of well over $1 million that are supposed to be returned if they leave before then. But once the deadline has passed, executive recruiters say that all bets are off.

headline: EARNINGS WARNING SENDS McDATA SHARES LOWER
abstract: McData Corp shares fall 26 percent after company warns it will report worse-than-expected loss for first quarter (S)

headline: U.S. Rejects All Support For New Court On Atrocities
abstract: Bush administration formally renounces support for new International Criminal Court, and says its prosecutors will not be given any information from US to help them bring cases against any individuals; decision is victory for faction of policymakers who argued treaty establishing court is flawed and dangerous; relieves US of obligations under 1969 Vienna Convention requiring states to refrain from undermining treaties they sign, even if they fail to ratify them (M)

headline: U.S.-Led Raids in Afghanistan Press Search for Qaeda Fighters
abstract: Hundreds of American-led forces hunt for Al Qaeda holdouts in Afghanistan, although two senior Afghan commanders whose troops also joined six raids in past three weeks say only two suspects have been detained and none killed so far; one Afghan intelligence official claims Osama bin Laden has been spotted twice in recent weeks just over border in tribal areas of Pakistan, but Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld discounts such reports; senior Afghan commanders say intelligence seems spotty and unreliable; note that raids over past three weeks have yielded only trove of weapons and ammunitions, and no dead Al Qaeda soldiers; White House has repeatedly insisted that war against terrorism will require patience; senior American officers discount any impending large-scale attack, largely because Qaeda and Taliban fighters have dispersed and are being tracked down in smaller numbers; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sharp's Profit To Fall
abstract: Sharp Corp forecasts profits for fiscal year ended Mar 31 fell 71 percent because of investment losses to 11 billion yen ($83 million), down from 38.5 billion yen a year ago (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Appeals Court Upholds EBay Ruling
abstract: California Appeals Court rules EBay is not liable if people sell fell fake merchandise on its site; affirms local court ruling last year in case brought by people who bought baseballs and other items on EBay with forged signatures of baseball players; court accepts company's argument that portion of federal communications law exempts Internet service providers from liability for actions of third parties; rules federal law supersedes several California statues that otherwise might have made company certify authenticity of sports-related collectibles sold on its site (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Policeman Killed In 'Road Rage'
abstract: Focus of French presidential election is likely to remain on law and order following death of police officer in Vannes; gunman apparently furious over driving incident sprayed bullets into police station (S)

headline: Dangerous locations : Security risks often underrated
abstract: On moving to Paris, personal safety was the least of my concerns — I considered myself city savvy having lived in London for five years. Had I known that I would be sexually assaulted on a Paris Metro platform, I might have been a little less cavalier.

headline: Cisco Picks 2 DarkGrey Offices
abstract: Cisco Systems Picks 2 DarkGrey Offices.

headline: Europe's Unease With U.S. Alters Britain's Middleman Role
abstract: Concern over rapidly escalating violence in Middle East has prompted European Union foreign ministers to gather in Luxembourg for rare emergency meeting on situation; there is growing concern in Europe that American efforts have failed to stem crisis; Romano Prodi, head of European Commission, proposes bringing American, Russian, European, United Nations and moderate Arab leaders together to press Israel and Palestinians to settle; violence has redoubled criticism in Europe of America's campaign to extend military campaign to Iraq; Europe's skepticism about US foreign policy will cloud upcoming talks between Prime Min Tony Blair and Pres Bush; there are some in Europe who complain that Blair is not articulating European concerns to Bush (M)

headline: Bush and Putin Sign Pact for Steep Nuclear Arms Cuts
abstract: Pres Bush and Pres Putin sign three-page Treaty of Moscow, committing US and Russia to most dramatic nuclear arms cuts in decades; accord clears way for what Bush and Putin hail as new era of cooperation focused on counterterrorism, trade, Russia's new relationship with NATO and halting spread of nuclear arms; treaty commits both countries to reducing their arsenals, now 6,000 warheads each, to no more than 2,200 at end of 2012, when treaty expires; after that, either nation would be free to rearm starting next year unless agreement is extended or amended; critics of accord say that it will leave Russia with large supply of deactivated warheads that could fall into hands of terrorists if they are not sufficiently guarded and that it frees US to stockpile warheads that can easily be reattached to missiles; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Pub Owner Expands; FRANCE: Manufacturing Rate Rises; IRELAND: New Research Site.

headline: More Reunions Set for Families In the 2 Koreas
abstract: North and South Korea agree to new round of reunions of family members divided by Korean War; exchanges will begin on April 28 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Police Suspended After Deaths
abstract: Argentine Pres Eduardo Duhalde orders two police officers, including senior inspector, detained in shooting deaths of two demonstrators during anti-government march; acts after newspaper photos show inspector pointing shotgun at one of victims and then disposing of body; scores 'atrocious hunting down of demonstrators;' nearly 100 other officers are suspended (S)

headline: COCA-COLA NAMES HEAD OF LATIN AMERICAN DIVISION
abstract: Coca-Cola Co says Steven J Heyer, president of its new-ventures division, will assume oversight of one of company's most embattled economic markets: Latin America (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Kevyn Aiken, advertising research manager at the Organic Living Group, New York, was promoted to director for sales development and advertising research.

headline: A Chip That Mimics Neurons, Firing Up the Memory
abstract: Dr Theodore W Berger, professor of biomedical engineering at University of Southern California, is developing basics for chip-assisted hippocampus, offering potential remedy for Alzheimer's and stroke-related language and memory deficits; advances in neuroscience make it possible to develop implanted circuits that mimic neural activity; Berger has created mathematical models of activities of neurons in hippocampus of lab animals and devised circuits that duplicate those activities; drawing (M)

headline: Finally, A Good Year To Look Offshore
abstract: Interview wit Merrill Lynch investment strategist David Bowers, who says 2002 may be good year to invest in foreign stocks (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: KELLWOOD, St. Louis, a maker of women's clothing, agreed to buy Gerber Childrenswear, Greenville, S.C., for about $135 million in cash and stock to gain lines of infant and toddler clothing and athletic socks.    ENSCO INTERNATIONAL, a driller of offshore oil wells, said it would buy Chiles Offshore, Houston, for $578 million in stock and cash to gain its rival's high-performance drilling rigs.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: Ruling On Blocked Merger Appeal Due; FRANCE: Consulting Units Bought; TURKEY: Oil Pipeline Planned; IRELAND: Beverage Company To Sell Shares.

headline: Robots Find a Muse Other Than Mayhem
abstract: Artist Douglas Repetto organizes robot talent show ArtBots; show features 10 robot-centric projects by artists, engineers and tinkerers; some robots create paintings and all exhibit some sort of creative process; photos (M)

headline: Musharraf Calls Indian Steps a 'Small Beginning'
abstract: As Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld arrived in India today, President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan said he was still waiting for more substantive gestures from New Delhi.

headline: OPEC Ministers Signal That Group Has No Plan to Lift Oil Output
abstract: Two OPEC ministers said on Saturday that oil supplies were adequate, indicating they had no plan to raise production to stem the 33 percent surge in prices so far this year.

headline: Carnival May Sell Unit to Complete Takeover
abstract: Carnival Corp says it might agree to sell British unit of P&O Princess Cruises to win European Union approval for takeover of Princess; says it is not prepared to dispose of its own British-based Cunard line (M)

headline: Vivendi Questioning Shareholder Vote
abstract: Vivendi Universal plans to call new shareholder meeting because it found evidence of fraud in electronic voting at April 24 assembly (S)

headline: Of College and Status
abstract: Naomi Schlessel letter comments on Tom Redburn's April 21

headline: Paradise for Sports Fans
abstract: Confluence of sporting competitions in last few weeks has driven traffic to Web sites; graph of traffic to sports Web sites; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Food Brands Acquired; GERMANY: Loss At Deutsche Telekom; GERMANY: Sales Fiction; FINLAND: Paper Profit Falls; ITALY: Bakery Acquired.

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: Europe SPAIN: Bid To Question Kissinger Fails; BELARUS: Protesters Sentenced.

headline: China Detains Leading Lawyer And Keeps Him Incommunicado
abstract: Police in Beijing detain Zhang Jianzhong, one of China's most prominent private lawyers, and hold him incommunicado for more than month on undisclosed charges; detention sends shivers through legal circles (S)

headline: Ex-Ford Chief Received $23 Million in 2001
abstract: Jacques A Nasser, ousted chief executive of Ford Motor Co, received compensation package worth $23 million as part of his 2001 pay and retirement; company lost $5.5 billion last year, its worst performance since 1992; Nasser received $1.75 million in base pay and no bonus, compared with $1.63 million in base pay and $7.7 million bonus in 2000; photo (M)

headline: DataBank; Tensions in a Week of Dispirited Trading
abstract: After a long string of losses, a few bargain hunters finally emerged on Wall Street at the end of last week. But most investors were too busy worrying about corporate earnings, terrorism threats and rising tensions between India and Pakistan to have much of an appetite to buy stocks.     In a week shortened by the Memorial Day holiday, share prices retreated, reflecting these domestic and global concerns. Investors were also concerned that many sectors of the market, especially technology, were overvalued, and that the economic recovery may be starting to slow, analysts said.

headline: New Questions Are Turning Up In the Inquiry Into Adelphia
abstract: Investigators into accounting problems at Adelphia Communications are turning up far broader number of questionable transactions between company and controlling Rigas family that had been apparent at first; Adelphia had financial involvement in family's purchase of Buffalo Sabres hockey team; other such dealings that have already been disclosed include company's financing of golf course built by family; Adelphia schedules meeting with lenders, including Citibank, Bank of America, J P Morgan Chase and others; company confirms grand juries in Southern District of New York and Middle District of Pennsylvania are investigating accounting problems at company; direct dealings between company and Rigas family was thought to total not more than $100 million, but it appears figure might be higher; dealings are separate from $2.3 billion in loans that Adelphia guaranteed to entities controlled by Rigas family; company's founder John Rigas spent $15 million to keep Buffalo Sabres afloat in 1994 and increased his stake over next few years; it is unclear whether he borrowed money to buy team as part of lending agreement in which Adelphia was liable for family's purchases or whether family had company make acquisition (M)

headline: In New Rebuff to U.S., Sharon Presses Military Sweep
abstract: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon vowed to continue Israel's military sweep through the West Bank after a Palestinian suicide bomber attacked an Israeli bus today.

headline: Tunisian Killed in Synagogue Blast Was Unlikely Convert to Militancy
abstract: Intelligence officials in Germany and France say that Nizar Ben Muhammad Nasr Nawar, 24-year-old Tunisian blamed for attack on ancient synagogue in Tunisia on Apr 11, was surprising convert to Islamic militancy; assault killed 19 people, 12 of them German, and is considered deadliest by operatives linked to Osama bin Laden since Sept 11; Nawar was killed in blast; effort is under way to find any Qaeda cells in Canada and Tunisia that backed Nawar before they cover their tracks and strike again; photo (M)

headline: Article 2002042290702638795 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology Paper Version         function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                            International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business             Technology           -      E-Business            -      Circuits            -      Columns               Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: NEWS Analysis : Candidates skirt facts on crime in France
abstract: PARIS:—  The rise of crime in France, a vast concern that may well decide the outcome of the presidential election next month, is one of the areas of French life where everybody senses the extent of the problem, but politicians shut up about the deepest nature of the causes.

headline: Barry Diller Has Second Job And $3 Billion For Shopping
abstract: Barry Diller, who will oversee Vivendi Universal's United States television and movie studios after Vivendi completes deal to buy control of USA Networks' entertainment assets, is also busy revamping USA assets he did not sell, to be renamed USA Interactive; is holding acquisition talks with seven companies and expects to buy at least four of them for total of up to $4 billion in bid to make USA major Internet and electronic commerce company; Vivendi deal will leave USA with no debt and $3.4 billion in cash to finance acquisitions; graph of USA's e-commerce businesses; photos (M)

headline: Mexico's President Opens Up the Files on Decades of Repression
abstract: Pres Vicente Fox declassifies Mexico's secret police files dating from 1952 through 1985, and first chance to examine documents is being given to government investigators and families of hundreds of people who disappeared while in custody during 1970's and 80's; opening of files follows shortly after Fox's signing of freedom of information law that will give Mexican people far greater right to know what their government is doing (M)

headline: Why Can't Johnny Retire?
abstract: Survey by Jump$tart Coalition for Personal Financial Literacy finds most high school seniors failed recent test of financial literacy, performance worse than predecessors (S)

headline: Kuwaitis Press U.S. Over 12 Held at Guantánamo
abstract: Families of all 12 Kuwaitis known to be detainees at Guantanamo naval base file federal lawsuit seeking right to meet with prisoners and know charges against them; detainees, who mostly insist they were in Afghanistan or Pakistan doing charity work, are now sending sporadic messages home; photo; Kuwaiti government is paying costs of suit (M)

headline: ATLAS AIR REACHES TENTATIVE AGREEMENT WITH PILOTS
abstract: Freight unit of Atlas Air Worldwide Holdings Inc reaches tentative contract agreement with its pilots and flight engineers, avoiding strike (S)

headline: A Smart Appliance, or Smart-Alecky?
abstract: DIARY A Smart Appliance, Or Smart-Alecky?.

headline: Sears to Buy Lands' End In a Deal That Unites Pants and Power Drills
abstract: Sears Roebuck & Co will pay $1.9 billion in cash to buy mail-order retailer Lands' End; agreement gives Sears exclusive rights to Lands' End products for its 870 stores nationwide; Sears also plans to tap into Lands' End customer file, estimated at 30 million households, to sell other products; Lands' End president-chief executive David F Dyer will manager Sears online shopping and catalog business; Lands' End is expected to expand sales by having its clothing and other products on Sears shelves and by having them featured on Sears Web site; Sears executives say they plan to operate Lands' End with no layoffs or cutbacks, but they hope that Lands' End customers will spill over into their sections of Sears stores; Sears chairman-chief executive Alan J Lacy says he expects that 15 percent to 20 percent of all apparel for sale in Sears will be from Lands' End by next year; graph; photo (M)

headline: 1,000 British Marines Join Australians in Firefight With Suspected Taliban
abstract: Nearly 1,000 British marines are airlifted to rugged corner of eastern Afghanistan north of Khost where Australian Special Forces came under fire from suspected Taliban fighters on May 16; several attackers are killed in battles, and no coalition soldiers are wounded; Afghan officials also report that unrelated American bombing near Khost killed nine people who appear to have no ties to Taliban or Al Qaeda; US and other donor countries meeting in Geneva agree to give enough funds to begin formation of new Afghan police force and army; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Summit Bombing Foiled, Police Say
abstract: Police in Spain say they foiled plan by Basque separatist group ETA to bomb summit meeting of leaders from European Union and Latin America this weekend; say they arrested two members of ETA in Madrid and found 90 pounds of explosives ready for use in car bomb and 400 pounds in apartment (S)

headline: Chile Will Privatize a New Span of Its Noted Social Safety Net
abstract: Chile's nominally Socialist government will allow private sector to manage nation's unemployment insurance system, which will rely on market forces (M)

headline: ROCKWELL COLLINS WILL ACQUIRE A UNIT FROM ACTERNA
abstract: Rockwell Collins Inc, maker of aircraft cockpit instruments, agrees to buy Acterna Corp subsidiary Airshow Inc for $160 million to gain electronic-control products for business jet passenger cabins (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Koizumi Ally Quits Parliament
abstract: Koichi Kato, close ally of Japan's Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi and leading figure in governing Liberal Democratic Party until recently, resigns from Parliament amid accusations that he received nearly $1 million in personal bank account from fund of political donations under control of former aide; photo (S)

headline: Executive Life: The Boss; Not Everything's a Story
abstract: The Boss column by Bill Shapiro on his work as managing editor of Time Inc Custom Publishing; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Forecasts A Loss
abstract: Japan's Sumitomo Trust expects to post loss of 42 billion yen ($316 million) for fiscal year ended March 31 because of losses on its stock portfolio (S)

headline: Talks Collapse on $750 Million Takeover of Global Crossing
abstract: Two Asian companies said on Saturday that they had failed to reach an agreement in talks on acquiring the troubled fiber optic network operator Global Crossing.

headline: Whispers Inside. Thunder Outside.
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission and other government entities revive fervor, dormant for nearly a generation, for investigating instances of possible insider stock trading; comb intently through huge numbers of stock sales by executives and others privy to confidential information; promise tougher penalties in effort to restore confidence among investors; photo; table of milestones since 1909 in laws governing insider trading; list of corporations in which insiders sold greatest amounts of stock (M)

headline: Critic of China Is Denied Entry To Hong Kong
abstract: Immigration authorities in Hong Kong refuse entry to Harry Wu, most prominent critic of prison labor in China; sends him back to US after detaining him overnight; cite reasons of 'safety;' Wu, who served 19 years in Chinese prison for 'rightist views,' is American citizen; Americans are normally allowed to enter Hong Kong without visas; photo (M)

headline: TRUMP CASINOS UNIT GETS AN INCREASE IN DEBT RATING
abstract: Debt rating of Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts Inc is raised for second time in five months by Standard & Poor's Corp after company makes $73 million interest payment to bondholders (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Well-Guarded Nests
abstract: Royal Society for Protection of Birds will employ Ghurkhas, British Army's fierce Nepalese regiment, to train its members in surveillance and camouflage techniques to photograph those who are trying to steal eggs of birds like endangered marsh harrier; thefts are puzzling because there is no significant market for eggs (S)

headline: Korea May Stop Phone Carrier Equity Deal
abstract: South Korean government threatens to scuttle SK Telecom's acquisition of largest single block of shares in KT Corp, Korea's dominant telephone company, in order to prevent KT from becoming arm of SK Group, one of Korea's largest conglomerates (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Big Gain At Unilever; BRITAIN: Economic Growth; SWITZERLAND: Earnings Investigation; FRANCE: Executive Change At Renault; GERMANY: No Recovery At Bayer.

headline: Two Latin Americas, Two Diverging Outlooks
abstract: Weak growth in Latin America is perpetuating continent's skewed income distribution, with wealthiest 10 percent of residents controlling 40 percent of region's income and poorest 30 percent accounting for under 10 percent of it; some 40 percent of Latin Americans still live in poverty; region is fragmenting economically, with nations like Brazil, Chile and Mexico pressing ahead with reforms and integration into global economy and nations like Venezuela and Argentina beset by political problems that obstruct growth; widening economic gaps and differing interests between two groups are frustrating attempts at regional trade pacts; few Latin American companies stress regional expansion; graphs of economic data; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: NTT Posts Record Loss
abstract: Nippon Telegraph and Telephone posts record loss for year of 812.1 billion yen ($6.4 billion) even though sales rose 2.3 percent; graph (S)

headline: Weaker Dollar Adds to Potential of Foreign Stocks
abstract: Investing abroad to take advantage of dollar's recent weakness discussed; currency plays big role in overseas returns, often overwhelming performance of stocks themselves; graph (M)

headline: Castro Calls March Against Bush's Criticism
abstract: Pres Fidel Castro calls for massive marches by Cubans to protest Bush administration's hard-line policies (S)

headline: Deep Fears Behind Australia's Immigration Policy
abstract: Australians' will to preserve their way of life drives popularity of rigid refugee policy introduced last year; photos; map (M)

headline: Israel's West Bank Siege Continues, Despite Minor Pullback
abstract: Israeli forces withdrew from several Palestinian villages today, but Prime Minister Ariel Sharon gave no signs that he planned to lift the siege on cities and towns.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: 1-800-FLOWERS.COM, Westbury, N.Y., said it would acquire the Popcorn Factory, Lake Forest, Ill., from Wand Partners, New York, for $4.9 million in stock and $7.3 million in assumed debt.    SPX CORP., Charlotte, N.C., a maker of technical and industrial systems, said it had acquired Daniel Valve Co., Houston, from Emerson Electric, St. Louis, an engineering firm. Daniel Valve has annual revenue of about $40 million. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Some See a Young Ovitz in Emerging Power Broker
abstract: Some people in Hollywood liken management style of Jeffrey Evan Kwatinetz, co-founder of upstart entertainment management company Firm, to young Michael S Ovitz, founder of Artists Management Group that has been acquired Firm; photo (M)

headline: India Jet Hits Building and Kills 7
abstract: A Indian MIG-21 fighter jet caught fire today and crashed into a three story bank building in the northwestern city of Jalandhar. Seven people were killed and 14 wounded.

headline: Musharraf Treading Gently Against Pakistani Militants
abstract: Doubts arise in Pakistan over commitment of Pres Pervez Musharraf to follow through on pledge made three months ago to crack down on violent Muslim groups and on religious schools that breed them; of nearly 2,000 people arrested in sweep of Islamic radicals, as many as 70 percent have been set free; after five militant groups were banned, members reorganized under new names; reform of religious academies has met with strong resistance, and schools continue to operate much as they always have; while Musharraf has not backed away from major policy reversal of choosing to support US in war against terrorism, direction of his policies are not so clear on most sensitive and entrenched domestic issues; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Executive Pay: $77 Million For E*Trade Chief
abstract: E*Trade Group paid its chief executive Christos M Cotsakos $77 million in 2001; photo (S)

headline: Syrians Holding Important Sept. 11 Suspect
abstract: A Syrian-born German citizen who is considered an important figure in the Sept. 11 attacks is being held in a Syrian jail, senior German officials said today.

headline: Anger in the Streets Is Exerting Pressure On Arab Moderates
abstract: Demonstrators in Jordan demand government sever ties with Israel, while protesters in Cairo block streets for fifth day; photo; anger has not gone beyond control of any of autocratic governments in region but officials fear further Israeli action against Yasir Arafat will put moderate Arab governments on collision course with their explosive, aggrieved populations; senior officials are especially edgy about Israel's encirclement in Ramallah (M)

headline: Deal to End Church Siege Is Snagged on Angry Details
abstract: Agreement to end siege of Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem by Israeli forces and release 100 people inside is snagged on angry details; negotiators are deadlocked over how many of Palestinian gunmen inside church will be sent abroad, most likely to Italy, or whether exile will be permanent or temporary; photo (M)

headline: Article 2002042592822954815 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //              JOB POSITIONS

headline: BRITISH POWER COMPANY POSTS LOSS FOR FISCAL YEAR
abstract: Britain's National Grid reports loss of $712 million for fiscal year ended March 31 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Angola: Amnesty For Rebels
abstract: Angolan parliament grants amnesty to Unita rebels as prelude to cease-fire (S)

headline: As Israeli Forces Head to Gaza, End of Church Siege Seems Near
abstract: Israeli tanks moved towards the Gaza Strip today, as the effort to lift the Bethlehem siege appeared to be back on track.

headline: PLANNED MEETING ON MIDEAST PEACE MAY BE DELAYED
abstract: Bush administration delays conference on Middle East peace first planned for early summer, and officials say they have not decided whether to offer any sort of specific American plan at all when talks are held, probably in late summer; CIA's director George J Tenet will leave on May 31 for brief trip to region to assess how to rebuild Palestinian security force free of extremist elements; Asst Sec of State William J Burns is already in region exploring ways to create more democratic Palestinian Authority; administration is under intense pressure from European allies and moderate Arab states to offer its own plan and timetable for final peace settlement; fear is that violence will again intensify as suicide attacks in Israel have resumed; Tenet and Burns are expected to return to Washington in time for visit next week by Pres Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, who at Bush's invitation is making unusual return trip three weeks after his last visit (M)

headline: Jospin's Advice to France: Please Pick, Ahem, Chirac
abstract: Prime Min Lionel Jospin, Socialist edged out of French presidenital race, asks voters to cast their ballots against far-right candidate Jean-Marie Le Pen when he faces Pres Jacques Chirac in runoff on May 5; Jospin's four-line statement does not mention Chirac, his longtime conservative rival, by name; many of Jospin's Socialist allies have already said they will vote for Chirac, if only to keep France from political chaos; photo (M)

headline: LABOR PROVISION VIOLATION WILL COST UNITED $8.9 MILLION
abstract: Arbitrator has ruled that United Airlines must pay flight attendants $8.9 million for violating terms of labor contract by employing attendants from Air Wisconsin after acquiring that airline; United bought Air Wisconsin in 1992 and operated it as separate carrier, using Air Wisconsin's attendants rather than United's; Air Wisconsin is now privately held (S)

headline: Tensions Mount Over Kashmir as Separatist Leader Is Killed
abstract: Abdul Ghani Lone, a moderate Kashmiri separatist leader, was assassinated today, a killing that India and Pakistan immediately charged each other with.

headline: Moderates In Arab Lands Accentuate The Positive
abstract: Moderate Arab governments, which got no advance warning of Pres Bush's call for removal of Yasir Arafat, brush aside demand, focusing instead on fact that once aloof Bush administration is now deeply involved in Middle East diplomacy; but commentators in several Arab states pour scorn on what they see as yet another vague American promise for solution, one they feel is largely shaped by Israeli demands; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: More North Koreans Seek Asylum
abstract: Two more North Koreans sneak into South Korean Consulate in Beijing, seeking political asylum (S)

headline: Staples Selects Competition Lineup
abstract: Staples Selects Competition Lineup.

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: CHINA: Mickey Plays Beijing?; INDIA: Disappointing Software Profit; South KOREA: Samsung's Profit Soars; JAPAN: Daiei Expects Another Loss.

headline: E-Commerce Report; Consumers Union plans to put its ratings system of Web sites and merchants on the Web.
abstract: Consumers Union, consumer advocacy group, plans to introduce new division, ConsumerWebwatch.org, which will create guidelines for good business practices by Web sites and rate sites based on their adherence to those standards; initial guidelines will encourage Web site to disclose information about five areas: corporate identity, advertising and sponsorships, customer service, corrections and privacy; effort is based on group's research showing that consumers have little trust in Web sites (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Why Is This Room So Popular? Shh. You're About to Find Out.
abstract: J William McCarthy comments on Web puzzle, What's Wrong With This Picture, he created to scare friend; it attracts 90,000 hits a day; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Ad Campaign For Bond Sales
abstract: Japan's Ministry of Finance hires a popular actress, Norika Fujiwara, to appear in commercials promoting bond sales to individual investors; photo (S)

headline: W.H.O. Delays End Of Smallpox Virus
abstract: World Health Orgn agrees to delay planned destruction of world's remaining stocks of deadly smallpox virus to allow more time to develop new vaccines and treatments; anthrax attacks in United States have renewed fears that militants or so-called rogue states could use germs as weapon (S)

headline: People
abstract: *Mark Dowley is named chairman and chief executive of Interpublic Sports and Entertainment Group (S)

headline: NOVARTIS RECEIVES APPROVAL FOR NEW FORM OF RITALIN
abstract: Novartis receives FDA approval for once-daily form of Ritalin, its drug for attention deficit disorder (S)

headline: With a Tray of Drinks, Jeeves Rolls Out to the Terrace
abstract: Evolution Robotics unveils 'personal robot system'; it is essentially laptop computer that sits on aluminum chassis equipped with rubber wheels and digital camera; creators say it will be able to roll around its environment responding to owners' simple desires; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Daiei Expects Another Loss
abstract: Daiei Inc, Japanese retailer, reports loss of 333 billion yen ($2.6 billion) in year ended Feb 28; sales fall 14 percent (S)

headline: Economy Creates 58,000 Jobs, but Jobless Rate Rises to 5.7%
abstract: New data suggests that despite businesses adding jobs for the first time since July, the labor market is lagging the growth seen elsewhere in the economy.

headline: Adelphia and Rigas Family Are Said to Be Near a Deal
abstract: Adelphia Communications is close to deal under which Rigas family would give up all its board seats and supervoting rights and forgive $575 million in debt; deal would also include either transfer of $1.2 billion in cable assets to Adelphia or cash flow from those properties, which is more than $90 million a year (M)

headline: Vodafone Posts Huge Loss for Year
abstract: Vodafone Group announces net loss of almost $24 billion in year ended March, largely result of write-downs in value of same deals and takeovers that once fueled its growth; says its write-downs for year included 6 billion pounds ($8.7 billion) in charges that were mostly related to investments in fixed-line telephone businesses in Germany, France and Japan; it also increased other write-down charges from about 11 billion pounds, to 13.4 billion pounds ($19.4 billion); chief executive Sir Christopher Gent comments; photo of Darryl Green, president of J-Phone, mobile arm of Japan Telecom, which is two-thirds owned by Vodafone; graph; photo (M)

headline: BLOCK SAYS EARNINGS WILL BE AT HIGH END OF FORECAST
abstract: H & R Block says it prepared record number of tax filings this year and that its income in fiscal year ended April 30 will be at top of range it had forecast earlier; reports $2 billion in fees for tax preparation and related services from Jan 1 to April 15 and says it served 18.1 million clients (S)

headline: Private Sector; The Philanthropy Connections Of Two 1980's Deal Makers
abstract: William E Simon Foundation

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Stake For Sale
abstract: Goldman Sachs plans to sell half of its 6.82 percent stake in South Korea's Kookmin Bank through offering of 11 million American depository receipts (S)

headline: $100 MILLION FINE FOR MERRILL LYNCH
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co agrees to pay $100 million in penalties to end New York State's investigation into whether its securities analysts promoted stocks of companies whose investment banking business Merrill wanted; admits no wrongdoing, but will stop allowing investment bankers to help determine how much analysts earn and will prohibit analysts from promising positive stock ratings to prospective clients or from lowering their ratings to punish companies for not hiring Merrill; settlement averts possibility that Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer would file criminal charges against Merrill or any of its analysts or managers; Merrill still faces civil lawsuits and complaints in arbitration by individual investors and possible federal prosecution; some former Wall Street analysts and plaintiff lawyers say deal will bring little real change because it will not end fundamental conflict of having analysts try to serve two masters--investors who follow their recommendations and corporations that pay investment banking fees to their firms (M)

headline: Nabors Shareholder Files Suit On Plan to Move to Bermuda
abstract: Lawsuit filed in Federal District Court says Nabors Industries, another big company planning to move to Bermuda in address only so it can sharply reduce its US taxes, misled shareholders about costs of plan while withholding critical information about dangers; contends up to half of shareholders' gains in Nabors stock could be wiped out with no future benefit if Bermuda transaction is completed and then later disallowed by Internal Revenue Service or Congress; also accuses Nabors directors of arranging their own pay on terms that benefit them at expense of shareholders they represent; suit is filed on hehalf of Steve Rosenberg and all other shareholders by law firm Kirby McInerney & Squire; suit comes as AFL-CIO and some shareholder rights groups are organizing opposition to Nabors plan; say that shareholders will have reduced rights and that Nabors managers, already highly paid, will be able to increase their pay after Bermuda move (M)

headline: POWELL ENDS TRIP; SEES NO CEASE-FIRE BEFORE A PULLOUT
abstract: Secretary of State Colin Powell leaves Israel without cease-fire he came for; says no truce could take hold until Israel withdraws from Palestinian-controlled cities and towns its forces have seized; antagonists seem angrier and more fearful of each other, and with less ground for hope that even high-level American intervention could force halt to violence by either side; Powell ends his six-day trip with harsh words for Israel and for Palestinians and their leader Yasir Arafat; some Israeli officials express satisfaction with his trip, saying he helped calm fighting along Israel's northern border; Palestinian officials bitterly assess his mission as failure, blaming Prime Min Ariel Sharon; Arab nations express frustration that US has not put more pressure on Sharon; Pres Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, one of few Arab nations that have been allied with US, cancels meeting with Powell during stopover in Cairo, sending his foreign minister instead; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Shunning NATO Summit
abstract: Min Igor S Ivanov says Russia will not attend NATO's Nov summit meeting in Prague, when number of nations will likely be invited to join alliance; comments underscore lingering animosity some Russians feel about NATO's expansion; photo (S)

headline: Perot Will Deliver Energy Papers
abstract: Perot Systems, information technology company, says it will deliver five boxes of documents to California's attorney general and California State Sen Joseph Dunn as part of investigation into whether company improperly coached energy traders on how to manipulate power prices; company's founder-chairman H Ross Perot will testify before legislative committee on July 11 (M)

headline: 1776, Relived Digitally: A Historic Square Sizzles
abstract: Lights of Liberty is sound and light show blending modern technology with 200-year-old history to enhance visitors' experience of Philadelphia's Independence Historical National Park; exhibit first opened in 1999; Revolutionary-era scenes are projected on buildings and headsets provide accompanying narration; headsets, designed by Aeptec Microsystems, are equivalent of microprocessors that work with modified MP3 technology; photos (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   7.00       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   3.50       Federal funds   1.75   1.72   4.04       3-month T-bills   1.70   1.70   3.44       6-month T-bills   1.80   1.82   3.45       10-yr. T-infl.   3.08   3.10   3.24       10-yr. T-note   4.96   4.98   5.26       30-yr. T-bond   5.54   5.55   5.66       Telephone bd.   7.62   7.73   7.80       Municipal bds.   5.32   5.32   5.35          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: No Breakthrough In Iraq Talks
abstract: United Nations and Iraq end three days of talks on disarmament with ageement to meet again, but no breakthrough on return of weapons inspectors to Baghdad (S)

headline: Want a Really Fine Wine? It Will Be Just a Few Years
abstract: DIARY Want a Really Fine Wine? It Will Be Just a Few Years.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: GERMANY: Number Of Unemployed Falls; SWEDEN: Shareholder Challenge.

headline: ABC is returning to its roots to reverse a ratings decline.
abstract: ABC network announces new prime-time lineup of shows for fall; will return to its roots as family-oriented network that will include seven new series in September, with two more to follow in January after Monday Night Football ends its season; confirms it will cancel Politically Incorrect with Bill Maher and replace it with new comedy talk show starring Jimmy Kimmel; WB network announces is fall lineup, adding six new shows; chart on ABC's fall prime-time lineup; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Muslims In Afghanistan
abstract: Chinese official reports that 300 Uighur Muslims from China's western province of Xinjiang were captured in Afghanistan fighting with Taliban forces and that hundreds more Chinese Muslim separatists remain hidden in Afghanistan and Pakistan (S)

headline: Justices Bolster Patent Holders' Rights
abstract: US Supreme Court, 9-0, gives inventors more power to sue competitors for making modified versions of patented protects; ruling partly overturns ruling by US Appeals Court; Justice Anthony M Kennedy says Federal Circuit improperly limited legal doctrine that lets patent holders sue others who make 'equivalent' products; adds appeals court decision would 'risk destroying the legitimate expectations of inventors in their property'; ruling may affect as many as 90 percent of 1.2 million patents now in force; case before court involved fight between Festo Corp, American subsidiary of German company Festo AG and SMC Corp, American branch of SMC of Japan, makers of air cylinders for industrial machinery; Federal Circuit put new restrictions on those who amend descriptions of their inventions to ensure approval of patent application; most patent seekers file amendments at some point (M)

headline: Article 2002042192714718116 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology Text Version         function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                            International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business             Technology           -      E-Business            -      Circuits            -      Columns               Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: Électricité de France Buying Seeboard, a British Utility
abstract: American Electric Power Co will sell its Seeboard regional power utility in Britain to state-owned French power monopoly Electricite de France for $975 million in cash and assumption of $1.05 billion in Seeboard debt; move raises possibility of European regulatory difficulties because French market remains closed to similar deals; Electricite de France already owns London Electricity and Western Electricity; American Electric Power, like other US power companies, is selling overseas assets to cuts its debt as credit rating companies scrutinize energy companies more closely after bankruptcy of Enron; photo (M)

headline: For China's Wealthy, All but Fruited Plain
abstract: Super-rich are emerging in China, along with thousands of multimillionaires, despite government's concern that emergence of wealthy class threatens social stability and Communist monopoly on political power; bold displays of wealth are still rare, while bureaucratic barriers and government prejudices make accumulation of vast wealth difficulty, even risky; some immensely wealth capitalists are gaining prominence abroad, including Li Qinfu, whose company's headquarters, Pinghu, resemble United States Capitol; photos; graphs of income distribution (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Steel Sale
abstract: Czech government accepts 25 billion koruny ($765 million) offer from Indian-born steel entrepreneur Lakshmi Mittal to buy and restructure Nova Hut steel mill in Ostrava; Mittal's LNM Holdings and its sister company Ispat International form world's eighth-largest steel group (S)

headline: Early Warning: There May Be None for Next Rate Increase
abstract: Federal Reserve policy makers do not like surprises, but they may be cooking up one for for analysts and investors who do not read Fed tea leaves closely.

headline: Adelphia Gives Reassurances About Services
abstract: Adelphia Communications releases letter that it sent last week to 3,500 agencies that grant cable franchises in which it assured them that it is working to provide good customer service, diverse programming and new services; letter is released in response to statement from Los Angeles City Attorney Rocky Delgadillo, who said company could have its license revoked if it does not improve service or pay fees on time; Adelphia has about 250,000 cable subscribers over five franchise areas in Los Angeles area (M)

headline: Critics Christen Ship Project As an Off-Course U.S.S. Pork
abstract: Two years after federal government announced ambitious plan to build two mammoth passenger cruise ships, first in US shipyard since 1950's, project has failed at cost of $187 million to taxpayers; unfinished and unfloatable hulls lay in Pascagoula, Miss, shipyard where government is seeking buyer to recoup costs; failed project, backed by more than $1 billion in loan guarantees, is derided as example of political pork gone wrong; shipyard is in home state of Senate minority leader Trent Lott and was father's employer; failure confirms worst fears of critics, who say project is corporate welfare debacle that illustrates dangers lurking behind tens of billions of loan guarantees government has extended to array of businesses; ships being built by American Classic Voyages were seen as way to jump-start dormant commercial shipbuilding industry; became government property after company filed for bankrutpcy protection in October 2001; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Cable Merger Planned
abstract: Spain's Telefonica plans to merge its money-losing digital television platform Via Digital with its only rival Canal Satellite Digital, which is owned by Sogecable; deal, which is expected to face scrutiny of regulators with European Union and at home in Spain, would create monopoly with 2.5 million clients and revenue of 1.3 billion euros per year (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: *CareerBuilder, Chicago, a job search Web site, hires Cramer-Krasselt, Chicago, to handle its ad account (S)
