headline: Afghans Free Many Seized in Reported Plot and Deny Political Aim
abstract: Afghan officials release nearly half of 300 people arrested in reported plot to topple government, while denying suggestions that detentions were part of campaign to stifle political opponents; Interior Min Yunis Qanuni says police discovered documents outlining plans to attack interim president, Hamid Karzai, and Mohammad Zahir Shah, former king who is expected to return from exile soon; release comes day after officials complete huge sweep through Kabul aimed at breaking up alleged conspiracy; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Set To Introduce New Technology
abstract: Microsoft to introduce new technology called TrustBridge as part of its revised Web services strategy; says technology will become increasingly useful as users connect from one consumer service to another on Internet and as business increasingly automates buying and selling operations (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Synagogue Attacked
abstract: Vandals attack synagogue in Rostov-on-Don, Russia (S)

headline: Surfing to Slimness
abstract: Media Metrix reports Web surfers are seeking online weight-loss guidance as beach season nears; top sites noted; table; photo (S)

headline: Chávez Allows Jailed Officers To Go Home
abstract: Pres Hugo Chavez of Venezuela releases several miltary officers from fort where they were in custody for questioning about their role in uprising and failed coup attempt; among those released is Rear Adm Carlos Molina, one of first high-ranking officers to denounce Chavez and leader of dissident group of officers who met to discuss role they would play in efforts to force Chavez out of power; Mario Ivan Carratu, military analyst, says government seeks to handle situation in tranquil way to avoid negative reaction or criticism from human rights groups; however, mood in country remains edgy (M)

headline: A Long War Slices Deep In Indonesia
abstract: Rebels are now on defensive in Aceh, northernmost province of Indonesia, which is rich in natural gas; have been pushed back from urban centers thick with soldiers and police patrols with orders from central government to wrap up war once and for all; civilian killings have reportedly increased in recent months, and rights groups report deaths, torture, disappearances and arbitrary arrests almost daily; maps; photos (M)

headline: A.I.G. ASKS FOR INQUIRY INTO POSSIBLE SHORT SELLING
abstract: American International Group asks New York Stock Exchange and Securities and Exchange Commission to investigate 'considerable short selling' of its shares after stock closes at $69.71, down $1.08 (S)

headline: Unions Say United Air Is Too Rosy On Contracts
abstract: Union officials at United Airlines say they are nowhere near reaching agreements with management on concessions, even though company's chief executive John W Creighton Jr has called such concessions important for securing federal loan guarantee; International Association of Machinists says labor cost cuts do not appear necessary for United's financial well-being (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Arrests In Beef Case
abstract: Five former Snow Brand Foods Co executives are arrested for allegedly defrauding Japanese government of 196 million yen ($1.5 million) by relabeling imported beef as domestic to win subsidies related to mad cow disease (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Apple Buys Firewire Developer
abstract: Apple Computer Inc has acquired Zayante, networking company, for undisclosed price (S)

headline: No Cease-Fire Until Withdrawal, Arafat Tells Powell
abstract: Yasir Arafat told Secretary of State Colin L. Powell today that no cease-fire was possible until Israel ended its military operation in the West Bank.

headline: On Kashmir Line, Pakistanis Wait, With Few Illusions
abstract: Soldiers on Pakistani side of Ksahmir's disputed frontier wait for assault by Indian Army that they expect could come at any moment; they harbor few illusions about their chances against their more powerful enemy; they are plotting defense and their military leaders are defiant; this reflects belief among Pakistanis that it would be Indians who start war, but that once one started, Pakistanis, however outgunned and outnumbered, would not suffer humiliations visited on them in wars past; world leaders fear that India's overwhelming superiority in conventional forces could prompt desperate Pakistani leadership to use their nuclear weapons to halt attack; photo (M)

headline: Talent Agents And Managers Look for Profit As Turf Shifts
abstract: Sale of Michael Ovitz's ailing Artists Management Group to lesser-known company called the Firm comes at time of turmoil and uncertainty among managers and agents that has not been seen in Hollywood since 1939; vote by Screen Actors Guild last month let lapse agreement dating to 1939 governing relations between agents and actors; agent's job is to find jobs and negotiate deals for clients for fee of 10 to 15 percent; agents used to exist side by side with amnagers, who cater more broadly to performers' needs; managers get fees of 15 percent or more, and, more important, are allowed to produce films and television shows for their clients; agents have been barred from doing that; agents have increasingly felt constricted by their agreement with performers as managers have become more aggressive in recent years; actors rejected proposal that would have let agents buy or sell as much as 20 percent of their businesses to production and distribution companies, including advertising agencies; Jeff Kwatinetz, founder of Firm, has been among most aggressive of managers and is now turning into formidable player with his deal to acquire most of important assets of Ovitz's company; Ovitz's partners, Rick Yorn and his sister-in-law Julie Silverman-Yorn, will join Firm and take some of their clients (M)

headline: 26 Palestinians Arrive From Bethlehem, Ready to Fight Israel Again
abstract: Twenty-six of Palestinians freed from Bethlehem's Church of Nativity arrive in Gaza Strip as part of accord between Israel and Palestinian Authority; vow to fight Israel anew as Gaza residents brace for Israeli attack; photos (M)

headline: HALLIBURTON AND HONEYWELL WIN ASBESTOS CLAIMS DELAY
abstract: Federal Judge Judith Fitzgerald extends for 30 days stay she ordered on over 250,000 asbestos-related claims against former Halliburton Co and Honeywell Inc units to give companies more time to settle claims; claims involve Harbison-Walker Refractories Co, formerly owned by Halliburton unit, and North American Refractories Co, former Honeywell unit; units, now owned by RHI AG, filed for bankruptcy in Jan (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Insurer's Revenue Rises
abstract: AXA says first-quarter revenue rose 2.5 percent, to 21.12 billion euros ($19.3 billion) from 20.6 billion euros year earlier; revenue rose 2.1 percent; chief executive Henri de Castries comments; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Shifts In Extremism
abstract: German government says membership in right- and left-wing extremist groups declined in 2001, but that there is increase in Islamic extremism; Interior Min Otto Schily calls global threat of terrorism his biggest concern (S)

headline: MOODY'S CUTS BOND RATING OF NORTEL TO JUNK LEVEL
abstract: Moody's Investors Service cuts debt rating of Nortel Networks to lowest investment grade, or junk; reduction affects $5 billion of Nortel debt (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of June 2 article on air conditioning in Singapore; former Prime Min Lee Kuan Yew studied law at Cambridge

headline: Economic Scene; How can the marketplace gauge fashions? Consider what to name the baby.
abstract: Virginia Postrel Economic Scene column on Prof Stanley Lieberson's book A Matter of Taste that analyzes how tastes in names shift and shed light on how fashion works; says contrary to common assumptions about how fashion works, names do not simply trickle down from high-income, well-educated parents to lower-income, less educated parents; holds newly popular names tend to catch on with everyone at about same time, and they spread both up and down; says whether names or clothes, fashion reflects primacy of individual taste over inherited custom; drawing (M)

headline: The Work Is Temporary, the Memories Lasting
abstract: On the Job column on temporary workers, who can be boon or burden for bosses; for temps themselves jobs can be either bother, blessing or 'movable feast;' drawings (M)

headline: Just How Far Can Trading Of Emissions Be Extended?
abstract: Bush administration wants to replace existing air quality controls and apply 'emissions trading' to other pollutants; environmentalists and economists warn that administration's 'Clear Skies' initiative, while generally promising improvements, threatens to intensify pollution in certain 'hot spots,' and could create poor incentives for businesses; in 1990's, sulfur dioxide levels fell broadly but they barely changed from Columbus, Ohio, to northern West Virginia; companies paid to pass on their obligations to reduce pollution in some of worst spots; David D Doniger, former EPA official who now sets policy at Natural Resources Defense Council, warns that abandoning existing safeguards would not only encourage concentrations of other pollutants it could even allow some plants to increase harmful emissions; Pres Bush hopes to cut pollution even more by letting electric utilities cut deals; diagram (M)

headline: Time Off, or Not
abstract: Kirstin Svenson letter on 'working maternity leaves' described in June 2 Executive Life article

headline: Interludes on Their Minds
abstract: DiØ

headline: 2 Swiss Banks Are Sued For South Africa Dealings
abstract: Switzerland's two largest banks, Credit Suisse Group and UBS, as well as Citigroup, are sued on behalf of four South African victims of apartheid; suit contend that banks' financial dealings prolonged white-only rule (M)

headline: Barry Diller Has Second Job and $3 Billion for Shopping
abstract: Barry Diller, USA Networks's chief executive, is negotiatiing with seven companies. He plans to buy at least four of them within the next six months.

headline: An Abrupt Departure Is Seen as a Harbinger; Leadership Shake-Up Could Spread As WorldCom and Its Rivals Regroup
abstract: WorldCom president Bernard J Ebbers resigns; company names vice chairman John W Sidgmore as president and chief executive; move reflects WorldCom's particular problems and broader turmoil in telecommunications sector, where earnings have been decimated by overinvestment in networks and business has yet to rebound from recession; Qwest Communications International chief executive Joseph P Nacchio is expected to leave soon; chronology of telecommunications deals made by Ebbers, 1983-2000; photo (M)

headline: Banks Sold Dynegy Stock to Recoup Loans
abstract: Dynegy Inc's former chairman-chief executive Charles Watson says bankers sold about one-third of his company stake to recoup millions of dollars in loans; partnerships controlled by Watson and his wife pledged undisclosed part of his 13.8 million shares as collateral for commercial bank loans; lenders foreclosed on and sold 4.4 million shares in May after security lost 70 percent of its value in month; Watson stepped down as chief executive on May 28 (M)

headline: Trial in Murder of Reporter Begins With Legal Maneuvers
abstract: Trial of four men charged in kidnapping and murder of Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl opens under tight security in Karachi, Pakistan, prison; adjourns after hour of legal maneuvering; lawyer for Ahmed Omar Sheikh, chief defendant, demands more documents; Salman Saqib charges he was beaten; other defendants are Fahad Naseem and Sheikh Muhammad Adeel; judge reportedly orders arrest of seven other defendants, who have eluded police for weeks (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Car Sales Fell in May Even as Rebates Continued  A 12 percent decline in car sales by Ford and General Motors helped drag May sales to their lowest monthly pace in nearly four years. Auto sales industrywide fell 6 percent in May. The one-month slump came even as automakers continued to offer rebates and to subsidize financing to keep interest rates low.    Analysts said the drop did not indicate that carmakers were in trouble. Even so, incentives were expected to increase. [Page C2.]

headline: Moscow Journal; The Smoothest Soviet Crooner, Still in Good Voice
abstract: Iosif Kobzon, for decades favored crooner of Russian TV and variety shows, has also been friend of the powerful around the world and a power player in his own right; in new Russia, he has perserved his political foothold as twice-elected deputy of Duma, or Parliament, winning 92 percent of vote; but he has been barred from visiting United States since 1995 because US government claims he has mob connections, charge he denies; he claims file on him is based on false charges that arose out of power struggle between officials in Kremlin and his friend, Mayor Yuri M Luzhkov of Moscow; Kobzon has sheaf of letters attesting to his good name; to date, not even hiring American lawyers has been of any avail; photo (M)

headline: Lawyer Says Andersen Ignored Problems at Troubled Charity
abstract: The trial of Arthur Andersen's second-largest financial problem — its audits of a Baptist foundation — began today in Arizona.

headline: Tyco Turmoil Deepens as It Fires Lawyer
abstract: Turmoil at Tyco International worsens as company fires general counsel Mark A Belnick, setting off public fight over reasons for his dismissal; Tyco alleges Belnick is impeding company's internal investigation into whether it paid personal expenses of its senior executives and made undisclosed loans to them; Belnick lawyer Stanley S Arkin says Belnick was fired after losing power struggle with vice president Joshua S Berman and David Boies, lawyer who was hired in April to represent Tyco's governance committee; Arkin says Belnick has done nothing wrong and is cooperating with Manhattan district attorney's criminal investigation of Tyco; Boies seems to be in charge of Tyco, with approval of its board, with firing of Belnick (M)

headline: In a Policy Shift, South Africa Will Make AIDS Drugs Available to More Pregnant Women
abstract: South African government, bowing to public pressure, will offer AIDS drugs to all poor pregnant women infected with HIV (M)

headline: BANK OF IRELAND ACQUIRES 61% OF FUND MANAGER IRIDIAN
abstract: Bank of Ireland says its asset management arm has bought 61 percent of Iridian Asset Management, fund manager in Connecticut, for $177 million; Bank of Ireland reports its 10th consecutive year of record annual profit, with 1.12 billion euros ($1.02 billion) before tax and exceptional items for year ended March 31 (S)

headline: Hobbled by Microsoft Policy
abstract: Letter from John B Cumming objects to Microsoft's policy on uninstalling and reinstalling Word (Apr 4 Q&A)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Strong Economic Growth
abstract: Thailand's economy grew 3.9 percent in first quarter compared with first quarter of 2001; National Economic and Social Development Board raises its forecast for economic growth this year to range of 3.5 percent to 4 percent from 2 to 3 percent (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Rebels Make Political Alliance
abstract: Rebel group Congolese Rally for Democracy-Goma, whose intransigence led to collapse of peace talks, announces alliance with several political parties, including one headed by veteran opposition leader Etienne Tshisekedi (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Communists Want To Purge A Leader
abstract: Russian news agency Interfax reports Communist Party leadership recommended expulsion of Parliament's lower house speaker Gennadi Seleznyov; call came in April after coalition of moderate and liberal Parliament members stripped Communists of most of their committee chairmanships; Seleznyov is among more moderate Communists, and has cooperated with Pres Vladimir Putin, to dismay of party members (S)

headline: German Police Arrest 'Militant' Group
abstract: German police, acting after months of surveillance, carry out dawn raids across country, arresting 11 members of what prosecutors call militant Islamic group providing support for Taliban fighters in Afghanistan and others (S)

headline: Enron Still Plans New Power Plant
abstract: Financial problems are not stopping Enron Corp's efforts to build power plant on outskirts of Memphis; proposed 500-megawatt plant, costing more than $100 million, would be built by Shelby Power I, limited partnership owned by Enron North America Corp (S)

headline: Israel Moves Into West Bank City as Envoys Start New Peace Bid
abstract: Israeli troops stormed into Nablus today, rounding up around 100 Palestinians, in the largest of the daily raids since April.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Insurer Seeks Investors
abstract: Citigroup and Lehman Brothers Holding are among companies in talks to buy as much as quarter of China Life, biggest insurance company in China (S)

headline: Wall Street Inquiry Expanded, With a Subpoena to Salomon
abstract: New York State Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer issues subpoena to Salomon Smith Barney requesting that firm produce all documents relating to research produced by Salomon's star telecommunications analyst Jack Grubman; move is part of investigation into conflicts of interest among Wall Street analysts; Spitzer requests documents dating to January 1998 and related to 54 telecommunications companies; firm's lawyers issue directive and advise employees to 'preserve all documents that may be relevant to the subjects covered by the subpoena until you are advised otherwise in writing by Office of the General Counsel'; Spitzer meets with top securities regulator in Washington and urges Congressional action to address conflicts on Wall Street; photo (M)

headline: To Fight Greed, Limit the Paycheck
abstract: John S Koppel letter comments on June 16 article concerning political parties' approaches to fighting corporate corruption

headline: AQUILA CUTS DIVIDEND TO PROTECT CREDIT RATING
abstract: Aquila Inc cuts its 2002 profit forecast and slashes its dividend to pay debt and help maintain its investment-grade credit rating; is selling $400 million in common stock and $500 million in bonds; annual dividend is cut to 70 cents per share from $1.20 (S)

headline: Industry Allies Seek to Limit Microsoft Drive Into New Fields
abstract: Corporate software users fear Microsoft may be trying to set itself up as Web gatekeeper with its online identity system; have formed Liberty Alliance to develop open and neutral standards for online identity systems, seemingly arcane technology that is seen as key to coming generation of Internet services and electronic commerce growth; alliance has growing roster of major companies; Microsoft is also finding its advances elsewhere slowed by wary industry partners and rivals; photo (M)

headline: G.I.'s Mistakenly Attack Friendly Afghan Soldiers, Killing 3
abstract: American Special Forces troops mistakenly fire on group of friendly Afghan soldiers in predawn firefight, killing three and wounding two others they mistook for Qaeda fighters, near Gardez, eastern Afghanistan; military officials see no sign that troops were tricked into attacking compound by faction seeking to bloody rival; map (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Toobin Moving to CNN as Legal Analyst
abstract: Jeffrey Toobin will leave as ABC legal affairs correspondent to join CNN as in-house legal expert; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Strike On Iraq Air Defenses
abstract: US and British warplanes bomb air-defense system in northern Iraq (S)

headline: VICTORINOX OFFERS TO BUY REST OF SWISS ARMY BRANDS
abstract: Swiss Army Brands Inc receives $24.9 million offer from Victorinox AG to acquire remaining stake in company (S)

headline: I.B.M. Says Earnings to Fall Short of Estimates
abstract: IBM warns that its sales and earnings for first three months of year will fall well below Wall Street's estimates; stock drops $9.84, to $87.41 per share, in heavy trading; several analysts suggest that Samuel J Palmisano, who became chief executive in March, might be 'managing earnings' downward in his first on job, so later comparisons will look more impressive; Merrill Lynch analyst Steven Milunovich says this suggests that there is no information-technology recovery; graph; photo (M)

headline: Of Metallica And the Business Suit
abstract: WHILE many technology companies were bragging about offering foosball tables and beanbags as employee diversions, Henry T. Nicholas III, the chief executive of Broadcom, the communications chip company, was ensuring that suits were the norm in attire for his 2,800 employees worldwide.    ''We didn't sit down and say that we wanted to be an anti-Silicon Valley company,'' Mr. Nicholas said. ''We just decided to run Broadcom with a different culture and management style.''    Leading by example, Mr. Nicholas, who is now 42, dresses in a suit, and employees know that business attire is the rule. But the company, once riding high, has seen its stock plummet, along with those of many other technology companies.    Mr. Nicholas and Henry Samueli, his former engineering professor at U.C.L.A., were co-founders of Baseband Technologies in 1991, working in the spare bedroom of Mr. Nicholas's condominium in Redondo Beach, Calif. After they renamed the company Broadcom, Mr. Nicholas earned a reputation for his love of the heavy-metal band Metallica and risky hobbies like skydiving.    He has no problem with confidence, even in the recent down market. ''From a long-term standpoint, the longer it goes on, the more of our competitors will die out,'' said Mr. Nicholas, who has a Ph.D. in electrical engineering and is known for his fierce competitiveness.    Broadcom's stock is now trading at $22.55 on Nasdaq, down from a high of $273 in August 2000. In the first quarter of 2002, Broadcom narrowed its loss to $166.1 million on net revenue of $238.8 million, compared with a loss of $356.9 million in the comparable quarter of 2001 on net revenue of $310.5 million.    Broadcom, based in Irvine, Calif., since 1995, makes chips for cable modems, computer network switches, digital-cable TV set-top boxes, fiber optic equipment and server computers. Mr. Samueli, the company's chief technology officer, and Mr. Nicholas each own about 12 percent of the company, which at one point made each worth more than $5 billion.    In the last two years, Mr. Nicholas said, he has been focusing his energy on international acquisitions. ''Some weeks, I spend more time in the air than on the ground,'' he said, traveling the world on his private Challenger 601 jet, which seats 14. ''I probably sleep on the plane at least three nights a week. I like toys that make me more efficient.''   JULIE DUNN

headline: Private Sector; Qwest's Angry Shareholders Play 'Follow the Meeting'
abstract: About 300 disgruntled Qwest Communications International shareholders attend meeting company shifted to Dublin, Ohio, from traditional Denver site; chairman Joseph C Nacchio tries to reassure audience that has watched share price tumble; photo (M)

headline: 3 Killed in Raid in Nablus; Peace Conference Idea Wins Initial Support on Both Sides
abstract: Israel and Palestinians express cautious support for peace conference announced by Bush administration, as Israeli soldiers launch raid into center of Nablus in which Israeli officer and two Palestinians are killed; in Bethlehem, Palestinian and Israeli negotiators remain deadlocked over siege at Church of the Nativity; much about conference remains unresolved, including its goals and topics of discussion; officials in Washington emphasize that it would be meeting of foreign ministers, not heads of state, in plan that seems intended to sidestep Prime Min Ariel Sharon's refusal to negotiate with Yasir Arafat because of Israel's belief that he sponsors terrorism; photos (M)

headline: Grim Warnings in Ramallah and a Disputed Death Toll in Jenin
abstract: Update of latest developments in Israeli-Palestinian conflict (S)

headline: At Indie Music Shop, A Guide via MP3's
abstract: Amoeba Music, independent store in Los Angeles, boasts large collection of CD's, LP's, cassette tapes and eight-tracks; calls itself largest independent record store on planet; customers can hear tracks at special listening stations before deciding whether to buy; photo (M)

headline: Minister Says India Won't Attack Pakistan
abstract: Interview with India's Defense Min George Fernandes, who says India has no plans to launch military attack against Pakistan over next few months even if severely provoked; rising tensions between both countries in recent months over issue of Kashmir noted (M)

headline: Court Orders New Meeting Of Vivendi Shareholders
abstract: French court acknowledges claim by Vivendi Universal that wireless electronic voting system used at its shareholder meeting last week malfunctioned and orders company to convene new meeting as quickly as possible; decision is welcome victory for Vivendi's chief executive Jean-Marie Messier; no date has been set for new meeting (M)

headline: Comforts of Home Yield to Tyranny Of Digital Gizmos
abstract: Comforts of daily life are yielding to tyranny of computerized appliances and consumers are becoming increasingly frustrated; relatively simple devices once controlled by twisting knob or pushing button are now endowed with digital commands that can take hours to master; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global Chip Sales Expected To Rise
abstract: Semiconductor Industry Association forecasts global semiconductor sales will rise 3.1 percent in 2002 and jump 23.2 percent in 2003 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Dome Owner
abstract: Anschutz Entertainment Group, controlled by billionaire Philip F Anschutz, has acquired London's Millennium Dome; themed exhibits will be replaced by 20,000-seat sports and entertainment complex (S)

headline: Polish Farmers Leery of European Union
abstract: Poland's small-time farmers fear that country's entry into European Union will flood country with cheap crop from rich member countries, pushing them out; some fear Germans will come in and buy land, turning Polish farmers into farmhands; more than one-third of Poles identify themselves as farmers, and they are at forefront of growing debate about virtues of membership; support for membership is down from mid-1990's, but polls show that more than half of Poland would vote for entry; photo; map (M)

headline: U.S. INQUIRY TRACKS INSIDERS AT ENRON
abstract: Project Grayhawk, financial scheme allegedly used by Enron's senior managers to increase profits by funneling inside information about company to affiliated partnership, is reportedly centerpiece of criminal investigation of company and its officers by FBI and Securities and Exchange Commission; witnesses reportedly tell investigators partnership used secret details in determining how and whether to limit exposure to swings in Enron stock; when Enron stock climbed, partnership and company profited handsomely; investigators seek to determine whether activity broke insider trading laws or another criminal statute; photos (M)

headline: Israeli Forces Hit Palestinian Offices in Hebron in Effort to Dislodge Gunmen
abstract: Israeli troops pound Palestinian Authority offices in Hebron for third day, firing heavy machine guns and rockets from helicopters to dislodge 15 gunmen holed up inside; seven Palestinian cities remain shut down for fifth day; two Palestinians killed in clashes; Israeli troops storm Nablus jail used as security headquarters, taking about 20 Palestinians into custody; current action is direct response to attacks that killed 31 Israelis in three days; Israeli prosecutors charge Lebanese-born Israeli, son of Jewish mother and Muslim father, with spying for Hezbollah (S)

headline: I.B.M. Gets Contract for Weather Supercomputer
abstract: US government awards IBM $224.4 million contract to build power new supercomputer as part of effort to close growing gap facing US scientists in weather prediction; machine, which is planned to reach theoretical peak speed of more than 100 trillion calculations per second by 2009, will be used to increase accuracy of forecasts of weather, floods and ocean conditions by National Centers for Environmental Prediction, part of National Weather Service (M)

headline: India Believes Pakistan Restrains Militants
abstract: Indian intelligence and military officials believe orders have been given to Pakistanis fighting Indian control of Kashmir not to cross over into Indian territory; cite intercepted communications between members of Islamic militant groups as well as on-the-ground observations; say conversations are vague and in coded language, but they offer some hope that Pakistan is responding to international pressure to cease support for militants; Pres Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan denied last week that there were cross-border infiltrations, but almost no one accepted that assertion; map (M)

headline: Vehicle Sales Fell in May Even as Big Rebates Continued
abstract: Ward's Auto Info Bank reports auto sales fell 6 percent in May from May 2001, to lowest monthly pace in nearly four years; slump, led by weak sales at General Motors, comes even as industry continues to offer big rebates and subsidize interest rates; photo (M)

headline: Israel Steps Up Military Pressure in West Bank
abstract: Israel presses military action in West Bank, storming into Bethlehem, where seven Palestinians are killed in fighting around Manger Square, and moving into nearby refugee camps; map; troops call for women ages 15 to 25 to appear for questioning along with men, in response to new phenomenon of female suicide bombers; troops also move on to Jenin for house-to-house searches; three people wounded in Passover bombing in Netanya die, bringing total to 25; man wounded in Haifa attack dies, bringing death toll in that bombing to 15; about 180 men inside Jibril Rajoub's security headquarters in Ramallah surrender, after CIA helps work out evacuation (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bank To Write Off Loss
abstract: Santander Central Hispano SA says second-quarter pretax profit will be cut by 700 million euros ($643 million) because of losses from selling its unprofitable Latin American Internet unit; graph (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Sit, Roll Over, Work: An 'Employee Pet' Game
abstract: New online game Metapet satirizes managers who use incentives and punishments; game players assume role of corporate managers given cyberhuman workers implanted with animal genes and have task of making 'employee pets' as productive as possible at least cost; co-creator Natalie Bookchin comments; photo (M)

headline: OPEC Decides on No Change In Oil Production Levels
abstract: OPEC decides to leave crude oil production levels unchanged, despite what industry experts expect will be considerable increase in demand that could send prices higher; OPEC seems willing to push prices as high as it can without provoking global recession; price of oil on New York Mercantile Exchange rises 44 cents, to $26.76; photo of Iraq's Oil Min Amir Mohammed Rasheed (M)

headline: More Woes for Europe's Cable Concerns
abstract: United Pan-Europe Communications says any failure to reach agreement with its bondholders to restructure its debts could force company to seek bankruptcy protection from creditors; Arthur Andersen, company's auditor, says company has suffered recurring losses from operations and ahs net capital deficiency that raises substantial doubt about its ability to continue as going concern; United Pan-Europe says it lost 4.4 billion euros ($3.9 billion) in 2001, more than double its loss of 2 billion euros in 2000; photo (M)

headline: Bryant Gumbel Informs CBS He Will Leave Morning Show
abstract: Early Show host Bryant Gumbel announces he is leaving CBS program; announcement raises questions about direction of program and Gumbel's future in television; CBS executives are emphatic that Gumbel is leaving of his own volition, that he no longer wants to continue grueling pace of morning television; CBS executives acknowledge that program's ratings have been disappointment; CBS News president Andrew Heyward comments; chart; photo (M)

headline: South African Breweries Near a Deal to Buy Miller
abstract: Boards of South African Breweries and Philip Morris Cos meet separately to vote on agreement that would allow South African Breweries to buy two-thirds of Miller Brewing Co for about $3 billion in stock and assumption of $2 billion in Miller Brewing debt; South African Beweries would become second-largest brewer in world; deal is latest sign of changes reshaping global brewing business; chart; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Shares Of Cree Rise
abstract: Shares of Cree increase 15 percent after company, semiconductor manufacturer, increases its revenue outlook for fiscal fourth quarter, saying improved performance and lower prices for chips used in wireless handsets resulted in strong demand; graph (S)

headline: Some Colleges Take Games Seriously
abstract: Rochester Institute of Technology has begun first master's program in computer game design; program takes its place alongside few other game design programs at colleges around nation; career opportunities for graduates are uncertain; photos (M)

headline: Sharon Says Prisoners Implicate Arafat in Financing of Terrorism
abstract: Israeli Government says Palestinian leaders under Israeli interrogation have implicated Yasir Arafat in financing terrorist attacks; three-page statement from office of Prime Min Ariel Sharon does not link Arafat to any particular attack or produce additional documents to back up its accusations; says Arafat approved money for operatives, knowing it would finance terrorist attacks against Israeli civilians; Sharon has repeatedly said no peace would be possible with Arafat; release of announcement, coming after Arafat's own release from monthlong siege in Ramallah, suggests Israeli Government has not revised that view as Bush administration and government of Saudi Arabia step up their efforts to end conflict; some of men cited as sources for Israeli accusation about Arafat have in past denied that Arafat had role in preparing terrorist attacks; prisoners include Marwan Barghouti, senior leader of Arafat's Fatah organization; photo; map (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dynegy Chief Much Richer For Being Forced Out  Charles L. Watson, the departing chief executive of Dynegy, is entitled under his contract to a huge severance check -- one that is about $33 million more than he would have made had the company allowed him to serve out the eight months he had remaining. Mr. Watson's contract specified that if he was forced out, he was to be paid what amounts to three years' compensation, including the projected value of stock options.     Why Dynegy's directors decided to take that financial hit is not clear. But it appears the board felt that with investor confidence ebbing, it could not afford to have Mr. Watson in charge for the rest of this year. [Page A1.]

headline: Kirch in Danger of Bankruptcy After Rescue Talks Break Down
abstract: The Kirch Group, Germany's second-largest media company, teetered on the edge of bankruptcy after rescue talks with bankers and investors, including Rupert Murdoch, broke down.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BECKMAN COULTER, Fullerton, Calif., a maker of medical laboratory supplies, said it had signed two new contracts and two renewal agreements to supply instruments, test kits, and blood and heart products to Premier Inc., a purchasing organization owned by more than 200 hospitals and health care systems. Sales are expected to be about $173 million.    WOOD GROUP, Aberdeen, Scotland, a provider of oil field equipment and services, said it had bought Operators and Consulting Services Inc., Lafayette, La., a provider of oil field services. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Auditing Firm Is Said to Be Dismissed By Adelphia
abstract: Troubled Adelphia Communications dismisses its auditors, Deloitte & Touche, even as it apparently comes closer to bankruptcy filing; cites firm's knowledge of questionable accounting practices between Adelphia and Rigas family-controlled entities, for which it also works, and its failure to understand or disclose them (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Seeking U.S. Help Against Rebels
abstract: Prime Min Sher Bahadur Deuba of Nepal will visit Washington to plead for military aid to battle Maoist rebels whose influence has now spread across kingdom; Bush administration has already asked Congress for $20 million (S)

headline: Surveillance Cameras Set To Keep Watch In Airliners
abstract: JetBlue becomes first airline to install hidden surveillance cameras in passenger cabin; most other American airlines are expected to install cameras, which let pilots watch passengers on two cockpit screens; critics seek assurances that passenger privacy rights will be protected; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Loss At Softbank
abstract: Softbank posts loss of 88.76 billion yen ($691 million) for year ended March 31, despite 2.1 percent revenue gain; stock price graph (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: E*Trade Raises Stake In Unit
abstract: Online broker E*Trade acquires additional 7 percent of its Japanese subsidiary, E*Trade Japan, for $30.7 million to raise its stake to 36.1 percent; E*Trade Japan says its net profit fell 58 percent, to 415 million yen ($3.2 million), in fiscal year ended March 31 (S)

headline: For Palestinian Refugees, Dream of Return Endures
abstract: Expectations by Palestinian refugees in Jordan of returning to homeland that was once Palestine ebbs and flows with tide of violence in West Bank and are also being shaped by time; sensual nostalgia of first generation for lifelong traditions is dying with them, replaced by much sharper, bitter demand by generations who cannot reminisce; predictions of old that children of 1948 refugees would forget about Palestine have proved premature; their great grandchildren are learning to spout tortured list of historical, religious, legal and cultural reasons why they should be allowed back; Israel's military offensive on West Bank is providing reinvigorated sense of history that is not only limited to refugee camps; photos; charts; map (L)

headline: Beyond Diego Rivera: Latin American Art and Its Avant-Garde
abstract: Cisneros Foundation, based in Caracas, Venezuela, has developed arts education Web site presenting 166 works from its collection; site emphasizes Latin American abstract art; photos (M)

headline: Prosecution Concludes Case In U.S. Trial Of Andersen
abstract: Prosecution rests its case in obstruction of justice trial of Arthur Andersen, after cross-examination in which government's last witness Paula Schanzle, FBI agent who worked on Andersen probe, is challenged by defense attorney Rusty Hardin about significance of Andersen's deletion of thousands of e-mail notes last fall; Andersen opens its case with Richard Corgel, practice director for North America, who describes series of conference calls that were held among Andersen partners last fall, as financial problems at Enron were becoming more apparent; government has presented evidence that conference calls ultimately led to destruction of records at Andersen; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo Names a No. 2 Executive
abstract: Yahoo names David Rosensweig chief operating officer, replacing Jeffrey Mallet, who announced his resignation in January; photo (S)

headline: Book Deal For Widow Of Reporter From Journal
abstract: Scribner acquires right to publish memoir by Mariane Pearl, whose husband, Daniel Pearl of Wall Street Journal, was kidnapped and killed reporting from Pakistan (S)

headline: New Life for Washington Watchdog
abstract: Markos Kounalakis, journalist, businessman and author, has donated over $200,000 to stabilize financially teetering Washington Monthly, small but influential neoliberal magazine; will serve as president and publisher; plans to contribute up to $1 million in next few years while searching for other supporters; original shareholders, including Warren E Buffett, have given up their holdings to let magazine reorganize as nonprofit; photos (M)

headline: How in a Little English Town Jihad Found Young Converts
abstract: Tipton, small town in English Midlands, is seemingly unlikely home of four Muslim young men, who told families last fall they were going to Pakistan for various reasons, and instead joined 'jihad' in Afghanistan; three were captured with Taliban in Afghanistan and are at Guantanamo naval base; fourth is missing; 'Tipton Taliban' come from Muslim generation angry and uncertain about its identity and prospects in Britain and across Europe, rejecting of material comforts their parents emigrated for, and so prey to politicized form of Islam; stories of Shafiq Rasul, Asif Iqbal, Ruhal Ahmed and Munir Ali recounted (M)

headline: When the Grim Reaper Calls, The Computer Goes Into Action
abstract: AryeÄ

headline: That Free Getaway Is About to Cost More
abstract: Two free nights at a Ritz-Carlton hotel might sound nice about now. If you're a loyal holder of a Merrill Lynch Signature Rewards credit card, and you have finally managed to rack up 32,000 points, you can claim your prize. But you'd better be fast.    As of May 1, Merrill Lynch says, it is raising the point levels needed to redeem the gift certificates and merchandise offered to customers. Unless you read the fine print in company mailings, however, you may not be aware of any deadline.

headline: BERKSHIRE PROFITS RISE ON HIGHER INSURANCE PRICES
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway says first-quarter net income rose 51 percent, to $916 million, from $606 million in 2001 period (S)

headline: Malone Seeks British Cable Debt
abstract: Liberty Media Corp offers to buy bonds issued by Telewest Communications in bid to preserve its stake in Telewest, British cable television company, should it be forced to exchange debt for shares; Liberty, investment vehicle of billionaire John C Malone, owns about 25 percent of equity in Telewest, and will spend as much as $350 million buying 20 percent of Telewest's bonds (M)

headline: Ericsson Battens Down Its Hatches
abstract: L M Ericsson, leading maker of wireless network equipment, says it will cut its work force by additional 20 percent, that it will probably lose money this year and that it will ask its shareholders for almost $3 billion in new investment; news sends company's stock plunging in value by almost one-quarter, closing at 27.3 Swedish kronor ($2.65) per share, lowest level in nearly five years; Ericsson lost 2.97 billion kronor ($289 million) in first quarter, compared with profit of 424 million kronor ($41.2 million) year earlier; layoffs will eliminate 17,000 jobs this year and next, reducing total work force to 65,000; company had 107,000 employees at end of 2000; restructuring will cost around $1 billion over two years; graph (M)

headline: China Hands Out Long Jail Terms to 2 Leaders of Democracy Party
abstract: Two leaders of the outlawed China Democracy Party have been given long prison sentences this week, a human rights monitor reported today.

headline: Chirac, a Victory in Hand, Sets His Sights on Another
abstract: Political analysts in France say Pres Jacques Chirac has hardly made mistake since his May 5 re-election, moving quickly into another crucial campaign, legislative elections on June 9 and 16; unless his supporterswin majority in Parliaemnt, he will face yet another five years as virtual lame duck, being forced to appoint and share power with leftist prime minister; trying to head off such an outcome, Chirac has shown sudden responsiveness to complaints against Paris elite that prompted many voters to defect from his camp just weeks ago (M)

headline: U.S. Seeks Safeguards on Diplomats Testifying at Milosevic Trial
abstract: State Department is negotiating terms under which Richard C Holbrooke and other American diplomats may testify in war crimes trial of former Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic; American push for secret testimony is frustrating tribunal's prosecutors, who have suggested that they may have to drop testimony of Holbrooke, who as Clinton administration's envoy to Balkans worked closely with Milosevic on 1995 accords that ended Bosnian war (M)

headline: Surfing From Site to Site With the Click of a Remote
abstract: ATI Technologies introduces new wireless device that can work as remote control for computers equipped with TV tuner cards made by ATI; photo (S)

headline: TALKS BREAK DOWN BETWEEN ANDERSEN AND JUSTICE DEPT.
abstract: Negotiations to settle criminal case against Arthur Andersen collapse when firm fails to accept deal before government-imposed deadline and Justice Dept then withdraws its offer; there is little likelihood two sides will resolve their differences before Andersen's criminal trial is scheduled to begin on May 6 in Houston; people involved in case say two sides were close to agreement on deal, but Andersen lawyers said they needed more time to discuss deal with their clients and government refused request to keep its offer on table as long as necessary; breakdown occurred because each Andersen partner is owner, meaning each must be consulted and agree to every aspect of deal before final decision can be made; process leaves Andersen incapable of responding quickly to rapidly changing situation; some insiders say faction of partners may welcome collapse of Andersen, thinking it could result in removal of 'noncompete' agreements that limit their ability to switch jobs (M)

headline: O Magazine Expands to South Africa
abstract: Hearst Magazines and Oprah Winfrey are scheduled to announce the introduction of the first international edition of O: The Oprah Magazine.

headline: U.P.S. Strike Vote Is Set
abstract: United Parcel Service workers represented by Teamsters will vote this weekend on giving their leaders authority to call strike if necessary, as union tries to speed up contract talks (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Daewoo Posts Loss
abstract: Bankrupt Daewoo Motor reports net loss of $2.73 billion in 2001, despite operating profit of approximately $8 billion; company officials credit restructuring efforts with cutting last year's net loss by 70 percent from 2000; company sold only 466,254 vehicles last year, down 40 percent from 2000, but says sales in first quarter of 2002 rose by 2.4 percent from first quarter of 2001; Daewoo's chairman Lee Jong Dae says takeover negotiations might end this month, with General Motors Corp agreeing not to lay off workers; photo (S)

headline: A Surprising Crackdown in Malawi
abstract: Pres Bakili Muluzi of Malawi defends ban on political demonstrations and the issue that prompted them: constitutional amendment to eliminate presidential term limits and allow him to prolong his rule; church leaders, lawyers and university students say Muluzi, whom they revered for ending 30 years of dictatorship and expanding political freedom, has become biggest threat to nation's fledgling democracy; photo; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Research: Study To Develop New Computing Systems
abstract: Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency chooses IBM, Sun Microsystems, Cray Inc and SGI to run research programs aimed at developing next generation of high-performance computing systems, which it expects to fill gap between today's supercomputers and expected arrival of quantum computing in 15 or 20 years; each program will receive about $3 million for initial one-year study to develop basic concepts and realistic performance measurements (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Figures Show Playstation's Strength
abstract: Sony Corp's video game division says it has shipped 30 million Playstation 2 consoles since system's introduction in October 2000, hightlighting challenges facing its rivals Nintendo and Microsoft Corp; Nintendo says it shipped 12 million of its GameCube consoles (S)

headline: Credit Squeeze Is Easing, But Boardroom Pall Lingers
abstract: Spread between interest rates paid on short-term debt issued by companies with so-so credit ratings and debt issued by companies with high ratings narrows, suggesting that riskier companies are having easier time raising money; Eastman Chemical in Kingsport, Tenn, now finds that it can borrow more easily and cheaply than it could earlier this year; photo; graph shows interest rate spread between debt issued by A2/P2-rated companies and AA-rated companies (L) (News analysis)

headline: In Pakistan's Interior, A Troubling Victory In Hunt for Al Qaeda
abstract: Faisalabad, industrial city deep in interior of Pakistan, has not been high on list of places considered hideouts for Al Qaeda terrorists, until FBI agents and Pakistani police raided house on outskirts and arrested some twenty Arab and other captives, including Abu Zubaydah, highest-ranking Al Qaeda figure captured since Sept 11 attacks; US has confirmed that Zubaydah was seriously injured in shootout, but said little else; Faisalabad does not have turbulent reputation of Pakistani cities that are factories of Islamic extremism; accounts of men who rented home reviewed; photo; map (M)

headline: The Perils of Measuring Managers Against the S.& P. 500
abstract: Mark Hulbert Strategies column discusses reasons why many fund managers and newsletter editors seemed to have outperformed Standard & Poor's 500-stock index since 2000; holds structure of index, weighted by market capitalization, skews assessment of relative performance; graph (M)

headline: Japan's Export Power Drifts Across the China Sea
abstract: Japan's trade surplus is set for structural decline as more production is moved overseas, Japan opens itself to imports and aging population transforms Japan from country of producers to one of consumers; merchandise trade surplus fell 38 percent in 2001, and China is expected to displace Japan this year as biggest exporter to US; Japan officials are trying to identify areas in which they can retain edge over China; photos; graph (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Falls
abstract: Ifo Institute's index of business confidence in western Germany fell to 90.5 in April from 91.5 in March (S)

headline: Michigan Governor to Offer Energy Research Plan
abstract: Michigan Gov John Engler will introduce plan that seeks to position state as center of research into alternative energy sources; initiative, called NextEnergy Plan, is expected to cost $30 million to $50 million over three to five years; it will include development of research center on 700-acre plot near Ann Arbor, tax exemptions for businesses that conduct research on alternative energy, venture capital fund to promote research and tax breaks for Michigan residents who buy automobiles or power sources that use alternative energy; Engler says much of idea is to ensure Michigan is not left behind if auto industry exchanges internal combustion engine for new technology; photo (M)

headline: 2 Senior Executives In West Coast Swing
abstract: Chris Lloyd is named to new post of managing director for advertising at Seattle office of DDB Worldwide; John Russell is leaving Wieden & Kennedy, where he was group account director, to join Leopold Ketel & Partners in new posts of president and partner; Jaime Leopold becomes chief executive (S)

headline: An Ethics Code Can't Replace a Backbone
abstract: Management must convince employees that the company is not using an ethics code to brush aside past events and, more important, that it acts on what it says it values.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Moldova: Telecom Sale Set
abstract: Moldova says it will sell 51 percent stake in state-owned telecommunications monopoly by August (S)

headline: After an Age of Digital Hubris, Wired's Editor Is Still a Believer
abstract: Chris Anderson, who has been under quiet attack from digerati since he took over as Wired's editor in June for his lack of Silicon Valley credentials and decision to replace several longtime editors, is optimistic about outlook for magazine despite sharp drop in advertising revenues and falling newsstand sales; cites planned redesign; Conde Nast editorial director James Truman comments; graphs of circulation and advertising; photo (M)

headline: E-tailers Grow More Consumer Friendly
abstract: ConsumerReports.org reports online merchants studied are improving Web site privacy policies, usability and product data; ranks top merchants on various criteria (S)

headline: The Faces Of Martyrs As a Calling In Demand
abstract: Interview with Majed Abu Ghosh, printer who holds Ramallah concession from Palestinian Authority to print ubiquitous 'martyr posters' of suicide bombers; photos (S)

headline: Extremist has exploited issues that haunt the nation's political class from left to right : Le Pen, breaker of taboos
abstract: PARIS:—  The man talks about "internment camps" or "transit camps" for illegal immigrants and "special trains" to carry them out of France. He designates himself nudgingly as a David fighting Goliath, and, half a breath later, more mockingly, as a nightmare bogeyman here to scare the hell out of, nudge, you know who.

headline: PRESCRIPTION MANAGER RAISES PROFIT FORECAST FOR YEAR
abstract: MIM Corp, which manages prescription drug benefits for insurance companies and health care providers, raises its profit forecast for year; expects sales of $620 million this year, 36 percent increase from $456.7 million in 2001 (S)

headline: Trial in American Reporter's Death Is Adjourned, Raising Doubts About Swift Resolve
abstract: Trial in kidnapping and murder of Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl convenes in secret for a few minutes in Karachi and then breaks for long adjournment; four defendants are in custody, including Ahmed Omar Sheikh, who is accused of abducting Pearl on Jan 23 (M)

headline: Irish Catholics To Open Inquiry Into Abuse Cases
abstract: Archbishop Sean Brady says Ireland's Roman Catholic Church will appoint independent investigator to review its handling of child sexual abuse by priests and will cooperate fully with government inquiry; move follows resignation of Brendan Comiskey, Bishop of Ferns, after acknowledging he failed to do enough to stop priests in his diocese from sexually abusing children (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Once-Novel Drug Company No Longer Sets Pace
abstract: Human Genome Sciences is beginning to look to some analysts like just another 'me-too' drug company; problem is that earliest drugs developed using Human Genome's gene-hunting technology have proved disappointing when tested on people; company is becoming more dependent on improved versions of tried-and-true drugs; such drugs represent nearly half products Human Genome has in clinical trials; company says it is dropping mirostipen, one of its most advanced genomics-based drugs, because drug has not shown sufficient effectiveness in clinical trial testing concerning whether it could increase infection-fighting white blood cells in cancer patients receiving chemotherapy; company says it will develop, for same use, longer-lasting form of G-CSF, protein already sold as Neupogen by Amgen; chief executive William A Haseltine comments; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: U.N. Fears 'Bloc' Voters Are Abetting Rights Abuses
abstract: UN Commission on Human Rights ends annual session in Geneva, Switzerland, with rights advocates complaining that nations with repressive governments, such as China and Iran, are increasingly managing to evade serious examination of their records; Human Rights Watch says commission has become hostage to group of human rights abusers; Mary Robinson, high commissioner for human rights, voices concern that bloc voting is weakening commission's role; says organization's rotating roster of 53 member nations should reconsider their approach; increasingly, voting alliances are emerging to prevent commission from singling out individual countries for criticism (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: Germany And I.B.M. Agree On Linux; Peregrine Names New Chief Executive; Microsoft Settles S.E.C. Charges.

headline: House Votes $1.3 Billion in Aid for Afghanistan
abstract: House of Representatives votes to provide $1.3 billion in economic and military aid to Afghanistan after demanding that Pres Bush devise strategy to establish law and order there; lawmakers express fear that US military success could be undermined if lawlessness persists in Afghanistan (M)

headline: But economists warn pace will slow : U.S. economy roars ahead at 5.8% rate
abstract: The U.S. economy steamed ahead at an annual rate of 5.8 percent in the first quarter, the government reported Friday — a sharp recovery from the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 and a renewal of its status as the engine of global growth.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Posts Loss
abstract: Swiss Reinsurance Ltd lost nearly $100 million last year, less than $120 million it had estimated earlier; expects income to grow by about 20 percent this year (S)

headline: Bristol-Myers Sees Big Drop In Its Sales And Earnings
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb jolts Wall Street by saying that its sales and earnings for first quarter and year will be significantly lower than investors had been expecting; says drug wholesalers, reacting to sales incentives from Bristol-Myers, have bought far more of its products over many months than what pharmacies needed to fill prescriptions; contends that is now hurting sales as wholesalers reduce their purchases in effort to lower their inventories; chairman-chief executive Peter R Dolan says company discovered that its projections of drug sales in US were 'dramatically off track' (M)

headline: How Banks Chased a Mirage
abstract: Big banks have little to show for over $40 billion they spent in 1990's acquiring investment banks except high-level turmoil in ranks; troubled marriages of banks and investment banks were inspired by relaxation of law that had kept commercial banks out of field; commercial banks were eager to get into investment banking because it is potentially far more profitable than making loans; after paying peak prices for acquisitions, many of big banks failed to keep key investment bankers whose talents made deals enticing; most big banks went after relatively small firms, whose tightknit culture and entrepreneurial approach often became lost in acquirer's bureaucracy; table of deals and their outcome; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Advent Reduces Sales Forecast
abstract: Shares of Advent Software Inc drop $13.37, to $22.10, after company reduces its sales forecast for year; graph (S)

headline: Argentina Shakes, Uruguay Rattles
abstract: Argentina is mired in worst economic crisis in its history and Uruguay appears to be only South American nation that is being taken under by its neighbor's troubles; Uruguayan government has been scrambling to adjust; Moody's Investors Service has lowered Uruguay's precious investment-grade rating to junk status, saying country is 'increasingly vulnerable to macroeconomic shocks emanating from Argentina'; Uruguay last year had its third year of economic contraction, with gross domestic product falling 2 percent; GDP is expected to decline similar amount this year; when Argentines were forced to devalue their currency in January, Uruguayan government reacted by doubling, to 12 percent, band in which it allows its peso to float; Uruguay's mostly dollar-denominated debt adds up to more than 60 percent of GDP because of devaluation; map; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Bank To Close More Branches
abstract: DBS Group Holdings, Singapore's biggest bank, plans to shut 12 more branches in Hong Kong in cost-cutting move (S)

headline: Waksal Kin Said to Sell ImClone Shares
abstract: ImClone Systems reportedly has found that relatives of former chief executive Samuel D Waksal in addition to his daughter, Aliza, sold ImClone shares in days before Food and Drug Administration rejected company's bid to sell cancer drug Erbitux; Waksal reportedly has been notified by Securities and Exchange Commission that it wants to bring action against him, move that helped spur his resignation (M)

headline: Envoy's Last Lap And a High Alert
abstract: Update on Mideast developments (S)

headline: Russia Convicts a Former K.G.B. General Now Living in U.S.
abstract: Oleg D Kalugin, retired KGB general who became vociferous critic of post-Soviet Russian governments, is convicted of treason in absentia and sentenced to 15 years in prison for disclosing state secrets to US; verdict and sentence are purely symbolic since Kalugin, who now lives in Silver Springs, Md, repeatedly rebuffed subpoenas to return to Moscow to defend himself; Kalugin says verdict is proof of resurgence of intelligence services under Pres Vladimir V Putin (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Uruguay: An Apology To Argentina
abstract: Pres Jorge Batlle of Uruguay makes unplanned, emergency trip to Buenos Aires to apologize to his Argentine counterpart, Eduardo Duhalde, for calling Argentina's politicians a pack of thieves and saying Duhalde has no political power or backing and does not know where he is heading; photo (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of June 11 report about KPMG Consulting's purchase of businesses in Europe; KPMG Consulting was spun off last year from KPMG LLC, not from KPMG International, worldwide partnership that includes the American firm; European businesses are being sold by KPMG International, not by KPMG LLP

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: STRYKER CORP., Kalamazoo, Mich., a maker of orthopedic devices, said it would buy Surgical Dynamics Inc., a provider of spinal implants, from Tyco International Ltd., Pembroke, Bermuda, a diversified manufacturer, for $135 million.    BOSTON SCIENTIFIC CORP., Natick, Mass., a maker of medical devices, said it had secured a one-year agreement with 21 banks that would provide it with a $1 billion line of credit to make acquisitions and investments.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Remec To Buy Spectrian For $160 Million
abstract: Remec Inc will acquire Spectrian Corp for about $160 million (S)

headline: Los Angeles Cardinal at Center of Strategy to Control Scandal
abstract: Cardinal Roger M Mahony's intimate involvement with details of how much police and public will be told about sex-abuse crisis in American Roman Catholic Church is made clear in more than 50 private e-mail messages among officials of Los Angeles Archdiocese, which were sent anonymously to KFI-AM, Los Angeles radio station; Mahony generally urges cooperation with police, which he also promises with respect to new accusation that he molested a young woman 32 years ago; denies charge (M)

headline: Senate Panel Votes to Ease Rules on Suits In Stock Fraud
abstract: Senate Judiciary Committee, reacting to document shredding at Arthur Andersen and what many lawmakers say was widespread fraud at Enron Corp, approves bill that would create new criminal statues for securities fraud and destruction of corporate audit documents; bill also offers additional protections to corporate whistle-blowers and prevents executives who lose securities fraud lawsuits from using bankruptcy to escape fraud-related verdicts and settlements; Republicans, led by ranking member of panel, Orrin Hatch, object strenuously to provision that would substantially lengthen amount of time plaintiffs have to file lawsuits; plaintiffs could file securities fraud lawsuits within two years of discovering questionable conduct, instead of one year under current law, and within five years of date of conduct, instead of current three years; proposal to extend time limit has drawn support from trial lawyers and opposition from business groups; two sides have been feuding over issue since 1991, when Supreme Court established national time limit to bring such cases; US Chamber of Commerce director Joe Rubin says extension would create host of problems; Consumers Union says allowing more time for people to bring securities fraud lawsuits would give 'defrauded investors' fair chance at recovering their losses; White House spokeswoman Claire Buchan issues statement without explicitly saying Bush administration would fight extension (M)

headline: Merrill Research Chief Will Leave in 6 Months
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co vice chairman Thomas W Davis, who oversees firm's research department, says he plans to leave firm in six months; Davis and other Merrill officials say his resignation is unrelated to investigation into potential conflicts of interest of Merrill's stock analysts; inquiry is being conducted by New York Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer (M)

headline: Article 2002042594249538866 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Job Market Text Version         function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                            International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business              Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: How to pick the right kindergarden
abstract: VIENNA—  'Oh, oh, we've got trouble," I thought, as I stood watching Emily at the playground from across the street. My normally bouncy three-year-old was standing motionless on the sidelines while the other kids at her Austrian kindergarten ran and played. Twenty minutes later, she still hadn't moved. She stood silent and forlorn. When I finally went to her, the look on her face said loud and clear: "Mom, get me out of here!"

headline: Study Faults U.S. Regulators In Aftermath Of Power Crisis
abstract: Study by General Accounting Office, investigative arm of Congress, shows more than year after California endured power shortages and soaring energy prices, Federal Energy Regulatory Commission is still not up to task of protecting consumers and ensuring that electricity is sold at reasonable rates; finds commission is hobbled by antiquated procedures, legislation and perhaps mind-set more suited to old days when energy producers were regulated monopolies; GAO says Congress should consider arming energy agency with tougher regulatory powers; commission chairman Patrick Wood III files response to study in which he generally agrees with criticism and suggestions for change (M)

headline: Microsoft Says Court Should Not Design Computer Systems
abstract: Hearings over Microsoft Corp's antitrust case returns to what has been most hotly contested question since government filed its suit four years ago: Can a court tell company how to design its own software code? America Online vice president John Borthwick urges Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly to require Microsoft to license stripped-down version of its Windows operating system that computer makers and other companies could choose to package with Web browsers, media players and other software components made by Microsoft competitors; Microsoft lawyer Richard C Pepperman, in his cross-examination of Borthwick, says stripping components out of Windows would prevent separate set of third-party programs that depended on them from working (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: Criticism On Censorship
abstract: The Committee to Project Journalists, the international press watchdog based in New York, urged Uzbekistan to release three journalists imprisoned for their work and to stop censorship and harassment of independent reporters. Uzbekistan, an American ally in Central Asia, has been criticized repeatedly by human rights organizations. The press group's statement came after a nine-day tour of the country.   Douglas Frantz (NYT)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Romania: Vampire Theme Park Seeks Funds
abstract: Romania hires PricewaterhouseCoopers to help it find about $30 million of financing needed to build Count Dracula theme park in medieval town of Sighisoara in Transylvania (S)

headline: PrivateSector; Know Your American Monuments And You Won't Go Directly to Jail
abstract: Hasbro Inc introduces new version of Monopoly game, Monopoly: The American Edition; questions about US history, new paper 'money' and national monuments in place of streets and utilities distinguish game from its predecessor; photo of Hasbro chairman Alan G Hassenfeld (M)

headline: Fed Releases March 19 Minutes
abstract: Minutes of Federal Open Market Committee's March 19 meeting show Federal Reserve officials saw 'strong evidence' that economy was recovering from recession and sent signal to investors that interest rates will have to rise at some point (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: RUSSIA: Visa Plan Angers Putin; SCOTLAND: Mandela Visits Lockerbie Bomber; NORTHERN IRELAND: Protestant Fighter Dead; GREECE: Fired Before He Could Quit;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Airline Posts Loss
abstract: British Airways posts pretax loss in fourth quarter of 2001 of 85 million pounds ($124 million), compared with loss of 65 million pounds year earlier; company lost 200 million pounds for all of 2001 (S)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: SOFTWARE AN ACQUISITION BY MICROMUSE Micromuse, which makes software to detect flaws in data networks, announced plans yesterday to acquire RiverSoft, a competitor. Micromuse, a 725-employee operation based in San Francisco, said that the offer for RiverSoft, based in Britain, was for £43.3 million, or $64.7 million. Micromuse said the deal would give it more products and technologies for finding and automatically solving problems in data networks like telephone networks. RiverSoft, which has 166 employees, said in a statement that the boards of both companies had reached an agreement on the offer.   Matt Richtel (NYT) E.D.S. IN $100 MILLION BANK DEAL Electronic Data Systems said yesterday that it had agreed to a $100 million contract to overhaul Bank Leumi's information-technology operations over the next five to seven years. Electronic Data Systems, based in Plano, Tex., said that Bank Leumi, based in Tel Aviv, would receive new software systems and an overhaul of all its major systems. A spokesman for E.D.S. said that the new systems should significantly cut Bank Leumi's operational and maintenance costs and cut the time it takes to move products and services to market. The spokesman said he expected Bank Leumi to recover the cost of the system in five to six years after installation.  (Dow Jones) HARDWARE OAK TECHNOLOGY SHARES FALL The shares of Oak Technology plunged 54 percent yesterday after the company cut its fourth-quarter sales forecast and said it would report a loss. Oak, which designs semiconductors for optical storage and digital imaging, fell $5.38, to $4.52. Sales are expected to be $34 million to $36 million in the quarter ending June 30. Oak Technology, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., had estimated that sales would increase from the third quarter's $42 million, the chief financial officer, John Edmunds, said in a telephone interview. Personal computer makers, facing increased inventories, delayed taking delivery

headline: Fixed-Income Schedule for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week include today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and a four-week bill being auctioned tomorrow.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.71 percent; the six-month issue was 1.89 percent; and the four-week bill was 1.69 percent.

headline: A Collision On Risks Of Energy Trading
abstract: Jones Murphy contends he was fired by Williams Companies, where he worked as risk manager, after repeatedly warning company that company had to reduce its risk in electricity and natural gas trading, especially with shaky counterparties like Enron; says company's employed accounting techniques that gave it great leeway to inflate profits on energy trading; also suggests that Williams succeeded in driving up gas prices in California in December 2000; Williams contends Murphy lacked understanding of company's business; Williams is now teetering -- its share price down sharply and its credit rating under scrutiny -- and plans to sell as much as $1.5 billion in equity and $3 billion in assets over next year to pare its $13 billion debt; photos; graph (L)

headline: A Strong Push Into Europe Lifts Profit Of Ryanair
abstract: Ireland's Ryanair has expanded aggressively in Europe; strategy has paid off in sharp increases in revenue and profit; Ryanair earned 150.4 million euros ($141.8 million) after taxes for fiscal year ended March 31, increase of 44 percent from year earlier; revenue rose 28 percent, to 624.1 million euros ($588.7 million); photo (M)

headline: Why Vote for Le Pen? A French Village Is Tight-Lipped
abstract: In Gisors, France, picturesque village 40 miles from Paris, 21 percent of those who voted cast ballots for right-wing extremist Jean-Marie Le Pen, but few will admit to it or even identify themselves to reporter; those who will talk say they agree with Le Pen that immigration is big problem; others say they voted for Le Pen in first round of elections to get attention of government; some insist they will continue to support Le Pen when he faces Pres Jacque Chirac in May 5 runoff; photos; map (M)

headline: Powell Begins A Crucial Trip To the Mideast
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell leaves for Middle East on one of most urgent and challenging attempts at American peacemaking in years; admits trip will be difficult; says it will not result in peace treaty, and maybe not even cease-fire; says goal is to help both sides out of tragic situation in which they find themselves; will meet first with moderate Arab leaders of Morocco, Saudi Arabia and Egypt; will ask them to step up pressure on Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat to halt suicide bombings that have led to Israeli military incursions; will meet with leaders of European Union and UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan, who have chided Bush administration for diplomatic reticence in its handling of crisis; will meet with Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon on final stop; hopes Israel will have taken meaningful steps by then to withdraw from Palestinian areas and that Arafat will have kept violence under control long enough to merit meeting (M)

headline: Protection on Doctor Bills
abstract: Joseph R Baker III letter on May 12 article notes New York law bars health care providers who participate in HMO's from billing members because of late payment by HMO

headline: Consumer Confidence Slips Less Than Expected; Incomes Rise
abstract: University of Michigan sentiment gauge reveals that consumer confidence fell less than expected in June, to 92.4, from 96.9 in May; Commerce Department reports 0.3 percent rise in May incomes (M)

headline: U.S.B. Device Gives Mac Users Another Wireless Option
abstract: USB device from D-Link and free software from Apple allow owners of newer Macintosh computers to use Bluetooth, short-distance wireless system; Apple will support only limited number of tasks for Bluetooth; photo (M)

headline: Ulster Violence Prompts a Call For Crisis Talks
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, order emergency talks with political parties in Northern Ireland over rising violence and deepening political distrust in province (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Profit Warning Hurts Veritas
abstract: Shares of Veritas Software Corp fell $5.90, to $30.96, day after company lowers its estimate for second-quarter earnings; says net income for first quarter was $44 million compared with loss of $156 million year earlier; revenue was $370 million compared with $387 million in 2001 quarter (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: G.M.'s Profit Drops 3.8% But Exceeds Expectations  The revival of General Motors continued as it reported a slight decrease in earnings, well above analysts' expectations, despite financial difficulties at its European unit. G.M. reported net income of $228 million, or 57 cents a share, with sales of $46.3 billion. That was down 3.8 percent from a year earlier. The company also raised its 2002 earnings estimate to $5 a share from $3.50. G.M.'s shares rose almost 5 percent, to $64.05. [Page C4.]    Bristol's Financial Officer Resigns  Bristol-Myers Squibb, struggling to recover from a series of disappointments, said that Frederick S. Schiff, its chief financial officer, would leave. Harrison M. Bains, vice president for tax and treasury, will serve as acting chief financial officer. [C2.]

headline: Edison Schools In Settlement With S.E.C.
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission says Edison Schools, nation's largest commercial operator of public schools and pioneer in field of for-profit school management, provided inaccurate information about its past revenue and maintained inadequate financial controls; also discloses that Edison agreed to settlement with commission that requires company, without admitting wrongdoing, to revise way it reports its revenue and to hire internal audit manager to strengthen its financial procedures; imposes no financial penalties; commission's announcement comes less than half hour before conference call by Edison executives that is intended to reassure investors, educators and parents that recent steep decline in Edison's stock price will not derail company's plans to take over 20 failing schools in Philadelphia this summer or impair its nationwide operations; founder-chief executive H Christopher Whittle says company is in discussions to raise $30 million to $50 million from unidentified investor; adds company will sharply scale back it pace of growth after coming school year, from more than 60 percent per year to about 30 percent (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: JOHN NUVEEN CO., Chicago, a manager of municipal bond funds, said it would buy NWQ Investment Management, a specialist in stock investing, from Old Mutual, London, an insurer, for $140 million in cash.    IMPAX LABORATORIES INC., Hayward, Calif., a maker of pharmaceutical products, received tentative approval for a generic version of the allergy drug Claritin-D. Final F.D.A. approval depends on the outcome of a patent lawsuit brought against Impax by Schering-Plough Corp., Madison, N.J., the maker of Claritin-D.
