headline: MediaTalk; PBS Anchor: Network News Is Expendable
abstract: PBS television news anchor Jim Lehrer says we may be moving to time when major commercial broadcast networks will get out of news business and leave informing to others, University of Pennsylvania commencement speech; questions focus of all-news cable channels; photo (M)

headline: PwC Consulting Selects Agencies
abstract: PwC Consulting, part of PricewaterhouseCoopers, selects offices of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos and McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising to handle worldwide creative assignments, including campaign to introduce new name for unit; spending estimated at $80 million to $100 million (S)

headline: James Cramer Says He Was Often Bad, but Not That Bad
abstract: Books about James J Cramer's approach to stock markets by Cramer and by former employee Nicholas W Maier take divergent views over ethics of Cramer's insider status; Cramer, who has already forced Maier's book publisher HarperCollins to retract some of most serious allegations in book, Trading With the Enemy, vows to sue; Cramer accuses HarperCollins executives of deliberately attacking him as part of larger corporate vendetta, because he appears on rival to Fox News Channel, which, like HarperCollins, is part of News Corp; Cramer is co-founder of TheStreet.com and talk-show host on CNBC; photos (M)

headline: Violent Mexico Kidnapper Held After a Nine-Month Manhunt
abstract: Pedro Barragán González, the man considered to be one of Mexico's most violent kidnappers, is under arrest.

headline: A NATION CHALLENGED: Briefly Noted; RUMSFELD'S TRIP
abstract: Sec Donald Rumsfeld to visit Afghanistan and other Central Asian nations, with stop in Moscow (S)

headline: KINDRED BUYING SPECIALTY HEALTHCARE FOR $45 MILLION
abstract: Kindred Healthcare buys Specialty Healthcare Services for $45 million to expand capacity by 8 percent (S)

headline: A Violent Death Exposes Fish Piracy in Russia
abstract: Russian government has lost control over fishing on its Pacific coast, where fishermen thwart government quotas and taxes by taking their catches directly to Japan and South Korea; Gen Vitaly Gamov of Russian border patrol, who sought to stop illegal fishing, died of burns received in May when three flaming jars of gasoline were thrown through his kitchen window; death shows difficulties Pres Vladimir V Putin faces in drive to break corrupt links between business and government; illegal fishing costs Russia $500 million a year in lost tax revenue, and evidence of declining fish stock abounds; photos; map (M)

headline: Italian Pasta Maker Bids For Big German Baker
abstract: Barilla offers to acquire Kamps of Germany, Europe's leading baker, for 994 million euros ($875 million) and assumption of $704 million in debt; Kamps executives and founding family members, who together own 15 perent of company, reject bid as too low; photos (S)

headline: A Lifetime of Making Split Ends Meet
abstract: Personal Business interview with Libby Munro Christensen, Scottish-born hair stylist who owns Chelsea Set in Maplewood, New Jersey; photo (S)

headline: After Shootings, Germany Seeks to Ban Violent Computer Games
abstract: German Government, responding to deaths of 16 people in Apr school shooting, Erfurt, proposes giving regulators right to ban violent computer games; proposed bill would let government agency that already regulates distribution of written material ban software deemed seriously dangerous to children, especially material depicting extreme violence; seeks ways to extend regulation to Internet; bill would also create computer game rating system (M)

headline: Negotiations By Andersen With KPMG Fall Apart
abstract: Negotiations to sell much of Arthur Andersen's foreign division to KPMG collapse, potentially cutting off one of few financial lifelines available to firm in wake of Enron debacle; Andersen Worldwide offices are already splitting off in virtual free-for-all of sales to competitors, drastically dimming prospects that enterprise will survive as unit, either alone or inside another firm; Andersen Espana -- Spanish unit and crown jewel in firm's world empire -- strikes its own deal with Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu; Andersen's board of managers calls for managers in each country where company maintains operations to attend meeting in London on April 4, and they are expected to discuss whether Andersen should revoke financial restrictions on sale of offices that increase cost for competitors; newly released documents show that a top Andersen partner, Carl Bass, expressed deep concerns dating back as far as 1999 about certain accounting used by Enron (M)

headline: Xerox to Restate $1.9 Billion in Revenue
abstract: Xerox Corp. inflated revenue by $1.9 billion over the past five years by misreporting the timing and makeup of equipment sales.

headline: INVESTING WITH: Bernard R. Horn Jr.; Polaris Global Value Fund
abstract: Carole Gould Investing With column describes investment style and philosophy of Polaris Global Value Fund manager Bernard R Horn Jr; photo; table; graph (M)

headline: Article 2002042392699266276 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                       International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics             Business           -      Media & Advertising            -      World Business            -      Your Money            -      Markets            -      Company Research            -      Mutual Funds            -      Stock Portfolio            -      Columns               Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Cement Stake
abstract: International Finance Corp, part of World Bank, plans to acquire as much as 13 percent of Cia de Cemento Argos SA of Colombia for $60 million to help Colombia's economy at time of political violence (S)

headline: Accidental Blast Kills 4 American Soldiers in Afghanistan
abstract: At least four American soldiers are killed and one wounded in Afghan desert outside Kandahar in accidental explosion while bomb-disposal unit was destroying captured weapons; US warplanes stage attacks on Iraqi air defense unit that fired on American warplanes patrolling no-flight zone; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld comments; photo (M)

headline: Agreement For Takeover Of Daewoo
abstract: General Motors Corp and creditors of Daewoo Motor, bankrupt Korean carmaker, reach detailed understanding on takeover of most of Daewoo; Daewoo's cerditors will set up escrow fund of $297 million to pay off any hidden Daewoo debts that might emerge; GM also succeeds in narrowing scope of deal to exclude some overseas Daewoo Motor properties that it did not want, notably plant in Egypt; removing unwanted assets lowers by $600 million overall value put on assets GM will acquire, to about $1.7 billion; GM will also not take on $260 million in debts that original plan called for it to assume; GM is to pay only $400 million of $1.7 billion purchase price (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: A Nation Reshaped
abstract: Parliament overwhelmingly endorsed a looser union between the two remaining republics. Constitutional experts now have to work out the exact structure of the new state, to be called Serbia and Montenegro, which was created under pressure from the European Union to stave off a Montenegrin independence bid and to discourage other Balkan separatists, especially in Kosovo, a province of Serbia. Serbia and Montenegro will be broadly autonomous but share a president, cabinet and army; either can leave the union after three years.   Daniel Simpson (NYT)

headline: $2 Million in U.S. Aid Is Missing From Colombian Police Fund
abstract: Columbian police oust Gen Gustavo Socha, official in charge of their antinarcotics efforts, and six other police officials after $2 million in United States aid funds is reported missing from special police administrative account; US official says as many as 20 police officers may have been pocketing money from account, which has been frozen since US officials discovered malfeasance two months ago and US suspended small portion of its aid for drug-eradication efforts; Colombia opens criminal probe; Jorge Enrique Linares is named to head antinarcotics unit (M)

headline: Ad Slump at AOL to Cause Parent to Miss 2002 Goals
abstract: AOL Time Warner reports $54.2 billion loss in first quarter, among biggest quarterly losses in corporate history; loss was $1.4 billion in quarter year earlier; revenue increased 7.1 percent, to $9.8 billion from $9.1 billion; company says it will not achieve its original financial goals for 2002 because online advertising market has deteriorated even further than it had expected; Richard D Parsons, who is to succeed Gerald M Levin as chief executive next month, comments (M)

headline: In Bush's Words: A New Call to Mutual Defense
abstract: Excerpts from Pres Bush's speech to German Parliament (M)

headline: Conservative Challenger Attacks German Chancellor
abstract: The conservative challenger for the German leadership launched an attack today on the current chancellor.

headline: Weighed Down By Its Troubles, Adelphia Nears Bankruptcy
abstract: Analysis of problems at Adelphia Communications that are expected to force it to file for bankruptcy; never-ending accusations of improprieties on part of Rigas family, controlling shareholders, proved too much for potential investors; Adelphia must now reorganize under fractured board while also facing other issues, including need to sell assets to raise money and likelihood of lawsuits from disgruntled shareholders and bondholders (M)

headline: Vivendi Chief Gets an Earful From Unhappy Shareholders
abstract: Vivendi Universal SA chief Jean-Marie Messier reports better-than-expected 15 percent increase in revenue for company's media and telecommunications businesses, compared with last year's first quarter, despite boos and hecking at shareholders meeting; revenue for those businesses was 6.8 billion euros, up from 5.9 billion euros last year; operating profit, on pro forma basis, was up 27 percent, to 436 million euros ($389 million), compared with 2001 first quarter; shareholders approve Canal Plus chief executive Pierre Lescure's dismissal by percentage of 55 to 45; also reject plan to set aside 5 percent of company's shares for executive stock options; photo (M)

headline: Tyco Sues Ex-Lawyer And Director
abstract: Tyco International files suit against former general counsel Mark A Belnick and former lead independent director Frank E Walsh Jr contending in separate cases that men wrongly took millions of dollars from company; suit alleges Belnick was paid $20 million that was not disclosed to Tyco's board and received $14.9 million in no-interest loans under program that was supposed to pay for employee moving expenses; more than $10 million in loans went to Belnick's purchase of vacation home in Utah; Belnick allegedly falsified records so that this pay and bonuses would not be disclosed to Securities and Exchange Commission; suit contends Belnick refused to cooperate with company's internal probe into undisclosed pay and benefits to former chairman L Dennis Kozlowski and other executives; suit demands Belnick immediately repay loans and any other misappropriated money; Walsh and charity he controlled allegedly received $20 million bonus from Tyco in 2001 that was not disclosed to Tyco's board; Walsh, who led committee that determined pay of Kozlowski, asked Kozlowski personally for bonus; Kozlowski approved it without consulting anyone else; suit demands Walsh return $20 million, plus interest; representatives for Belnick and Walsh deny accusations (M)

headline: Market Place; Possible Savior Returns to AOL As Its Growth Appears Weak
abstract: AOL Time Warner says co-chief operating officer Robert W Pittman will resume day-to-day management of company's America Online Internet service, 15 months after giving up post; move underscores sense of urgency about America Online's slowing growth; it may also end rumors that Pittman might leave AOL Time Warner when Parson's becomes chief executive next month; move makes clear that America Online unit will be Pittman's main priority; Barry Schuler, America Online's chairman and chief executive, is reassigned to lead new division that will focus on developing interactive digital services; suggests that Pittman might not retain day-to-day oversight of America Online for long term; photo (M)

headline: SAUDI TELLS BUSH U.S. MUST TEMPER BACKING OF ISRAEL
abstract: Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia tells Pres Bush bluntly that United States must temper its support for Israel or face grave consequences throughout Arab world; Saudi officials at meeting at president's ranch in Texas say Abdullah warned that US would continue to lose credibility in Middle East and create more instability there unless it did more to stop Israel's incursions into Palestinian areas; Adel al-Jubeir, Abdullah's foreign policy adviser, says Prime Min Ariel Sharon wants to drag region 'over a cliff'; American officials offer far more positive account of meetings; Pres Bush says he and crown prince formed 'strong personal bond'; both Bush and Jubeir say crown prince did not threaten in any way to reduce Saudi oil exports to US; Bush, who infuriated Arab world week ago by calling Sharon 'a man of peace,' says he told Abdullah he is counting on Israel to withdraw forces from Palestinian areas, including resolving standoffs in Ramallah and Bethlehem; photo (M)

headline: Canadian Leader Attacked In a Loud Ethics Brouhaha
abstract: Prime Min Jean Chretien freezes dozens of government contracts, reorganizes his cabinet and issues new rules on political donations and conflicts of interest; he is struggling to contain worst ethics controversy to face his Liberal Party in years, involving what opposition calls pattern of government ministers' handing out contracts to friends and companies who donate to party; Globe and Mail, Canada's most influential newspaper, calls for Chretien to resign; he has held office since 1993 and will probably survive crisis, but controversy has already intensified jostling among party politicians likely to use gathering of Liberals in Feb to position themselves as his successor (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Deloitte Is Said To Face Inquiry Over Adelphia
abstract: Fiasco at Adelphia Communications is posing problems for its auditor Deloitte & Touche; Securities and Exchange Commission, which has been investigating Adelphia's dealings with Rigas family and why company failed to disclose more than $3 billion in transactions with entities controlled by family, has begun separate inquiry into Deloitte's role; Deloitte is bracing for almost guaranteed wave of lawsuits by disgruntled shareholders whose investments have plunged in value in wake of Adelphia's debacle; analysts say Deloitte is in especially precarious position because it appears that it not only acted as accountant for Adelphia but also was auditor for Rigas-controlled entities; Deloitte declines comment (M)

headline: Business; Venture Capitalists See Investors Grow Mutinous
abstract: Article on rising tensions between venture capitalists and investors since Internet bubble burst in 2000; many venture capitalists are still doing well for themselves because of large management fees collected from investors, even as investors have watched lush profits shrivel; photo (M)

headline: Ex-Envoy Faults Salvador Army Over Torture
abstract: Robert E White, former United States ambassador to El Salvador, testifies in civil suit brought by Salvadorans who accuse their country's military of torturing them two decades ago; says failure of military leaders to rein in murderous troops has been biggest obstacle to democracy; says senior officers not only ignored repeated American admonishments but even appeared to encourage killing of civilians in name of fighting leftist insurgents; defendants in case are Jose Guillermo Garcia, former defense minister, and Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova, former director of National Guard; both are retired generals who were colonels at time (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  Consumer Price Index: May  Housing Construction: May

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline Merger Approved
abstract: Fair Trade Commission approves merger of Japan Airline and Japan Air System, country's No. 1 and No. 3 carriers (S)

headline: Bush's Statement Received Favorably in Europe
abstract: LONDON, April 4 — President Bush's statement on the Middle East was received favorably tonight in Europe, where sentiment has been running high that the United States must put pressure on its Israeli ally to curb military actions against the Palestinians and to end the isolation of Yasir Arafat.

headline: A Pull Felt by Dads as Well: Staying Home
abstract: Lis

headline: Companies Trim Health Benefits For Many Retirees as Costs Surge
abstract: Surging inflation in medical costs prompts many large employers to cut back on health care benefits for retirees, or to require them to pay more for coverage; reductions in health benefits stem mainly from sudden sharp increases in employer spending on prescription drugs last year; drugs account for 40 to 60 percent of employers' overall spending on Medicare-age retirees' health care; Medicare health maintenance organizations, which used to provide generous benefits, including drug coverage, have made far-reaching cutbacks, forcing employers to pay for retirees' drug coverage, since traditional Medicare does not cover cost of most drugs; as result, current health care costs for retirees are soaring 18 percent a year, on average, and large companies' liabilities for future health care costs for retirees are rising as much as 34 percent; many medium-size companies have stopped promising retiree health care coverage to new hires; photos; chart (L)

headline: Palestinians Convict 4 in Killing, but Sharon Dismisses Trial
abstract: Palestinians today announced they had tried and convicted four men accused of assassinating an Israeli government minister.

headline: Mission Control for the Living Room
abstract: Consumer electronics makers, personal-computer hardware and software developers and set-top box designers are set to battle for control of living room with range of game systems, audio centers, set-top boxes and digital video recorders; face challenge of making home networking experience effortless from couch; new entertainment servers all include microprocessor, networking capability, graphical user interface and huge hard drive; photos; drawing (M)

headline: Ex-Governor to Look Into Union Stock Deal
abstract: Board of Ullico, union-owned insurance company, names former Illinois Gov James R Thompson to investigate private sale of comapny stock that resulted in big profits for its directors; federal grand jury in Washington is investigating whether Ullico's sale and subsequent repurchase of its stock enabled several union presidents on its board to enrich themselves improperly at expense of labor unions, which are company's chief shareholders (M)

headline: ISRAEL SURROUNDS ARAFAT COMPOUND IN A PREDAWN RAID
abstract: Israeli forces re-enter Ramallah on West Bank: encircle headquarters of Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat and put entire city under curfew; Army says move is to block those it seeks to arrest from taking refuge; wrecks most of compound with bulldozers and explosive charges; reports arrests of nine suspected terrorists in house-to-house searches; raids come on eve of Prime Min Ariel Sharon's meeting with Pres Bush in Washington immediately after Camp David meeting between Bush and Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Amazon is told not to help anyone fake results ever again.
abstract: Seurities and Exchange Commission does not charge Amazon.com with faking its own books in connection with its Amazon Commerce Network, alliance of other Internet sites in which Amazon invested and received advertising revenue; SEC concludes that Amazon did help one of those companies falsify its books; Amazon accepts cease-and-desist order from SEC, ordering it not to help anyone else violate securities laws (M)

headline: Private Sector; A Hip Toyota, by His Design
abstract: Profile of Craig Kember, 28-year-old lead designer at Toyota Motor Corp and embodiment of its current campaign to attract younger car buyers; photo with Toyota Matrix, small sports wagon; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Steel Strike Ends
abstract: BHP Billiton Ltd says 24-hour strike at its Western Port factory in Australia ends, allowing its steel unit to resume supplies to customers including automakers Toyota, Ford Motor and Mitsubishi; strike threatened to stop production at Australia's four biggest automakers (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Bill Blummer was named vice president for United States sales at the New York office of Terra Lycos, succeeding Rich Gotham, who resigned.

headline: The Top Editor Is Departing MSNBC.com
abstract: Merrill Brown, founding editor who led MSNBC.com

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mbeki Pledges Leadership On Aids
abstract: Pres Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, who has questioned safety of commonly prescribed AIDS drugs and causes of the disease, says he is prepared to provide greater leadership on issue and urges people to practice safe sex to help combat country's leading epidemic; photo (S)

headline: At Least 30 Killed in Kashmir by Suspected Islamic Militants
abstract: Three heavily armed men killed 30 people today and wounded 48 in wild sprays of gunfire on the outskirts of Jammu.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Fears Over Dengue Fever
abstract: Guatemalan health officials declare national alert against dengue fever after tallying 789 cases, Jan-May; urge people to clean homes to stop breeding mosquitoes that carry potentially fatal disease (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Top Chechen Reported Killed
abstract: Russia's Federal Security Service says it killed Arab-born Chechen field commander known as Khattab, suspected of links to Al Qaeda, in operation in mid-March; past reports of Khattab's death have proved false; he is accused of torturing and executing Russian prisoners (S)

headline: S.& P. Plans a Hedge Fund Index
abstract: Standard & Poor's to create hedge fund index (S)

headline: U.S. Regulators Are Requiring Full Details Of Energy Sales
abstract: New rule adopted by Federal Energy Regulatory Commission will force electricity traders to report individual transactions in detail beginning in July, preventing them from concealing sort of fake 'round-trip' trades that have allowed large energy producers to inflate their volumes and revenue; Sen Joseph I Lieberman, chairman of Governmental Affairs Committee, discloses that Federal Energy Regulatory Commission investigated Enron's online-trading system last year but concluded that 'chance of Enron failing financially was remote'; says internal report by commission in August raises serious concerns about Enron's online-trading system, including 'competitive advantage' it gave Enron's traders; lawyer Stephen Hall, author of December 2000 memorandums that outlined how Enron traders had increased profits by manipulating California electricity markets, says in testimony prepared for Congress that upon learning of tactics, he immediately warned Enron officials, including company head trader, that maneuvers were deceptive and should be stopped; Hall was helping Enron prepare for litigation and investigations in California; California Atty Gen Bill Lockyer says there are newly uncovered documents that originated in late 2000 which outline schemes to manipulate energy prices; says documents discuss trading stategies described in Enron memos released last week and include handwritten notes by Enron's head West Coast trader; notes suggest that Enron made large sums trading electricity in California (M)

headline: When Conceiving New Products, 300 Brains Are Better Than One
abstract: My column in last week's Circuits featured nine ideas for high-tech products that don't exist but should. Once again, the e-mail response from you, the readers, shows that 300 brains are mightier than one.

headline: Brokers Caught in Cross-Fire In Client Suits Against Merrill
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co's 14,000 brokers are caught in cross-fire as brokerage firm prepares to defend itself in court against angry investors; Merrill still faces lawsuits from customers who contend that they lost money because they were misled by recommendations of firm's analysts; estimates of Merrill's liability in those cases run as high as $5 billion and are weighing heavily on Merrill's stock price, which has dropped nearly 30 percent since April; graph (M)

headline: Dutch Report Criticizes U.N., Not Soldiers, in Bosnia Massacre
abstract: Netherlands Institute for War Documentation five-year probe into 1995 massacre of over 6,000 unarmed Muslim men and boys by Bosnian Serb forces in Srebrenica, Bosnia, finds small contingent of Dutch peacekeepers defending United Nations safe area were powerless to stop killings; institute head Hans Blom tells Dutch Parliament that Dutch government, military commanders and UN share responsibility; report holds Dutch troops knew more about murderous intent of Serbs than reported and offered no opposition when Serbs separated men and women; finds they were outmanned and under instructions not to actively defend enclave (M)

headline: Article 2002042393765369617 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                       International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business             Technology           -    E-Business          -      Circuits            -      Columns               Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: India Success In Software Is Set Back By War Talk
abstract: Threat of war with Pakistan is taking toll on India's computer software industry; new business is drying up because foreign clients, mainly Americans, are avoiding travel to region; companies in Bagalore, main technology center, are rushing to shore up disaster recovery plans, even though city is far from Pakistan; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: England: Progress Reported In Lockerbie Talks
abstract: British, American and Libyan officials make progress in London to work out compensation for families of 270 victims of bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988 (S)

headline: Rightist's Showing in French Election Deplored Across Europe
abstract: Europeans of widely varying political persuasions deplore rise of Jean-Marie Le Pen and his National Front in France and say that although he stands little chance of becoming president in runoff, his preliminary success is cause for concern across Continent; many commentators use words like 'shame,' 'blemish' and 'embarrassment' for France, noting French have often been quick to spot failings and excesses in its neighbors (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Rebels Kill More Than 50
abstract: Maoist rebels attack police posts in western Nepal, killing at least 48 policemen and 6 passengers on bus (S)3

headline: Burnett and Images End Relationship
abstract: Leo Burnett USA, lead agency for US Army, and Images USA end agreement under which images created Army campaigns aimed at attracting black recruits; Army spends $5 million to $6 million on advertising focused on blacks and $95 million over all (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: New Economic Chief Appointed
abstract: Jeon Yun Churl is named finance minister of South Korea; promises to pursue reforms as part of market-oriented economic policy (S)

headline: MOTOROLA FORECASTS A SECOND CONSECUTIVE ANNUAL LOSS
abstract: Motorola Inc proxy statement filed with Securities and Exchange Commission says company expects to post annual loss of 2002, its second consecutive one, after accounting for 'special items' (S)

headline: U.S. Backs New Trade Rules on Drugs
abstract: US says it will back revision of global trading rules that would allow poor countries to import patented drugs quickly and cheaply to deal with health crises like AIDS; 144 members of World Trade Organization begins three days of meetings in Geneva on topic (M)

headline: Boeing Wins $4.4 Billion Contract in Korea
abstract: Boeing Co wins $4.4 billion contract to supply 40 F-15 fighter jets to South Korea; photo (M)

headline: White House Hints That U.S. May Increase Middle East Role
abstract: The Bush administration showed signs today of bending to criticism that it must get more involved in the Middle East crisis.

headline: Threat Is Seen to Microsoft Windows
abstract: Massachusetts Institute of Technology Prof Stuart E Madnick says Microsoft Corp's Windows software could collapse under antitrust proposal by nine states to strip Internet Explorer from operating systems; testifies that it would be 'difficult, if not impossible,' to carry out states' proposal for 'modular' version of Windows that lets computer makers easily remove programs like Internet Explorer or Windows Media Player; Madnick, under cross-examination, acknowledges that Internet Explorer was not bundled into Windows when operating system was first offered in 1995 (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Computer Network Expects A Loss
abstract: Computer Network Technology Corp says it will post loss for its first quater; shares close at $6.97, down $1.80; graph (S)

headline: Online Gallery Is on the Block: Visitors Came, but Didn't Buy
abstract: Eyestorm.com, online art gallery, has been declared insolvent; chairman David Ross confirms company is being liquidated (M)

headline: Article 2002042090427392377 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology Text Version         function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                            International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business             Technology           -      E-Business            -      Circuits            -      Columns               Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: Fears of War Roil India's Stock Markets
abstract: India's stock markets slump for eighth consecutive session as India and Pakistan appears to teeter on brink of war; Bombay's benchmark market falls 1.9 percent, to its lowest close since November; index has fallen 9 percent since May 14, when gunmen stormed family headquarters of army camp in state of Jammu and Kashmir, killing 32 people; India's Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee rules out any negotiations with Pakistan over Kashmir, and Indian rupee slides to new closing low of 49.05 against dollar; Pakistan's Karachi Stock Exchange suspends trading after 14 percent decline over three previous days; central bank sells dollars to support its currency; graph (M)

headline: Telecommunications Issues Fall Sharply
abstract: Investors in troubled telecommunications sector step up selling of their shares; hardest hit are Qwest Communications International and WorldCom, companies with heavy debt loads and enough questions about their accounting to be subjects of investigations by Securities and Exchange Commission; but companies like Verizon Communications, SBC Communications and BellSouth, which had fared well by comparison this year, sag under selling pressure (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: New Central Bankers
abstract: Japan's government names Toshikatsu Fukuma and Hidehiko Haru to Bank of Japan's policy board, replacing Toshio Miki and Nobuyuki Nakahara, whose terms expired; new appointees back board's extremely loose monetary stance, news conference (S)

headline: The New Yorker: Add Hard News, Hold the Glitter
abstract: David Remnick's stewardship as New Yorker magazine editor assessed as magazine is up for 9 National Magazine Awards; his news-driven, high-tempo version of magazine is short on historical idiosyncrasies; his steady approach seems to have ensured magazine's future; circulation graph; photos (M)

headline: Discord Over Killing of India Muslims Deepens
abstract: Leaders of India's Hindu nationalist-led government warn Western nations in recent days to cease lecturing country about official failure to prevent Hindu mobs from killing hundreds of Muslims, but issue refuses to die; more than 40 people have perished in continuous violence in western state of Gujarat in past week, with official death toll rising in last two months to 900; more than 100,000 people, mostly Muslims, are estimated to have fled to relief camps; maps (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: 4 Charged With Defrauding Banks of Over $600 Million  Four New Jersey men were charged with defrauding banks of more than $600 million through an international scheme to secure loans for illusory metal-trading deals, federal authorities said.    Prosecutors said the men presented themselves to banks as brokers of metals-trading deals and created the illusion of legitimate transactions by creating shell companies, fabricating documents and recruiting people to pose as customers. [Page C2.]    Higher Profits for Hewlett-Packard  Hewlett-Packard reported higher profits in its second quarter despite weak revenue amid sluggish corporate spending on computer technology. It also delivered a sober outlook for the rest of the year saying it was ''not counting on a meaningful improvement'' in technology spending until 2003. The report was its last as a stand-alone company. [C4.]

headline: MASCO BUYS 5 MAKERS OF WINDOW AND PLUMBING PARTS
abstract: Masco Corp buys five window and plumbing parts makers in California and Britain for about $220 million (S)

headline: A Radical Overhaul for South African Mining
abstract: Parliament will begin final work on bill to give South Africa ultimate ownership of all of nation's mineral resources, which mining companies would then exploit only under license, giving state final say on mining; move is aimed at turning mines into engines of economic betterment for more of black majority; photo (M)

headline: Northrop Takes Steps Toward Friendly Deal With TRW
abstract: Northrop Grumman is planning to hold talks with top executives of TRW about negotiating friendly takeover deal after Northrop's $6.7 billion hostile bid is rejected by TRW shareholders; TRW chairman Philip A Odeen comments; photo (M)a

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Isuzu Raises Loss Forecast
abstract: Isuzu Motors raises its forecast for expected loss in fiscal year ended March 31 as truck sales slumped; expects to lose 43 billion yen ($335 million) (S)

headline: Thousands March in Washington in Support of Palestinians
abstract: Tens of thousands of Arab-Americans rally in Washington, urging American policy not to support Israel's actions in West Bank; days before, large rally in support of Israel took place at same space on Washington's spacious Mall; photo (M)

headline: CARDINAL HEALTH TO BUY SYNCOR FOR $900 MILLION
abstract: Cardinal Health Inc to buy Syncor International Corp, radioactive diagnostic materials maker, for about $900 million in stock; will also assume $202 million in Syncor debt (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Flat Outlook At Electrolux
abstract: Electrolux, world's largest maker of home appliances, expects no sales growth in industry this year as falling demand in Europe wipes out recovery in US; company says net income before one-time gains rose 15 percent, to 1.23 billion kronor ($120 million) in first quarter (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: NATO Countries Approve Pact Giving Russia Role of a Partner
abstract: NATO today approved an agreement accepting Russia into a new partnership on terrorism, arms control and crisis management.

headline: Venezuelan Says Revolt Hasn't Derailed His Plans
abstract: Pres Hugo Chavez of Venezuela says experience of being ousted from office in popular uprising, then restored to power two days later, has not fundamentally changed him, int; short-lived coup exposed country's raw and angry divisions between great masses of poor people who support Chavez and antagonized middle and upper class that despises him; Chavez says economy will grow and that his government is firmly in place; he has, since his return, asked opposition, which he often denigrated in past, to join his government in 'great debate' and has promised to 'sheathe' his sword, acknowledging that his harsh language has hurt people; says relations with United States are strained because of suggestions that American officials were involved in coup; Bush administration has denied playing any role in Chavez's removal, and Chavez himself says he hopes those rumors are false; photo (M)

headline: A Russian Rights Crusader, Made by Mary Kay
abstract: Saturday Profile of Anya Vanina, unlikely civil liberties campaigner in her small village of Plyussa, in forested corner of northwest Russia; interview; photo; Vanina, 39, steely-willed woman with soft voice, is part of new generation of Russian dissidents speakig out against injustices arising from pervasive economic decay; she explains inspiration from Mary Kay cosmetics company, which she says shows respect for individuals and self-worth

headline: Unloading His Books, But Not His Conscience
abstract: Fred Bernstein article on ethics of Amazon.com urging its customers to resell their used books through Amazon; notes Authors Guild opposes strategy because authors make no money on resales; compares his experiences with reselling books to used bookstore and online; drawing (M)

headline: U.S. Prosecutors in Newark Join Investigation of Schering
abstract: United States attorney's office in Newark is investigating how Schering-Plough Corp manufactures one or more prescription drug products; investigation is said to concern whether company uses imported, relatively inexpensive chemical ingredients not approved fr use in US in its products (M)

headline: ISRAEL LIFTS SIEGE AS ARAFAT YIELDS SIX WANTED MEN
abstract: Palestinians trapped for month in Yasir Arafat's humbled compound in Ramallah erupt in celebration after Israeli forces withdraw as part of American-brokered compromise; almost simultaneously, gunfight breaks out at Church of Nativity in Bethlehem, setting off fires in church compound where Palestinian gunmen and noncombatants have been under Israeli siege since early Apr; Arafat explodes in rage at news from Bethlehem; gunfight subsides quickly and fire is put out, but skirmish and Arafat's obvious suspicion that Israel is double-dealing underscores how distant even a truce remains; Israeli troops have now withdrawn to outskirts of all West Bank towns but Bethlehem; photos; map (M)

headline: New Web of Trust Topples a Mighty Mexican Cartel
abstract: Crackdown by coalition of Mexican and American prosecutors has caused downfall of multibillion-dollar cocaine cartel run by Benjamin and Ramon Arellano Felix; just last summer Benjamin Arellano Felix could be seen drinking tequilla with senior Mexican police officials long in his pay; he and top confederates wielded more power and influence in drug trade from Mexico into US than any other group; now Ramon is dead and rest are all in jail; bringing down Arellano Felix dons seen as biggest victory in years in bloody drug war Mexican had seemed certain to lose; chronology of events; photos (M)

headline: Diplomatic Problems Stall Japanese Food Aid to North Korea
abstract: North Korea has relied on international donations to feed its people since famine struck in 1995, but now big donors are reluctant to pledge new food aid, even if that means ending programs to feed more than million schoolchildren and elderly people; Japan, most important holdout, is reportedly calculating that North Korea's vulnerability offers historic opportunity for breakthroughs on range of diplomatic problems; publicly, major donors have long insisted that politics should not dictate emergency relief decisions; even Bush administration, which calls North Korea part of 'axis of evil,' has met its pledged commitments to country for year; Japan sees renewed food crisis as chance to resolve series of major irritants with North Korea (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Schering-Plough Agrees To Pay $500 Million Fine  The drug maker Schering-Plough has agreed to pay a $500 million fine because of its repeated failure to fix problems in manufacturing dozens of drugs at four factories. If approved by the court, the agreement would impose, by far, the largest financial penalty on a drug company for failing to follow guidelines.    The agreement relates to violations dating as far back as 1998 that inspectors have found at plants in New Jersey and Puerto Rico. The violations involve some 200 medicines, including Claritin, the allergy medicine that is Schering's top-selling product. [Page A1.]

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Vodafone Considers Write-Offs
abstract: Vodafone Group says it will provide more details on whether it will write down value of some recent acquisitions, including April 2000 purchase of Mannesmann for $168 billion, when it reports earnings for 2002 on May 28 (S)

headline: ISRAELIS BROADEN WEST BANK RAIDS AS ARABS PROTEST
abstract: Israeli soldiers and tanks pour into West Bank as Palestinians continue attacks and as angry demonstrations spread across Arab world against Prime Min Ariel Sharon's all-out campaign to quash intifada; Army attacks headquarters of Jibril Rajoub, powerful Palestinian security chief in West Bank; moves into Bethlehem and Tulkarm with scores of tanks, armored personnel carriers and armored bulldozers backed by infantry; troops in Qalqilya reinforce positions and begin house to house searches; armored vehicles are stationed in Beit Jala, largely Christian hilltop village within range of Jewish settlement of Gilo; Palestinian sniper kills Israeli in Har Homa housing development built on land conquered in 1967; suicide bomber blows self up in car at junction between East and West Jerusalem, killing policeman; 11 Arabs accused of collaborating with Israel are executed by Palestinians in West Bank; Israeli Army reports rounding up more than 700 people in Ramallah, where Yasir Arafat remains besieged in two rooms of wrecked headquarters for fourth day; city's residents are running out of food and water and hospital is running out of supplies; fighting in and around city described; Israeli Government bars body of mediators from UN, US, European Union and Russia from meeting with Arafat; says Arafat will remain isolated until end of terrorist threat; Palestinian Information Minister Yasir Abed Raboo accuses US of abetting Israeli campaign; both sides regard Pres Bush' remarks supporting Israel's right to seek security as virtual green light for Sharon; Israeli commentators and analysts feel, in light of American go-ahead, military campaign should move as intensely and as quickly as possible; protests against Israel and US mount; tens of thousands clash with police in Cairo, Egypt, and Amman, Jordan; photos; diagrams; maps (M)

headline: Board Changing At Omnicom Group
abstract: American Association of Advertising Agencies chooses upbeat theme, Looking Forward, for its 84th annual meeting in Dana Point, Calif; Ken Kaess, vice chairman of association, says no one wants to look back on bleak year; it is measure of industry's difficulties that attendance promises to be among lowest ever for conference (M)

headline: ISRAELI OPERATION ENGULFS RAMALLAH WITHOUT A BATTLE
abstract: Israeli tanks and troops surround Yasir Arafat's battered compound in Ramallah, extending shutdown of nearly all of Palestinian West Bank; more than 600,000 Palestinians are confined to homes; new offensive, in contrast to earlier military action in April, meets with no resistance; Prime Min Ariel Sharon says troops will remain until suicide bombings stop; action comes after Palestinian officials order house arrest of Sheik Ahmed Yassin and several other high-ranking officials of Islamic militant movement Hamas in Gaza; comes as Pres Bush prepares to announce new Mideast policy, including path to creating Palestinian state; photos (M)

headline: KRAFT FOODS DISCUSSES PURCHASE OF MEXICAN JUICE MAKER
abstract: Kraft Foods Inc, Philip Morris Cos unit, is in talks to acquire Jugos del Valle, Mexico's largest juice maker (S)

headline: South Korea Presses Hynix to Reconsider Micron Deal
abstract: South Korean officials regroup after surprise rejection of rescue plan for Hynix Semiconductor by Hynix's own board, saying that they still hope to revive deal and that board can expect no help if it continues to try to chart independent course; Finance Min Jeon Yun Churl says government has long since concluded that Hynix is no longer viable and says government is opposed to rolling over loans or providing new credit; Hynix was $6.8 billion in debt before it entered negotiations with Micron Technology in January (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ITT INDUSTRIES, White Plains, a military contractor and maker of electronics components, said it had won a five-year contract to provide the U.S. Army with night vision devices. The contract's value could reach $450 million if all options are exercised.    BRANDYWINE REALTY TRUST, Philadelphia, which owns, manages or has an interest in 299 properties, agreed with Amtrak to develop a 28-story office center with more than 500,000 square feet of office, conference and retail space next to the 30th Street Station in Philadelphia.

headline: Congratulations! Here Comes the Bill
abstract: Graph details costs of weddings

headline: Bertelsmann, in a Reversal, Agrees to Acquire Napster
abstract: Bertelsmann AG, in startling reversal, agrees to acquire assets of Napster Inc for $8 million; possibility of deal seemed remote just few days ago, when Napster's board rejected $5 million purchase offer; Napster chif executive Konrad Hilbers and founder Shawn Fanning announce they are returning to Napster as part of deal; Hilbers will also become chairman of board; by purchasing assets of company and not acquiring it in merger, Bertelsmann may be able to limit its liability in record industry's copyright infringement lawsuits against Napster (M)

headline: Pope Says Only Talks, Not Fighting, Can End Mideast Crisis
abstract: Pope John Paul II, in Easter homily, calls for end to crescendo of attacks and revenge between Israelis and Palestinians; urges discussions between both sides; says nothing is resolved through reprisal and retaliation (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: New Version Of Kazaa Is Issued
abstract: Users of Kazaa will soon have access to network that will charge fees to download files; Sharman Networks, which distributes Kazaa software, issues new version of software that will still allow users to trade and download music files free, but will access to parallel network, Altnet, that intends to charge users for access to music (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Debate Grows Over Links In Government to Business  Disputes over contacts between corporations and senior government officials who regulate them have become an almost daily ritual of Washington life. While the debate is not new, it has heated up. Senate Democrats have become emboldened in challenging an administration with strong pro-business leanings.     The issue has also underscored the differences in disclosure among executive departments and independent agencies. [Page C5.]

headline: Executive Life: The Boss; Rubin Made Me Do It
abstract: The Boss column by Internal Revenue Service Commissioner Charles O Rossotti describes his first job, at Boston Consulting Group; photo (M)

headline: Protests, and Friends Too, Await Bush in Europe
abstract: Pres George W Bush will be met with both cheers and protests in Germany, first stop on his European tour; sharp criticism of Bush administration's perceived unilateralism that predated Sept 11 has returned resurgent; photos (M)

headline: Israelis Raid Center of Nablus; Peace Talks Get Wary Support
abstract: Israeli soldiers raided the center of the West Bank city of Nablus today, while negotiators remained deadlocked in the siege in Bethlehem at the Church of the Nativity.

headline: Home Security, With a Memory
abstract: Napco Security Group unit has build home security system that can remember 1,200 types of movements and distinguish among them; chief executive Richard Soloway comments on refining motion detectors; photos (M)

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Generator Maker of Fraud
abstract: S.E.C. Accuse

headline: Train Rolls Into Another In Tanzania, Killing 200
abstract: At least 200 people die when passenger train in central Tanzania that apparently experienced mechanical failure rolled backward down hill into cargo train; authorities say death toll could rise; map (M)

headline: Article 2002042190742338897 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: International Text Version         function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                         International           -      Africa            -      Americas            -      Asia Pacific            -      Europe            -      Middle East               National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business              Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: GLAXOSMITHKLINE TO PAY $420 MILLION FOR DRUG RIGHTS
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline will pay Adolor Corp and Unigene Laboratories Inc for rights to bowel-paralysis and osteoporosis treatments; Glaxo will pay as much as $270 million to Adolor for rights to bowel treatment alvimopan, while Unigene will get as much as $150 million for hormone treatment for osteoporosis; Glaxo will give up rights to Factive, experimental antibiotic, after regulators in US do not approve it (S)

headline: President Set to Step Down at Microsoft
abstract: Richard Belluzzo, who has been president and chief operating officer of Microsoft Corp for about one year, will step down in May and leave Microsoft in September; departure is part of reorganization that is intended to give heads of Microsoft's business divisions greater independence; chief executive Steven A Ballmer and Belluzzo comment (M)

headline: New Shuffles in Media At Interpublic Group
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies shuffles some top media executives at its units; names Ira Carlin, chairman and chief executive at Universal McCann Worldwide, to new post of worldwide chairman at Magna Global; Robin Kent succeeds Carlin at Universal; Hans Germeraad is named to new post of regional director for European operations for Magna Global (S)

headline: Arafat Willing To Face Voters, His Aides Say
abstract: Yasir Arafat's two top aides say he is willing to run for election within six months, as members of Palestinian Legislative Council present detailed proposals to curtail his power, replace his ministers and hold elections by early next year; Palestinian legislators accept Arafat's invitation, which he offered under pressure at home and abroad, to propose changes to improve Palestinian governance; Ziad Abu Amr, one of eight legislators drawing up reform proposal, cautions that effort faces struggle; expects Arafat to bargain to maintain his powers; but he predicts that proposal would easily win majority in full council; in sign of their ambitions for democracy, legislators plan to issue their proposal as letter to Palestinian people, rather than to Arafat (M)

headline: Japan's Central Bank Paints A Brighter Economic Picture
abstract: Bank of Japan says it expects Japan's $4.1 trillion economy to contract by about 0.5 percent in fiscal year that began April 1; it had previously predicted 1 percent contraction; bank says even though wholesale and consumer prices will fall this year, they will do so more gradually; bank's policy board, which leaves monetary policy unchanged at its meeting, says Japan's exports and industrial production are picking up, and with them outlook for corporate profits; adds growing competition and costs of writing off bad loans will continue to depress job creation, wages and prices, limiting consumer spending and any chance of full-blown recovery; says economy is expected to stop deteriorating toward latter half of fiscal year and turn upward again, though it is not likely to gain much upward momentum (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Former Ally Of Koizumi Arrested; SRI LANKA: Strict Defamation Law Repealed; TAIWAN: 'Black Boxes' Recovered At Crash Site; CHINA: Arrests In Cafe Fire.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Netratings Buys A Jupiter Unit
abstract: NetRatings, which measures and analyzes Internet audiences, acquires AdRelevance, which measures online advertising spending, from competing Internet researcher, Jupiter Media Metrix; deal is valued at $8.5 million (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ENBRIDGE ENERGY PARTNERS, Houston, a transporter of oil and gas to refineries, said it would buy assets for $929 million from Enbridge, Calgary, Alberta, a pipeline company.    GOODRICH CORP., Charlotte, N.C., the largest U.S. maker of aircraft landing gear, won a contract from Virgin Atlantic Airways, London, to equip its planes with video surveillance systems.

headline: From a Slab, Fashioning A Clutch PC
abstract: J D Biersdorfer State of the Art column on full-size tablet computers that can utilize point-and-click interfaces, voice recognition and stylus input; Microsoft Tablets are due out later in year; features of ViewPad 1000, introduced by ViewSonic Corp, discussed; drawing; photos (M)

headline: Confidence in the Economy, But Not the Market
abstract: Susan Weinschenk, PhD, letter responds to June 2 article which discussed paucity of investors returning to stock market despite positive signs concerning economy

headline: Article 2002042390832504308 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                      International           -      Africa            -      Americas            -    Asia Pacific          -      Europe            -      Middle East               National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business              Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: Spanish Workers Hold Hostages at Cookie Plant
abstract: Workers at cookie factory in Aguilar de Campoo, Spain, are holding hostage six managers and lawyers, in hope of forcing change of heart by owners, United Biscuit Group, which plans to close plant; plant employs 212 people (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Former 3com Chief At Start-Up
abstract: L William Krause, former chief executive of 3Com Corp and Exodus Communications, is named president and chief executive of Caspian Networks, succeeding Bill Sickler (S)

headline: KOHLBERG KRAVIS TO SELL NEARLY HALF ITS STAKE IN IDEX
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co plans to sell almost half of its stake in Idex Corp, maker of industrial pumps, for estimated $163 million (S)

headline: Between Voting Days, Le Pen's Fiery Image Returned to Spotlight
abstract: Jean-Marie Le Pen, who won second place in first round of French presidential race by playing down overt racism and anti-Semitism, reverts to type in second round and is crushed by Pres Jacques Chirac; photo (M)

headline: FORD FOLLOWS G.M. IN BACKING OFF NO-INTEREST LOANS
abstract: Ford Motor Co joins General Motors Corp in backing away from no-interest loans on new cars and trucks; raises some cash discounts by $500 to $3,000, matching level set by GM; Ford's latest incentive program, which runs through July 1, continues zero percent financing on some vehicles in some regions (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Estimates Affect Genesis Shares
abstract: Genesis Microchip Inc shares fall $6.66, to $16.70, setting new 52-week low after some analysts slash earnings estimates (S)

headline: After U.S. Scraps ABM Treaty, Russia Rejects Curbs of Start II
abstract: Russia responds to United States' decision to abandon 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty by saying it is no longer bound by 1993 accord known as Start II that outlaws multiple-warhead missiles and other especially destabilizling weapons in two nations' strategic arsenals; some experts dismiss Russia's action as political gesture, signaling displeasure but little else in world remade by forces unleashed after Soviet Union's collapse; other experts fear that Russia's move could exacerbate trend toward more unstable nuclear balance, especially if current thaw between East and West begins to chill; State Dept spokesman claims Russia's action was not surprise (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Serious Computing, Big Fun
abstract: Butterfly.net Inc plans to announce its Butterfly Grid, software development tools and network for so-called massively multiplayer video games, which can be played by thousands of people at same time; IBM will supply most of underlying technology for game grid; Butterfly chief executive David Levine comments (S)

headline: Look, Ma, No Tangle of Wires, Just Beams of Infrared Light
abstract: Israeli company Infra-Com uses infrared light signals to replace tangle of wires connecting computer to peripherals; transceiver in each hardware device connects them all; photo (M)

headline: VENEZUELA'S CHIEF FORCED TO RESIGN; CIVILIAN INSTALLED
abstract: Transitional government headed by leading businessmen replaces Venezuelan Pres Hugo Chavez, hours after military officers force him to resign; it is sudden end to turbulent three-year reign of mercurial strongman elected on promises to distance his country from United States while uprooting Venezuela's old social order; Chavez, firebrand populist who had said he would remake Venezuela to benefit the poor, is obligated to resign in meeting with three military officers after large street protests in which at least 14 people are killed by gunmen identified as his supporters; Pedro Carmona Estanga, head of Venezuela's most important business assn, is installed as interim president; photo (M)

headline: Canada Is Expected to Increase Rates
abstract: Bank of Canada is expected to raise interest rates April 16, for first time in almost two years; central bank is expected to raise overnight lending rate by one-quarter point, to 2.25 percent; graph (M)

headline: It's Official: Hewlett-Compaq Merger Won
abstract: Final results of Hewlett-Packard proxy contest confirm that shareholders approved company's merger with Compaq Computer; tally by IVS Associates shows company won by about 45 million votes, margin of less than 3 percent among more than 1.6 billion share-votes cast on March 19 (S)

headline: Shares Drop Sharply on General Electric's Profit Decline
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 205.65 points, or 2 percent, to 10,176.08; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 26.78 points, or 2.4 percent, to 1,103.69; Nasdaq composite index falls 41.83 points, or 2.4 percent, to 1,725.24; graph; chart (M)

headline: Executive Life: The Boss; From Passion to Patience
abstract: Managed Objects chief executive Siki Giunta The Boss column on her career; photo (M)

headline: Remembering Edison
abstract: Al Kunze letter on Apr 4 article on Edison National Historic Site, West Orange, NJ, recalls meeting Thomas Edison

headline: Inventories Decline At Businesses, a Hint Of Slow Recovery
abstract: Commerce Department reports business inventories fell in February for 13th month as sales declined; says 0.1 percent drop in supplies of unsold goods, reflecting declines at wholesalers and manufacturers, matched decrease in January; businss sales fell 0.9 percent in February, biggest drop in three months, after 0.9 percent rise in January (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Unemployment Rises
abstract: Hong Kong's unemployment rate rose to 7.4 percent in period from March to May compared with 7.1 percent from February through April; graph (S)

headline: Israeli Army Withdraws From a City In Ruins
abstract: Israeli troops withdraw from Nablus, leaving behind residents short on food and basic services and seething over what they have endured; city is in disarray, much of it without water and parts with no electricity; casualty counts continue to rise; photo (M)

headline: Japan Braces for a 'Designed in China' World
abstract: Major Japanese manufacturers that have already shifted much production to China are now planning to open research and development units there; crumbling of informal wall that kept assembly in China and research in Japan may spell end to Japan's last great competitive advantage over China; will bring both new opportunities and wrenching change for Japan, which has been lately coasting on wealth built up in earlier decades; table of Japanese companies moving research to China; photos (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Mild Protest of John Kennedy Jr. Biography
abstract: Group of former staff members of George magazine and their friends plan mock toast to new book American Son, memoir of magazine's late founder, John F Kennedy Jr, by former George editor Richard Blow; seek to protest what they call Blow's exploitation of Kennedy's death; suspect Blow used public silence about Kennedy he imposed on magazine's staff to sell book; photo (M)

headline: Cellphones Not Killing Real Ones
abstract: Maritz Research survey finds 79 percent of Americans say they are very unlikely to give up traditional phones and use cellphones for all calls in next year; 42 percent say cellphones have led them to use their existing lond-distance companies less (S)a

headline: PEDIATRIX MEDICAL SHARES DROP ON NEWS OF U.S. INQUIRY
abstract: Shares in Pediatrix Medical Group, which disclosed late last week that Federal Trade Commission was investigating its 2001 acquisition of Magella Healthcare Corp, fall 31 percent, to $26.20 (S)

headline: Publishers Council Spinning Off Ad Unit
abstract: Magazine Publishers of America will spin off its Custom Publishing Council into separate organization; council represents companies that publish magazines on behalf of advertisers; Chris McMurry is named chairmana nd president of council; Lori Rosen is named executive director (S)

headline: In Argentina's Bank Holiday, Cash Is Most Scarce Commodity
abstract: A growing number of stores in Buenos Aires are refusing to accept any form of payment other than cash.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   7.00        Discount rate   1.25   1.25   3.50        Federal funds   1.75   1.82   3.91        3-month T-bills   1.69   1.70   3.39        6-month T-bills   1.78   1.80   3.35        10-yr. T-infl.   3.03   3.03   3.25        10-yr. T-note   4.83   4.85   5.23        30-yr. T-bond   5.46   5.46   5.69        Telephone bd.   7.55   7.55   7.86        Municipal bds.   5.27   5.27   5.37          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: When Small Funds Aren't Necessarily Better Funds
abstract: Mark Hulbert column discusses new research contradicting view that mutual funds with relatively few assets under management enjoy performance advantage over largest funds; notes earlier studies that found small funds outperformed large ones ignored funds that had gone out of business; graph; graph of fund expenses (M)

headline: Article 2002042293483108937 -- No Title
