headline: Publishers of Web Sites File Suit to Stop Pop-Up Ads
abstract: Group of 10 Web site publishers is suing Gator, online advertising and information storage company, to stop it from placing pop-up ads over their sites without permission; publishers, which include Washington Post Co, Dow Jones & Co, Tribune Interactive and New York Times Co, file suit; Gator spokeswoman Mandy Mladenoff says company has issued statement that it is considering countersuit against publishers; suit maintains that its pop-up ads violate copyright and trademark laws and that they allow Gator to profit unjustly from user traffic generated by these Web sites (M)

headline: 100 Are Hurt As Soccer Loss Leads to Riot In Moscow
abstract: Outdoor broadcast of World Cup soccer match turns into drunken rampage outside Kremlin after Russian team loses to Japan; hundreds of rioters destroy dozens of autos and scores of storefronts and injure perhaps 100 people; 11 law enforcement officers reportedly are wounded; photo (M)

headline: In Tough Times, Bigger Boats Rule the Sea
abstract: Sales of new boats drops 6 percent in 2001, to 541,000, but sales of upscale, highly equipped motorboats and sailboats remain strong, driving up total amount spent on boats and accessories; graphs (S)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: PERU: Minister Resigns In Protest; GUATEMALA: Ex-Troops End Blockade; COLOMBIA: Rebel Sought By U.S. Is Captured.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Plan To Apply To NATO
abstract: Ukraine will tell NATO Secretary Gen Lord Robertson that it is beginning application process for membership; he will visit in July, marking anniversary of charter declaring special relationship between Ukraine and NATO (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: SWITZERLAND: Bishops Deplore Abortion Vote ; GERMANY: Leader To Boycott Forum ; Northern IRELAND: New Belfast Violence.

headline: CHIRAC RE-ELECTED AS FRANCE REJECTS HIS RIGHTIST RIVAL
abstract: Pres Jacques Chirac is re-elected by widest margin in French history, as voters from left and right turn out in droves to deal categorical defeat to Jean-Marie Le Pen, extreme rightist; wins slightly more than 82 percent of vote and Le Pen almost 18; Chirac hails France for having reaffirmed republican values in victory speech; pledges to engage himself with determination and spirit of unity and to work quickly to fulfill campaign promises; resounding victory is largely hollow one, since it is likely to resonate bitterly among large number of French voters who said they voted reluctantly for Chirac, simply to prove that France was not bastion of ultra-right; Socialist leaders, who rallied behind Chirac in face of Le Pan's candidacy, quickly make clear their support is at end; Le Pen concedes election, saying results are 'stinging defeat for hope' in France; says nation is in hands of robbers and complains that he was victim of totalitarian methods to keep him out of office; photo (M)

headline: Article 2002042493723510918 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Business Paper Version         function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                            International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics             Business           -      Media & Advertising            -      World Business            -      Your Money            -      Markets            -      Company Research            -      Mutual Funds            -      Stock Portfolio            -      Columns               Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: Vivendi Chief Weathers a Crucial Board Meeting
abstract: Embattled Vivendi Universal SA chairman Jean-Marie Messier survives all-day meeting with directors concerned about company's strategic direction, ballooning debt and poor stock performance; company's board appears to support Messier in his effort to remake himself and his professional reputation; company says it will not convene another shareholder meeting this year; Messier had said Vivendi would consider holding new meeting because electronic voting system at original meeting in April had been tampered with; company also announces that board has approved Messier's proposal to create new committee to oversee corporate governance procedures; new committee is to be led by vice chairman Edgar Bronfman Jr and Marc Vienot, chairman of board's audit committee and former chairman of Societe Generale; photo (M)

headline: Finance Ministers to Discuss Fighting Terrorism and Poverty
abstract: As protesters streamed into Washington, finance ministers gathered today to take up proposals for battling terrorism and poverty.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Pipeline Decision Is Delayed
abstract: Thailand's Prime Min Thaksin Shinawatra delays decision on whether to proceed with controversial natural gas pipeline that would cut across southern Thailand to Malaysia so he can study alternative routes; project, $500 million Trans Thai-Malaysia Pipeline, is joint venture of Thai oil company PTT and Malaysian company Petroliam Nasional (S)

headline: Cantor Sues Rival Firm In London
abstract: Cantor Fitzgerald sues London-based brokerage firm Icap charging it hired away Edward Bird, Luigi Boucher and Spencer Gill, three of Cantor's top London-based swap traders; is asserting that Icap persuaded three to breach their contracts as part of deliberate effort to damage firm in aftermath of Sept 11 terrorist attacks, in which 658 Cantor employees were killed and company's New York offices in World Trade Center's north tower were obliterated; Icap says brokers left Cantor because they were unhappy with company's offer of new contracts that would have linked their annual compensation more directly to performance; Icap chief executive Michael Spencer paid sympathy visit to Lee Amaitis, chief executive of Cantor Fitzgerald's London operations, not long after terrorist attacks (M)

headline: Court Is Told Microsoft Kept Strategy Even After Ruling
abstract: Microsoft Corp vice president Will Poole says company bundled more multimedia features into Windows XP even after Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ruled company illegally integrated extra functions into operating system to protect its monopoly; nine states challenging Microsoft's proposed settlement of federal government's antitrust case suggest that Microsoft had not dropped efforts to squash competition and would not be restrained by accord (M)

headline: Text: Bush's Remarks on Middle East
abstract: Atext of President Bush's remarks on the Middle East, as transcribed by eMediaMillWorks Inc.:

headline: Carter to Go to Communist Cuba In First Visit by Ex-U.S. President
abstract: Bush administration will allow Jimmy Carter and Rosalind Carter to visit Cuba as part of small delegation, first visit by former US president since 1959 revolution; Fidel Castro has invited Carter and offered him stage to speak to Cuban people (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Abuses In Chechnya Cited
abstract: Human Rights Watch says it has documented 80 instances in which Chechen civilians have disappeared while in custody of Russian soldiers; says actual number is probably much higher (S)

headline: AT&T Lost Almost $1 Billion, But There Were Bright Spots
abstract: AT&T Corp reports first-quarter loss of $975 million compared with loss of $373 million year earlier; revenue fell 11.3 percent, to $12.02 billion from $13.55 billion; chairman C Michael Armstrong comments (M)

headline: Campaigning In France, An Old Hand Is a Wild Card
abstract: French presidential candidate Jean-Pierre Chevenement distinguishes himself in huge electoral field by campaigning in places like dreary low-income neighborhood outside Paris (S)

headline: Article 2002042292238435928 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //              JOB POSITIONS

headline: Reordering Priorities
abstract: Maritz Research survey reveals that Sept 11 terrorist attacks caused American workers to reorder their priorities, putting less emphasis on work and more on family (S)

headline: Article 2002042494081893718 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Job Market Text Version         function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                            International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business              Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: A Photo Program for the Home, And One for the Road
abstract: Roxio offers new software PhotoSuite Platinum Edition, which provides users with easy-to-use interface to edit and modify digital pictures; offers mobile edition which uses Palm for display; photo (M)

headline: New Immigration Plan in Britain Would Restrict Asylum Seekers
abstract: Britain announces intention to tighten its immigration laws by ordering failed asylum seekers to leave country within days and to file any appeals from their home country or whatever country they arrived from; proposal, to be incorporated in bill now moving through Parliament, comes as new figures show applications for asylum in Britain have soared this year; 75 percent of them are rejected; refugee support groups assail plan; most new arrivals reach England from another European country, most frequently from refugee camp near Calais, France; immigrants often pay middlemen thousands of dollars to get to Western Europe from places like Afghanistan, China and Iraq, and are willing to run risks of repeated attempts at often dangerous passage (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Insurer Acquires Rival
abstract: Societa Assicuratrice Industriale will buy La Fondiaria Assicurazioni, ending 10-month takeover battle, to create Italy's biggest casualty insurer; deal values Fondiaria at 1.86 billion euros (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: HONG KONG: New Microsoft Offices; INDONESIA: Challenge From Insurer;.

headline: Becoming Less German
abstract: Rolf E Breuer's most immediate goal when he takes over for Josef Ackermann as chief executive of Deutsche Bank is to bolser bank's lagging stock price by drastically cutting costs; Deutsche Bank is one of biggest banks in world but it is less efficient than its competitors and its market capitalization makes it hard for bank to engage in any big deals; no one expects Deutsche Bank to fall victim to foreign takeover any time soon, but bank that used to be at very heart of Germany Inc has already ceased to be German institution in many respects; more than half of bank's powerful new executive committee, led by Ackermann, are non-Germans and three of them are Americans; chart; photo (M)

headline: Casino Stocks: First, Check the Map
abstract: Outlook for investing in gambling industry stocks, which have climbed 94 percent from their Sept lows, discussed; some investors say better bargains may be found in gambling companies that operate outside Las Vegas; market premium on Las Vegas-focused operators could evaporate if labor problems are not resolved; graph of casino stock performance; photo (M)

headline: An Accidental Start
abstract: Willis Group head Joe Plumeri The Boss article reflecting on his working life; photo (M)

headline: North and South Korea Trade Charges Over Naval Clash
abstract: North and South Korean governments trade charges over who was responsible for clash at sea in which South Korean patrol boat was sunk and four South Koreans were killed; another 22 South Korean marines and sailors are wounded in new battle in same Yellow Sea waters; photo; map (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: Europe RUSSIA: Communist Leader Denounces Summit ; BRITAIN: Guilty Verdict In Foot-and-mouth Case.

headline: Investing; Stocks vs. Bonds: A Risk Scoreboard
abstract: New study by Moody's Investors Service, based on work of Nobel laureate William F Sharpe, concludes that corporate bonds outperformed stocks on risk-adjusted basis between Jan 1990, and May 2002; photo; graph (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Setback For Sulzer
abstract: Device sold by Sulzer Medica that tests heart valves is pulled from British market after patient dies when piece of device breaks off during surgery; company accepts responsibility for product, which was made by another company but distributed by Sulzer, and is providing replacements (S)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Awaiting an Inventor To the Editor:.

headline: Thai Premier Offers Compromise of Sorts on Pipeline Dispute
abstract: Thai Prime Min Thaksin Shinawatra orders Thai oil executives to shift spot where proposed natural gas pipeline would come ashore six miles away from cluster of traditional Muslim villages that oppose pipeline onto land belonging to Thai navy; compromise does little to molify pipeline opponents; proposed Trans Thai-Malaysia Pipeline, joint venture of two nations' state-controlled oil companies, PTT and Petroliam Nasional, would carry gas from jointly owned offshore fields to Malaysia; Thaksin says his government will postpone, but not cancel, construction of two deeply unpopular coal-fired power plants south of Bangkok (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Celerity Files For Initial Offering
abstract: Technology BriefinÔ

headline: Preparing for Divorce Before the Wedding
abstract: Most adults surveyed see some benefit to having prenuptial agreement, which spells out how assets should be divided when marriage ends, but are nevertheless lukewarm or strongly opposed to idea for ordinary people; only 28 percent endorse idea; single women over 55 are most likely to demand agreement (S)

headline: Despite Billions for Discoveries, Pipeline of Drugs Is Far From Full
abstract: Fewer new drugs are being developed despite constant increases in spending on research and development, causing some to worry that new product pipeline may be running dry; industry's output of new drugs has risen only modestly in last two decades despite more than sixfold increase, after adjusting for inflation, in research and development spending, to more than $30 billion annually; in last few years, output has actually declined; graphs; photo (M)

headline: DOW JONES HAS DOWNBEAT FORECAST AFTER BIG PROFIT GAIN
abstract: Dow Jones & Co says net income rose to $129.8 million in first quarter from $6.18 million year earlier; sales fell 15 percent, to $392.9 million (S)

headline: U.S. Criticizes Israel's New Electronic Fence Along West Bank
abstract: White House and State Dept offer veiled criticism of Israel's construction of new security fence on West Bank, warning it should not constitute unilateral declaration of border, as Pres Bush heads into final consultations on new proposals for Middle East peace (M)

headline: Ad spending on cable and syndicated shows is below the peak but still topping expectations.
abstract: Advertisers are spending more than expected on both cable networks as well as syndicated programming; these sectors of television industry are expected to bring in at least $6.5 billion during what is known as upfront market, 14 percent increase from last year's performance; figure matches showing by broadcast networks, which improved more than 14 percent, from $7 billion to about $8 billion; syndicators appear to be doing better than cable counterparts; analysts estimate syndication sales will total $2 billion, up 17.6 percent from $1.7 billion in 2001-02 (M)

headline: India Calls a Speech by Pakistan's President 'Dangerous'
abstract: Indian government says Gen Pervez Musharraf delivered 'dangerous' speech on May 27 that offered no new steps to relax tensions between India and Pakistan; accuses Pakistan of continuing to support infiltration of terrorists into India's side of Kashmir; says it will de-escalate only after Pakistan ends infiltration; Musharraf's speech offered denials of Pakistan's involvement in infiltration and warning that country is ready for war if India attacks; Britain's Foreign Min Jack Straw meets with Musharraf in Islamabad in bid to cool tensions; will meet with Indian officials on May 29; maps; photos (M)

headline: Just how much did the networks get from advertisers? For once, they seem to want to tell.
abstract: Broadcast television networks, in unusual moves, are disclosing how much prime-time advertising they sold in advance for fall season; CBS reports commitments of $1.9 billion to $2 billion for season; ABC, holding previously published figures were too low, says it sold $1.5 billion in upfront market; other networks see reports aimed at stock analysts; photo (M)

headline: Mixed Vote at TRW on Suitor
abstract: Shareholders of TRW Inc strike down two measures that would have paved way for Northrop Grumman Co to proceed with $6.7 billion hostile takeover; shareholdes narrowly vote in favor of allowing Northrop access to TRW's confidential financial statements, leaving open prospect of successful Northrop bid (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Challenge To The President
abstract: Supreme Court of Pakistan begins hearing petitions by major political parties and Islamic religious groups challenging constitutionality of referendum called for Apr 30 by Pres Pervez Musharraf in move to extend his unelected presidency for five more years (S)

headline: Article 2002042093178819704 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                       International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics             Business           -      Media & Advertising            -      World Business            -      Your Money            -      Markets            -      Company Research            -      Mutual Funds            -      Stock Portfolio            -      Columns               Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Earthlink To Sell Internet Access At Gateway
abstract: EarthLink Inc to resell high-speed Internet access provided by AOL Time Warner's cable television lines at Gateway stores (S)

headline: Former Israel Prime Minister Calls Arafat 'Terrorist Chieftain'
abstract: Former Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu chided the United States today for pressuring Israel to withdraw its forces from the West Bank.

headline: Market Place; Master Fixer Of AOL Suffers First Setback In Cable Loss
abstract: AOL Time Warner's new chief executive Richard D Parsons, who is known in media industry for his ability to manage people, has suffered his first setback with loss of AOL Time Warner's control of cable television systems to Advance/Newhouse; it appears that Newhouse family grew concerned that financial results of their cable systems could be sacrificed in favor of America Online division, and that by reducing fees that America Online paid to cable systems, reported results of of America Online division might be enhanced while results of cable operation might suffer; Advance/Newhouse chief executive Robert Miron says separation was neither unfriendly nor angry (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Bring Back Beige, Now To the Editor:.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   8.00       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   4.50       Federal funds   1.75   1.73   4.47       3-month T-bills   1.67   1.67   3.78       6-month T-bills   1.84   1.87   3.80       10-yr. T-infl.   3.08   3.12   3.41       10-yr. T-note   5.20   5.23   5.30       30-yr. headline: Britain Scuttles Plans to Publish Iraq Dossier
abstract: Britain has scuttled plans to publish an intelligence dossier on Iraq's secret arms programs.

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Nissan Posts A Profit; JAPAN: Profit For Suzuki.

headline: Splits Over Palestinian Statehood and Arafat Role Are Unresolved
abstract: President Bush and Prime Minister Ariel Sharon remained divided today about how to move toward the creation of a Palestinian state and whether to deal with Yasir Arafat.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Scotland: Mandela Visits Lockerbie Bomber
abstract: Nelson Mandela said Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al-Megrahi, the Libyan intelligence agent convicted in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie, which killed 270 people, should be moved from his high-security prison in Scotland to a Muslim country ''trusted by the West'' and be permitted to appeal his case to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg. Mr. Megrahi lost an appeal in Scotland in March. Mr. Mandela, who played a crucial role in persuading Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to hand over Mr. Megrahi for trial, met with Mr. Megrahi in his Glasgow prison.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Hewlett PC to Use a Chip Made by Transmeta
abstract: Hewlett-Packard will use Transmeta Corp microprocessor in its planned Compaq Evo tablet PC; is first major United States customer for chip, used by several Japanese computer makers (M)

headline: Dell Says Hewlett Merger Is Opening Doors
abstract: Dell Computer president Kevin Rollins says his company has 'without a doubt' benefited from uncertainty among corporate customers about effect of Hewlett-Packard's planned purchase of Compaq Computer Co; says main effect of pending merger so far has been invitations to Dell to bid on large corporate accounts; Rollins's comments and similar ones from founder-chief executive Michael Dell come during presentation to Wall Street analysts in which Dell sketches out out its plans to double its revenue of $60 billion over next four or five years; photo (M)

headline: Fares Don't Rise, So Airlines Struggle
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer Market Insight column interviews Deutsche Bank airlines analyst Susan M Donofrio on outlook for struggling industry she evaluates; photo (M)

headline: Bomb Kills 4 In Jalalabad But Minister Is Uninjured
abstract: Afghanistan's defense minister Muhammad Fahim escapes apparent assassination attempt unhurt as bomb explodes in crowd lining streets of Jalalabad to welcome him for visit; four people are killed and 18 are wounded; attack is seen as latest incident in organized effort to undermine American-backed government of Hamid Karzai, which took office in December (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Multinational Viagra Fraud
abstract: Spanish police detain Irish citizen accused of trafficking in unlicensed Viagra pills made at clandestine Asian laboratory, sold through Web site with servers in United States and Britain and mailed out in candy wrappers; Pfizer is only company licensed to sell drug (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Arbitrator Named In Retail Bid
abstract: Castorama Dubois Investissement SCA and Kingfisher PLC agree to name Rothschild & Cie Banque to arbitrate their dispute over Kingfisher's 5.3 billion euro ($5 billion) offer for rest of Castorama under terms of 1998 accord under which it bought 55 percent stake; Castorma says former arbitrator, Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, failed to disclose its role as adviser to another company headed by Kingfisher chairman Francis Mackay; photo (S)

headline: Goldman Profits in Sale of Korean Bank Stake
abstract: Goldman Sachs sells about 60 percent of its stake in Koomin Bank of South Korea for $633.6 million, three times price it paid for shares when it invested in bank three years ago; Kookmin officials deny that Goldman's sale of shares reflects any lack of confidence in bank's future (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Low Price Hurts Oil Concern
abstract: Russia's Yukos Oil Co says lower oil price late last year was reason its 2001 net profit dropped 6 percent, to $3.5 billion; oil production rose 17 percent in 2001 compared with year before; company announces increase in oil and gas reserves by 6 percent through discoveries in Siberia (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Executive Change At Easyjet
abstract: EasyJet founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou will resign as company's chairman at annual board meeting in 2003; Colin Chandler, who is joining board as deputy chairman, will succeed him; photo (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LANDS' END INC., Dodgeville, Wis., said it received a license to make an exclusive line of clothing bearing the logos of the Major League Baseball clubs through 2004. Terms were not disclosed.    ULTRALIFE BATTERIES INC., Newark, N.Y., said it won a five-year contract worth up to $32 million to provide batteries to the Army Communications and Electric Command.

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Iran Escapes Rights Scrutiny
abstract: Iran's record on human rights will not be monitored by United Nations Human Rights Commission this year, after nearly two decades of such scrutiny; commission votes, 20-19, to reject European Union proposal to censure Iran for executions and torture and suppressing press (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   7.00        Discount rate   1.25   1.25   3.50        Federal funds   1.75   1.75   3.98        3-month T-bills   1.68   1.69   3.34        6-month T-bills   1.74   1.76   3.29        10-yr. T-infl.   3.02   3.00   3.26        10-yr. T-note   4.77   4.79   5.12        30-yr. headline: PrivateSector; Happy to Take Credit for Once
abstract: National Minority Supplier Development Council to honor Verizon Communications chief executive Ivan Seidenberg; Verizon spent $1.5 billion in 2001 on goods and services supplied by minority-owned businesses; photo (S)

headline: Risking Limbs for Height, and Success, in China
abstract: Hundreds of young Chinese, mostly women obsessed with stature, are undergoing often painful and extremely risky leg-lengthening operations to increase height, willing to take risks in country where tallness is prerequisite for jobs, colleges and even spouses; operation, developed by Russian doctor 40 years ago to treat dwarfism and deformed limbs, works on principle of distraction osteogenesis in which bone is cut during surgery and gradually pulled apart leading to new bone formation in resulting gap; is also used in US, but mainly for therapeutic purposes; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Real Estate or Stocks?
abstract: Dr Dan Farrell letter on Daniel Akst's May 5 article cites advantages of investing in residential real estate over stocks

headline: Private Sector; Have Skis, Will Barbecue?
abstract: For George N. Gillett Jr., leisure sports and meat consumption definitely go hand in hand. ''I obviously like to ski, hunt and fish,'' he said with a laugh. ''And I also love to eat beef and pork. We've been active in both of these businesses for a long time.''    What is Mr. Gillett, who owns the Montreal Canadiens hockey team, up to now? With the help of Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, the Dallas leveraged-buyout firm, he is buying majority stakes in ConAgra Beef and Swift, both units of ConAgra Foods.

headline: For Indian Troops on Line of Control, Anger Hasn't Subsided
abstract: Indian Army commanders in Palanwala, India, on front lines of major military confrontation with Pakistan, are not encouraged by recent hopeful talk about decreasing tensions; say they are still angry about attack month ago that killed soldiers' wives and children in their homes; they blame attack on Pakistan's intelligence agency, and voice skepticism about claims that Gen Pervez Musharraf is reducing infiltration by Islamic guerrillas across border into Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir; India's army is firmly under control of elected government, unlike Pakistan, but American officials worry that India and Pakistan could stumble into war, making psychology of India's fighting men and officers important matter; map (M)

headline: Nokia Warns of Falling Sales, but Remains Optimistic on Earnings
abstract: Nokia of Finland, the world's biggest mobile phone maker, said that it would meet second-quarter earnings estimates, though it sharply reduced sales forecasts for the period.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Analysts Question Motive Behind Microsoft Release  After four years of legal battles, the first -- and perhaps only -- visible result of the government's antitrust case against Microsoft will arrive this summer: an update to the Windows XP operating system that lets users hide the icons of some Microsoft programs. Microsoft agreed to the changes in Windows as part of a settlement reached last fall.     But it is not clear whether that settlement is the final word on how Microsoft must change its business practices. Some analysts say Microsoft may have decided to show off the software last week because the primary audience is the federal judge who is deciding whether to approve the settlement. [Page C5.]

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction: June 13 headline on review of Double Bond, biography by Carole Angier, misspelled surname of its subject; he is Primo Levi

headline: Reading the Details Of Earnings Reports
abstract: Robert A Myers letter on Apr 14 article on General Electric annual report holds investors need competent, objective analysts to interpret corporate financial reports

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Government Wants To Sell Bank Stake
abstract: Mexico is seeking to raise $1 billion and reduce its deficit by selling stake in Grupo Financiero BBVA Bancomer, nation's biggest bank (S)

headline: St. Petersburg Journal; He Celebrates That Word, but He'd Stamp It Out
abstract: Publication of first volume of The Big Dictionary of Obscenity by scholar Aleksei Plutser-Sarno engenders controversy in St Petersburg, Russia, where City Council member Vatanyar S Yaga threatens filing of language-purity legislation to outlaw both public cursing and untranslatable foreign words in advertising; volume is exhaustive study of one of three most pungent words in Russian language; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Sega Forms Wireless Division
abstract: Sega.com, Internet arm of Sega, has created division that will make games for wireless devices like cellphones and hand-held computers; about half of Sega.com's employees in Japan and US will report to new division, Sega Mobile (S)

headline: Japan Braces for a 'Designed in China' World
abstract: The crumbling of an informal wall that long kept assembly in China and research in Japan may spell the end of Japan's last great competitive advantage over its low-wage neighbor.

headline: Private Sector; An Old Name Helps a New Business
abstract: Mark F Rockefeller forms online venture, IEG SponsorDirect, that will match groups seeking sponsors with corporate sponsors; his partner is research and consulting firm IEG; he admits family name should help venture; photo (S)

headline: New Economy; Eye-popping graphics can spice up Web sites, but they also create barriers.
abstract: Web designer Sarah Horton article admits fancy graphics and page designs are often barriers between people and information they seek; notes graphic text used for navigation links cannot be read by screen-reader software to blind or enlarged by people who need large type; notes video provided without captions or text transcript is not accessible to blind or deaf; proposes sites design in features that accommodate all users; drawing (M)

headline: Ford's Manager Of Luxury Division Is Resigning Post
abstract: Wolfgang Reitzle resigns as top manager of Premier Automotive Group, luxury division of Ford Motor Co, to become chief executive of Linde, German industrial company; will be succeeded by Mark Fields, chief executive of Mazda, which is controlled by Ford; will continue to work as consultant for Ford, which is counting on Premier to help it regain profitability; Premier includes Volvo, Jaguar, Land Rover, but Lincoln-Mercury, group's largest brand, will again become part of Ford's North American operations; financial analysts expected Reitzle's departure but are not enthusiastic about change; photos (M)

headline: Bush Proposes Doubling U.S. Support for Education in Africa
abstract: Pres Bush proposes doubling amount of money his administration spends on education in Africa, to $200 million over next five years; says he intends to visit Africa next year; makes announcement prior to summit meeting of industrial nations in Canada, at which Africa's development is to be discussed; $200 million would train teachers and pay for 4.5 million textbooks and scholarships for girls; Bush, at Washington dinner in memory of Rev Leon H Sullivan, also repeats commitment to spend $500 million to prevent pregnant women from passing on AIDS virus to babies (M)

headline: Ovitz Is Said To Be Seeking Graceful Exit
abstract: Michael S Ovitz, Hollywood talent agent whose efforts to become power in production of movies and television progams have foundered, is in talks to merge or sell his troubled company, Artists Management Group; prospective buyers include Firm, aggressive four-year-old company headed by Jeff Kwatinetz that rivals Ovitz and shares his goal of blending talent management with creation of entertainment projects and business deals for its roster of celebrities; no decision has been made, and there is no timetable for completing deal; photos (M)

headline: In Afghan Villages, Elders Begin an Ancient Process to Choose a National Government
abstract: Afghans embark on complicated and lengthy process of choosing new leaders, nearly five months after Taliban forces were swept from power; every village in land will be consulted; will put forward one or more representatives to go forward to regional gatherings, which will select 1,500 people to attend loya jirga, or grand council, in Kabul from June 10 through 16; council will formally be convened by former King Mohammed Zahir Shah, set to return to Kabul within days after 29 years in exile (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Starbucks Opens 2 Cafes
abstract: Starbucks opens its first two cafes in Spain; operation, run as joint venture with Grupo Vips, leading restaurant and retail group, and El Moli Vell, Catalan bakery chain, plans 10 to 15 more outlets besides two Madrid stores within next two years and is expected to make profit by 2005 (S)

headline: Venezuela Woes Worsen as State Oil Company Calls Strike
abstract: Six-week tussle over Pres Hugo Chavez's management of Venezuela's state oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela, turns into his most serious crisis, with exports of oil disrupted by labor slowdown and general strike called for April 9 by labor and business leaders; government ministers say exports remain normal, but analysts and company executives say five-day slowdown among oil workers and managers has forced scaling back of operations at several refineries and cutback in production at wellheads, all of which have disrupted shipments to US and other countries; photo (M)

headline: Hints of Cruel Fate for American Lost in Chile
abstract: Recently declassified State Dept and CIA reports indicate that Boris Weisfeiler, only American citizen to have 'disappeared' in Chile during Gen Augusto Pinochet's reign, was probably kidnapped by Chilean state security forces and turned over to heavily armed pro-Nazi religious sect; military informant says Weisfeiler, Russian-born Jew, was interrogated, tortured and executed by sect in 1985; Weisfeiler, who taught at Pennsylvania State Univ, was experienced trekker hiking through Andean foothills at time of his alleged abduction; Chilean government's explanation for his disappearance, never challenged publicly by United States, was that Weisfeiler drowned while fording river four feet deep; American records show that diplomats at US Embassy in Santiago pushed to have case investigated aggressively, but were blocked by State Dept officials in Washington, who were unwilling to provide money needed for investigation; Olga Weisfeiler, Boris Weisfeiler's sister, says she is angry that her brother was not protected by United States government and that she has been given run-around by State Dept when she asks them to look into her brother's disappearance; photos; map (L)

headline: Lenders Trying An Alternative To Foreclosure
abstract: Mortgage lenders have significantly reduced rate of foreclosures, instead altering schedule of loan payments in hope that drop in borrowers' income would turn out to be relatively brief; Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, government-created companies, have driven much of change; now, as economy continues to show signs of recovery, lenders' bet seems to be paying off; mortgage delinquencies have begun to fall, suggesting that many homeowners are getting back on their feet; lenders can thus avoid staggering losses that their newfound flexibility could have caused if economy had deteriorated further; analysts say decline in foreclosure rate has helped solidify progress that many struggling urban neighborhoods have made in recent years; photo; graphs (M)

headline: EnCana Cites 'Round-Trip' Trades by Unit
abstract: EnCana, Canada's biggest natural-gas producer, says that 8 percent of gas trades conducted by Houston subsidiary last year were made at no profit with Reliant Resources to increase volumes; unit of EnCana's PanCanadian Energy division sold and then bought back about 250 million cubic feet of gas per day in 'no margin' trades with Reliant (S)

headline: Oil Prices Decline as Saudis Offer Assurance on Supplies
abstract: Crude oil prices fall almost 3 percent after Saudi Arabia, world's leading exporter, says it will ensure that consuming nations have enough oil to cover any losses caused by 30-day halt in exports by Iraq; graph; chart (M)

headline: Remember Sunscreen, And Tax Strategies
abstract: Sampling of strategies for cutting income taxes offered by accounting firm BDO Seidman (M)

headline: U.S. Farm Bill Adds to a Rising Canadian Anger Over Trade
abstract: Many Canadians see farm bill approved by Congress as yet another slap in face, following American moves against some of Canada's biggest exports; Canada and US are each other's biggest trading partner; under 1988 trade deal, reinforced by North American Free Trade Agreement, customs duties have been virtually eliminated; but that has not ended disputes over subsidies; Canada is one of several countries that have attacked new farm bill and is considering complaint to World Trade Orgn over $70 billion increase in subsidies; now Canadian farm groups are asking their govnerment for extra $1.3 billion Canadian ($848 million) in support (M)

headline: PrivateSector; There's Always a Bright Side
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Harvey L Pitt addresses executives gathered at Economic Club of New York dinner; latest dastardly corporate news mutes their traditional camaraderie; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Makes Case For Long Distance
abstract: Qwest Communications International, the dominant local phone company in 14 Western states, says independent evaluation of its operations in 13 states has shown its support services for competitors linking to its network are good enough for Qwest to be allowed into long-distance business; says it expects to gain state and federal approval to offer long distance in at least some states as early as September (S)

headline: American Web Browsers Continue a Global Turn
abstract: Foreign policy experts note continuing eagerness of many Americans to comprehend world, nine months after terrorist attacks that sparked that interest; say Web sites are getting several million hits a month, and polling organizations say they are finding strong support for greater international cooperation on major issues; interest in American foreign policy has also risen in smaller world affairs councils around country and in local chapters of United Nations Assn of US (M)

headline: KODAK SAYS PROFIT FELL FOR A 7TH CONSECUTIVE QUARTER
abstract: Eastman Kodak says first-quarter profit fell 74 percent as sales declined for fifth consecutive quarter; net income fell to $39 million from $150 million; sales declined 9 percent, to $2.71 billion from $2.98 billion (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Honduras: Panel To Investigate Assassinations
abstract: The government announced the creation of a ''truth commission'' to look into the political assassinations of 187 people during the 1980's. The commission, which is to start work next month under the sponsorship of the United Nations, will have access to military archives.   David Gonzalez (NYT)

headline: Court Nullifies Finding Against a Reporter
abstract: Federal appeals court rules that former New York Times reporter Susan Antilla did not intentionally represent Robert Howard, founder and former chairman of Presstek, in a false light; decision nullifies two-year-old ruling that found Antilla liable for invasion of privacy and awarded Howard $480,000; Times was not named in suit (M)

headline: Taking a Risky Road
abstract: Analysis of risks involved in Bush administration's plans for international conference on Middle East; all other participants in talks see strong American role as indispensable to pushing forward toward solution to conflict; but overwhelming votes in Congress in support of Israel make clear that Pres Bush has little political support for pressing Israel to make painful concessions in new bid for peace; there are divisions within Bush administration itself over how to proceed, and it is not clear that Bush is willing to accept, or to take big risks to play, forceful role; he must deal with Prime Min Ariel Sharon, who has spent his entire career fighting to protect Israel's territorial gains and resisting imposed peace, and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, man Bush distrusts so deeply that he has refused to meet with him (M)

headline: EL PASO SELLS $525 MILLION IN ENERGY PROPERTIES
abstract: El Paso Corp says it sold $525 million of energy properties in first quarter to raise cash after disclosing in December that it had $2 billion in off-the-balance-sheet debt; sales consisted of 527 billion cubic feet of gas reserves in East and South Texas (S)

headline: Breakdown In Talks On Standoff At Church
abstract: Talk turns to desperation at Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, where estimated 220 people are under siege since Israeli military attacked city weeks ago; Palestinians say food has run out and have refused to discuss negotiating for final settlement to siege until Israelis allow food to be delivered for everyone inside; fate of 25 wanted men, believed to be among those trapped inside, remains sticking point; chaotic events at church underscore larger problems with negotiations to end siege peacefully; described; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of May 30 article on United Nations Sec Gen Kori Annan, concerning Sir Brian Urquhart

headline: Testimony on Cuban Arms
abstract: Carl W Ford Jr, assistant secretary of state, says United States believes that Cuba is developing biological weapons in at least limited way, but lacks 'clear, incontrovertible proof' (S)

headline: Climate of Risk for Advisers Is Seen Shifting After Enron
abstract: Despite legal hurdles to holding lawyers, accountants and other professionals liable when company succumbs to fraud, experts are predicting that such claims will rise in wake of Enron's collapse; in case raising spectre of such liability, investors recently won pivotal round against some of same players whose deep pockets are at risk in litigation over Enron--including Arthur Andersen, J P Morgan Chase and Mayer, Brown, Rowe & Maw, Chicago-based law form that is helping defend Andersen in Enron document-destruction case; case involves failure in 1999 of Commercial Financial Services that bought hard-to-collect credit card debt and repackaged it as securities; federal judge in Tulsa last month denied defendants' motion to dismiss lawsuit (M)

headline: 2 Tinkerers Say They've Found A Cheap Way To Broadband
abstract: Layne Holt and John Furrier and their Etherlinx are using wireless data standard known as WiFi or 802.11b to build system to offer broadband Internet access cheaply; system can transmit Internet data up to 20 miles at high speeds, enough to blanket entire urban regions and make cable or DSL connections obsolete; system uses inexpensive repeater antenna attached to outside of customer's home; could undermine cellular phone companies by offering much cheaper method for mobile Internet access; photo (M)

headline: Japanese Computer Is World's Fastest, as U.S. Falls Back
abstract: A Japanese laboratory has built the world's fastest computer, a machine that matches the raw processing power of the 20 fastest American computers combined.

headline: Article 2002042492258377110 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                       International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business             Technology           -      E-Business            -      Circuits            -    Columns             Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: INVESTING WITH/Neil J. Hennessy; Hennessy Cornerstone Growth Fund
abstract: Profile of Hennessy Cornerstone Growth fund and its manager, Neil J Hennessy, who relies on computer model that, he says, gives his shareholders consistency they crave; photo; graph (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: The Value Of Burberry
abstract: Britain's Burberry says it will be worth $1.72 billion to $2.18 billion when it sells shares to public next month; will use $37 million to buy out Korean distributors and $15 million for expansion, including opening of new flagship stores in US and Asia; rest of money will be used to pay down debt; chief executive Rose Marie Bravo comments (S)

headline: In Israel, Frantically Figuring the Results of Military Force
abstract: Israeli forces reportedly arrest 10 wanted men and seize small cache of weapons in Ramallah campaign, begun on March 29; surround Palestinian security services building; spokesman says 200 to 250 people are inside, many accused of planning or organizing major terrorist attacks against Israel; 124 Israelis have died and 700 have been injured in string of suicide attacks; toll is higher than during any month in nation's history except during wars; photo (M)

headline: Andersen Witnesses Defend Intent of Shredding
abstract: Defense in Arthur Andersen's criminal case has its strongest day since trial began, with two witnesses challenging government evidence that members of firm intended to obstruct federal inquiry by destroying thousands of documents related to Enron; most powerful moment comes when former Andersen executive assistant Shannon Adlong tearfully testifies about January telephone conversation she had with her boss David B Duncan, who is now government's main witness; Adlong testifies that Duncan assured her that neither he nor anyone else at firm had done anything wrong in shredding Enron records; John Stewart, senior accounting adviser at firm, testifies about e-mail message to him from Andersen lawyer regarding firm's document-retention policy; Stewart, under cross-examination by prosecutors, spells out in detail series of instances in which Andersen's team working on Enron repeatedly ignored advice of firm's top specialists on accounting issues or simply failed to consult specialists at all; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro falls on concern rising oil prices and wage demands from Germany's second-largest union will lead to faster inflation; euro settles at 87.44 cents, down from 87.94 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: F.C.C. Rules On Ownership Under Review
abstract: Federal appeals court orders FCC to reconsider rule that allows company to own two television stations in local broadcast market only if there are at least seven other companies owning stations in that market; in practice, rule prevents single company from owning more than one television station in a small or medium-size market; FCC chairman, Michael K Powell, has often spoken out against rules put in place under his predecessors that curb consolidation in media and telecommunications industries; court ruling is only latest in recent series of legal and regulatory moves that have weakened regulations limiting size of media companies; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; Celebrating the Gifted and Black
abstract: Black luminaries to assemble for awards event opening Black Business Hall of Fame, Cleveland; hall hopes to jump-start renaissance of black commerce; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Links Bosnia Role To Immunity From Court
abstract: US raises ante in opposition to International Criminal Court, threatening to veto renewal of multinational force in Bosnia unless peacekeepers are granted immunity from court; dispute pits US against European Union and other UN members; Pres Clinton signed treaty but Bush administration withdrew support (S)

headline: No Records Found to Back WorldCom's Shift of Billions
abstract: Investigators looking into WorldCom scandal have found no records to support decisions to shift billions of dollars in expenses on company's books; find that sums involved--which reduced reported operating expenses over last five quarters--were exactly those needed for WorldCom to meet its margin goals; interviews with company's board show former chief financial officer, Scott D Sullivan, reported that he independently decided to make expense shifts without consulting with WorldCom's former accountants, Arthur Andersen, or other senior executives; lack of records is likely to be crucial in unfolding investigations of Worldcom; House Financial Services Committee will hold hearing on how company overstated profits and understated expenses and subpoena WorldCom chief executive, John D Sidgmore, former chief executive, Bernard J Ebbers, and Sullivan; photo (M)

headline: Adelphia Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: Adelphia Communications and more than 200 of its subsidiaries file for bankruptcy protection; company, which has been under investigation by Securities and Exchange Commission and two federal grand juries, says it will continue to provide cable service to more than 3,500 towns and cities and that employees will continue to be paid; arranges loan of $1.5 billion to help it reorganize with J P Morgan Chase and Citigroup as lead banks (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: PAKISTAN: Pearl'S Widow Won'T Have To Testify; CAMBODIA: Increase In Rape Reported;.

headline: ABC to End 'Politically Incorrect'
abstract: ABC will announce that Politically Incorrect with Bill Maher, its late-night comedy-discussion program, will go off air in January and be replaced by show starring comedian Jimmy Kimmel (M)

headline: Seven Held in Pakistan on Bombings
abstract: Authorities said today they had detained seven men for questioning about bombings, including an attack at the U.S. Consulate.

headline: Faced with falling market share, Travelocity plans a $40 million campaign.
abstract: Travelocity, one of top online travel agencies, is introducing $40 million advertising campaign designed to promote its travel planning and purchasing features and increase its declining market share; Richards Group has designed campaign; photo (M)

headline: Speech Stuns Palestinians and Thrills Israelis
abstract: Israeli officials expressed the hope that perhaps, at last, Yasir Arafat would be ousted and a new, peace-seeking Palestinian leadership installed.

headline: Fears About Microsoft Return, in Mexico
abstract: Legislators in Mexico City are preparing their own attack against new agreement by Microsoft Corp and Mexican government that could drive millions of new Internet users to use Microsoft products; Microsoft last week agreed to support e-Mexico project, government initiative to bring Internet access by end of six-year presidential term of Vicente Fox; Microsoft deal is drawn criticism because it smacks of handing company a de facto monopoly; e-Mexico is one of Fox's most ambitious public works projects; deal presents such huge advantages for Microsoft in many critics' minds that several members of Mexico's Congress have begun to question how it came about; they say Fox administration may have signed on to Microsoft-written proposal with no debate of its wisdom or its implications for Mexico's software industry (M)

headline: Lawyers for California Doubt Effect of Enron Memos
abstract: California lawyers say that Enron Corp memos released this week outlining questionable strategies for wringing profits from electricity market in California will probably have only modest and indirect effect on their efforts to win refunds from power generators (M)

headline: Bush Presses Pakistan on Kashmir And Orders Rumsfeld to Region
abstract: Pres Bush will send Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld to India and Pakistan in effort to defuse threat of nuclear war between longtime enemies; makes strongest demand yet that Pres Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan crack down on infiltration of terrorists into India, amid growing alarm that five-month-long military buildup has reached new point of crisis; Sec Colin L Powell is sending his deputy, Richard L Armitage, to region next week; Bush has been praising Musharraf for his pledge to clamp down on Islamic extremists who carry out attacks on Indian civilians along line of separation, and newly harsh tone appears aimed at assuaging Indian rage over incursions; Bush also warns remnants of Al Qaeda thought to be gathered in western Pakistan not to exploit India-Pakistan conflict to make trouble along Pakistan's western border (M)

headline: Paul Gottlieb, Longtime Publisher of Art Books, Dies at 67
abstract: Paul Gottlieb, former Harry N Abrams publisher and editor in chief, dies at age 67; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Pipeline Acquisition
abstract: Gaz de France and TotalFinaElf SA plan to buy natural gas pipelines owned by French state to retain control of networks they operate; Gaz de France pays deposit of 176 million euros ($155 million) and TotalFinaElf pays 12.2 million euros ($10.7 million); buying pipelines will enable two companies to keep control over gas they sell and keep network out of hands of rivals (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: More Hindu-Muslim Violence
abstract: Parts of Ahmedabad in India's western state of Gujarat are under curfew after renewed Hindu-Muslim violence (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Novica.com will use money from elephants' paintings to preserve the species, make a profit and gain new customers.
abstract: Some online retailers are giving away some or most of profits from certain sales to charitable organizations in move to spur sales and customer loyalty; efforts include Novica.com plan to give most of profits from sales of paintings produced by elephants to groups that support elephant preservation; photo (M)

headline: FRENCH POLLS SEE CHIRAC  LANDSLIDE IN VOTE TOMORROW
abstract: Polls continue to predict landslide for France's center-right president, Jacques Chirac, perhaps because most of electorate objects to extremist views of his opponent Jean-Marie Le Pen, who has repeatedly made racist and anti-Semitic statements; one poll predicts that Le Pen will get 18 to 25 percent of vote, which would be more than he has ever gotten; Chirac, who got less than 20 percent of vote in first round of voting, has been buoyed by popular rejection of Le Pen; several prominent Socialists say honor of France is at stake, sentiment likely to give Chirac biggest victory of his life; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: F.T.C. Details Anti-Spam Efforts
abstract: FTC and law enforcement officials from eight states and Canada report dozens of lawsuits and settlements against various Internet schemes and senders of unsolicited e-mail, including include illegal chain letters, Web site selling cure for cancer and site that sells compact discs but fails to deliver some discs or refunds; test of more than 200 spam e-mail messages finds that vast majority do not have working 'remove me' or 'unsubscribe' options (S)

headline: TWO SIEGES FUEL TENSION AS ARAFAT MEETS U.S. ENVOY
abstract: Israeli-Palestinian relations settle into tense stalemate, as American envoy meets with Yasir Arafat without resolving twin sieges in Ramallah and Bethlehem that threaten to stir new violence day afer Israel ends military sweep through West Bank; Israeli forces maintain blockade of Palestinian cities, returning to conduct lethal, pinpoint strikes, killing at least seven Palestinians in West Bank and Gaza Strip and losing one soldier; negotiations are stalled in Bethlehem, where Israeli forces surround 250 people, some said to be wanted men, in Church of Nativity; Jibril Rajoub, head of Palestinian preventive security forces in West Bank, says his security forces have been devastated by Israeli attacks, and that security cooperation between Israelis and Palestinians is now impossible; Rajoub's popularity has declined in part because he is seen by Palestinians as too cooperative with US and Israel; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Executive Shift At Palm
abstract: Palm Inc says Todd Bradley, chief operating officer of company's Solutions Group, will become its president as well (S)

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Xerox of Accounting Abuses
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission files lawsuit against Xerox Corp in federal court in Manhattan, claiming that for four years company fraudulently used its accounting to 'burnish and distort' its financial results; Xerox, which said last week that it agreed to pay $10 million fine, did not admit or deny accusations laid out in SEC's 32-page complaint (M)

headline: QUANTA SERVICES AND AQUILA SETTLE PROXY FIGHT
abstract: Quanta Services reaches agreement that will end hostile bid by Aquila, energy trader that is its largest shareholder, to control Quanta's board; Aquila will end its proxy contest for control of board and will withdraw all litigation and arbitration; also agrees not to buy Quanta's shares on open market or begin another fight for control of board (S)

headline: WELLA BUYS NOON--IN--CHINA COSMETICS COMPANY
abstract: Wella's Intercosmetics unit buys 75 percent stake in Noon-in-China cosmetics company, which does business as Tony & Tina (S)

headline: Chrysler Warns About Sales in Canada
abstract: Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler starts notifying dealers that it will stop honoring warranties for 2003 model year on new cars and trucks bought in Canada for use in US because sales reduce automaker's profit (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Carey International, Washington named Stein Rogan & Partners, New York, part of Interpublic, as its first agency of record.

headline: Top-End Camera From Fuji Tells Stories in 6 Million Pixels
abstract: Fuji announces new 6.1 million pixel digital camera FinePix S2 Pro; it will rival other high resolution cameras; introduction is scheduled for July; photo (M)

headline: China Evades U.N. Criticism of Rights Abuses
abstract: China escapes critical resolution, while Cuba is once again in international dock as UN Commission on Human Rights begins annual review of rights abuses around world; US, usual sponsor of China resolution, lost seat on panel in upset vote last fall, and no other country steps forward; Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International report increased violations by China last year; nine Latin countries call on Fidel Castro to permit rights monitor to visit Cuba (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Fuel-Cell Research Pact
abstract: Honda Motor and Plug Power, fuel-cell maker, say they will study possibility of developing dual-purpose Plug Power fuel cells that could provide household heat and power while producing hydrogen needed to replenish fuel cells in hydrogen-powered cars Honda hopes to market later this decade; fuel cells would consumer natural gas, which is already readily available to many homeowners; graph (S)

headline: For the Queen Mother, Solemn Drums (and Offstage Disputes)
abstract: Britain begins formal farewell to Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother, with 400,000 lining London streets as 1,500 soldiers escort body to Westminster Hall, where it will lie in state on public view until funeral; male members of royal family and Princess Anne escort coffin; polished view of monarchy on display contends with offstage disputes and public indifference; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Executives Take Pay Cut; HONG KONG: Bank To Close More Branches;.

headline: Runaway Spending In Corporate Perks
abstract: Philip Kaplan letter on Apr 7 article holds perks for retired executives show corporations are as wasteful as any government; photo

headline: UAL Endorses A Pilots' Deal With Pay Cuts And U.S. Aid
abstract: Board of UAL Corp, parent of United Airlines, approves tentative agreement with its pilots on cuts that would save $520 million in costs over three years; agreement is subject to approval by United's 9,000 pilots, and it will not take effect unless airline obtains loan guarantee; board also approves plan to cut $430 million in costs over three years from management ranks; agreement calls for 10 percent cut in hourly pay but gives pilots annual raises averaging 7.9 percent in 2003 through 2005; photo of UAL Corp chief executive John W Creighton Jr (M)

headline: Rigas Family Is Giving Up Voting Control Of Adelphia
abstract: John J Rigas and his family finally surrender control of Adelphia Communications; giving up control of Adelphia because of growing turmoil about questionable dealings may be last chapter of Rigas family's involvement in business they built into nation's sixth largest cable operator but pushed to brink of ruin; besides surrendering their supervoting rights, which gave them control of 60 percent of company, Rigases cede four of their five board seats, forgive $567 million in debt owed to it by Adelphia and effectively turn over $1.2 billion in cable assets that family bought with loans backed by Adelphia; Rigas's son-in-law Peter Venetis refuses to give up his board seat despite board resolution calling for his resignation; announcement prompts Nasdaq officials to allow trading in Adelphia's shares to resume after more than week; photo (M)

headline: Anatomy of a Raid in the Afghan Mountains
abstract: US military is using special operations teams in aggressive hunt for small groups of Al Qaeda and Taliban forces dispersed in Afghanistan's Stirmaska Mountains near Pakistan border; operations, which began in late April, described; mark new phase in American-led war, in which conflict is no longer being decided by precision munitions and large-scale infantry operations, but by allied forces mounting counterinsurgency campaign; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: A Woman On The Ticket
abstract: Jose Serra, presidential candidate of Brazil's governing Social Democratic Party, names Rita Camata as running mate; she would be nation's first woman vice president; photo (S)

headline: When a Business Trip Becomes a Family Affair
abstract: Growing number of professionals are taking family members along on business trips and making it mini-vacations; National Business Travel Association survey finds that number of business travelers who made mini-vacation of their trips rose to 8.8 million in 1999 from 6.5 million in 1991; forty-six percent of those surveyed said they expect to bring spouses along with them in coming months, and 15 percent said they took children along; 1998 survey by Travel Industry Association of America drew similar conclusions; photo (M)

headline: Article 2002042292889761030 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                      International           -    Africa          -      Americas            -      Asia Pacific            -      Europe            -      Middle East               National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business              Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: Andersen Team Weighs Asking Judge to Undo Guilty Verdict
abstract: Lawyers for Arthur Andersen are discussing plans to ask Judge Melinda Harmon to throw out firm's conviction on obstruction of justice charge, based in part on rationale given publicly by jurors for verdict; jurors say they did not unanimously accept govrnment's position that Andersen obstructed justice by destroying thousands of documents related to Enron when firm knew of SEC investigation into company, but nevertheless concluded that Andersen was guilty because of efforts by Nancy Temple, Andersen lawyer, to remove certain language from draft copy of memorandum; defense lawyers argue that jurors rationale means that Andersen was, in essence, convicted for something that is not a crime (M)

headline: Gucci Posts 42% Decline In Net Income
abstract: Gucci Group's first-quarter net income falls 42 percent, to 35.5 million euros ($34 million); revenues fall 1.5 percent, to 607.6 million euros (M)

headline: Big Board Considers Putting New Rules on Corporate Boards
abstract: New York Stock Exchange is considering taking steps to help shore up investor confidence in corporate governance in aftermath of Enron Corp's collapse; one change would require companies whose shares trade on Big Board to limit participation on their audit and compensation committees to independent directors; exchange is also discussing requirement that would force companies to separate job of chairman from chief executive, reducing control over company's operations exercised by top executive; charges are discussed at meeting of Corporate Accountability and Listing Standards Committee, group that was formed in mid-February to formulate new rules on corporate governance (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Sale Of Christian Music
abstract: EMI CMG, Christian music label, starts Internet subscription service that lets users create compact discs and download songs to portable devices; service, called burnitfirst.com, charges consumers $9.95 per month for right to download, 'burn' and transfer 20 tracks from Christian musicians (S)

headline: Vivendi Chief Pushes TV Shake-Up
abstract: Vivendi Universal chief executive Jean-Marie Messier attempts to rally investor sentiment and company's board behind his plan to shake up management of company's money-losing pay television unit, Canal Plus; unit's five-member executive board votes 3 to 2 to formally dismiss unit's director Pierre Lescure, who will be replaced by Xavier Couture; some 1,000 Canal Plus employees demonstrate outside Vivendi's headquarters off Champs-Elysees; Messier is expected to name Jean-Laurent Nabet to help Couture engineer turnaround at Canal Plus; photos (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Talk Is Nowhere, And It's Everywhere
abstract: More than dozen articles from never-published final issue of Talk magazine have been revived in other publications; Entertainment Weekly and The Face, British magazine, ran portions of cover story about Courtney Love; other articles have or will appear in Vanity Fair, Rolling Stone, Details magazines; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: Protests As World Bank Meets
abstract: Antiglobalization protesters demonstrate peacefully as World Bank convenes its annual European conference in Oslo, Norway, on ways to fight global poverty; in opening remarks, bank's chief economist Nicholas Stern urges rich nations to increase development aid and dismantle trade barriers against poor countries (S)

headline: Market Place; Wall St. Push to Water Down Securities Laws
abstract: Some members of securities industry lobby Congress to bar states from going after violators of securities laws, such as Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer of New York is doing in his investigation of stock analysts; proposed amendment on subject may be attached to Sen Paul S Sarbanes's bill to tighten regulation of accounting firms and brokerage analysts; opponents of amendment see it threat to individual investors (M)

headline: Changes Made at Auditor
abstract: PricewaterhouseCoopers names Greg Brenneman president and chief executive of its PwC Consulting unit, replacing Tom O'Neill, named unit chairman (S)

headline: Fear of Loss Of Democracy Led Neighbors To Aid Return
abstract: Latin American diplomats say Venezuela's neighbors helped pave way for Hugo Chavez's stunning return to power by refusing to accept legitimacy of coup that overthrew him and by threatening to impose sanctions; efforts have opened breach between US and its democratic allies in Western Hemisphere; US reaction has left many Latin American countries with impression that Bush administration is selective in its support for democracy; up until coup, US adopted policy of restraint, seemingly content to let Chavez collapse under his growing unpopularity (M)

headline: Hewlett Executives Defend Decision Before Vote
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co chief executive Carleton S Fiorina, in series of combative courtroom exchanges, defends decision not to disclose to shareholders internal reports that raised doubts about benefits of merger with Compaq Computer Co; sums up essence of suit brought by dissident director Walter B Hewlett by telling Hewlett's lawyer 'you are accusing the chief executive officer of a publicly traded company of lying'; issue that Judge William B Chandler 3d must decide is whether Hewlett-Packard managers had 'duty to disclose' reports by teams from both companies that were planning how to make merger meet financial goals used to justify deal (M)

headline: Parsons Has No Plan to Split AOL Time Warner Despite Woes
abstract: Richard D. Parsons, who is set to become chief of AOL Time Warner, said that his company still faced significant tactical problems and still had to answer big questions about its strategic direction.

headline: Israel Continues Sweep of Cities, Taking Hebron
abstract: Israeli tanks and armored vehicles roll into Hebron, occupying one remaining major West Bank city, while Palestinians and Israelis report heavy fighting on other parts of West Bank; in Jenin, Israeli soldiers search house to house for weapons and wanted men; guerrilla fighters in Lebanon fire nine rockets across border into Israel, eighth crossborder attack since Mar 12; Prime Min Ariel Sharon, speaking before Pres Bush's address, says military operation in West Bank may last several weeks; in Ramallah, Yasir Arafat remains holed up in office compound for seventh day, surrounded by Israeli soldiers; in Bethlehem, as many as 150 gunmen remain barricaded for second day inside Church of the Nativity; Israeli officials claim gunmen are holding 15 or 20 priests hostage; priest inside church, in telephone interview, denies Israeli claim, saying men are not threatening priests; photos; maps; diagram (L)

headline: MIDEAST TURMOIL: The History; Imperative of Faith, Advanced by Force
abstract: Article on history of Israeli-Palestinian conflict, dating back to May 14, 1948, day when Jews of Palestine formally proclaimed their state, following through on United Nations vote in Nov 1947 to divide Palestine into two states, one Jewish and one Arab; photo (M)

headline: Aventis to Pay $480 Million For Rights To New Drug
abstract: Aventis agrees to pay up to $480 million to Genta for rights to promising but still experimental cancer drug known as Genasense; drug is primarily designed to enhance effectiveness of other chemotherapy drugs, not to be used by itself (M)

headline: Beijing Mayor Cracks Down on Internet Cafes After Fatal Fire
abstract: Beijing Mayor Liu Qi orders all Internet cafes in city closed temporarily after at least 24 die in fire in unlicensed cafe in university district; fire is said to be deadliest in city in more than 50 years (M)

headline: Tenuous Truce in Venezuela for the State and Its Oil Company
abstract: Pres Hugo Chavez and managers of Petroleos de Venezuela battle to uneasy truce in struggle for control of state oil monopoly; fear persists at company, with many managers afraid to discuss their role in street protests that led to Chavez's two-day ouster; economy would collapse without oil monopoly, but Chavez has steadily cut investment in production and reduced output to drive up prices; Venezuela now accounts for just three percent of global production, down from ten percent in 1970's; graph (M)

headline: NATO and Russia Shake Hands, but Will They Come Out Sparring?
abstract: Translating agreement making Russia a junior member of NATO into real NATO-Russia cooperation will be daunting challenge; many experts say that leaders on both sides of East-West divide may have buried cold war, but that too many veterans of era still neither like nor trust one another very much (M)

headline: Pope Banishes a Shadow Left By Bulgaria's Tie to Shooting
abstract: Pope John Paul II tells throng of well-wishers in crowded square in Sofia, Bulgaria, that he bears no grudge over accusations that Bulgarian secret service may have tried to have him killed in 1981; says he loves Bulgarian people; his presence in Bulgaria provides kind of absolution government has long sought; even some Bulgarians doubt that men acquitted in pope's attempted murder were entirely innocent; pope's efforts to return attention to his peace-seeking missions in Eastern Orthodox territory are dimmed by news that Rembert G Weakland, another American bishop, is under suspicion in sex abuse scandal that is engulfing Roman Catholic Church in US: photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Datalex To Delist Nasdaq Shares
abstract: Datalex, Irish developer of software for travel industry, will voluntarily delist its American depository receipts from Nasdaq on April 25; chief executive Neil Beck says that all institutional shareholders and more than 95 percent of company's private shareholders are in Ireland and Britain and that decision will save money; company's shares are traded on Irish Stock Exchange (S)

headline: Budget Office Says Tax Receipts Fell Sharply, Increasing Deficit
abstract: The Congressional Budget Office said that tax receipts through April were $75 billion below its projections, insuring that the federal budget deficit this year will be far bigger than anticipated.

headline: Son of Kim Dae Jung held in bribery scandal
abstract: SEOUL:—  President Kim Dae Jung's youngest son has been arrested and held without bail in connection with a bribery and influence-peddling scandal that has shaken his father's government.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Allergan Drug for Fighting Wrinkles
abstract: Botox, wildly popular treatment for wrinkles, is approved by Food and Drug Administration for cosmetic use to treat frown lines; approval permits Allergan, maker of Botox, to begin multimillion-dollar marketing campaign aimed at doctors and consumers; photo (M)

headline: In a word : Savoring a language's flavor
abstract: PARIS—  When I was a girl, my mother had a cookbook subtitled, "The way to a man's heart is through his stomach." Whether or not that is still true in the 21st century is debatable. But it is fair to say, even today, that one way to the heart of a foreign culture is through its expressions involving food.

headline: Kanombe Journal; After the Horror, Truth and Some Healing, Maybe
abstract: Rwanda is reviving traditional village courts to handle cases of 100,000 people charged with various offenses linked to 1994 killings of some 800,000 Tutsi and moderate Hutu; dozen such gacaca trials open around nation; trial in Kanombe described; map; photo (M)

headline: TWO ELECTRONICS RETAILERS REPORT STRONG PROFITS
abstract: Best Buy reports net income for fiscal fourth quarter of $350 million, up 84 percent from a year earlier; Circuit City Group reports net income of $152.7 million for quarter, up 51 percent (S)

headline: Arafat Court Said to Convict 4 Israel Seeks
