abstract: Israeli-Palestinian confrontation shifts increasingly to political and public relations fronts; Palestinians besieged with Yasir Arafat announce that 'military field court' tried and convicted four assassins of Israeli Tourism Min Rehavam Zeevi in Oct, and gave them sentences ranging from one to 18 years; Prime Min Ariel Sharon dismisses trial; Western diplomats say purpose of trial is to bolster Arafat's claim that he is fulfilling demands to crack down on terrorists; contemptuous Israeli reaction comes as no surprise to Palestinians; Israel continues to mount raids into Palestinian cities and towns to kill or seize wanted men; photos (M)

headline: Business; A Cloth Man With an Iron Will on Trade Policy
abstract: South Carolina Rep Jim DeMint faces tough Republican primary in re-election bid because textile billionaire Roger Milliken, dissatisfied with DeMint's key Dec vote to give Pres Bush expanded trade-negotiating authority, is backing challenger, Phil Bradley; Milliken has elevated race to event of national interest, with Bush stumping for DeMint; photos (M)

headline: New Economy; Cable Is Offering More Viewing On Demand
abstract: Cable television companies are spending billions on technology to increase availability of video on demand, which enables consumers to select programs they want to watch, when they want to watch them; see move as way to win back some households from satellite services, which lack capacity to offer service; only about third of eligible households have chosen to pay for option; drawing (M)

headline: Private Sector; Shredding Up a Storm in Houston
abstract: Name recognition has soared for Shred-it, whose Houston office had contract with Arthur Andersen to destroy Enron's unwanted documents (S)

headline: Learning curves : Helping children break the language barrier
abstract: BERLIN—  One recent bedtime, five-year-old Alec Kubekov read an English book to his mother, a selection from the "Biff and Chip" series. As his father walked in to say goodnight, Alec began translating the book into Russian. "It was a good translation," said his mother. "He was translating for sense, not word for word."

headline: Five, Including F.B.I. Agents, Are Named In a Conspiracy
abstract: Five people, including FBI agent Lynn Wingate and former agent Jeffrey A Royer, are charged by federal prosecutors in Brooklyn with using confidential government information to manipulate stock prices and extort money from companies; conspiracy led by Amr Ibrahim Elgindy, known as Tony Elgindy and Anthony Pacific, stock adviser who has clashed with regulators and is well known among traders in small stocks for his aggressive attacks on companies he considered overvalued; prosecutors say Elgindy obtained government information about publicly traded companies and then used that information to predict which stocks would fall and to persuade companies to pay for his silence; hundreds of investors have paid up to $7,000 per year for his stock recommendations; FBI agents arrest Elgindy, Derrick W Cleveland, Troy Peters, Royer and Wingate; indictment alleges Royer, who worked at FBI from 1996 until December 2001, gave Elgindy and Cleveland information from confidential government datebases about criminal histories and continuing criminal probes of companies; in return, Royer received more than $30,000 from Cleveland; FBI agent Wingate began to pass along information to Elgindy after Royer left bureau to join Elgindy's firm Pacific Equity Investments (M)

headline: Panel Backs Relaxing Rules On P.&G. Drug For Heartburn
abstract: Food and Drug Administration panel recommends allowing Procter & Gamble to sell Prilosec, heartburn medicine it distributes and AstraZeneca manufactures, without doctor's prescription; drug will rival Pepcid, marketed by Johnson & Johnson, for leadership in $1.6-billion-a-year market for over-the-counter heartburn treatments (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ovitz's Struggle Ends As His Company Is Acquired  Michael S. Ovitz's struggle to return to a pre-eminent position in the Hollywood entertainment business has ended with the folding of his management company into one run by a younger generation.     The deal, in which a company called the Firm acquires the operations of Ovitz's company, marks yet another downturn in the career of Mr. Ovitz, who had helped turn the Creative Artists Agency into the most powerful talent agency in Hollywood. [Section A.]

headline: Glaxo Freezes Prices Of AIDS Drugs in U.S.
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline, acknowledging budget constraints of many state programs intended to help people with little or no health insurance afford AIDS drugs, says it is freezing American prices of its six AIDS drugs through January 2004; freeze includes its most widely prescribed AIDS drug Combivir; company will also continue to provide some drugs free to low-income people eligible for its patient assistance program (M)

headline: In Treason Trial, Echoes of Soviet Past and K.G.B. Secrets
abstract: Oleg D Kalugin, former KGB general living in US, is being tried in absentia for treason for divulging state secrets in his autobiography and in his public testimony at trial of American Army reservist George Trofimoff, convicted of espionage in Florida in 2001; trial is only one of several prosecutions of espionage cases that have been vigorously pursued in past two-and-a-half years under Pres Vladimir V Putin, who spent career as KGB operative before becoming director of agency's successor Federal Security Service; Kalugin comments; says motive is political revenge; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Internet: Enterasys Set To Fire 30% Of Work Force
abstract: Enterasys Networks Inc, computer-networking equipment maker under investigation by Securities and Exchange Commission, will dismiss 730 workers, or 30 percent of its employees, and trim capital spending as sales fall; graph (S)

headline: Overseas Americans : 4 associations to lobby for rights in Washington
abstract: WASHINGTON—  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED Saturday, May 25, 2002:

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India and Pakistan: Effects Of Tension
abstract: Yamaha Motor Co, Sony Corp and other Japanese companies tell employees to leave India and Pakistan, joining governments from around world that have urged their citizens to leave as risk of war increases (S)

headline: A Chávez Comeback More Astounding Than His Fall
abstract: Pres Hugo Chavez's apparent return to power in Venezuela may be even more astounding than his sudden fall; fiery strongman, who rose to power on tidal wave of support from poorest classes of oil-rich country, was not out of sight for 48 hours before violence erupted in streets; photo; other Latin governments have also questioned legitimacy of interim government led by military and business leaders (M)

headline: Disney marshals its parts into a new kind of advertising deal.
abstract: $1 billion deal recently struck between Walt Disney Co and OMD USA, media arm of Omnicom Group, has become subject of much controversy in world of media advertising; OMD Worldwide president-chief executive Joe Uva says far-reaching pact, considered to be largest of its kind, represents critical shift in way media will be bought and sold; OMD will be able to tap into ABC properties like 2003 Super Bowl, Academy Awards and National Basketball Association games, as well as Disney's radio, magazine and Internet units; ABC Television president Mike Shaw comments; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: Europe FRANCE: Jail Awaits Big Mac Attacker ; BRITAIN: Waterlilies, At.

headline: Niece of Israeli U.N. Ambassador Killed
abstract: Noa Shlomo, 18, niece of Yehuda Lancry, Israeli ambassador to United Nations, is among those killed by Palestinian suicide bomber who blew up bus near Haifa; photo (M)

headline: Bush Pledges Partnership With Russians on Energy
abstract: Pres Bush and Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin agree to begin what Bush calls 'major new energy partnership,' with more American investment in Russia's oil and gas industry and faster ways for its products to reach world markets; joint statement is seen by analysts more as American nod to Russia's energy might than as agenda for concrete action; news sends oil prices down 27 cents, or 1 percent, to $25.88 per barrel on New York Mercantile Exchange; Bush calls on American businesses to 'take the lead in developing vast energy resources of Russia and Caspian' (M)

headline: Global Crossing Alternatives Are Considered
abstract: Hutchison Whampoa and Singapore Technologies Telemedia, which have proposed buying bankrupt Global Crossing's assets, could miss creditors' deadline for making formal offer; reportedly are reluctant to raise $750 million bid significantly because network assets of other troubled communications companies have come on market (M)

headline: Powell Says Details of a Palestinian State Will Come Soon
abstract: President Bush will soon give a more specific vision for creation of a Palestinian state, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today.

headline: Market Place; A boardroom battle at the expense of shareholders.
abstract: Market Place column on boardroom battle at Spectranetics Corp, maker of medical lasers to treat heart disease, that pits chief executive Joseph A Largey against rest of board; says so far, Largey is loser, but final battle has yet to be fought (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sony Raises Web Exposure
abstract: Sony Corp will buy 1 percent of RealNetworks Inc, provider of online digital video technology, for estimated $11 million; Sony is looking to increase its links to Internet (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Bill Intended To Shield Children
abstract: House of Representatives approves bill that would create .kids.us Internet extension restricted to child-friendly material; bill would require operator of .us domain, NeuStar, to create subdomain limited to sites appropriate for children 12 or younger; Neustar will be expected to monitor this extension and remove any objectionable material (S)

headline: Canada and U.S. to Cooperate in Inquiry on Bombing
abstract: American military personnel will cooperate with Canadian officials investigating the accidental American bombing of a Canadian military exercise in Afghanistan.

headline: Behind the Upheaval in Venezuela
abstract: Turmoil surrounding Pres Hugo Chavez exposes deep social and racial rift in Venezuela between upper and middle classes, who tend to be lighter skinned, and poor majority; Chavez's turbulent political career has been driven by entrenched polarization; he comes from poor family, rising to power by seizing on swelling discontent among country's poorest masses; photos; graph (M)

headline: Judge Refuses to Postpone Andersen Trial
abstract: Federal Judge Melinda Harmon, in another setback to Arthur Andersen, denies firm's request that its trial on obstruction of justice charges be postponed because of concerns about finding impartial jurors; firm argues in pretrial hearing in Federal District Court, Houston, that potential jurors are being prejudiced by wave of publicity, and as result many have prejudged Andersen as guilty (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Reserves Tapped For Debt
abstract: Argentina's Ministry of Economy decides to use almost $800 million in foreign reserves rather than default on first installment on repayment of $2.5 billion loan from World Bank (S)

headline: New Questions On Auditors For Adelphia
abstract: New details about Rigas family's self-dealings are raising questions about how much Adelphia Communications' accountants and its audit committee knew about--and possibly ignored--conflicts that were created by transactions; in documents filed with Securities and Exchange Commission, Adelphia details dozens of transactions between Rigas family and company, from undisclosed loans that totaled about $130 million to support family-owned Buffalo Sabres hockey team to corporate purchase of 50 cars from Preston Cars, company controlled by Adelphia founder John J Rigas; filing reveals previously undisclosed deals, including one in which family bought for about $500,000 some 3,600 acres of land on which Adelphia had bought timber rights for $26.5 million; company invested $3 million in Songcatcher, film produced by Ellen Rigas Venetis, daughter of John Rigas; NFHLP, partnership owned by Rigas family that owns Buffalo Sabres, withdrew cash from cash fund within company to finance some of its investments in team; one of most significant questions raised by disclosures is why Deloitte & Touche, accountant for both company and family-controlled entities, did not inform Adelphia's audit committee that family was using company's credit lines to buy Adelphia stock (M)

headline: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES NAMES LEAD DIRECTOR FOR BOARD
abstract: Computer Associates confirms that Lewis Ranieri, one of its directors and former vice chairman of Salomon Brothers, has been named to board to be lead director; board also gives chairmanship of audit committee to director Walter Schuetze, former chief accountant at Securities and Exchange Commission (S)

headline: Energy Trader Cancels Deal; Shares Tumble
abstract: Turmoil worsens in deregulated electricity industry after Reliant Resources, big independent power producer and trader, cancels $500 million bond sale amid questions about whether all of its trades are real; Reliant discloses it bought power from another company while simultaneously selling same amount back to that company, move that increased its reported trading volume, key measure of company's health; shares in big independent power producers and traders skid after announcement, worsening year-long slump; photo (M)

headline: Privacy Policy On Web Shifts As Profits Ebb
abstract: Internet companies, pressed for profits, are increasingly selling access to their users' postal mail addresses and phone numbers and flooding them with junk e-mail; changes in privacy policy by Internet portals Yahoo and Excite cited; many marketing experts question whether risks to companies reputations may outweigh revenue gains; photos (M)

headline: What's in a Name? For Ritz-Carlton, About 25%
abstract: Millennium Partners is building $155 million, 17-story, 220-apartment tower in Boston that will carry hotel name and offer hotel amenities like room service, housekeeping and health club, but have no outright accommodations at all; photo (M)

headline: Bank Holiday and Creditors Add to Crisis in Argentina
abstract: The Argentine financial situation took a turn for the worse over the weekend after the government suspended bank and foreign exchange operations indefinitely.

headline: Moody's Sees Risks in Threats to Landmarks
abstract: Moody's Investors Service, in another indication of financial concerns about threat of terrorist attacks in New York and other cities, says it is reviewing its ratings on $5 billion in loans on about dozen big commercial buildings and groups of buildings; most of buildings are in Manhattan (M)

headline: Defense Secretary Tells NATO To Beat Terrorists to Punch
abstract: Question of possible miiltary action against Iraq hangs in air as Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld urges NATO defense ministers meeting in Brussels to take fight against terrorism to terrorists with pre-emptive attacks on shadowy networks or hostile states armed with biological, chemical or nuclear weapons; says group must expand its definition of collective self-defense; NATO officials emphasize extent of resistance among member countries, even staunch American allies like Britain, to attack in Iraq (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: NEW FINANCIAL OFFICER AT PEREGRINE; F.B.I. SEARCHES SOFTWARE MAKER;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Monetary Policy Unchanged
abstract: Bank of Japan keeps its zero interest rate policy unchanged; says it will continue to keep up 15 trillion yen ($119 billion) of surplus cash in money markets and guide short-term interest rates toward zero (S)

headline: Article 2002042492983257422 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: International Paper Version         function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                         International           -      Africa            -      Americas            -      Asia Pacific            -      Europe            -      Middle East               National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business              Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: A Sense of Sorrow, and Humor
abstract: My Job column by R J Damiano describes being funeral director in Long Branch, NJ; photo (M)

headline: Investigators Cite Inconsistencies In Martha Stewart Stock Case
abstract: Congressional investigators say there are 'troubling inconsistencies' between what lawyers for Martha Stewart have told them about time of her sale of ImClone Systems shares and what her stockbroker Peter Bacanovic is reported to have said; Congressional spokesman Ken Johnson says requests for documents have not been met, one week after those requests were made; House Energy and Commerce Committee is also seeking records from Merrill Lynch, where Stewart's trade was handled; Johnson says committee also wants to interview Bacanovic, who handled sale for Stewart (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: 100 Lashes For Premarital Sex
abstract: Adama Yunusa is sentenced to 100 lashes by Islamic court for having sex with her fiance, Isa Katagum, who escapes punishment; sentence will be carried out after baby is born (S)

headline: A Credit Gauge Strengthens
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp reports credit ratings of American corporations improved slightly during first-quarter 2002 after long decline (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: GERMANY: Construction Strike; MERGER SCRUTINY TO PERSIST; GERMANY: Kirchmedia Retains Control; ROMANIA: Vampire Theme Park Seeks Funds; BRITAIN: Go Fly Takeover Approved;.

headline: Office Turf: No. 1 Faces An Upstart
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column examines software available at no charge from www.openoffice.org, or for $76 from Sun, company that started and coordinates project; Sun package offers several extra functions as well as discounts to corporations buying in quantity; package was developed by group of programmers intent on making dent in Microsoft monopoly by offering software to compete with Microsoft Office, which is priced at $580; OpenOffice has word processor, spreadsheet and slide-show programs and runs in 27 languages on choice of three operating systems; timing of release coincides with Microsoft's new Office XP and pricey upgrade plan; in trials, OpenOffice is almost clone of Microsoft software and appears to be compatible with Microsoft-generated documents; drawing (M)

headline: Israeli Forces Pull Back From Jenin, But Blockade Still Remains
abstract: Israel withdraws its forces to outskirts of Jenin refugee camp, leaving Palestinians to search ruins for their dead and missing; Prime Min Ariel Sharon has called Jenin 'capital of Palestinian terror' and presented Israel's two-week operation there as counterterrorist offensive; as operation winds down, Israel continues to treat Jenin as threat, with tanks and troops forming ring around city and blockading it; number of dead in Jenin remains unknown; Israeli officials say about 100 homes were destroyed, but officials from United Nations agency that oversees Palestinian refugee camps are making their own count; photos (M)

headline: Gates to Bankroll Nutrition Project
abstract: Bill Gates, chairman of Microsoft Corp. appears at General Assembly Special Session on Children and pledges to bankroll bulk of $70 million effort to combat malnutrition; says Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation would contribute $50 million over five years to help fortify basic foods for children in developing world; Canadian and American governments are also contributing to project (S)

headline: Reading the Details Of Earnings Reports
abstract: Michael R Chiavoni letter holds Apr 14 article does not provide facts needed to determine whether investors can trust General Electric earnings report

headline: Market Place; One man occupies the really hot seat for Vivendi's crucial television ambitions.
abstract: Market Place column on financial problems facing France's Vivendi Universal focuses on Vivendi's $10.3 billion acquisition of USA Networks' film and television operations; says how and whether that deal delivers on its promise will probably prove more vital to Vivendi's long-term prospects than identity of person running financially-plagued pay-TV unit Canal Plus; says Barry Diller will become chief of new Vivendi Universal Entertainment operation, but will have little control over operation; holds real task of making Vivendi's US television ambitions reality will fall to executive Michael Jackson; photo (M)

headline: EARLY INQUIRY FEAR SEEN AT ANDERSEN
abstract: Former Arthur Andersen partner David B Duncan tells prosecutors that members of firm grew concerned in Aug about possibility of federal inquiry after allegations of accounting fraud at Enron were raised by Sherron S Watkins, whistle-blower at company; Duncan's statements indicate that roots of obstruction of justice scandal reached back further than previously believed; he says that in response to Watkins' criticisms and other problems, Andersen formed unofficial committee that month to begin reviewing firm's documents relating to Enron; says decision to destroy documents emerged as result of those discussions; prosecutors will use Duncan's testimony to argue that destruction last Oct by Andersen of thousands of documents and e-mail messages related to Enron was not spontaneous decision of few employees, but culmination of months of discussions about how to get Enron's files ready for review by outside investigators; argument that Anderson officials anticipated review of Enron records by Securites and Exchange Commission after learning of Watkins' allegations is critical to proving that document destruction was conducted to impede official inquiry (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel To Cut 3,500 More Jobs
abstract: Nortel Networks says it will cut 3,500 more jobs and might sell its optical-parts business amid new projections of flat to lower second-quarter sales; says meaningful recovery in long-haul optical market is not expected before late 2003 or early 2004; graph (S)

headline: Adrian Evans, Chief of Lazard in London, Is Dead at 60
abstract: Adrian Evans, chief executive of London partnership of Lazard LLC, dies at age 60 (M)

headline: Investigators Are Questioning Sale of ImClone Shares by a Friend of Martha Stewart
abstract: Congressional investigators probing possible insider trading in ImClone stock following announcement on December 28 that Food and Drug Administration rejected its anticancer drug Erbitux are seeking information about sale of shares by Dr Bart Pasternak, Connecticut doctor, on same date; Pasternak's ex-wife flew to Mexico with Martha Stewart around time trade was made; remains unclear whether Pasternak's sale was related to Stewart's sale of 4,000 shares of ImClone stock day earlier (M)

headline: Ex-Soldier Fabricated Chechnya Story, Russian Officials Say
abstract: Russian officials and acquaintances of Andrei Samorodov say former Russian Army officer was not serving in army in 1999, at time he claims he fled battlefield in Chechnya to escape pressure from fascist cadets to execute civilians there; Samorodov apparently fabricated his case for political asylum in United States, which was granted in May 2000; Samorodov has declined to comment since his account of events was challenged (M)

headline: Gazprom Chief Calls In Sick, Or Maybe It's a Conspiracy
abstract: Aleksei Miller, chief executive of Russian natural-gas monopoly Gazprom, fails to attend annual meeting, citing illness; his absence stirs speculation of conspiracy (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Zero Rate Unchanged
abstract: Bank of Japan leaves its zero-interest-rate policy unchanged; bank has been under less pessure to ease monetary conditions with economy showing signs of life (S)

headline: Article 2002042191933399854 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                       International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business              Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: Mexico Now Appears to Be Developing the Politics of Stalemate
abstract: Mexico inches toward politics of stalemate as Institutional Revolutionary Party, former governing party, has succeeded in blocking coalition government of Pres Vicente Fox at every opportunity in Congress; Fox is struggling to consolidate political power in capital and throughout Mexico (M)

headline: ISRAELIS CAPTURE AN ARAFAT DEPUTY IN THE WEST BANK
abstract: Israeli forces arrest Marwan Barghouti, leader of Yasir Arafat's Fatah movement in biggest catch of its West Bank military offensive; he is accused of planning and financing terrorist attacks while masquerading as politician without military role; Prime Min Ariel Sharon says capture is evidence of value of Israeli mission; says Israel will try Barghouti, who is brought to Jerusalem for questioning; Palestinians insist Barghouti is not military man; warn arrest is likely to provoke more violence; arrest deprives Arafat of trusted lieutenant while further complicating Sec of State Colin Powell's effort to arrange truce after more than 18 months of fighting; arc of Barghouti's career--from Israeli prisoner, to peace advocate, to supporter of conflict to Israeli prisoner again--discussed; once popular with Israeli officials, he is now simply regarded as terrorist; Sharon announces Israeli forces will withdraw within week from Nablus and Jenin, two West Bank cities where fighting has been fiercest, but again defies American demands that Israeli military operation end; says military will remain in Bethlehem and Ramallah until it suceeds in capturing or exiling wanted men trapped in each city; speaks with Pres Bush by telephone; tells him plans for withdrawal from Nablus and Jenin; photos (M)

headline: Bomb in Pakistan Mosque Kills 12 and Hurts Dozens
abstract: Powerful bomb explodes at mosque in Bukker, in central Pakistan, during religious festival, hurling bodies into air and killing 12 worshipers, all of them women and children; explosion also wounds 23 people; it appears to be latest attack in long-running feud between Sunni and Shiite Muslim sects that has taken more than 2,000 lives over past decade; Gen Pervez Musharraf hoped to reduce such sectarian feuds when he banned militant groups in Jan; hundreds of members of radical Sunni and Shiite groups were detained, but most have since been released; apart from militant groups, Pakistan's Sunnis and Shiites mostly live and work together in peace (M)

headline: President Bush's Speech to the German Parliament
abstract: Following is the text of President Bush's speech on Thursday to the German Parliament, as provided by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.

headline: 2 Agencies Shut Offices As Work Falls Off
abstract: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA: 2 Agencies Shut Offices As Work Falls Off**Arnold Worldwide is closing its San Francisco office, citing continued weak advertising economy there; office's top executives, Jim McGinn and Stu Cooperrider, will return to Arnold's Boston headquarters and 17 other employees will be laid off; Grey Worldwide is closing its Fort Worth office and will lay off 11 employees (S)

headline: Railroads Raise Freight Rates
abstract: Railroads Raise

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Move To Ban Basque Party
abstract: Spanish cabinet agrees on bill to ban Batasuna, party considered poiltical wing of armed Basque separatist group ETA (S)

headline: Korea Plans Gradual Easing Of Currency Exchange Rules
abstract: South Korea's Economic Affairs Sec Han Duck Soo says government hopes to make country leading Asian business hub by gradually lifting restrictions on ways its currency, the won, is traded and used abroad; business leaders have complained that current rules make it difficult to do business overseas, and that they deter multinational companies from investing or operating in South Korea; government has announced that exchange regulations will be lifted in stages over nine years (M)

headline: U.S. and Britain Begin New Combat Mission in Afghanistan
abstract: A new operation to destroy Al Qaeda and Taliban forces is under way in Afghanistan involving British Royal Marines, officials said today.

headline: Investigators Named in Canadian Deaths
abstract: Brig. Gen. Stephen T. Sargeant of the Air Force and Brig. Gen. Marc Dumais of Canada will lead an inquiry into why an Air National Guard pilot mistakenly bombed Canadian troops in Afghanistan last week.

headline: Japan's Four Big Banks Move Toward a Recovery
abstract: Japan's biggest banking companies--Mizuho Holdings, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking, UFJ Holdings and Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group--report large losses for 2002 fiscal year ended March 31, but four banking companies expect to show modest profits in 2003 fiscal year; together four lost 2.68 trillion yen ($21.5 billion); banks are shaping more focused strategies, concentrating on commercial lending or wealthy individuals or mass market; analysts believe worst is over for banks; chart (M)

headline: Czech Voters Block Return of Center-Right Ex-Leader
abstract: Czech voters reject comeback bid by their contentious former prime minister, Vaclav Klaus, opting apparently for less confrontation in politics and smooth road toward joining European Union; voters choose to keep in power center-left Social Democrats, whose new leader, Vladimir Spidla, campaigned on greatly increased spending and quick accession to European Union; photos (M)

headline: Arafat's Words: No 'Terror Attacks'
abstract: Transcript of Yasir Aafat's television address in which he repeats commitment to international war against terrorism

headline: Europe's Opinion of Bush Rises; Still, Many Disagree With Him
abstract: European opinion of President Bush as a foreign policy leader has significantly improved since Sept. 11, according to a new poll.

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: Africa NIGERIA: Obasanjo To Seek Second Term ; NIGERIA: Death Penalty Sought ; LIBERIA: Independent Newspaper Closed ; Aid For 31 African Countries.

headline: US BANCORP UNIT FINED $250,000 BY NASDAQ BODY
abstract: US Bancorp Piper Jaffray and senior investment banker Scott Beardsley are fined by National Association of Securities Dealers for threatening to drop Antigenics Inc as research client unless biotechnology hired firm to arrange stock sale; US Bancorp is fined $250,000 and Beardsley $50,000; case is first in which NASD punished company for making threat linking underwriting and research coverage (S)

headline: A Pioneer Takes a Break
abstract: Update on Andrew D Klein, Wit Capital founder who stepped down as vice chairman and chief strategist of successor company, SoundView Technology Group, in Jan when first online investment bank retrenched; he says he wants to work with European tech startups, interview; has invested so far in three companies; photos (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Reality-TV Idea: Gay Men Groom Straights
abstract: Reality-TV program The Queer Eye for the Straight Guy could make Bravo's fall schedule; show promises to follow makeover of what casting notice calls 'crude and uncultured' straight guy into 'hip and happening Renaissance man at the hands of five fabulously trendy gay men'; shows's producers, Scout Productions,' hope to find their transformative men in worlds of fashion, interior design, culture, grooming and food and wine (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: THE HAGUE: Delay In Milosevic'S Trial; GERMANY: Convictions In Attack On Foreigners; CZECH REPUBLIC: Agreement On New Government; FRANCE: JuppÉ Rises On Chirac'S Coattails;.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Rebels' Cease-Fire Rejected
abstract: Maoist rebel leader Pushpa Kamal Dahal proposes monthlong cease-fire in fighting in Nepal; Prime Min Sher Bahadur Deuba rejects plan, saying Maoists betrayed him last year when they broke off peace talks; Deuba is in United States seeking military aid to help crush insurgency (S)

headline: Article 2002042194211291664 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                       International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business             Technology           -      E-Business            -      Circuits            -    Columns             Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: GERMANY: Wage Talks Break Down; FRANCE: Consumer Spending Rises; SPAIN: Stake In Builder Acquired.

headline: On Taliban's Old Turf, A Campaign of Disruption
abstract: Officials in southern Afghanistan say killings of four soldiers in Shah Wali Kot district north of Kandahar is most gruesome of multiple signs that Taliban supporters and other groups are intent on committing violence to disrupt political process in country and fight interim government and its American backers; victims' car was said to be carrying papers for loya jirga, grand council that is to meet in Kabul from June 10 to 16 to choose new leaders for Afghanistan; photo; map (M)

headline: Aides' Joy Cannot Blunt Arafat's Anger at Israelis
abstract: Joyful office workers and men hoisting rifles emerge from Yasir Arafat's bullet-pocked office building in Ramallah, taking in fresh air for first time after 34 days of Israeli siege; Arafat himself does not leave building, but issues scathing indictment of Israelis over news that fighting has broken out at siege around Church of Nativity in Bethlehem; Arafat's aides say he felt tricked, that Israelis timed their withdrawal from Ramallah with assault on church in Bethlehem; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Tyco Reconsiders a Sale Of Its Plastics Operation  Tyco International plans to announce tomorrow that it may suspend the auction of its plastics unit, executives close to the company said. Its asking price was apparently too high.    In addition, Tyco has so far failed to find a buyer for all or part of CIT, its financial division, and may have to instead spin that unit off in an initial public offering as a way to generate cash, the executives said. [Page C2.]    Trial Opens in Hewlett-Packard Case  On the first day of trial, lawyers representing Walter B. Hewlett, the dissident director of Hewlett-Packard who has filed suit to challenge its planned merger with Compaq Computer, contended that management had repeatedly misled shareholders about projected gains from Compaq even as senior executives inside the two companies had become more pessimistic. [C4.]

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WARNACO GROUP INC., New York, the apparel maker, said it was asking a federal bankruptcy judge to approve its plan to close 25 outlet stores and hire a liquidator to sell inventory.    ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP., Plano, Tex., an information services provider, said it had signed a $200 million contract with Baylor Health Care System, Dallas, to set up a program that tracks patient data.

headline: At a Shoppers' Mecca, Now, Retail for Locals
abstract: Woodbury Centre, 68-acre retail development between Woodbury and Central Valley, NY, is scheduled to open in fall; development, owned by Allied Partners, is more than 81 percent leased and negotiations are under way to add bookstore, electronics store and other shops; maps (M)

headline: GENERAL ELECTRIC TO BUY DRUCK FOR $335 MILLION
abstract: General Electric will buy Druck Holdings, British maker of electrical measuring instruments, for 229 million pounds ($335 million) (S)

headline: Argentina's President Suffers Double Blow
abstract: Article on apparent unraveling of Argentina governmentnoted

headline: W.T.O. Loophole Allows a Surge in Protectionism
abstract: 'Safeguard' exception that was supposed to be small, minor loophole in global trade rules is being used often for protectionist ends, putting at risk decades of progress in liberalizing world trade; safeguard agreement was used in two cases in 1995 when it went into effect; 53 cases used loophole in 2001; Bush administration invoked it in March to justify selective tariffs on imported steel, and European Union in turn invoked it to justify countermeasures; surge in use of safeguard comes despite fact that World Trade Organization has yet to bless single safeguard measure that has been challenged before it (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Terror Suspect Won't Fight Extradition
abstract: Amine Mezbar, also known as Adel Tobbichi, Algerian man suspected of being part of plot to bomb United States Embassy in Paris, tells Canadian court he will not resist request from Netherlands to extradite him (S)

headline: Witness Cites Confusion In Shredding At Andersen
abstract: Arthur Andersen investigator David Stulb testifies at firm's criminal trial that David B Duncan, partner who confessed to shredding documents related to Enron, needed internal legal advice about what documents needed to be kept; point made by Stulb, prosecution witness, may well serve defense team because he testifies that Duncan did not realize significance of what he was doing; Rusty Hardin, Andersen's lead lawyer, tells reporters after proceedings that Duncan did nothing wrong (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Openwave Will Acquire SignalSoft
abstract: Openwave Systems Inc, which makes wireless Internet software, will buy SignalSoft Corp for about $59 million in effort to expand its line of wireless data services; will buy downloading technology to enable delivery of Java applications for games and multimedia content from Ellipsus Systems Inc for about $17.5 million (S)

headline: Private Sector: Executive Pay; Options Foe Is Not So Lonely Now
abstract: Profile of Sen Carl Levin, who has long opposed current accounting for stock options as misleading practice that gives executives 'stealth compensation' and entices some to act to boost stock prices at expense of long-term corporate health; he sponsors bill to strip companies of lucrative tax benefits they get when options are exercised, unless they deduct cost of options on their income statements; he says he does not oppose options, interview; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Montenegro: Government Resigns
abstract: Montenegrin government of Prime Min Filip Vujanovic resigns amid dispute over new plan to reconstitute Yugoslavia; photo (S)

headline: AT&T and Unions Agree on Contract
abstract: AT&T reaches tentative agreement with unions representing 12 percent of its work force; 18-month contract includes 6 percent pay raise and $250 bonus; company will also increase pensions by 8 percent, cover higher health-insurance premiums for retirees, and pay interest of 5.5 percent on cash in workers' retirement accounts; workers are represented by Communications Workers of America and International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers (S)

headline: Saatchi & Saatchi Gets New P.& G. Accounts
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co is consolidating its worldwide Pamers diaper-products account at Saatchi & Saatchi in New York; some duties had previously been handled by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Stocks And Currency Sink
abstract: Uncertainty grows concerning both performance of economy and outcome of upcoming presidential election, causing Brazilian currency to fall to record low against dollar and stock prices to sink; declines follow rating services' lowering outlook for Brazil's economy (M)

headline: United Wants Loan Backing From U.S.
abstract: United Airlines files application with Air Transportation Stabilization Board for $1.8 billion guarantee to back $2 billion in private loans; plan calls for cutting more than $950 million from labor costs over three years as well as forming partnership with US Airways in which they will share revenue by booking passengers on each other's flights; United's chief executive John W Creighton Jr comments; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: More Bank Losses Seen
abstract: Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group becomes last major bank group to forecast loss for fiscal year ended March 31; company now expects to lose 145 billion yen ($1.1 billion) (S)

headline: How Settlement Is Worded Could Be Costly to Merrill
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co executives hope to reach settlement soon with New York State Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer on accusations that some of its stock analysts mislead customers tha twould require Merrill to pay fine of as much as $100 million; real cost of that agreement, if it can be reached, would hinge on what Merrill says in response to Spitzer's accusations; Spitzer has demanded that Merrill admit to wrongdoing, while firm's executives ae holding out hope that apologies will suffice (M)

headline: Plan to Change Internet Group Is Criticized As Inadequate
abstract: Internet Corp for Assigned Names and Numbers president M Stuart Lynn's call for internal reform, which focuses mainly on structural and financing problems, has spurred larger debate; critics hold Icann, in addressing policy issues, is slow, bureaucratic and lacking openness; some have asked Commerce Department, which was instrumental in creating Icann, to get involved; some within United State government are wary of Lynn's call to make Internet's naming and address allocation system, intentionally designed as private nonprofit corporation, multinational quasi-governmental body (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailers End Merger Talks
abstract: British retailer Woolworths Group abandons talks to merge with BHS, department store chain controlled by Philip Green (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Liquor Maker Posts Gain
abstract: Allied Domecq posts first-half net income of 174 million pounds ($254 million), up 52 percent from 114 million pounds ($166 million) a year ago; chief executive, Philip Bowman, says he expects to meet analysts' forecasts this year; photo (S)

headline: White House Gets 24 Hours To Turn Over Enron Papers
abstract: Sen Joseph I Lieberman gives White House 24 more hours to turn over to his committee data about their contacts with Enron as Bush administration and committee Democrats debate how subpoenaed documents will be handled by panel investigators; committee staff members begin reviewing documents; Texas utility regulators propose fining Enron $7.1 million for allegedly manipulating state's wholesale power market last August; photo (M)

headline: Afghans Say 5 Killed in a U.S. Raid Were Farmers
abstract: Afghans say five people killed in May 12 raid by US Special Forces on village of Char Chine in Oruzgan province were farmers; American military spokesman says that troops raided compound suspected of being sanctuary for senior members of Taliban and Al Qaeda and that five killed opened fire first; villagers describe raid; map; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Dominican Republic: Human Rights Plea
abstract: Human rights advocates urge Dominican government to protect people of Haitian descent who have been denied citizenship; Human Rights Watch report says darker-skinned people are singled out and deported (S)

headline: At Least 12 Die As Car Bomber Hits Israeli Bus
abstract: Car bomb blows up next to bus near town of Afula in northern Israel, killing at least 12 people, including car's driver, and wounding dozens more; attack casts pall over mission of George J Tenet, US director of central intelligence; Yasir Arafat lays out for Tenet his plans to reorganize Palestinian security apparatus, proposing to consolidate dozen-odd police and intelligence forces into few streamlined agencies under his direct control; Prime Min Ariel Sharon has already told Tenet that first priority is that Arafat should stop all violence and terrorism and that no real reforms are possible in Palestinian Authority without Arafat's removal from leadership; will travel to Washington on June 7; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: McAfee.com Accepts Buyout Offer
abstract: McAfee.com agrees to buyout offer from Network Associates, two weeks after it rejects earlier bid as too low; Network Associates will grant 0.768 of a share for each McAfee.com share, instead of 0.675 of a share, sweetening share offer 16 percent; revised offer is worth $235 million compared with $248 million for earlier bid; McAfee.com reports first-quarter profit of 11 cents per share, or 8 cents excluding special items, in contrast to loss of 6 cents year earlier, beating Wall Street's expectations; sales rose 46 percent, to $18.8 million, slightly less than analysts expected (S)

headline: Curb on Gas Emissions Is Stalled in California
abstract: Bill to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from automobiles stalls in California State Assembly; bill would be first to restrict automotive emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases thought by many scientists to be linked to global warming; bill directs California Air Resources Board to develop plan for reducing greenhouse gas emissions by January 2005, to be put into effect for 2009 model year; bill has met with staunch opposition from auto industry (M)

headline: Darra Adam Khel Journal; When It's Business, the City Sticks to Its Guns
abstract: Over 3,000 father-and-son operations that make, trade and sell weapons from open-front shops line streets of isolated Darra Adam Khel, Pakistan; gunsmithing tradition goes back at least century, passed down through generations; customers include rebel armies from around world and Pakistanis; map; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Cease-Fire Monitors
abstract: International monitors begin enforcing cease-fire in Nuba Mountains, site of some of fiercest fighting in Sudan's civil war between southern rebels and government in north (S)

headline: White House Is Working To Nail Down Mideast Plan
abstract: Latest suicide bombing and Israeli reprisal raids elicit strong and familiar condemnations from senior Bush administration officials, but they also insist that events will not deter them from discussing new proposals for peace with Pres Hosni Mubarak of Egypt this weekend and Prime Min Ariel Sharon of Israel when he arrives day later; Bush and his national security adviser Condoleezza Rice are said to be leaning toward notion of outlining parameters or timetable for final peace settlement that would follow lines of proposals under discussion before negotiations broke down; international pressure for presidential response expected to intensify after Bush's meetings with Mubarak and Sharon (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Amcor Buys Bottler
abstract: Amcor will buy bottling assets of Schmalbach-Lubeca, owned by German insurance giant Allianz for 2.88 billion Australian dollars or $1.55 billion; purchase will make it world's largest producer of plastic soft drink bottles (S)

headline: ADELPHIA, CLOSE TO BANKRUPTCY, GETS A LOAN
abstract: Troubled cable television operator Adelphia Communications, ready to file for bankruptcy, reaches agreement with J P Morgan Chase and Citigroup to receive $1.5 billion loan, permitting it to continue operations while in reorganization (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Web address of International Home Exchange Network, mentioned in June 9 article about home exchanges for vacationers

headline: A Rising Toll for Bush: No Peace, More Blame
abstract: For a president whose fortunes were lifted beyond expectation after Sept. 11, George W. Bush has had a bad week.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Jobless Rate Falls
abstract: Canada reports its unemployment rate fell to 7.7 percent, Mar, from 7.9 percent in Feb (S)

headline: The Price of Gold Is Shining. Hedging of Gold Is Not.
abstract: Portfolios column examines sharp increase in price of gold that has swung sentiment sharply against hedging by investors; graphs (M)

headline: KROLL TO PAY $140 MILLION IN STOCK FOR ONTRACK DATA
abstract: Kroll Inc agrees to buy Ontrack Data International for about $140 million in stock to add data-recovery and electronic-discovery services for litigation (S)

headline: Cisco Buoyed By Earnings, But It Sees No Turnaround
abstract: Cisco Systems reports profits for is fiscal third quarter ended April 27 that are better than expected; says it earned $729 million; sales were up 2 percent over last year but $40 million less than expected by Wall Street analysts; president-chief executive John T Chambers predicts no quick recovery from slowdown in spending by its customers at telecommunications providers and large corporations (M)

headline: Peter Bauer, British Economist, Is Dead at 86
abstract: Peter Bauer, British economist who challenged utility of giving development aid to poor countries, believing that it often perpetuated their poverty, dies at age 86; photo (M)

headline: Panoramic Chief Moves to Arnold McGrath
abstract: Panoramic Chief Moves To Arnold McGrath Mary Baglivo, the president and chief executive at Panoramic Communications in New York, the company that owns agencies like Earle Palmer Brown, is leaving to become president at Arnold McGrath, the New York office of Arnold Worldwide Partners.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Effort To Ease Tensions With U.S.
abstract: Prime Minister Jean Chrétien has set up a Liberal Party task force to study ways to improve relations with the United States as tensions over bilateral trade grow. Mr. Chrétien announced the formation of the group after he failed to persuade President Bush to end tariffs on Canadian soft wood lumber.   Clifford Krauss (NYT)

headline: Lenders Plan to Take Control of Hynix Board
abstract: Creditors have decided to take control of Hynix Semiconductor's board, which has obstructed their efforts to sell Hynix's main businesses to pay off debt; government-run Korea Exchange Bank says creditors will convert $2.3 billion in bonds they hold into shares of company's stock on June 7 (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Output Edges Higher; JAPAN: Back Taxes Sought.

headline: Ruth Fertel of Steakhouse Fame Is Dead at 75
abstract: Ruth Fertel, founder of Ruth's Chris Steak Houses, dies at age 75; photo (M)

headline: PrivateSector; Finding Creative Reasons For Dreary Results
abstract: Securities analysts say WorldCom chief executive Bernard J Ebbers was probably sharing frustration, not serious analysis, when he questioned ethics of consultants who help WorldCom's biggest clients negotiate contracts; say he implied consultants improperly revealed to clients data obtained in private talks for other clients; consultants dispute charge; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Error Kills 4 Canadians in Afghanistan
abstract: American fighter pilot mistakenly drops 500-pound bomb on group of Canadian soldiers conducting training mission in southern Afghanistan, killing four and wounding eight; Pentagon says accident occurred after pilots of two F-16's saw muzzle flashes on ground below and thought they were under attack; it is not clear whether pilots were given permission to attack or independently dropped bomb in what they believed was self-defense; Canadian military officials say training area is well known to American forces; Pres Bush calls Prime Min Jean Chretien of Canada to express condolences and to pledge full investigation of incident with Canadians; central issue for investigators will be whether pilots of F-16 team sought permission from air controllers to attack (M)

headline: But in Vocal Brussels, Boos, Boos, Boos
abstract: Jean-Marie Le Pen, member of European Parliament who rarely shows up to participate, appears at Parliament meeting in Brussels but is booed by colleagues before making remarks; intended to elaborate on his idea that France should pull out of European Union and restore French franc (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of May 5 article on alcoholic beverage market in India; ten percent is rate of increase in consumption

headline: Aides to Bush Say Arafat Financed a Terrorist Group
abstract: Reports showing that Yasir Arafat is continuing to finance the Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades is said to have led President Bush to demand the Palestinian leader's ouster.

headline: China's Man to Watch Steps Into the U.S. Spotlight
abstract: Vice Pres Hu Jintao, who is expected to take over as China's leader this fall, will make his first visit to United States in diplomatic debut that will be closely watched at home and abroad; he has spent last year parroting Pres Jiang Zemin's calls to modernize Communist Party; he has worked tirelessly inside party through string of jobs in provinces, building alliances and leaving no imprints; trip to United States is scripted step into spotlight for Hu, who has reportedly never seen US; to protect his standing at home, he must strike delicate balance; photo (M)

headline: An F.C.C. Move Catches the Media Industry in Mid-Yawn
abstract: Douglas H McCorkindale, chairman of Gannett, and Shaun Sheehan, Tribune's vice president for Washington affairs, are unhappy that FCC will not complete its review of six important media ownership rules until next spring; other media executives, analysts and investors, however, view FCC decision to review rules as group rather than piecemeal as just procedural step that will not change long-expected loosening or elimination of most of ownership rules under consideration (M)

headline: Judge Blocks Anthology That He Says Poses as a Novel
abstract: Best-selling author David Baldacci wins rare preliminary injunction from Federal Judge John G Koeltl stopping publication of anthology of mystery stories by five authors whose cover closely resembled that of one of Baldacci's novels; Koeltl blocks release of New Millennium Press book The Mighty Johns on grounds that publication might confuse Baldacci's fans and harm his reputation; New Millennium chairman Michael Viner says he plans to republish book this spring with new cover that complies with court's order; dispute had it origins in July 2000, when Baldacci agreed to contribute to anthology edited by Otto Penzler for token $2,000 but New Millennium promoted book with cover displaying Baldacci's name in large foil letters above title of his story, giving impression that book was Baldacci's next blockbuster novel (M)

headline: Pentagon Official Warns Asians to Guard Against Terror
abstract: Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz warned America's allies in Asia today to keep their guard up against terrorist activities within their borders, cautioning that even nations with large Muslim populations remain targets for attack by Islamic extremists.     ''I still think the terrorism problem is felt as a little bit remote, as a little bit America's problem,'' Mr. Wolfowitz told reporters traveling with him to a three-day regional security conference here that ends on Sunday. ''It's not just America's problem. The targets also very explicitly include the 500 million Muslims who live in the Pacific Rim.''

headline: After an Age of Digital Hubris, Wired's Editor Is Still a Believer
abstract: Wired magazine is one of the digital revolution's most cherished tribal artifacts. But in the smoldering aftermath of that revolution, is it still necessary?

headline: Pakistani President at the Fulcrum of Crisis
abstract: Analysis of whether Pakistani Pres Pervez Musharraf has power and will to rein in Muslim guerrillas in Kashmir and ease crisis with India; how much Pakistan government aids guerrillas is at heart of border confrontation involving million troops; Pakistanis deplore Pres Bush's apparent endorsement of Indian view that Pakistan orchestrates and controls guerrilla war in Kashmir; map (M)

headline: The Really Hot Seat at Vivendi
abstract: While Barry Diller focuses his efforts on USA Networks, the real task of making Vivendi's United States television ambitions a reality will fall to Michael Jackson.

headline: Madagascar May Break Up In Dispute Over Election
abstract: End to political standoff that has divided Madagascar since disputed December 2001 presidential election no longer seems within easy reach, despite apparent settlement reached in April; Marc Ravalomanana, recently declared winner, is planning inauguration on May 6 while Didier Ratsiraka, longtime leader who refuses to relinquish power, is drawing up outlines of new, separate state that would split country in two (S)

headline: PPG SETTLES ASBESTOS CLAIMS FOR $2.7 BILLION
abstract: PPG Industries settles asbestos injury claims for $2.7 billion and will take charge against earnings of about $500 million; settlement will be paid over next 21 years by company and at least three-dozen insurers; most of claims are result of company's 50 percent ownership position in Pittsburgh Corning (S)

headline: In Remote Library Stacks, an All-Seeing, Scanning Robot
abstract: Researchers at Johns Hopkins University have designed robot that can move about inside library and locate book requested by user, remove it from shelf and take it to nearby scanning station; in second stage of system, not yet developed, second robot in scanning station would scan specific pages of book that user could then view over Internet from any location; plan would eliminate delays in gaining access to material and facilitate conversion of printed material into digital format; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Japan Can Search For Mystery Ship
abstract: China will allow Japan to recover suspected North Korean spy ship that Japanese Coast Guard sank in Dec 2001 in Chinese waters (S)

headline: Germans See Link to Al Qaeda In Synagogue Blast in Tunisia
abstract: German investigators uncover growing evidence suggesting that recent explosion at synagogue in Tunisia was deliberate attack planned at least partly in Germany by people linked to Al Qaeda; most tantalizing thread is apparent transcript of brief telephone conversation between driver of propane-laden truck that exploded outside synagogue and German man under surveillance for months because of his contacts with radical Islamic organizations (M)

headline: China Raises H.I.V. Count In New Report
abstract: China publishes new statistics about severity of its AIDS epidemic; estimates that 850,000 people have been infected with HIV by end of 2001, up 30 percent from government estimate year ago, and 200,000 people might already have progressed to AIDS; these are highest numbers yet put out by Chinese government, which is slowly coming to terms with epidemic, but numbers fall far short of estimates made by foreign experts working in China as well a some Chinese researchers (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: CAMBODIA: Talks On A Rights Tribunal ; VIETNAM: Refugees Head For U.S. ; The HAGUE: Indonesia-malaysia Island Case.

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: MADAGASCAR: 2 Killed In New Fighting ; NIGERIA: Respite For Woman Who Faces Stoning A; CONGO: A Step Toward Talks.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FLEMING COS., Lewisville, Tex., the U.S.'s largest grocery wholesaler, said that it would buy seven Super1Foods stores from closely held Brookshire Grocery Co., Tyler, Tex., to expand in the Dallas area. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC, Natick, Mass., a maker of medical devices, said it had agreed to buy the closely held Enteric Medical Technologies, Foster City, Calif. Terms were not disclosed.    DELTA AND PINE LAND, Scott, Miss., the largest producer of cottonseed in the United States, said it had bought the half of D&M International, a maker of insect-resistant cottonseeds, it did not already own from its partner in the venture, Pharmacia, Peapack, N.J., a drug maker. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Karzai Swears In New Cabinet
abstract: Afghan President Hamid Karzai swore in his new cabinet today, managing a show of unity despite continued rumblings of dissatisfaction and intimidation.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: A Gain In Employment
abstract: Canada adds 30,500 jobs in May, capping busiest five months of hiring since 1994 and heightening expectations that central bank will raise interest rates to restrain inflation (S)

headline: Fear and Rage in Gaza, And Threats by Hamas
abstract: Abdel Aziz al-Rantisi, political leader of Hamas, militant Palestinian group, justifies suicide bombing in Netanya, in contrast to quick condemnation by Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat; says 'martrydom operations,' will continue unabated so long as Palestinians have no better way to fight Israeli occupation of their territories; says he is unperturbed that Palestinian Authority may again crack down on Hamas and other Islamic militants; photo (M)

headline: Bush Is Said to Back Growth Of Mission in Philippines
abstract: Pres Bush reportedly supports expanding American military training mission in Philippines, which would probably increase risks to scores of American military advisers there; officials say Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld and Pentagon aides are still consulting with other American and Philippine officials on details, but that Bush has agreed in principle to allow Special Forces troops to train with Philippine soldiers on jungle patrol tracking down remnants of Abu Sayyaf rebel group (M)

headline: Good Times For Toyota, But It Faces More Rivalry
abstract: Analysts say Toyota Motor Corp's long run of good luck may be ending and that sustaining its dominance will be harder in future; three Japanese rivals are getting back on their feet, led by non-Japanese executives; Mazda Motor, Mitsubishi Motors and, especially, Nissan Motor are back in black; analysts say they are bringing out new products that will chip away at Toyota's lead; photo of Toyota president Fujio Cho (M)

headline: Le Pen Accused of Torturing Prisoners During Algerian War
abstract: Le Monde, major French newspaper, publishes allegations by four witnesses that far-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen tortured people he accused of hiding weapons during Algeria's war of independence when he was member of paratroop regiment; allegations come less than week before Parliamentary election regarded as bellwether of right-wing sentiment; reopen debate about his past that has swirled through France for years; are fiercely denied by Le Pen (M)

headline: Bush, in Berlin, Calms Some European Fears With Talk of Partnership and Aid
abstract: Pres Bush delivers well-prepared speech to German Parliament that pleases his supporters and surprises some critics; touches on sensitive topics without belaboring them and emphasizes shared values and risks of trans-Atlantic alliance; Chancellor Gerhard Schroder praises address, noting Bush's emphasis on cooperation with allies and international development aid; Robert Kagan of Carnegie Endowment for International Peace says problems of 'continental drift' between Washington and Europe are longstanding but that Bush made moving and important speech; photo (M)

headline: Bucharest Journal; The King's Heir? Hmm, That's Not Fully Apparent
abstract: Bid by man calling self Prince Paul Philip of Hohenzollern for Romania's defunct throne has long been stuck in Romania's labyrinthine legal system, even though provincial court acknowledged his father as legitimate first-born son of King Carol II; last king, Mihai I, challenged ruling from exile in Switzerland; Paul is now appealing to European Court of Human Rights to endorse his claim; dispute centers on whether Carol's short-lived marriage to commoner was permitted by constitution of day, and hence whether Lambrino line of his family can inherit royal titles and property; Paul and wife, Lia, comment, interview; diagram of family lineage; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AVIS RENT A CAR SYSTEM INC. Parsippany, N.J., a unit of the Cendant Corp., has eliminated commissions to travel agents handling negotiated corporate and government accounts in the United States and Canada. The move followed similar action, announced earlier this week, by the Hertz unit of the Ford Motor Co.    SCHOLASTIC CORP., New York, the U.S. publisher of the Harry Potter series of children's books, said it had bought Baby's First Book Club, a marketer of cloth books and toys for children up to eight months old, from Sandvik, Norway, a publisher, for $7.5 million.

headline: U.S. Political Leaders Seek Unity on Mideast, for Now
abstract: Bush administration and Congressional leaders of both parties scramble to keep lawmakers united behind Pres Bush's Middle East policy as long as Secretary of State Colin L Powell is in Mideast; they worry that actions by rank-and-file lawmakers expressing strong support for Prime Min Ariel Sharon of Israel or condemnation of Yasir Arafat would complicate Powell's efforts to broker cease-fire and start political talks; Bush is facing increasing criticism from right and left that his pressure on Israel to withdraw from Palestinian territory clashes with his own vow to take uncompromising stand against terrorism after Sept 11; Sen Charles E Schumer and other Democrats say administration undercuts its own stand against terrorists by pressuring Israel and meeting with Arafat; Bush's national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, meets with lawmakers for second day in row, including some of Israel's staunchest Democratic supporters in House (M)

headline: ORBITZ AND NAVIGANT MAY OPEN BOOKING SYSTEM
abstract: Orbitz, Internet travel booking site, and Navigant International, corporate travel agent, are expected to announce that they have opened up their system to commercial travel agents, who have complained that airlines deny them access to discount air fares offered directly to customers on Web; all fares that are now sold on Orbitz, which is owned by five major airlines, will become available on proprietary computerized reservations systems used by travel agents; travel agents have charged Orbitz with anticompetitive practices; Justice Department is investigating those complaints (S)

headline: Company In Trouble? Just Let Him Loose
abstract: Profile of attorney David Boies, founding partner of Boies, Schiller & Flexner, firm specializing in defense of companies and individuals accused of dubious accounting and worse; his current field of defending embattled corporations and executives could become legal profession's hottest new branch of practice; photos; chart (M)

headline: Private Sector; Talking About Real Money At a Business School Dinner
abstract: Columbia economics professor Joseph E Stiglitz, Nobel laureate, and Sanford I Weill are honored at Columbia University Business School's annual dinner; Weill photo (S)

headline: Serbian Rift Widens Into a Parliament Walkout
abstract: Rift among reformers who ousted Slobodan Milosevic deepens as lawmakers from Pres Vojislav Kostunica's party storm out of Serbian Parliament and accuse their rivals of authoritarian behavior (M)

headline: Ex-Rite Aid Officials Face U.S. Charges Of Financial Fraud
abstract: United States attorney's office, after joint probe with Securities and Exchange Commission, charges Martin L Grass, Rite Aid Corp's former chairman and chief executive, former vice chairman and chief counsel Franklin Brown and former chief financial officer Franklyn Bergonzi with securities and accounting fraud that led to record $1.6 billion restatement of earnings; Grass and Brown are also charged with tampering with witnesses and obstructing probes; executive vice president Eric S Sorkin is charged with lying to grand jury; Grass and Brown deny wrongdoing; SEC aide Wayne M Carlin says criminal pattern at Rite Aid was extensive; securities lawyers say import of criminalizing earnings management extends well beyond Rite Aid; SEC, in separate complaint, says Rite Aid managers overstated company's income in every quarter from May 1997 through May 1999 by large amounts; photos (M)

headline: Gap Profit Declines By 68% in Quarter
abstract: Gap Inc says first-quarter profit fell 68 percent as sales slumped; net income fell to $36.7 million from $115.5 million year earlier; sales in quarter, ended May 4, fell 9.1 percent, to $2.9 billion from $3.2 billion (S)

headline: Where Tuareg roam / Better days in Timbuktu : In Mali, a fragile democracy is coming of age
abstract: TIMBUKTU, Mali—  Compared to the bad old days of the 1990s, things are looking up in Timbuktu. The Tuareg rebellion is over, tourists are back, and a new airport and a cyber cafe are easing the isolation of this city on the edge of the Sahara that did not get television until 1996 and still does not take credit cards.

headline: Debt Offerings Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week include today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and a four-week bill being auctioned tomorrow.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 1.67 percent; the six-month issue, 1.75 percent; and the four-week, 1.67 percent.

headline: If the Shoe Fits, Buy Two Pairs
abstract: Online Shopper column reports on buying shoes online; drawing (M)

headline: Big Holder Wants 3 Adelphia Board Seats
abstract: Leonard Tow, who controls about 12 percent of stock of troubled cable television company Adelphia Communications, has notified Adelphia that he wants three board seats that he says he is entitled to fill; Tow sold his company Century Communications to Adelphia in 1999 for $5.6 billion; says deal gives him option to name three Adelphia directors and that he intends to be one of them himself; two others would be executives of Citizens Communications, telecommunications company in which Tow is currently chief executive (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: MADAGASCAR: Election Recount Ordered ; South AFRICA: Aids Policy Change.

headline: For the Sims, It's Time to Play Outside in the Sun
abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column reviews The Sims: Vacation and Sid Meier's SimGolf, expansion games to go with original Sims video games; photos (M)

headline: Young Egyptians Hearing Call of 'Martyrdom'
abstract: Prospect of promising young Arabs in countries surrounding Israel being drawn to Palestinian cause and seeking 'martyrdom' has become very real in recent weeks; Egyptian officials confirm that six young men and women have been stopped trying to sneak into Israel in last week, apparently to carry out attacks; in response, Egypt has tightened control of border, hoping not to provoke any incidents; explosive response of young Arabs to call to 'open the doors to jihad' is largely rooted in secular concerns; young Arabs frustratred by lack of opportunity at home identify with plight of Palestinians; photos (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Shot Across a Bow: A Sail Recaptured
abstract: Team from company PaparazziH2O races around San Francisco Bay photographing boats with spectacular backdrops and circling each to get shots from multiple angles; then they maneuver close enough to throw small yellow ball aboard that tells people they have photos and where to go to view them for possible purchase; company was started by Cris Hammond, who had commissioned photos of his own sailboat and found process cumbersome; photo (M)

headline: Refugees Languishing in Camps as the U.S. Admits Many Fewer
abstract: Refugee resettlement groups say that because of security concerns, refugee admissions to US since Sept 11 have slowed to trickle, even as number of civilians fleeing war worldwide inches up; says result is refugees languishing in crowded, foul and sometimes unsafe camps overseas; Bush administration set at 70,000 number of refugees it would admit in current fiscal year, which began last Oct 1; so far, fewer than 14,000 have been allowed to enter (M)

headline: 'Ha-Ha, I'm in Hawaii': Automatic E-Mail Replies
abstract: Q. How do I set up an automatic reply to tell people who e-mail me that I will not be answering my mail while I am on vacation?    A. Check with your Internet service provider to see if it has a vacation or automatic reply service. (It is a function that works best at the server level.) Most corporate and university mail systems have some sort of program that will let you set up a short message reporting your absence that will be sent automatically to anyone who sends you an e-mail message.

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: Africa ANGOLA: Amnesty For Rebels; RWANDA: Genocide Defendants Boycott Trial; CONGO: Leaders To Assess Peace Efforts.

headline: ICAHN OFFERS $13.50 A SHARE FOR MORTON'S GROUP
abstract: Financier Carl C Icahn offers shareholders of Morton's Restaurant Group $13.50 per share in bid to gain control of company; offer valued at $56.6 million; Castle Harlan Inc has offered $12.60 per share, or $52.8 million (S)

headline: MERIT PAY IS DELAYED FOR FORD'S MIDLEVEL EMPLOYEES
abstract: Ford Motor Co will delay merit raises for 47,500 midlevel salaried employees in North America until at least Aug 1 as company seeks to conserve cash (S)

headline: Warehouse Vacancy Rates Are Up as Rents Fall
abstract: Cushman & Wakefield says warehouse industry is in slump all over country, with vacancy rates rising to 9.9 percent nationwide at end of first quarter from 7.5 percent in year-earlier quarter; says annual asking rental rates have fallen to $5.75 per square foot from $6.16 in corresponding period; graph; photo (M)

headline: Before You Answer, Know Who's Asking
abstract: National Association of Tax Professionals warns consumers about new type of fraud that aims to steal people's identities and assets through phony tax forms (M)

headline: Vote by Hyundai Workers Is Inconclusive
abstract: Voting on wage offer by Hyundai Motor Co's South Korean workers is inconclusive; union will decide whether to resume strike or renegotiate with management (M)

headline: Nicotine-Laced Water May Soon Be in Stores
abstract: Bottles of nicotine-laced water are the latest entry in a long line of products intended to help smokers get their nicotine fix through less carcinogenic means.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Auditor Revises Razorfish Letter
abstract: Arthur Andersen withdraws statement that it had substantial doubt about Razorfish Inc's ability to continue as going concern (S)

headline: To Find a Job, Leave a Career
abstract: Data showing many people in US and elsewhere change careers to find new jobs noted (S)

headline: Market Place; Edison Schools Gets Reprieve: $40 Million In Financing
abstract: Edison Schools Inc arranges to borrow at high interest rate $40 million it needs to finance its takeover of 20 struggling Philadelphia public schools, ending financial crisis that threatened its expansion into city; deal buys time for company founder H Christopher Whittle to show that public schools can be operated at profit, which he has yet to do; company's financial condition remains uncertain; photo (M)

headline: SHARES OF VERIDIAN CLIMB 13% ON FIRST DAY OF TRADING
abstract: Veridian Corp stock rises 13 percent in first day of trading; company sells 13.5 million shares to raise $216 million (S)

headline: Next Anchor For NBC News Not Drawing Big Audiences
abstract: NBC is staking future of its flagship newscast NBC Nightly News on anchor Brian Williams, whose program on MSNBC has not drawn average audience anywhere near those of his direct competitors: Bill O'Reilly on Fox News Channel and The Point and Live From programs shown on CNN; cable ratings have raised question of how well Williams will do in far more competitive battle of network evening news (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Arrests In Cafe Fire
abstract: Beijing officials arrest two teenage boys charged with intentionally setting fire that killed 24 people in unlicensed Internet cafe (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Poor Telecom Outlook; GERMANY: Volkswagen Profit Falls; SWITZERLAND: Setback For Sulzer.

headline: New Suicide Raid Casts Doubt on Israeli Strategy
abstract: Suicide bombing of bus near Haifa that killed eight people, mainly soldiers, and injured 14 has many Israelis questioning whether apparent gains of current military offensive against Palestinian militants are short-lived; Israeli officials hold offensive has sharply cut frequency of attacks inside Israel; Hamas, militant Islamic group, claims responsibility for attack; says bomber is from Jenin refugee camp (M)

headline: Accountants At Andersen In Denver Plan To Join Rival
abstract: Accountants in auditing group at Arthur Andersen's Denver office reach tentative agreement to join rival KPMG; Denver auditor has signed nonbinding memorandum of understanding with KPMG; partner Jeffrey S Finnin encourages clients to follow auditors to new firm (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Taiwan: Down With Chiang Kai-Shek
