abstract: Taiwan's Interior Ministry orders government offices and schools to remove portraits of Chiang Kai-shek, who ran Taiwan under martial law for 26 years, and his son, former Pres Chiang Ching-kuo; calls move apolitical; photo (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Laura Harris, associate art director at HealthAnswers Inc., Pennington, N.J., was promoted to the new post of art director.

headline: In Israeli Bed, Failed Bomber Tells of 'Love of Martyrdom'
abstract: Interview with Zaydan Zaydan, failed Palestinian suicide bomber, who says he undertook mission because of his love of martyrdom and not as act of revenge; insists he was drawn to martyrdom by what he read in books, not by anything he heard from imam or priest; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: Argentine Leader Scrambles to Find His Way Out of a Mess
abstract: Pres Eduardo Duhalde of Argentina abandons his unpopular plan to convert billions of dollars in bank deposits into long-term bonds after lawmakers make clear they would refuse to pass bond bill because it favors interests of foreign banks over Argentine voters; Duhalde, whose presidency is in the balance, steps up urgent search for new minister of economy; in place of bond bill, government now proposes measure that would severely limit ability of depositors to withdraw money, even when they have court rulings allowing them access to bank accounts; judicial experts say new plan appears to be unconstitutional; accounts have been largely frozen since Dec, but recent court decisions freed millions of dollars; photo (M)

headline: ISRAELIS TO DELAY U.N.  FACT-FINDERS
abstract: Israel, alarmed that composition and mandate of UN fact-finding team are stacked against Israel, delays its arrival until members and precise assignment are clarified; Israeli and Palestinian negotiators also hold first joint meetings to resolve standoff at Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, where about 250 Palestinian gunmen are holed up; decision on UN team reflects deep concern that plans, including Sec Gen Kofi Annan's statements, amount to 'setup' to accuse Israel of war crimes during military operation to ferret out terrorists in Jenin; photo; Martti Ahtisaari, heading UN team, elevates retired US Gen William Nash to full member in response to Israeli complaint that team had no military expert who understands problem of door-to-door fighting in crowded slum; Israel also fears Sadako Ogata and Cornelio Sommaruga will be too receptive to charges of aid workers; official says plan was not made in 'honest way' and goes beyond Security Council mandate (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Auditor Quits Chip Maker's Account
abstract: Applied Digital Systems says its auditor Grant Thornton has quit over accounting dispute; Grant Thornton says noncash $14 million expense from acquisition of Medical Accounting Systems should be recorded as one-time charge; this would result in loss for company in first quarter; graph (S)

headline: G.O.P. Pension Overhaul Is Approved by the House
abstract: US House, 255-163, approves pension-law overhaul that Republicans say will substantially improve safeguards for employees; many Democrats complain it offers only limited changes and will actually scale back some existing employee protections; Democratic alternative is defeated 232-to-187; photo (M)

headline: Outsiders' Precautions Taking a Toll on India
abstract: Precautions taken by foreign governments and businesses because of possibility of war between India and Pakistan are causing havoc in India; travel warnings have all but emptied country of both tourists and businesspeople from developed countries; evacuations of embassy and consular employees have left no one to process visa applications from Indian businesspeople or to answer questions about customs, trade and other regulations; moving goods in and out of some parts of country is becoming difficult; Indian companies find themselves fielding floods of inquiries about whether it is safe to keep doing business; some businesspeople comment; photo (M)

headline: Senegal stuns France, 1-0, as World Cup opens
abstract: SEOUL:—  Sport is able to conjure magic. Here in the capital of South Korea on Friday, Senegal, at its first World Cup, beat the champion of the world and Senegal's former colonial master, France, 1-0. The solitary goal was scored by a big midfielder, Pape Bouba Diop.

headline: Deloitte Consulting Is Close to Decision
abstract: Deloitte Consulting, which will separate from Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu later this year, narrows review of its advertising account (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Court Challenge To Mugabe
abstract: Zimbabwe's leading opposition party, Movement for Democratic Change, files petition in court to challenge results of presidential election last month; opposition officials say Pres Mugabe's re-election was marred by vote-rigging and violence (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nintendo Expects Record Profit
abstract: Nintendo expects to earn record profit for second consecutive year, thanks to weaker yen (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AirGate Shares Fall On Reduced Forecast
abstract: Shares in AirGate PCS, which sells wireless telephone service under Sprint PCS name in Southeastern US, plummet after it reduces its quarterly forecast for new subscribers (S)

headline: U.S. and Europe Investigating Online Currency Trade Venture
abstract: Justice Department and European Commission are looking into online currency trading venture called FXA11 run by some of world's largest banks for possible anticompetitive behavior; Charles A James, assistant attorney general for antitrust division of Justice Department, says this is significant enterprise; James comments after meeting with his European counterpart Mario Monti (M)

headline: MSNBC Picks News Veteran As Top Editor
abstract: Jerry Nachman has been hired as editor in chief of MSNBC, where he will also be host of his own late-afternoon talk show; photo (M)

headline: Educated Filipinos, Disillusioned at Home, Look Abroad for a Better Life
abstract: Educated families and young professionals are leaving Philippines in droves; they are unconvinced that their country is worth long-term sacrifice of staying there, 15 years after fall of dictator Ferdinand Marcos; their onetime dreams of democracy and prosperity fade before dreary reality of persistently weak economy, some of world's worst pollution, rampant urban crime and corruption at every level of government; their departure deprives their homeland of chance to build stable middle class and to crack political system still encrusted with oligarchs of past; photo (M)

headline: Editor Named at The Times on the Web
abstract: New York Times Digital, Internet division of The New York Times Co, announces that Leonard M Apcar will become editor in chief of its flagship Web site, The New York Times on the Web; Apcar will assume his new duties on June 10 (S)

headline: Article 2002042091311977961 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //            Education">                                                                   Comments Concerning Race Divide Harvard Law School

headline: MediaTalk; Hip-Hop Publisher Doubles Back Into Radio
abstract: David Mays, founder of popular hip-hop magazine The Source, will be co-host of national three-hour radio show each weekend called The Source Street Beat; program will be produced by Source Enterprises in joint venture with Excelsior Radio Networks and distributed to hip-hop stations around country; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Growth Estimate Raised
abstract: Bank of England raises its estimates of Britain's likely economic growth rate, setting off speculation that interest rates will rise later in year; bank says annual growth rate will expand to about 3 percent by beginning of 2003, up from 2.4 percent forecast in February (S)

headline: From TV Advertisers, Thumbs Up and Down
abstract: Advertisers assess winners and losers as major television networks unveil their fall prime-time lineups (M)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   7.00       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   3.50       Federal funds   1.75   1.70   3.92       3-month T-bills   1.69   1.72   3.51       6-month T-bills   1.83   1.85   3.46       10-yr. headline: Investing; In a Large Family, Many Views on Investing
abstract: Fund managers at Fidelity Investments, despite access to same research, make own decisions on which stocks to buy and sell; William Bower, who runs Fidelity Diversified International fund, comments on why he has been selling stocks in sector that Richard R Mace Jr, who manages three smaller funds, has been buying; photo (M)

headline: A Jury Orders Genentech to Pay $300 Million in Royalties
abstract: California jury orders Genentech Inc to pay $300 million to City of Hope National Medical Center, saying company deprived hospital of royalties it deserved for work that help lay foundation for biotechnology industry; jury also rules that Genentech acted with malice or fraud, which entitled City of Hope to punitive damages in addition to compensatory damages; City of Hope general counsel Glenn L Krinsky and Genentech vice president Sean A Johnston comment; case reviewed (M)

headline: Opening Files in Mexico
abstract: The lower house of Congress unanimously passed Mexico's first freedom of information bill Wednesday.

headline: KPMG Chief Alters View of Meeting
abstract: KPMG chief executive Eugene D O'Kelly backpedals after finding himself publicly contradicting Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Harvey L Pitt over sensitive fraud investigation involving Xerox Corp; O'Kelly, in letter o senior lawmakers, offers more benign description of private meeting with Pitt than he did earlier in month; O'Kelly had said in e-mail message to KPMG employees that in April 26 meeting he forcefully criticized SEC probe of firm for its work for Xerox; Pitt has said investigation was never raised at meeting; O'Kelly says he never mentioned Xerox by name in meeting; Xerox settled lawsuit last month with SEC by paying $10 million fine (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: Africa NIGERIA: Court Sides With Government On Oil; SUDAN: Cease-fire Monitors.

headline: Stock Sales by Philip Morris Executives
abstract: Philip Morris Cos executives, including chairman Geoffrey C Bible and tobacco unit chairman Michael Szymanczyk, recently sold 504,155 shares for $27.6 million as stock neared record high (S)

headline: Revised Data Show Slower Pace of Growth
abstract: Commerce Department reports Gross Domestic Product grew at annual rate of 5.6 percent in first quarter, down from 5.8 percent in April; drop reflects less consumer and government spending and larger decline in business investment than estimated; first-quarter growth is still faster than 1.7 percent pace in final quarter of 2001 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Koizumi Backs Aide After A-Bomb Remarks
abstract: Despite strong criticism in Parliament, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, left, said he would not consider firing his chief cabinet secretary for suggesting that Japan could soon consider acquiring nuclear weapons. Yasuo Fukuda had told reporters that Japan's self-imposed ban on nuclear weapons could be changed as easily as the Constitution, which governing-party lawmakers say should be amended to allow Japan to field a regular army rather than just a self-defense force. Mr. Koizumi, at a special session of a parliamentary committee, said his cabinet planned no changes concerning the nuclear ban.   Howard W. French (NYT)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Metromedia Fiber Defaults On Payment
abstract: Metromedia Fiber Network Inc says it has defaulted on $30 million debt interest payment to Verizon Communications Inc; it is second time this month Metromedia missed debt payment; company is discussing restructuring agreement with bondholders and may seek Chapter 11 protection from creditors (S)

headline: Personal Business; These Vacations Are on the House
abstract: Home swaps for vacationers can be arranged on Internet quickly and easily; growing number of businesses, including International Home Exchange Network and Home Base Holidays, provide home listings and help arrange exchanges (M)

headline: Bank Holiday And Creditors Add to Crisis In Argentina
abstract: Crisis that has crippled Argentine economy for past five months takes sudden turn for worse after government suspends bank and foreign exchange operations indefinitely and country's creditors, meeting in Washington, reject bailout on Pres Eduardo Duhalde's terms; government officials explain sweeping embargo on banking and foreign exchange transactions by saying there is no longer enough money in banking system to meet obligations; move apears to reflect government's growing anxiety at its inability to reach agreement with International Monetary Fund that would inject up to $20 billion in new funds into economy; IMF is insisting that Duhalde rein in spending by 24 provincial governors; this would force firing of up to 400,000 government employees at time when unemployment is already above 20 percent; photo (M)

headline: Developers Threaten to Gobble Up a Famous Hong Kong Market
abstract: Many Hong Kong merchants and longtime residents are appalled by plans by developers to demolish Stanley Market, island's most famous Chinese street market, to build nine-story hotel and air conditioned shopping mall; while other street markets have already been bulldozed and replaced by malls with little protest, Stanley's merchants and Hong Kong's small community of historic preservationists seem determined to fight latest scheme (M)

headline: Can Computers Foil Air Pirates?
abstract: Aviation experts say many of electronic building blocks are in place for computer system onboard airplanes that would thwart hijackers; say system to bar terrorists from crashing plane into building, or even crashing plane at all, would require no basic breakthroughs; doubt such system will be used any time soon because of costs, risks and pilot resistance; proposals noted; diagrams; photos (M)

headline: Worried Pakistanis Wait for Captured Fighters
abstract: Thousands of Pakistanis who slipped across the border to fight with the Taliban now remain prisoners of the Afghan Army or of warlords demanding ransom.

headline: U.S. Releases Colombia Aid, Citing Progress on Rights
abstract: State Dept reports that Colombia is making progress in deterring human rights crimes by armed forces and right-wing paramilitary groups, clearing way for release of $62 million in American military aid; this draws immediate criticism from human rights groups and some skepticism in Congress, where lawmakers had established procedure to curb abuses against civilians in Colombia; Colombia is third largest recipient of American aid (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profits For Soap Maker
abstract: Japan's Kao Corp says profit rose 1.4 percent in six months ended March 31; company earned 60.2 billion yen ($463 million) as sales grew 2.1 percent (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Negligence Inquiry After Quake Deaths
abstract: Taiwan experiences hundreds of aftershocks from March 31 earthquake (S)

headline: Bush Officials Met With Venezuelans Who Ousted Leader
abstract: Bush administration officials report meeting several times in recent months with leaders of coalition that temporarily ousted Venezuelan Pres Hugo Chavez and agreed with them that he should be removed from office; give conflicting accounts of what US told opponents of Chavez about acceptable ways of ousting him; reportedly insisted that Venezuelans use constitutional means; are also said to have been less categorical about encouraging ouster; disclosures follow accusations by rights advocates, Latin American diplomats and others that administration turned blind eye to coup plotting activities, or even encouraged people who temporarily removed Chavez; actions would place US at odds with fellow members of Organization of American States, whose charter condemns overthrow of democratically elected governments; critics say in its zeal to rid itself of Chavez, administration damaged its credibility as chief defender of democratically elected governments; even though administration officials deny encouraging Chavez's ouster, they did not hide their dismay at his restoration (M)

headline: Under Siege, Without Power or Water
abstract: Description of conditions in Ramallah after week of occupation by Israeli tanks and guns; water is running out because electric system driving pumps is broken; electricity itself is out in third of town; once-bustling streets are completely empty and office buildings, restaurants and buildings that used to house Palestinian national institutions are wrecked (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: New Palm Operating System
abstract: Palm begins shipping final version of its new operating system to licensees and developers; new system will not be available until later this year (S)

headline: Palestinian Authority Sets a January Vote
abstract: Palestinian Authority officially announce plans to hold elections for president and legislative offices in January as part of broad proposal for civic and security reform that stops short of Pres Bush's demand for Yasir Arafat's replacement; one Palestinian minister says Arafat will run again, while others say it is too early to predict who candidates will be; Hussam Khader, Palestinian legislators and one of Arafat's most passionate critics, says Bush's demand for Arafat's removal will keep him in power for years to come; photo (M)

headline: VIVENDI ALLOWED TO BID FOR SAFETY-KLEEN DIVISION
abstract: US Bankruptcy Judge Peter Walsh delays Safety-Kleen Corp's sale of its chemical-services division to allow North American unit of Vivendi Universal to offer competing bid; Clean Harbors Inc has bid $311.3 million for division (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Nvidia Shares Jump On Forecast
abstract: Shares in Nvidia Corp jump 17 percent after company says earnings for quarter will top expectations, and announces retatement of its results for last three years; Securities and Exchange Commission requested investigation into its financial statements in February; graph (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Party's Message Is Delivered
abstract: Ireland's high court rejects Labor Party senator's bid to stop country's dominant political party, Fianna Fail, from having its slogan and logo stamped on more than half of all mail handled by state-owned postal service, weeks before general lection is scheduled; party is paying $10,000 a month for ads in space previously sold only to charities (S)

headline: Discussing Mars and Talking to Astronauts Via a Webcast
abstract: The Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum presents a live two-hour interactive Webcast on the Internet and via a satellite broadcast.

headline: Energy Trader Plans Layoffs
abstract: El Paso Corp reduces its profit forecast and announces plans to lay off about 300 employees in its trading unit and to sell assets and $1.5 billion in stock to raise cash and trim debt; company and its chief executive William A Wise are backing away from energy trading one year after El Paso opened offices for 500 traders in Houston; Federal Energy Regulatory Commission is investigating whether El Paso withheld capacity on pipelines to California when prices soared in 2000 and 2001; Canada's TransAlta Corp says it engaged in some of round-trip trading practices being investigated by commission (M)

headline: Hymns, Not Gunfire, Fill Bethlehem
abstract: Religious services are held in freshly scrubbed basilica of Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem for first time since end of 39-day siege by Israeli forces; hundreds of worshippers and clergymen gather for Greek Orthodox services and for Roman Catholic rites after refuse left behind by trapped Palestinians is swept away; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: EMERSON RADIO, Parsippany, N.J., a maker of televisions and VCR's, said it had repurchased 4.4 million shares of its outstanding stock to help increase per-share earnings.    I.B.M., Armonk, N.Y., won a 10-year contract with Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, New York, to use new software to further automate the payment of health claims. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Meg Whitman and eBay, Net Survivors
abstract: Success of eBay Internet auction business and its chief executive Meg Whitman stands out amid crash of firms and their flamboyant technologists and visionaries that upstaged eBay during Internet boom; she provided disciplined management, steering clear of many seemingly lucrative opportunities to keep eBay focused on nurturing its trading community and expanding its ranks and scope of goods it deals in; graphs of gains in users, merchandise sold and net income; photos (M)

headline: Drug Shares and Hewlett Drag Down S.& P. and Dow
abstract: Standard Poor's 500-stock index falls 6.21 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,091.07; Dow Jones industrial average loses 54.46 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,243.68; Nasdaq composite index gains 6.51 percent, or 0.4 percent, to 1,725.56; US bond prices rise; price of 10-year note climbs 11/32, to 97 6/32; yield falls to 5.25 percent from 5.29 percent; 30-year bond rises 8/32, to 95 1/32; yield drops to 5.73 percent from 5.75 percent; graphs; charts (M)

headline: 18 Dead in Shooting at High School in Eastern Germany
abstract: A recently-expelled student opened fire in his former school in Erfurt, Germany, today and killed 18 people including himself.

headline: U.S. Says Iraq Moved Missiles To No-Fly Zone
abstract: Senior Pentagon officials say Iraqi military has moved surface-to-air missiles into southern and northern 'no-flight zones' patrolled by American and British pilots, putting those pilots at significantly higher risk; Gen Richard B Myers, chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff, plays down significance of moves, saying Pres Saddam Hussein frequently moves missiles and radar; incident comes at time of increased tension between Iraq and United States (M)

headline: New York State Weighs Suit Over Losses
abstract: New York State Comptroller H Carl McCall says he is considering lawsuit against WorldCom because New York State Common Retirement Fund lost at least $200 million; says fund still has about 8.8 million shares of WorldCom, even after selling most of its stock in last two weeks; New York State also owned $80 million in WorldCom bonds, which are also now worth far less; aide to New York City Comptroller William C Thompson Jr says losses in city's five major pension funds should be about $100 million (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Unemployment Rate Rises
abstract: Brazil's unemployment rate rose to 8.2 percent in April from 7.8 percent in March and from 7 percent in April 2001 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Fiber Optic Bankruptcy
abstract: KPNQwest files for bankruptcy in Dutch court after receiving court protection from creditors last week (S)

headline: Swiss Voters Lift Restriction On Abortions
abstract: Swiss voters agree to ease country's abortion laws, among Europe's strictest, and bring them closer to much of rest of continent's laws and actual practice in Switzerland; about 72 percent of voters approve measure permitting abortions in first 12 weeks of pregnancy, provided woman requests procedure in writing and agrees to counseling and medical advice (S)

headline: Opening Files in Mexico
abstract: Mexico's lower house of Congress unanimously passes country's first freedom of information bill; Senate is expected to approve measure, which would compel government to release most public records (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Another Journalist Arrested
abstract: Zimbabwe arrests fourth journalists for reporting charge made by opposition party that supporter had been beheaded by government-backed militants; charges are dismissed against one of journalists; journalists and party officials, who say they were misled, admit story was false (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Defense Ministry To Hear Tribes' Claims
abstract: British Defense Ministry agrees to mediate claim by 220 members of Masai and Samburu tribes in Kenya who seek $8-million compensation for deaths and wounds caused by unexploded bombs remaining from British military exercises (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: New Chip Plant
abstract: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing plans new semiconductor plant in China to serve growing mainland market; chairman Morris Chang tells shareholders he is scouting for site (S)

headline: Europe Orders Deutsche Post to Repay Public Money
abstract: European Commission orders Deutsche Post, postal group partly privatized in 2000, to repay 572 million euros ($545 million) in public subsidies it says were wrongly used to undercut prices of rivals in the parcel delivery; says Deutsche Post ran up that amount in losses by selling its door-to-door parcel delivery service at below cost from 1994 to 1998 and that losses were then covered by state money that should instead have been used to pay for Deutsche Post's public service missing, which includes delivering letters throughout Germany (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Check Point Offers Glum Outlook
abstract: Check Point Software Technologies expects first-quarter earnings and revenue to be below Wall Street expectations; says diluted per-share earnings will be 24 cents to 25 cents on revenue of $104 million to $105 million; graph (S)

headline: Investing; Where Telecom Bargain Hunters Turn
abstract: IT has been two months since Ivan G. Seidenberg, the chief executive of Verizon Communications, mused at an investment conference that his company might bid for WorldCom ''for the fun of it'' if the stock price of that long-distance and Internet carrier continued falling.     Since then, WorldCom's shares have dropped 80 percent, to $1.58 on Friday. But as Mr. Seidenberg wryly suggested, conditions in the communications sector are so tough that Verizon has no real interest in WorldCom at any price. Verizon, along with rivals like SBC Communications, BellSouth and Deutsche Telekom, all have plenty of their own problems without taking on WorldCom's, which include gigantic debt and an accounting investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Doctor, You Have Mail
abstract: Miriam A Stuart letter on June 6 article about e-mail between doctors and patients bemoans lack of response to her inquiries

headline: Filing Raises Concerns About Merck Unit
abstract: As Merck & Company prepares the initial public offering of its unit that manages pharmacy benefits next week, a regulatory filing has raised concerns about the subsidiary's future profitability.    Although by some counts the unit, Medco Health Solutions, is the nation's largest drug plan manager, it said in a filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission that its gross operating profits had been slim and were becoming slimmer.

headline: Broad Tax Sought on Music Storage in Canada
abstract: broad tax sought on music storage7

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Party Suspends Ex-Foreign Minister
abstract: Former foreign minister Makiko Tanaka is suspended from Japan's governing party over accusations that she misused public funds intended for staff salaries (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Manugistics Shares Fall After Loss Is Posted
abstract: Manugistics Group shares plunge after company reports it will lose $16 million to $18 million in first fiscal quarter ended May 31; company had predicted profit (S)

headline: CBS Has 2-Year Deal With Late-Night Host
abstract: CBS will keep Craig Kilborn, its late-night follow-up host to David Letterman, in place for two more years.

headline: Andersen Trial Yields Evidence In Enron's Fall
abstract: Evidence introduced at criminal trial of Arthur Andersen & Co indicates for first time that improper accounting decision, which set in motion demise of Enron Corp, served mainly to benefit financial interests of single corporate insider, outside partnership managed by company's former chief financial officer, Andrew Fastow; shows Fastow was driving force behind adoption of accounting decision, which allowed entities held by partnership that owed money to Enron to avoid particular losses; provides road map to ultimate direction of government's continuing criminal investigation into collapse of company, laying out path investigators will revisit in coming months while trying to determine whether company was victim of folly or crime; photo (M)

headline: In Philadelphia
abstract: Travel article on Philadelphia, Pa; city's highlights noted; photo (M)

headline: Pentagon to Investigate Its Role in Venezuela
abstract: Pentagon orders review of its actions during 48-hour ouster of Pres Hugo Chavez of Venezuela to ensure that American military officials did not encourage coup; senior Defense Dept official stresses that Pentagon has no evidence, nor even suspicion, of American involvement in Chavez's brief removal from office; Rear Adm Carlos Molina, one of anti-Chavez leaders of failed coup, has said he believed he was acting with American support (M)

headline: The Collective Power Of a British Brand
abstract: Sir Richard Branson letter replies to May 26 profile of his company, Virgin Group

headline: In London
abstract: Travel article on London, Eng; highlights of city noted; photo (M)

headline: Toehold on a Long Trek to Heal India-Pakistan Rift
abstract: American diplomacy in Pakistan and India has produced tiny victory for each side in struggle over Kashmir and provided toehold on which to proceed, but road to any long-term solution will be difficult and dangerous (M)

headline: Weaving Nile's Daily Life Into Dream of Change
abstract: Profile of Attiyat Al-Abnoudi, pioneer female documentary filmmaker whose 25 films underscore Egypt's gritty social reality, particularly for its poorest; although she has been interviewed often on Egypt's state-run television, network never shows her films; she says there is no official ban, but that there is no market in Egypt for poverty and misery she captures on her films; they have won more than 30 prizes, many in Europe; photo (M)

headline: Drug Makers And F.D.A. Fighting Hard Over Quality
abstract: Major drug makers and federal regulators are increasingly squaring off over problems at factories that could affect quality of medicines being produced; Schering-Plough and Abbott Laboratories announced this week that Food and Drug Administration is continuing to scrutinize their factories or products; Schering said FDA is conducting criminal investigation in Puerto Rico, where it operates two factories; Wyeth, Eli Lilly and several other large drug makers have also recently been criticized by federal regulators, who have found numerous problems with how they make prescription drugs and other medical products; because of manufacturing problems, some badly needed products are in short supply; chart; photo (M)

headline: Panoramic Chief Moves To Arnold McGrath
abstract: Mary Baglivo, president and chief executive at Panoramic Communications, is leaving to become president at Arnold McGrath, New York office of Arnold Worldwide Partners (S)

headline: 34, Including 12 Children, Killed as Bomb Rips Military Parade
abstract: A bomb ripped through a military parade in southwest Russia today. At least 34 people died and another 130 were hospitalized.

headline: Article 2002042191771979791 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                       International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics             Business           -      Media & Advertising            -      World Business            -      Your Money            -      Markets            -      Company Research            -      Mutual Funds            -      Stock Portfolio            -      Columns               Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections              Winter Olympics                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: Bush Is Said to Expect Israel To Pull Out 'Without Delay'
abstract: State Sec Colin L Powel4

headline: Banking Mergers Gain Momentum in Europe
abstract: the depressed share prices of banks, pummeled by a lethal rising bad loans and falling investment-banking fees, have been a deterrent to mergers in the industry.

headline: Koizumi Aide Hints at Change to No-Nuclear Policy
abstract: Japanese Cabinet Sec Yasuo Fukuda says Japan might someday possess nuclear weapons, breaking with decades-old policy officially forswearing weapons of mass destruction; statement creates furor in Tokyo and enrages Japan's neighbors; Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi says issue has been blown out of proportion (S)

headline: Senate Panel Passes Curb on Tax Moves
abstract: Senate Finance Committee passes bill to deny tax breaks to some American companies that have reincorporated in Bermuda, or plan to; bill would also permit IRS to monitor several insurance companies that have acquired Bermuda offices to eliminate taxes on profits earned in US (S)

headline: Article 2002042193473524791 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology Paper Version         function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                            International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business             Technology           -      E-Business            -      Circuits            -      Columns               Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: U.S. Bounty For Militants' Arrest
abstract: United States offers reward of up to $5 million for information leading to arrest of five top leaders of militant Philippine Muslim group Abu Sayyaf; group is holding two American missionaries hostage, Martin and Gracia Burnham; Deputy Defense Sec Paul D Wolfowitz to visit southern Philippines next week to check on progress of rescue operation (S)

headline: The Trials of Job Hunting Beyond a Certain Size
abstract: Difficulties faced by obese people in job hunting5

headline: Executive Life: The Boss; Lesson on a Dinner Plate
abstract: Charles Holliday Jr, chairman and chief executive of DuPont, writes The Boss column on his career; photo (M)

headline: For Dogged German Challenger, It's Still About the Economy
abstract: Edmund Stoiber makes malaise of German economy his core issue in campaign to unseat Chancellor Gerhard Schroder in Sept 22 elections; Stoiber, candidate of Christian Democratic Union and his own Christian Social Union, gives interview with American journalists in advance of visit to Washington in which he tries to show his familiarity with foreign policy, urges even closer relationship with US and works to undercut any idea that he is provincial xenophobe, while defending restrictions on immigration; his perception as dour bureaucrat and 'Bavarian pit bull' puts him at disadvantage with the personable, telegenic Schroder; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: *Correction of June 10 Critic's Notebook article about possibility that American writers will be allowed to compete for Booker Prize in Britain; Martin Amis has never won the award

headline: Mexico Releases All but 9 Officials Arrested in a Crackdown
abstract: Tijuana, Mex, police chief Carlos Otal, who was detained with 40 other officers suspected of drug corruption, is back on job only week after being accused of being on payroll of Arellano Felix drug cartel; all but 9 of 41 jailed offices have been released, although federal prosecutors have not publicly cleared them and Pres Vicente Foz says they are still being investigated; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: *Advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: Meager Harvests in Africa Leave Millions at the Edge of Starvation
abstract: Severe hunger is sweeping across southern Africa as result of two years of alternating droughts and floods, coupled with mismanagement of food supplies; Malawi, Zimbabwe, Zambia and Lesotho have been declared national disasters, and Mozambique and Swaziland are also struggling; United Nations expects four million people to need emergency aid in next few months as this season's meager harvest runs out; photos; map; graphs (L)

headline: Foreign Distillers Seek To Slake India's Thirst
abstract: Traditional disapproval of alcohol consumption has diminished among India's middle class, attracting big foreign distillers to Indian market; these companies have had no problems in setting up representative offices or even establishing local distilleries that produce domestic-label brands; are having trouble selling own beverages produced overseas because of stiff competition from well-entrenched Indian companies whose prices are much lower; have convinced government to cut, but not eliminate, very high taxes on imports; photo (M)

headline: A Costly Rebirth for a Big Old Resort
abstract: Mountain View Grand, sprawling mountain resort that was built in Whitefield, NH, in late 1920's and had been closed since 1986 will reopen on May 22 after four-year restoration; Kevin Craffey bought former Mountain View House for $1.3 million and has since invested millions more; Craffey plans to build 200 condominiums around golf course; condos, to be offered for sale beginning at reopening of resort, will mainly be two to four bedrooms in town house style, at prices from $190,000 to $600,000; photo (M)

headline: Investment Counseling From the 'Real' Pros
abstract: Alex Berenson column reacts to press release from investment adviser Conning & Co urging its insurance company clients to offer investment advice to employees in 401(k) retirement plans; questions value of advice from insurance companies and employers; suggests politicians provide advice, citing big investment gains by Pres Bush and others (M)

headline: British Utilities Are Expected to Combine
abstract: National Grid Group, which owns electricity transmission network in England and Wales, will announce its acquisition of Lattice Group, which owns Britain's gas pipelines, in deal that brings together Britain's largest suppliers of electricity and natural gas; deal is for $9 billion in stock and assumption of $9 billion in debt; it comes amid consolidation in utility industry throughout Europe (S)

headline: U.N. Official Urges Food Aid For the Poor As a Priority
abstract: Jacques Diouf, head of United Nations Food and Agriculture Orgn, says development experts mesmerized by international trade and high technology must tackle poverty first; says 815 million people go to sleep hungry, and when officials from 183 nations meet in Rome June 10, they should reassess world food situation; his organization estimates that poor countries are falling $30 billion a year short of $180 billion needed to meet targets for cutting hunger that were set at world food summit meeting in 1996 (M)

headline: Article 2002042491129140760 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                       International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics             Business           -      Media & Advertising            -      World Business            -      Your Money            -      Markets            -      Company Research            -      Mutual Funds            -      Stock Portfolio            -      Columns               Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: With Indonesia Politics Up for Grabs, Islam's Role Grows
abstract: During his five years in Britain as a doctoral student in accounting, Zul Zulkieflimansyh remembers thinking that his homeland, the largest Muslim country in the world, should be doing better by its 220 million people.    A veteran of the tough world of Indonesian student politics, Dr. Zulkieflimansyh, 29, decided that Islam was the answer, and the newly formed Justice Party the perfect vehicle. He returned home several years ago determined to do something to bring about change.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Announces New Leadership and Strategy
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co, seeking to project image of decisiveness and synergy after acquiring Compaq Computer Corp, introduces its executive team and product strategy; Hewlett-Packard's chief executive Carleton S Fiorina and president Michael D Capellas, former chief executive of Compaq, present plan; photo (M)

headline: A New Afghan Army Takes Shape, With G.I.'s as Trainers
abstract: American Green Berets begins training first 240 soldiers and officers of new multi-ethnic Afghan national army; military officials say it could take two years to prepare national force; up to 200 Special Forces soldiers will lead training; Pentagon reports American forces found two large arms caches in raids near Herat, in west, and Orgun, in east (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Steel Concern Expects a Loss
abstract: Japan's Nippon Steel Corp expects to lose 30 billion yen ($228 million) in fiscal year that ended March 31 instead of breaking even as it writes down value of its stock portfolio; lowers its sales target to 2.58 trillion yen ($19.6 billion), 6.2 percent below 2000 levels; Nippon Steel's subsidiaries Daido Steel Sheet Corp and Taiyo Steel Co will form holding company and merge operations in October (S)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Ronald Baron; Baron Growth Fund
abstract: Interview with Ronald Baron, manager of $948 million Baron Growth Fund who says he invests for long term and pays little heed to brokerage firm's research when making stock picks; chart; photo (M)

headline: Google's Toughest Search Is for a Business Model
abstract: Google, Internet search company with reputation as best way to find things on Internet, faces number of challenges; its very success as nation's sixth most popular Internet site raises question of whether Yahoo will see it as too much of rival to continue using it as its search engine; Google's effort to expand to other areas has yet to pay off; Google, leader in searching Web pages, is tiny force in rapidly growing market for selling advertising related to searches; founders Sergey Brin and Larry Page say they still believe stress on improving search technology will attract users and advertisers; graphs of search sites and of Google's traffic; photo (M)

headline: Hewlett's Chief Says Count Confirms Victory
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co says count by independent inspectors IVS Associates has confirmed that it won shareholder vote in fierce proxy battle to acquire Compaq Computer Co; vote can be challenged, and Walter B Hewlett, who led proxy battle opposing Hewlett's planned purchase of Compaq, promises he will do so; Hewlett's representatives are expected to insist on recount of some or all of votes; tally, deemed preliminary until all recounts are completed, gives Hewlett-Packard margin victory of 45 million votes, or about 2.8 percent of more than 1.6 billion shareholder votes cast; photos of Hewlett-Packard's chief executive Carleton S Fiorina and Compaq's head Michael D Capellas (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article on May 19 about Vagit Alekperov, chief executive of the Russian oil company Lukoil, referred incorrectly to Richard Matzke, a nominee to its board. He is a former vice chairman of ChevronTexaco, not a current one.

headline: Article 2002042092986515260 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                       International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics             Business           -      Media & Advertising            -    World Business          -      Your Money            -      Markets            -      Company Research            -      Mutual Funds            -      Stock Portfolio            -      Columns               Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Oil Concern's Margin Falls
abstract: BP says first-quarter profit margins for refining oil and selling fuel fell to their lowest points in decade as reuslt of high levels of supply and lower demand; BP's margins from refining oil were down 30 percent, compared with fourth quarter of 2001; margins from selling fuel declined 45 percent over same period; says it is on target to increase production for year by 5.5 percent; graph (S)

headline: ANALYSTS SAY WORLDCOM PLANS UP TO 16,000 NEW LAYOFFS
abstract: WorldCom Inc, struggling phone company, says it plans more job cuts; some analysts say cuts could total up to 16,000 (S)

headline: An Anti-American Boycott Is Growing in the Arab World
abstract: American support for Israel is driving grass-roots effort to punish America by boycotting its consumer products throughout Arab world; word is being spread via Internet, mosque sermons, fliers and even mobile phone messages; purchases of American goods generated by 300 million Arabs form very small part of American exports, but long boycott could retard spread of franchises and other products; boycotts are largely effort of individuals and small groups without government involvement; they reflect growing sentiment that Arabs should distance themselves from United States, and they want their governments to do likewise; photos (M)

headline: ISRAEL PULLS BACK IN 2 CITIES, SAYING OFFENSIVE IS OVER
abstract: Israel withdraws forces from center of Nablus and parts of Ramallah while establishing blockades around both cities; declares end to what it calls first stage of its West Bank offensive; leaves troops poised inside Palestinian-controlled territories for further strikes; Israeli soldiers and tanks continue to occupy Ramallah compound of Yasir Arafat, and to surround Church of Nativity in Bethlehem; Israel demands handover of wanted men it believes to be inside two places; Secretary of State Colin Powell says he is pleased with action, but that it does not go far enough; urges Israel to loosen siege of Arafat to give him chance to show if he could bring security situation under control; Palestinian ministers denounce partial withdrawal of troops as sham; photo (M)

headline: Dakar Journal; Fight Night in Senegal: Money Pummels Tradition
abstract: Wrestling has long been part of West Africa's traditions, contest through which young men test their courage; in Dakar, Senegal, a thoroughly Westernized city, wrestling has shed its traditions and become big-money sport, with most famous wrestlers adopting names like 'Tyson' and 'Holyfield' and hiring image consultants; they now fight for money rather than to gain standing in their village; photo; map (M)

headline: Net Rises 61% at King Pharmaceuticals
abstract: King Pharmaceuticals Inc reports first-quarter net income rose 61 percent, to $71.3 million, up from $44.2 million in 2001 period; agrees to buy Johnson & Johnson's Ortho-Prefest hormone replacement therapy for $108 million; will pay $7 million more when it gets Food and Drug Administrational approval to rename product Prefest; reports chief executive Jefferson Gregory will succeed his brother, John, as chairman (S)

headline: Korea, Reacting to a Sell-Off, Wants Stiff Rules for Analysts
abstract: South Korea's Financial Supervisory Service governor Lee Keun Young, in veiled warning to securities firms, calls for strict guidelines on 'professionalism' of investment advisers responsible for analyzing merits of South Korean companies; says purpose is to 'create an environment that adheres to market principles'; Lee's remarks reflect investigation into complaint by Samsung Electronics against UBS Warburg for report by analyst that sharply lowered outlook for company (M)

headline: Beijing Journal; From Pest to Meal: A Leap Forward?
abstract: Beijing Journal on potential extinction of sparrows, because of pesticide pollution and Chinese taste for small birds; photo; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Verio To Get Loan
abstract: NTT Group's long distance carrier, NTT Communications, will lend $305 million to its unprofitable subsidiary, Verio Inc; NTT already wrote down $4.4 billion loss in half-year ended Sept 30 because demand for Verio's Internet services plunged (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: TELECOMMUNICATIONS CONTRACT DISPUTE; BRITAIN: Cable Concern Narrows Loss; THE NETHERLANDS: Construction Acquisition; BRITAIN: Drug Seller Surges;.

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: Europe BRITAIN: Egyptian Sought By U.S. Is Freed; BRITAIN: 1,000 Fans Barred From World Cup; IRELAND: Looking For A Mandate; SWITZERLAND: Salinas Investigation Ends.

headline: Nils Ringertz, 69; Built Online Nobel Museum
abstract: Dr Nils R Ringertz, who helped create substantial Internet presence for Nobel Foundation by transforming its outdated Web site into online museum that includes recorded oral histories, dies at 69 (S)

headline: Brazilians to Acquire a Stake in Argentine Brewery
abstract: Companhia de Bebidas das Americas, Brazil's largest beverage company, agrees to acquire stake in Quilmes Industrial, Argentina's leading brewery, and signals that it wants to take control of company; Companhia de Bebidas das Americas, known as Ambev, will transfer its existing businesses in Argentina, Bolivia, Paraguay and Uruguay to Quilmes Industrial; Ambev will pay $346 million to Bemberg family, which controls company, for 37.7 percent stake (M)

headline: Tenet Healthcare Settles Billing Dispute
abstract: Tenet Healthcare Corp will pay $55.75 million to settle allegations that two of its hospitals overbilled Medicare program (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sony Increases Disclosure
abstract: Sony Corp, in rare move for Japanese company, says it will disclose data on salaries and retirement allowances paid to its directors (S)

headline: An Organizer From Treo Adds Color but Skips the Phone
abstract: Handspring introduces new hand-held organizer that can display more than 4,000 colors; device has built-in keyboard and handwriting recognition program; photo (M)

headline: U.S. India-Pakistan Mission Fails to Ease the Standoff
abstract: Christina Rocca, senior American diplomat, ends two-day visit to India and Pakistan; reports little sign of progress in reducing military standoff between two nuclear-armed rivals; her mission came day after attack in Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir that killed 34 people; India quickly blamed Pakistan for sheltering Islamic militants it blames for attack; Pakistan immediately condemns killings, but diplomats fear incident could open war between two nations (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: A Sinn Fein Lord Mayor
abstract: Belfast City Council elects Alex Maskey as first lord mayor from Sinn Fein, political party of Irish Republican Army (S)

headline: The Saturday Profile; A Doctor-Spokesman Attends to Papal Image
abstract: ''These cardinals,'' said Joaquín Navarro-Valls with mock chagrin as he swept a visitor into his office just off St. Peter's Square. ''They come by without any appointment. You cannot say no. So it's, 'Yes, your eminence, just have a seat.' ''    Nineteen years into his career as papal spokesman, Dr. Navarro-Valls, now 65, still has occasional headaches with the centuries-old papal bureaucracy, the Roman Curia.

headline: Some at Wall St. Journal Fear Return to Manhattan
abstract: Wall Street Journal's editors say former newsroom is ready to reopen at World Financial Center nine months after attacks on World Trade Center forced staff to flee its offices, but many of reporters and editors say they are afraid to go back; group of reporters and editors present managing editor Paul E Steiger with results of employee survey indicating that of 175 reports and editors responding, 126, or 72 percent, want Journal to relocate from World Financial Center; Steven Goldstein, spokesman for Dow Jones & Co, which owns Journal, says that although company appreciates feedback, its management is neither surprised nor persuaded by results; photo (M)

headline: Guilty Plea Made in Investment Fraud Case
abstract: William J Zylka, who portrayed himself to investors as scion of wealthy family and international business success, admits stealing $27.7 million from Evergreen Security, defunct offshore investment fund; authorities say fund was Ponzi scheme in which money from new investors wasn use to pay interest to earlier funds (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Heroin Flow Continues
abstract: United Nations says Afghanistan remains world's top supplier of heroin to Europe and produces most of opium-based drugs consumed in Central Asia (S)

headline: People
abstract: Jeff Hasen is named president at Wong Doody Communications (S)

headline: Videotape Links Al Qaeda With Sept. 11 Hijackers
abstract: Videotape broadcast by Arab satellite television network Al Jazeera shows man identified as one of September 11 hijackers stating that his impending death was intended to send message that time had come to kill Americans in their own homeland; hijacker, identified as 20-year-old Saudi Ahmed Alhaznawi, who helped seize United Airlines flight that crashed into field in Shanksville, Pa; videotape also shows Osama bin Laden with second-in-command, Ayman al-Zawahiri; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Mozambique: Trial In Journalist's Killing
abstract: Supreme Court of Mozambique decides there is enough evidence to try six men accused of killing Carlos Cardoso. country's best known journalist; he was investigating accusations of corruption in banking sector when he was killed in Nov 2000; six men include former bank manager (S)

headline: S.E.C. Dispels Shadow on I.B.M., Saying Company Is Not a Target
abstract: Research report by SEC Insight saying Securities and Exchange Commission is opening inquiry into IBM sends shares of company to 52-week low, closing down $4.82, at $84.19; after trading closes, SEC releases statement saying 'regarding the reports of a preliminary inquiry by the SEC into IBM, the SEC staff opened inquiry and closed it without action shortly thereafter' (S)

headline: The Dead and the Angry Amid Jenin's Rubble
abstract: Widespread devastation from Israeli military assault on Palestinian refugee camp in Jenin in West Bank described; aid groups charge Israeli soldiers with blocking aid from reaching camp; team from International Committee of the Red Cross is allowed to enter camp for first time to search for wounded, evacuate sick and remove rotting corpses; photo (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Foiling Air Terrorists To the Editor:.

headline: Tyco Rethinks Planned Sale Of Its Plastics Operation
abstract: Tyco International is reconsidering sale of its plastic unit and plans to announce that it may suspend auction for business because no potential buyer has expressed willingness to pay Tyco's asking price (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Insurer's Bankruptcy
abstract: Indonesian court declares Manulife Financial Corp's local business bankrupt after lawsuit brought by liquidator of company owned by Dharmala Group, one-time partner with Manulife; court declares Manulife bankrupt because it did not pay Dharmala, with which it had joint venture, 22.4 billion rupiah ($2.6 million) dividend in 1999 before Manulife bought Dharmala's stake (S)

headline: The Sierra Club criticizes Ford's chief in a campaign for fuel-efficient cars.
abstract: Sierra Club introduces advertising campaign that ties fuel economy to patriotism and calls for action by Ford Motor Co chairman-chief executive William Clay Ford Jr, who was once viewed by group as ally; campaign, produced by Haddow Communications, is being rolled out in dozen states; campaign includes radio spot and television ads featuring former Sen Bob Kerrey and Jack Shanahan, retired vice admiral; both men urge auto industry to take action to cut oil use; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Acquittal Prompts Calls For Inquiry
abstract: Acquittal in stabbing death of Damilola Taylor, 10, of two youths with history of terrorizing their London neighborhood spurs calls for probe of police and prosecution procedures (S)

headline: San Diego's High-Rise Slump Lingers
abstract: San Diego's dormant downtown market showed signs of life last year after 10 years without any high-rise office construction; projects by developers Catellus Urban Development Group and Lankford & Associates have been delayed as developers struggle with lingering effects of downtown office building boom in late 1980's and early 1990's; graph; map (M)

headline: U.S. Businesses Dim as Models For Foreigners
abstract: Foreign confidence in US as place to invest and as business model is badly shaken by scandals involving Enron, Global Crossing and now WorldCom; immediate impact is discernible in value of dollar, which has been sliding since March and has now fallen to lowest level against euro in 28 months; loss of investor confidence is serious because US, which runs huge trade deficit with world, must attract net inflow of $1.3 billion in foreign money every day; more enduring impact of accounting and boardroom scandals may be tarnish they spread on American philosophy that emphasizes bare-knuckle competition, aggressive deal making, high level of public disclosure and fantastic rewards for executives who deliver the goods; there is groundswell among executives in Europe against American system of corporate accounting -- so-called generally accepted accounting principles -- that was supposed to be gold standard in disclosure; graphs (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Advanced Set-Top Boxes To Be Shipped
abstract: Scientific Atlanta is shipping its advanced home entertainment server, Explorer 8000, to homes this week for trials; AOL Time Warner has already ordered 100,000 units, which its maker says is first cable box with built-in digital video recording capability (S)

headline: New Economy; By selling its disk-drive business, is I.B.M. relinquishing the past, or is it simply preparing for a leap into the future?
abstract: Industry analysts speculate on whether IBM mortgages its future with plan to sell much of its magnetic disk data storage business to Hitachi; note difficult dynamics of fast-paced industry; execution of each new generation of rapidly changing technology has to be flawless or else market share can collapse overnight; IBM may be gambling that its research in so-called nanotechnologies will make spinning magnetic storage disks obsolete in decade or so; drawing (M)

headline: Argentine Congress Tightens Rules on Bank Withdrawals
abstract: Argentina steps away from immediate financial collapse after Congress moves quickly to approve temporary emergency legislation that places new obstacles in path of estimated 1.5 million bank depositors who for months have been seeking access to their money; under new law, judge's edict will not be enough to unfreeze bank account; passage of bill comes less than day after Pres Eduardo Duhalde abandons highly unpopular alternative plan to convert $12.5 billion in savings into low-interest long-term bonds; photos (M)

headline: MTV Wunderkind Is Drafted to Fix VH1
abstract: Viacom brings in Brian Graden, programming president of its MTV unit, to revive its fading VH1 music channel; hopes he can attract audience in age group from mid-20's through Woodstock generation; VH1 has failed to develop any new hits in last two years and lost more than 20 percent of its audience in past year; audience graph; photos (M)

headline: Tough Talk Resonates In a Nation Sick of War
abstract: Alvaro Uribe Velez swamps nearly dozen opponents to win solid first-round victory in Colombian presidential election; photo (M)

headline: Ignoring Risk, Afghan Refugees Rush Home
abstract: Thousands of Afghan refugees are returning home from Pakistan, where they fled at onset of Soviet invasion in 1979; more than 300,000 have migrated home in two months since UN refugee agency began assisting repatriation; refugee officials believe as many as 1.2 million could also return from Pakistan and Iran; say it could take three years, perhaps longer, before estimated 5 to 6 million in neighboring countries return; those returning home seem to be ingoring naysayers who worry about risk of anarchy if new government in Kabul fails to rein in warlords who currently control much of country, or if Taliban and Al Qaeda regroup for new guerrilla war; map; photos (L)

headline: American Antiterror Inspections Will Begin at 3 European Ports
abstract: US secures permission to station specially trained American customs officials in Rotterdam, Antwerp and The Hague to learn more about cargo heading for US and to screen sea containers for possible weapons of mass destruction; talks are under way with five other European ports; similar arrangement is already in place in Canada with three Canadian ports (M)

headline: Bush's Gamble: Seeking a Delicate Balance
abstract: Analysis: complex effects of Pres Bush's forceful speech on Israeli-Palestinian conflict are reflected in reactions on both sides: among Yasir Arafat's aides, praise and alarm and in Prime Min Ariel Sharon's camp, stony silence; speech caught Israeli Government by surprise; if Secretary of State Colin Powell's mission is greeted by another wave of Palestinian suicide attacks, Sharon may get free hand to deal with Arafat; photos (M) seeking; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Auto Sales Climb 2.9% With Only Ford Lagging  Every major automaker except Ford Motor reported sales increases last month, evidence of an economic recovery that helped propel the stock market.    Over all, automobile sales rose 2.9 percent in April from a year earlier, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank. [Page C2.]

headline: Two Fund Laggards Try a New Approach
abstract: DIARY Two Fund Laggards Try a New Approach  Ameritor Financial, whose mutual funds are ranked by Morningstar Inc. as among the very worst, is embracing socially conscious investing with a conservative bent.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Developer Bought Out
abstract: Saville Gordon Estates agrees t{

headline: Security Alert on Smart Cards
abstract: Two computer security researchers report finding smart cards vulnerable to a relatively inexpensive method of criminal attack. Page C2.

headline: Business; How a Side Effect Might Turn Into Success
abstract: LEONARD S. SCHLEIFER, the son of a sweater manufacturer who grew up in the Rego Park section of Queens, was on his way to becoming a distinguished scientist. But after he earned an M.D. and a Ph.D. and started a research career in 1984 at Cornell University, he became fascinated with the biotechnology revolution. Though he had never held what he jokingly calls a ''real job,'' he decided to build a company that delivered better drugs to people.    So in 1988, he assembled a group of Nobel Prize winners and other researchers and created Regeneron Pharmaceuticals in a former Union Carbide laboratory here.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Japanese Chip Makers In Alliance
abstract: Fujitsu and Toshiba will form alliance to create sophisticated computer chips, focusing on large-scale integrated circuits, which are typically used in digital consumer products like mobile phones and game consoles (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Study Finds Some Setbacks for Broadband
abstract: Pric ewaterhouseCoopers study finds number of factors have sharply slowed adoption of broadband Internet services, delaying point at which these services will be widely accepted until 2006; expects number of United States subscribers to rise to 35.3 million by 2006, from 9.4 million in 2001 (M)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: CHILE: Request Granted On Pinochet; BRAZIL: 124 Acquitted In Killings.

headline: Behind a Forceful Statement, A Sense of a Need to Gamble
abstract: Seeds of Pres Bush's speech lay in his comment days ago about understanding Israel's need to defend herself; overwhelmingly negative worldwide reaction to that, including demonstrations that roiled Arab world, convinced him and senior advisers of need for broad new statement of purpose and high-stakes gamble; Bush has now put himself at center of conflict that has defeated countless attempts at resolution; for now, he seems to have deflected growing domestic and international criticism of policy that was widely seen as floundering (M)

headline: Lehman Brothers Lays Off 60 in Europe
abstract: Lehman Brothers Holdings lays off 60 bankers and support staff members at its European business (S)

headline: Private Sector; Keeping Up With the Joneses
abstract: Jones Apparel Group withdraws proposed new stock option plan, which included 1.5 million shares for new chief executive Peter A Boneparth; decision responds to anger from shareholders and employees, many of them members of needletrades union (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: Europe GEORGIA: Russian Soldiers, Uninvited, Arrive ; FRANCE: Government Liable For War Damages; YUGOSLAVIA: Official Found Dead.

headline: Korea Slaughters 10,000 Pigs After Return of Foot and Mouth
abstract: South Korea agricultural officials said they had slaughtered about 10,000 pigs after discovering animals dying of foot and mouth disease.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Asbestos Limit Overruled
abstract: House of Lords, England's highest court, overturns previous ruling that barred people from collecting compensation for asbestos-related illness if they were exposed to material by more than one employer; ruling could expose insurers to billions of pounds in additional claims for respiratory illness and cancer that has been linked to asbestos (S)

headline: Who Should Police The Financial Markets?
abstract: Rep Michael G Oxley letter disputes Gretchen Morgenson's May 26 column backing policing and fining of Merrill Lynch by New York attorney general's office

headline: COMDISCO PLANS SALE OF ASSETS TO PAY CREDITORS
abstract: Computer service company Comdisco Inc reaches reorganization plan with creditors and plans emergence from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in mid-August; plan calls for three-year sale of remaining assets (S)

headline: At Least 100,000 in France Protest Far Rightist
abstract: Estimated 100,000 demonstrators steam through streets of Paris and other French cities in further protest against strong showing of far-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen in first round of presidential balloting; demonstrations draw impromptu alliance of human rights groups and antiracism, student and labor organizations opposed to Le Pen and his anti-immigrant policies and proposals for mass deportations of foreigners without legal residence in France (S)

headline: Four Killed as North and South Korean Navy Vessels Trade Fire
abstract: South Korea reports four of its marines were killed, one is missing and 18 other marines and sailors were hurt in gunbattle with North Korean navy vessel in Yellow Sea off South Korean west coast; says North Korean vessel crossed line beyond which such vessels are banned, ignored warnings to turn back and opened fire, badly damaging South Korean vessel before eventually turning back; charges truce violation; says boat was accompanying fishing boats; incident follows series of incursions by North Korean vessels; Pres Kim Dae Jung calls emergency national security council meeting (M)

headline: Kmart Loses $1 Billion in Five Weeks
abstract: Kmart Corp lost more than $1 billion during five weeks ended May 1; chief financial officer Al Koch says company might not be able to meet its goal of emerging from bankruptcy by next summer; sales in stores open at least one year fell 16.4 percent from March 28 to May 1, to $2.1 billion (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: TAIWAN: Rates Lowered; SOUTH KOREA: Daewoo Investor; JAPAN: Penalty For Barclays;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: G.M. Drops Michelin
abstract: General Motors Corp drops Michelin as provider of premium tires in Europe because French company's products are too expensive; GM still has contracts with Michelin in US, which last until 2006 and 2007; Continental AG says it will take over part of contract to supply tires to GM's European division (S)

headline: Philip Morris Drops Beer To Concentrate Elsewhere
abstract: Philip Morris Cos president-chief executive Louis C Camilleri says decision to sell Miller Brewing Co to South African Breweries will allow Philip Morris to focus on its core food and tobacco businesses; graph (M)

headline: TWO COMPANIES DECIDE TO REINCORPORATE IN BERMUDA
abstract: Shareholders of Leucadia National Corp and Cooper Industries approve measures to reincorporate in Bermuda; Leucadia says it has no immediate plans to complete move to Bermuda because such transaction would be treated as sale of assets and company would incur tax liability of about $315 million; Cooper expects to follow up and reincorporate in Bermuda by May 21 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Trade: Whispering With Japan
abstract: Australia and Japan decide to work toward bilateral free trade agreement, but step is so tentative that it is not mentioned in official communique concluding two-day visit by Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi; Prime Min John W Howard says after meetings that both sides want agreement, but 'there will be difficulties'; Australia considers its agricultural exports as central issue; photo (S)

headline: Child Traffickers Prey on Bangladesh
abstract: Article on child trafficking in Bangladesh, considered one of most vulnerable spots in global trafficking market because of desperate poverty and demand for cheap labor elsewhere; problem has attracted attention of Bangladesh Government, which has enacted trafficking law with stiff penalties; ambitious public education campaign is under way, but even those involved in effort doubt it will do much to combat hugely lucrative business; many say crackdown by Western countries on immigration only makes trade more perilous and smuggler's trade more lucrative; plight of Nuru Miah and Rubel Hussain, young boys repatriated after being taken to Dubai to serve as camel jockeys, discussed; map; photos (M)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   7.00       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   3.50       Federal funds   1.75   1.73   3.91       3-month T-bills   1.72   1.72   3.52       6-month T-bills   1.85   1.85   3.47       10-yr. headline: Allies Discuss Terrorism and the Middle East: Bush and Blair on Policy
abstract: Excerpts from news conference held by Pres Bush and Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain in Crawford, Tex; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Names Financial Officer
abstract: Verizon Communications names Doreen Toben chief financial officer to succeed Frederic V Salerno, who announced his retirement on April 29 (S)
