headline: Hamas Leader, Under Attack From 2 Sides, Remains Defiant
abstract: Hamas, militant Islamic group responsible for some of most devastating suicide bombings in Israel, comes under double-barreled attack in last 24 hours; Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat orders arrest of members and places spiritual leader, Sheik Ahmed Yassin, under house arrest; Yassin remains defiant; says suicide bombings will continue; Israeli helicopter gunship kills six people, including two described as Hamas leaders; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Poor Outlook At Pearson
abstract: Pearson warns earnings for first half of year will continue to be depressed by weaker advertising sales and that recovery is not exxpected this year (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Penalty Setting Delayed
abstract: World Trade Organization delays setting amount European Union countries can levy as retaliation for US tax breaks that organization ruled illegal; arbitrators have asked for more information and additional seven weeks to examine European demand for $4 billion in sanctions after World Trade Organization ruled that provisions in American tax law violated global rules; Bush administration counters that amount should be less than $1 billion; ruling is expected June 17 (S)

headline: Hewlett-Packard Is Accused of Misleading Holders
abstract: Lawyers representing dissident director Walter B Hewlett deliver sweeping attack on integrity and credibility of management of Hewlett-Packard Co, contending that it repeatedly misled shareholders about projected gains from its planned purchase of Compaq Computer even as senior executives inside companies became increasingly pessimistic; main evidence presented in court by lawyers for Mr Hewlett is series of documents prepared by teams from Hewlett-Packard and Compaq who were planning how to merge companies smoothly to achieve cost-saving and profit-enhancing goals that justify merger; Mr Hewlett is challenging shareholder vote, which Hewlett-Packard won by slender margin; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: A Poke At U.N.
abstract: Prime Min Hun Sen suggests United Nations pulled out of talks with Cambodia on setting up trial of former Khmer Rouge leaders because it wanted to avoid embarrassment; bases his gibe on historical reality that United Nations continued to recognize brutal Communist movement throughout its reign of terror and for decade after; photo (S)

headline: Clio Awards Honor DDB Worldwide
abstract: DDB Worldwide takes top honors at annual Clio Awards ceremonies; DDB is named agency network of year and receives 31 Clios, including 2 Grand Clios; Fallon Worldwide and Harvest Films are other big winners (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: South Korea: Trial Starts For President's Son
abstract: Kim Hong Gul, son of South Korean Pres Kim Dae Jung, goes on trial on corruption charges; another son, Kim Hong Up, also faces charges (S)

headline: Gazans Await Israeli Attack Despite Lack Of a Buildup
abstract: Sammy Abu Samhadanah, who commands Gaza Strip militia allied with Yasir Arafat, plots strategy if Israel expands military action from West Bank; Israeli security official says Gaza is not of as much concern because recent suicide attacks have been carried out by Palestinians from West Bank (M)

headline: Hong Kong Passions About Tiananmen Seem to Be Fading
abstract: Hong Kong annual candlelight vigil to remember protesters killed by Chinese military in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in 1989 draws sparser crowd than usual this year; poll by group with reputation for impartiality finds that more than half of Hong Kong's population is satisfied with Beijing's rule of China and, separately, with Beijing's handling of Hong Kong affairs (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Sales Gain At Travel Agencies
abstract: Internet travel companies Expedia and Hotel Reservations Network post first-quarter revenue gains; Expedia says net income totaled $5.7 million compared with loss of $17.6 million; revenue was $116 million, up from $57.2 million year ago; Hotel Reservations reports adjusted net income of $17.4 million, up from $11.4 million year earlier; net income grew to $12.9 million from $1.8 million; graph (S)

headline: Most Influential? It's Mom
abstract: 57% of 411 executives surveyed by Fortune Magazine say their mothers were most influential people in their lives; 36 percent cited fathers (S)

headline: Chinese Court Hands Down Prison Sentences for 2 Leaders of a Banned Party
abstract: Human rights group reports Chinese court has given Hu Mingjun and Wang Sen, leaders of outlawed China Democracy Party, long prison terms on subversion charges; Xintong, whose husband, Xu Wenli, promoted party and has been jailed since 1998, fasts and calls foreign reporters demanding better medical care for ailing Xu (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Financial Officer Retires At Sun
abstract: Sun Microsystems Inc chief financial officer Michael E Lehman will retire on July 1; vice president Steve McGowan will succeed him (S)

headline: Politics Kills Momentum of Madagascar Job Boom
abstract: Continuing struggle over Madagascar's Dec 16 presidential elections has taken life out of country's garment industry, which boomed after US cut quotas and duties on clothing from dozens of poor African countries; anger of elections has led to widespread strikes; Antananarivo, capital and manufacturing center, is loyal to Marc Ravalomanana, its mayor, and is blockaded by militias loyal to Pres Didier Ratsiraka and thus unable to obtain raw materias like fabric and to ship finished goods abroad; photos (M)

headline: Salomon Brothers May Face WorldCom Shareholder Suits
abstract: Citigroup's investment banking division, Salomon Smith Barney, generated over $100 million in fees from its client, WorldCom, in exchange for services including merger advice, stock-offering promotion and arranging loans; disgruntled WorldCom shareholders and bondholders are likely to sue Salomon, seeking some payback for billions of dollars they lost (M)

headline: Brazil's Roller Coaster Market
abstract: Brazilian stocks, bonds and national currency, the real, oscillate widely in nervous trading, amid continued concerns about outcome of Brazil's coming presidential election and signs of weakness in country's economy; real has fallen by more than 10 percent since beginning of June, and main stock market index has dropped to eight-month low; Luiz Inacio da Silva, presidential candidate of left-wing Workers' Party, is ahead in pre-election polls; investors remain worried although he has declared his intentions to honor government's obligations; graph; photo (M)

headline: Six Suspected Of War Crime Will Give Up, Serbia Says
abstract: Serbia says six war crimes suspects will surrender voluntarily to international tribunal at The Hague; deadline passes for 23 people to surrender or face arrest and deportation; arrests planned (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Enron Agrees to Pay More In Severance to Workers  Enron has agreed to pay nearly $30 million in additional severance to about 4,200 former employees who were laid off after the company filed for bankruptcy protection. If the federal judge in the bankruptcy case approves the deal, Enron will pay former employees up to $7,900 in additional severance pay. Many former employees have already received as much as $5,600.     Enron and its creditors have also agreed to allow an employee committee to investigate and try to recover some of the retention bonuses the company paid to some high-level executives just ahead of the bankruptcy filing in December. [Page C11.]

headline: Russia Says Capital Flight Is Reversing
abstract: Russia's Finance Min Aleksei Kudrin and central bank governor Sergei Ignatiev says that more money is now flowing into Russia than out, suggesting that Russians are bringing some of their 'flight capital' back home to spend or invest after years of stashing it overseas; say Russia will have surplus in its capital account in second quarter of 2002, meaning net flow of capital into country; photo (M)

headline: A Learning Curve for Whittle Venture
abstract: Some educators say there is more at stake in Edison Schools' takeover of 20 public schools in Philadelphia than reputation of its chief executive, H Christopher Whittle, and that failure could put back movement toward private marketplace of school options; many say Whittle has surrounded himself with smart, talented people who do not know enough about business and finance to keep Edison out of trouble; Thomas Toch, writer at National Center on Education and Economy, says Whittle has become standard-bearer for people who believe that private-sector management can transform America's public schools; photo (M)

headline: Publishers Wary of Books on Church Scandals
abstract: Publishers are wary as they begin shipping first new books on Roman Catholic Church sexual abuse scandal; fear story may repel core Catholic audience; some Catholics seem to believe media's focus on problem is becoming overblown; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: ARGENTINA: President Threatens To Quit ; BRAZIL: U.S. Offers Missiles; CUBA: Terror Designation Rejected.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: SmartForce Forecasts A Loss
abstract: Shares of SmartForce drop 32.2 percent after company slashes its first-quarter earnings and revenue outlook, citing slowed economy; terminates its agreement to buy Centra Software; graph (S)

headline: An Abrupt Departure Is Seen as a Harbinger
abstract: The abrupt departure of Bernard J. Ebbers from WorldCom came sooner than Wall Street expected, but long after many investors and analysts began viewing it as inevitable.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: New Aids Policy
abstract: India announce new AIDS prevention policy, emphasizing safer blood supply and counseling to curb transmission; country has nearly four million infected people (S)

headline: Rip 'n' Roll: A Date With 8 Jukeboxes
abstract: New developments in portable music recordings discussed; capacity has expanded so entire music library can be portable; article includes review of 'jukeboxes' that hold 20 gigabytes, or roughly 4,000 songs, running about 300 hours; photo (M)

headline: Adelphia to Put Some Cable Systems Up for Sale
abstract: Adelphia Communications is putting several of its cable systems on market in effort to raise cash; is offering its Southern California system as well as systems in Florida, Virginia and Carolinas and Georgia (M)

headline: A Testy Branson Flirts With the Market Again
abstract: Sir Richard Branson, who has been wary of stock market since taking his Virgin Group private in 1988 after only two years as public company, plans to take up to eight Virgin companies public; has shielded most of his $5 billion empire from public scrutiny in web of offshore trusts that serve as holding companies; will begin effort with Virgin Blue, Australian budget airline that will go public in 2003; he dismisses renewed speculation about his solvency spurred by plan; holds he courts stock market only to let loyal partners cash out their investments; growing number of critics hold his charm and knack for publicity mask shaky finances; graphs of stock performance of two public Virgin companies, of group revenue and of Branson's stakes in eight companies going public; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Wireless Company Acquisition
abstract: Proxim, maker of wireless-network equipment, will buy wireless equipment unit of Agere Systems for $65 million to bolster its ownership of local area networks; Warburg Pincus and Broadview Capital Partners will invest $75 million in Proxim to finance purchase (S)

headline: House and Senate Support Israel in Strong Resolutions
abstract: House and Senate vote overwhelmingly to express strongly worded support for Israel in its recent military operations, largely brushing aside last-minute attempts by Bush administration to soften language criticizing Palestinians; two resolutions are nonbinding, but they put legislative branch of government on record as backing military actions of Prime Min Ariel Sharon, even as Pres Bush calls on Israel to end its 'occupation' of Palestinian towns; Senate votes 94 to 2 on its resolution and House votes 352 to 21 for its tougher-worded measure which questions whether Yasir Arafat is 'viable partner for peace'; in emotional debates in House and in Senate, members from left and right repeatedly call Arafat 'terrorist' and 'despot'; minority of lawmakers express reservations about policies of Sharon; 29 House members vote present as protest that resolution is too tilted toward Israel (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: NEC Plans Spinoff
abstract: NEC Corp says it will spin off its nonmemory semiconductor business in October; new company will make system chips, general semiconductors and some devices; graph (S)

headline: Marriages Made in Culinary Heaven
abstract: Mimi Sheraton humorous article fantasizes about silly packaged comestibles that could result from mergers between nonfood brand names and well-known edibles; drawing (M)

headline: Health Organization Declares Europe Free of Polio
abstract: The World Health Organization declared today that Europe is free of polio, which once claimed hundreds of thousands of children yearly.

headline: Mars and other marketers offer scaled-down spots based on the simple pleasures in life.
abstract: Candy maker Mars is revamping its advertising for Milky Way to promote candy bar as one of life's small delights; American part of campaign features television commercials comparing bar to momentary thrills; photo (M)

headline: 3 British Bankers Are Accused of Fraud in Offshoot of Enron Case
abstract: Federal prosecutors in Enron investigation file criminal complaint against three Britons, Gary Mulgrew, Giles Darby and David Bermingham, accusing them of defrauding their employer, National Westminster Bank, of $7.3 million through dealings with partnership related to company; describe plan hatched by bankers and Enron executives to trick National Westminster into selling valuable investment to another entity for far less than it was worth; unknown to bank, that entity--partnership known as Southamption--was owned by Enron executives, and British bankers indirectly held stake in it as well; executives and bankers pocketed tens of millions of dollars in profits within weeks of sale; Southampton partnership was used by group of Enron insiders, including former chief financial officer Andrew S Fastow, to make millions of dollars that arguably should have gone to Enron; transaction in question found its genesis in entity known as LJM Cayman, partnership controlled by Fastow that was created to do deals with Enron (M)

headline: 3 North Koreans in Beijing Defect to Seoul
abstract: South Korean Embassy in Beijing says that three North Koreans sought refuge there, and South Korean government demands that Chinese authorities treat case in 'humanitarian manner' (S)

headline: Economic Scene; In numbers we trust, provided they're safe from political meddling.
abstract: Alan B Krueger Economic Scene column on Office of Management and Budget Office's Statistical Policy Directive No 3; says directive affects way economic news is discussed and is cornerstone for trust in federal statistics; holds directive prevents political appointees from publicly commenting on sensitive economic indicators until at least one hour after professionals who produce date have had chance to explain findings; says it also restricts those within government who can receive sensitive data early; photo (M)

headline: 2 Girls, Divided by War, Joined in Carnage
abstract: Deaths of two teenage girls, one Israeli and one Palestinian, are invoked by Pres Bush as he describes horrors of escalating conflict in Middle East; says suicide bombing by 18-year-old Palestinian girl Ayat al-Akhras that also killed 17-year-old Israeli girl Rachel Levy could mean future of Palestinian people and Israeli people is also dying; two girls were both high school seniors, and they looked strikingly similar; vastly different trajectories of their lives intersected for one deadly moment at entrance of Jerusalem supermarket last week; photos (M)

headline: U.S. to Send More G.I.'s to Yemen and Philippines
abstract: Pentagon prepares to increase its commitment to global war on terror by readying new troops for deployment to Yemen and Philippines; logistics assessment team already in Yemen is paving way for arrival of as many as 150 American troops; initial group of 50 to 70 soldiers will be sent by end of month, and will consist predominantly of Special Forces troops; will also include seaport and airport security specialists; training by Navy and Coast Guard of Yemeni forces that patrol 1,500-mile-long coast noted; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says there are no plans to resume port calls in Yemeni port of Aden, where terrorists bombed destroyer Cole 16 months ago killing 16 American sailors; presence of about 575 American troops in Philippines advising and training local troops to combat Abu Sayyaf rebels on Basilan island noted; Rumsfeld says he is awaiting final proposal from military advisers for deployment of additional troops, mostly engineers and civilian affairs specialists (S)

headline: U.S.-Led Forces Hunting Taliban Kill 1, Seize 50 in Compound Raid
abstract: American-led troops hunting remnants of the Taliban raided a compound west of Kandahar today, the Pentagon said today.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Retailers Expand
abstract: Carrefour, Europe's largest retailer, and Wal-Mart Stores Inc will invest combined $57 million to open three outlets each in China's northeastern province of Heilongjiang amid mounting competition for consumer spending in mainland (S)

headline: The Self-Checkout: Lots of Swiping, No Stealing
abstract: Systems have been developed that allow supermarket shoppers to scan and bag items without waiting in long check-out lines; scale eliminates possibility of theft and touch-screen monitor guides shoppers through process; three main vendors are Optimal Robotics, NCR and PSC; large supermarket chains, including Kroger, Albertson's and A&P, have embraced technology and other types of retail outlets are interested; photo with details captions shows how system works (M)

headline: Bonuses Once Meant to Retain Talent Now Risk Outrage
abstract: WorldCom, which will give 17,000 workers it is laying off a few weeks' severance pay, recently paid 558 top executives roughly $237 million in retention bonuses; this executive-reward system is set to expire July 30 (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: John Gaffney, president at ArnoldMPG, Boston, was named chief operating officer for the United States operations of the Media Planning Group.

headline: World Business Briefing: Americas
abstract: CANADA: Job Cuts At At CHILE: Copper Business Sold.

headline: For the Song in Your Heart, A Keyboard 'Fun' Button
abstract: Creative Labs offers Prodikeys, computer keyboard that doubles as 37-key MIDI (musical instrument digital interface) keyboard; it is bundled with music software program; photo (M)

headline: What Was the Heart of Enron Keeps Shrinking
abstract: Book value of Enron Corp's trading desk, source of nearly all of its profits, has plunged, in part because of changes in market during fall and winter and in part because desk reportedly sometimes exaggerated worth of deals to inflate profits; company's bankruptcy reorganization plan revolves almost entirely around generating cash by liquidating unit that houses trading desk and still owns book; Enron has sold trading desk to UBS for percentage of profits it generates; some creditors hope Enron is merely trying to lower expectations with its low estimates of book's current value; photo (M)

headline: Afghan Refugees Allowed to Pass After Poppy Farmers End Protest
abstract: Thousands of Afghan refugees begin trek home across country's eastern border after poppy farmers, at government's behest, call off protest that had blocked refugees' passage; however, fighting at western border and confusing situation in east highlights tenuous hold that interim government headed by Hamid Karzai exerts over fractious and war-torn country; poppy farmers can earn much more by taking crops to market than government is willing to pay them to destroy harvest although there is confusion about amount government would pay; photo (M)

headline: Fighting 'Light Skin' as a Standard of Beauty
abstract: Irene Njoroge, cosmetologist in Nairobi, Kenya, campaigns against skin-lightening cream, product that has become essential part of many African women's beauty routines, and big business, too; says women are being exploited by irresponsible beauty manufacturers who are cashing in on common perception in Africa that lighter one's skin, wealthier, better educated and more attractive one is; notes that labels on skin-whitening agents fail to disclose potentially harmful, sometimes fatal, effects of creams; her organizaiton, called Beauty Without Danger, conducts neighborhood tours to document extent of problem to Kenyan authorities; photo (M)

headline: PFIZER TO BUY BACK STOCK; MAY SELL 2 BUSINESSES
abstract: Pfizer Inc will buy back as much as $10 billion worth of its stock over next 24 months, its largest repurchase ever (S)

headline: Chief Executive Resigns Position As Adelphia Expands Inquiry
abstract: Adelphia Communications says founder-chief executive John J Rigas has resigned and that it is conducting investigation into issues raised during preparation of its 2001 financial statements; also says it is suspending audit by accountant Deloitte & Touche, while it conducts its inquiry; says it has hired lawyer David Boies to advise it in connection with its investigation and other matters; Rigas, who will remain on board, will be succeeded by Erland E Kailbourne, former chairman and chief executive of Fleet National Bank's New York region; will serve as chairman and interim chief executive; Rigas's son Timothy, chief financial officer, may resign his post and his board seat; news leaves investors wondering how company will cope with deadline to submit its 2001 financial statements to Nasdaq on May 16; if it does not submit statements, it runs risk of being delisted, which could set off chain of events leading company into bankruptcy court; Adelphi plans to ask Nasdaq for extension; graph (M)

headline: F.T.C. CHALLENGES CYTYC'S PURCHASE OF DIGENE
abstract: Federal Trade Commission challenges Cytyc Corp's planned $283 million purchase of medical-test rival Digene Corp, saying acquisition threatens competition; says it will seek to block purchase until administrative law judge considers agency's complaint (S)

headline: PALM HARBOR BUYS NATIONWIDE, A MODULAR HOME BUILDER
abstract: Palm Harbor buys nationwide

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Leader Urges Calm For World Cup
abstract: Pres Kim Dae Jung calls for moratorium on strikes and political infighting in South Korea through end of World Cup soccer finals on June 30; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Airgate Shares Drop
abstract: AirGate PCS Inc shares drop sharply on concern that fiscal third-quarter growth may lag forecasts (S)

headline: Headphones for a Big Sound From the Smallest Devices
abstract: Bose Corp introduces new lightweight headphones for use with portable CD and MP3 players that produce full-range sound associated with heavier headsets; photo (M)

headline: PAYOUT SCHEDULE SET FOR UNITED FLIGHT ATTENDANTS
abstract: Arbitration panel rules that United Airlines flight attendants should get $48 million from April 1, 2002, to March 21, 2003, to make up for lower-than-average wages; this is tantamount to 5.49 percent wage increase (S)

headline: Afghan Leader Vows Political Reforms and War on Corruption
abstract: Afghanistan's newly elected president, Hamid Karzai, lays out plans for government to 1,600 delegates of loya jirga or grand council, promising to defend them against intimidation and to reform intelligence service and judicial systems; partly mollifies delegates, frustrated at lack of progress on other important issues since council convened and voted overwhelmingly to elect him leader of two-year transitional administration; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: Subpoenas Planned For Executives; S.E.C. Files Fraud Charges.

headline: E.D.S. Cites Lag in Orders For Decline In Earnings
abstract: Electronic Data Systems reports first-quarter earnings that declined 21 percent; says profit was $354 million compared with $446 million year earlier; sales increased 7 percent from year ago, to $5.3 billion; chairman-chief executive Richard H Brown comments (M)

headline: Press Conference Following President's Meeting With Saudi Crown Prince
abstract: Remarks made by President Bush following his meeting with Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia on Thursday, as provided by the White House.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Jonathan Daly was named senior partner and global planning director for the Pfizer account at J. Walter Thompson, New York, part of the WPP Group. He had been director for account planning at Foote, Cone & Belding, New York, part of the FCB Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: A Chinese Dad in Defense of the Average Child
abstract: Interview with Zhou Changyi, Chinese author whose book--I'm Mediocre, I'm Happy--has horrified many Chinese, especially parents, for whom advanced education is consuming goal; photo (M)

headline: Compressed Data; More Troubles Are Expected for Telecommunications
abstract: Study by corporate turnaround expert Carter Pate predicts bankruptcy filings by public companies will fall by over 20 percent in 2002, to around 200; sees telecommunications as leading trouble spot; says telecommunications companies that avoid bankruptcy have relatively bright future (S)

headline: Global Crossing Altered Sports Deal, Records Show
abstract: Bankruptcy court documents suggest Global Crossing altered 2001 deal with sports marketing company IMG Worldwide in move similar to those that spurred probe of whether company used swaps to inflate sales; show TWI Interactive, IMG unit, sought $30 million deal to acquire communications services in exchange for advertising and marketing services; TWI proposed straight barter deal, which Global changed to allow for equal exchange of cash (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: ADOBE POSTS DECLINES IN EARNINGS AND SALES; MANUGISTICS TO SHUT SOME OFFICES; ALLIANCE WILL ACQUIRE LIQUID AUDIO;.

headline: GUILTY PLEA SEEN IN THE SHREDDING OF ENRON RECORDS
abstract: David B Duncan, Arthur Andersen accountant whose destruction of records related to Enron led to criminal indictment of firm, reportedly will plead guilty to single felony count of obstruction of justice and will serve as government witness; move is seen as setback to firm's efforts to exonerate itself; could be boon to federal prosecutors pursuing criminal investigation of Enron since it will give government its highest-ranking and most knowledgeable witness to financial decisions that ultimately pushed Enron into bankruptcy; photo (M)

headline: Partisanship Dissolves Tax Shelter Hearing
abstract: House Ways and Means Committee hearing on offshore tax shelters is adjourned because of partisan bickering before issue can be fully discussed (M)

headline: Germans of One Mind About Two Rivals: Dubious
abstract: Residents of Bremen, German

headline: E-Diaries (Tap, Tap) Aid Drug Trials
abstract: Electronic gathering of self-reported data is being utilized in drug trials; aids efficiency and accuracy, reduces paper and allows data to be collected daily via modem (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Yahoo Stake Sold; JAPAN: The Check Is In The E-mail; INDIA: Toyota Parts Expansion; CHINA: Retailers Expand.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: U.N. Governor Overrules Assembly
abstract: Kosovo's fledgling assembly tries to assert its independence by refusing to recognize border treaty signed by Yugoslavia and Macedonia, but is overruled by United Nations governor Michael Steiner, who tells assembly move exceeds limited self-rule powers (S)

headline: Private Sector; The Chinese (Insurers) Are Coming
abstract: People's Insurance Co of

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Protestant Fighter Dead
abstract: Mark Fulton, 42, a Protestant paramilitary fighter who succeeded Billy Wright as head of the Loyalist Volunteer Force after Mr. Wright was shot to death in 1997 by Catholic inmates, was himself found dead, a belt around his neck, in his prison cell outside Belfast. He had been in jail since December 2001, accused of conspiring to murder a Protestant rival, and had expressed fear of being murdered.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Israelis Deploy More Troops as Palestinian Attacks Continue
abstract: Israeli tanks poured into the West Bank today in a massive military deployment, as Palestinians continued attacks and demonstrations spread across the Arab world.

headline: Koreans see soccer impresario as presidential timber
abstract: SEOUL:—  The tycoon's son who brought the World Cup soccer tournament to South Korea has emerged as the biggest winner of a show whose popular success has exceeded all expectations.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Food Brands Acquired
abstract: Associated British Foods agrees to buy Mazola cooking oil and 18 other Brands from Unilever for $360 million; deal will make Associated British Foods top retail food ingredients manufacturer in North America; graph (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: U.S. Resident Detained
abstract: Colleagues say Yang Jianli, United States-based Chinese democracy advocate, has been detained in Kumming after sneaking into China to probe recent labor unrest (S)

headline: U.S. Subpoenas Wellpoint Documents
abstract: WellPoint Health Networks Inc, one of California's biggest health insurers, says US attorney's office in Boston has subpoenaed documents about its relationship with TAP Pharmaceutical Products; subpoena seeks information related to TAP's drugs Lupron and Prevacid (S)

headline: Bannu Journal; Where Al Qaeda's the Quarry, G.I.'s Are Elusive
abstract: Article on elusive presence of US Special Forces soldiers in remote tribal areas of Pakistan, searching for Al Qaeda terrorists; operations in Bannu, home to of Pashtun Muslims who despise outside military forces, described; Pakistan Government has banned journalists from tribal region, and Bannu is as close as they can get; map; photo (M)

headline: A Hay Fever Showdown
abstract: Battle for over-the-counter market in genetic allergy medication Claritin heats up following Food and Drug Administration approval of request by Schering-Plough to sell it over counter (S)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   8.00       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   4.50       Federal funds   1.75   1.88   5.10       3-month T-bills   1.75   1.79   4.01       6-month T-bills   2.06   2.11   3.91       10-yr.
