headline: MSNBC Signs 'Hardball' Host Into 2009
abstract: Chris Matthews, host of MSNBC talk show Hardball With Chris Matthews, agrees to stay with network through June 2009; will also host weekly program of political analysis; MSNBC will shift Hardball to 9 pm to make it centerpiece of its prime-time lineup; photo (S)

headline: Q&A / Takashi Asai : How to escape Japan's next crisis
abstract: In the early 1990s, Takashi Asai, a financial reporter at Mainichi Shimbun, a Japanese daily, published a series of books warning of the coming disaster in which banks would face a crisis, prices would fall and life-time employment would crumble. At the time, they were not taken seriously. Today they read like a recounting of the economic events of the past decade in Japan. In 1996, Asai started a publishing enterprise, Daini-kaientai, which, among other things, issues financial newsletters to wealthy individual investors. He also runs an investors' club. His fans like his no-holds-barred critique of government policy and his bold counsel on how to defend one's wealth, including suggestions that people move to New Zealand. Asai believes the Japanese economy will probably collapse within a few years, possibly as early as next year, and that the government's assurances that it can never go bankrupt should not be accepted. He discussed ways that individuals can protect their assets with Miki Tanikawa.

headline: Bleeding to Death
abstract: Bethlehem's streets are terrifyingly empty of everyone except Israeli soldiers searching for Palestinian gunmen; shops are closed and few residents venture out; some ambulances are unable to reach wounded; Israeli officials say they know their violence could breed more gunmen and suicide bombers, but they insist they have no choice; say their invasion of Bethlehem should at least slow their opponents down; photo; map (M)

headline: Staples Selects Competition Lineup
abstract: Staples Inc names nine advertising agencies to compete in review for broadcast creative part of its account, with billings estimated at $50 million to $70 million; those duties had been handled last eight years by Cliff Freeman & Partners, which decided against taking part in review (S)

headline: In Assisted Living, A Matter of Geography
abstract: Study finds that cost of assisted-living communities averages $2,159 a month nationwide but varies greatly by region, being most expensive in New York City and cheapest in Jackson, Miss (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Shell Goes Ahead With North Sea Deal
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group will proceed with its planned 3.5 billion pound ($5 billion) acquisition of Enterprise Oil despite new 10 percent tax levied against oil and gas profits from North Sea region; tax is part of British budget prepared by Chancellor of Exchequer Gordon Brown (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: RUSSIA: Communists Want To Purge A Leader; BELARUS: Crackdown On; KOSOVO: U.N. Governor Overrules Assembly; FRANCE: Still Defiant In Beef Dispute.

headline: The Corporate Poll, Sales Pitch Attached
abstract: Examples of recent corporate polls whose sponsors were trying to show need for their products (S)e

headline: Strong views, pro and con, on ads linking drug use to terrorism.
abstract: Bush administration's new antidrug advertising campaign seeks to strike chord with young people by linking drug use to supporting terrorism; it has struck nerve with critics who contend message is inappropriate and goes too far; proponents call advertisements powerful and factual; critics say link between drug use and terrorism is overreaching wartime propaganda; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Report Cites Rights Abuses
abstract: Human Rights Watch issues 200-page report accusing government of Vietnam of wide range of abuses against hill tribes of Central Highlands, including crackdown on unapproved Protestant worship(S)

headline: France's short work week a mixed blessing
abstract: VALENCIENNES, France:—  At 1:15 p.m., workers at a Toyota plant here finish the early 7-hour shift. Thanks to France's 35-hour work week, "We are going to work less and have more and more hobbies," says Afekir Ahmed, a union leader.

headline: Format's Redesign Yields Faster Image Files
abstract: Compression format that reduces file size of photographs for electronic transmission is being redesigned and promises better quality and speedier downloading; updated format uses waveless technology which encodes and sends image in continuous stream, yielding higher resolution as file opens (M)

headline: Blows Keep Coming for an Argentina Long in Crisis
abstract: Argentina's already disastrous economic crisis is suddenly threatening to become even worse; Pres Eduardo Duhalde says it may be impossible to reach any agreement with International Monetary Fund; central bank president Mario Blejer is stepping down; will be replaced by Aldo Piganelli; Blejer's departure leaves Economic Min Roberto Lavagna as undisputed chief of government's economic team; Lavagna embarks on three days of meeting with country's creditors in New York and Washington to get $18 billion from lenders; Argentine peso is down 2.5 percent, to 3.86 to dollar;

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Nationwide strike in Venezuela reduces oil shipments from nation, No. 2 source of US imports; crude oil prices rise; chart (S)

headline: Genentech Told to Pay $200 Million in Damages
abstract: California jury orders Genentech to pay $200 million in punitive damages to City of Hope National Medical Center for failing to pay royalties under contract that dates back to founding of biotechnology industry; new damages come on top of $300.2 million in compensatory damages awarded by jury in early June, bringing total Genentech must pay to $500 million; Genentech says it will ask Judge Edward Y Kakita, who presided over trial, to set aside verdict and, if that fails, will appeal to higher court; Genentech chief executive Arthur D Levinson and chief financial officer Louis J Lavigne Jr comment; case reviewed (M)

headline: 'Click, Click' Can Be Music to Real Estate Brokers' Ears
abstract: National Association of Realtors survey reveals that homebuyers' use of Internet improves real estate brokers' business; graphs (S)

headline: Saks Reports $25.4 Million Quarterly Loss
abstract: Saks Inc reports first-quarter net loss of $25.4 million compared with net income of $26.5 million year earlier; sales in quarter ended May 4 fell 2.6 percent, to $1.43 billion from $1.46 billion (S)

headline: The Sport of Financiers
abstract: Of 125 elite players competing at United States Bridge Championships, Memphis, Tenn, 25 are employed in corporate finance, accounting or capital markets trading (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Says It Will Meet Goals
abstract: Technology Brief

headline: Home on the Road: B & B's Lure Business Travelers
abstract: Many bed-and-breakfast lodges have reinvented themselves to compete more directly with hotel chains for business travelers; they are providing guests with Internet access, dual phone lines and fax machines, and are offering various conveniences; photo (M)

headline: Drug Makers' Generic Tactics Criticized
abstract: Federal Trade Commission chairman Timothy J Muris, Bush appointee, contends that brand-name drug companies are using illegal tactics to prolong their monopolies on prescription medicines, depriving consumers of benefits of less expensive generic drugs; members of Congress say they will try to pass legislation this year to allow swifter access to generic drugs; Muris says brand-name drug companies delay sale of generic drugs by improperly listing patents with Food and Drug Administration and filing lawsuits against makers of generic drugs; FTC, in first action of its kind, says drug company Biovail Corp illegally acquired exclusive patent license and improperly listed patent with FDA for purpose of stifling generic competition with its drug Tiazac, which is used to treat high blood pressure and chronic chest pain (M)

headline: Israelis Say Arab Dead in Jenin Number in Dozens, Not Hundreds
abstract: Israeli Army rebuts rumors of massacres and mass burials in Jenin refugee camp on West Bank; says number of Palestinian dead is not in hundreds but in dozens; will allow Red Cross to monitor collection of 26 bodies following Israeli Supreme Court ruling; takes members of media on tour to stem growing outcry, which led court to enjoin it from burying Palestinians in enemies' cemetery; mass destruction in Jenin refugee camp described; occurred during army operation to take control of camp, which turned violent after 13 Israeli infantrymen were killed in ambush; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Alitalia Is Recapitalized
abstract: European Commission approves 1.4 billion euro ($1.3 billion) recapitalization of Alitalia even though Italian government is financing 62 percent of program (S)

headline: MIDEAST TURMOIL: The Battle; A Different Fight, A Different Victory
abstract: Israeli forces withdraw to edges of Nablus, and Palestinian fighters there return to streets, slapping posters on walls to celebrate their dead and vowing even fiercer struggle against Israel; this suggests that Israel may find it impossible to sustain its inroads, nor did it negate Palestinians' ability to fight back another day (M)

headline: New Twist in Case of U.S. Reporter Killed in Mexican Hills
abstract: Appeals panel in Mexican state of Jalisco reinstates convictions of two Huichol Indian, Juan Chivarra de la Cruz and Miguel Hernandez de la Cruz in murder of Philip True, American journalist who was killed in December 1998 while hiking alone in southwestern Sierra Madre; photo; map (M)

headline: 12 Bids? Goodbye, Old Rust Bucket
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column shares experience of selling car at Ebay auction site, from listing through eventual sale; auto sales are site's fastest growing category; drawing (M)

headline: Britain's Nonwhites Feel Un-British, Report Says
abstract: Britain's reputation as one of Europe's more stable multiethnic socities was shaken last summer by series of riots in cities with substantial immigrant populations; 40,000 nonwhite residents live in Sheffield, and despite fact many of them were born and raised there, they identify themselves as anything but British; they call themselves Afro-Caribbean, or Asian; this self-definition strikes nerve in Britain, where government has made taking common sense about British nationhood to immigrant population a critical measure of progress in push for racial integration and assimilation; nonwhite people in Sheffield who have had success in getting education, finding jobs and building stable lives say they do not feel they are part of same nation inhabited by white residents, and they resent official entreaty to think otherwise; for many of them integration appears to be less of goal than it is for government; photos; chart (L)

headline: Scrutiny Increases for Martha Stewart
abstract: Questions remain about activities surrounding Martha Stewart's decision to sell nearly 4,000 shares of ImClone Systems Inc's stock last December; Stewart's friend Dr Samuel D Waksal refuses to testify before Congressional committee investigating whether ImClone misled investors about regulators' attitude toward its application for cancer drug Erbitux; Congressional investigators are said to be seeking records of brokerage firm Merrill Lynch and telephone logs of Stewart; Stewart's broker Peter Bacanovic refuses to comment on matter; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Back Taxes Sought
abstract: Japanese tax authorities are seeking as much as 7 billion yen ($56 million) in back taxes from some of Morgan Stanley's real estate funds based in US; funds, which are registered in Delaware, invested in Japanese property in 1999 and 2000 and did not pay taxes on 18 billion yen in income (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Setback For MobilCom Executive
abstract: Shareholders of MobilCom hand vote of no confidence to company's chief executive Gerhard Schmid after inquiry ordered by France Telecom found that stock option plan he proposed broke German securities rules; MobilCom's shares fall 14 percent after Schmid admits he violated rules by failing to give finance chief Thorsten Grenz enough information about option program; vote further erodes Schmid's credibility and gives France Telecom's chief executive Michel Bon upper hand for control of MobilCom (S)

headline: LEHMAN SELLS PART OF ITS STAKE IN PEABODY ENERGY
abstract: Lehman Brothers Inc and other shareholders sell 17 percent stake in Peabody Energy Corp for over $257 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Pulp Mill Spinoff
abstract: Abitibi-Consolidated Inc to spin off pulp mill to raise as much as $259 million (S)

headline: NATO Must Attack Terrorists Before They Hit, Rumsfeld Says
abstract: NATO must take the war on terrorism to the terrorists by pre-emptive attacks, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi's Cash Plan
abstract: Shares in the world's largest media company, Vivendi Universal of France, fell 8.4 percent yesterday after the company announced a plan to raise cash. On Thursday, the company proposed leasing stock in its water subsidiary Vivendi Environnement to Deutsche Bank as collateral for a loan valued at 1.4 billion euros. That was seen as a sign that cash flow was weaker than investors had estimated. Vivendi was originally expected to sell 15 percent of the subsidiary. Acquisitions by the chief executive, Jean-Marie Messier, have left the company with $30 billion in debt. Shares in Vivendi Environnement fell 2.7 percent, to 32.1 euros.     Kerry Shaw (NYT)

headline: MORTON'S ACCEPTS CASTLE HARLAN'S $63 MILLION OFFER
abstract: Morton's Restaurant Group, owner of chain of steakhouses, accepts $63 million takeover offer from Castle Harlan Inc, which raised its offer to match that of Carl C Icahn (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Advanced Micro Introduces New Chip
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices Inc adds new low-power chip, Au1100, for wireless gear as company tries to challenge Intel Corp in fast-growing markets (S)

headline: UN aide sees no conflict in business and diplomatic roles : Envoy to Burma offers to resign
abstract: BANGKOK:—  The United Nations special envoy to Burma, Ismail Razali, acknowledged Monday that his company was doing business with Rangoon's military government and offered to resign if the deal was found to be a conflict of interest.

headline: Fund Managers Gloomy About U.S. Stocks
abstract: Merrill Lynch survey reveals that managers of mutual funds are gloomy about prospects for stocks of American corporations (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi Suit Dismissed
abstract: French court dismisses petition by shareholder activist Colette Neuville to name independent expert to examine whether Vivendi Universal chief executive Jean-Marie Messier properly informed board about his $100 billion of acquisitions that contributed to record 2001 loss (S)

headline: On Border With Lebanon, 'This Family Is Never Scared'
abstract: Hezbollah apparently seeks to draw Israel into new front while it is deeply engaged in fight against Palestinians with daily shelling of Israeli forces in heavily fortified bunkers along Lebanese border; Israel, which has been responding with largely symbolic air strikes that carefully avoid villages where shells come from, makes clear that it will target Syria for sponsoring attacks; Israelis living near border comment; photo (M)

headline: Andersen Auditor Testifies Policy Entailed Shredding
abstract: Arthur Andersen auditor Patricia S Grutzmacher testifies in firm's criminal trial that when partner Thomas H Bauer referred to its document-retention policy, he meant that employees should start destroying documents; Grutzmacher says on Oct 23, Bauer told Andersen employees working on Enron Corp matters that they should make sure they were in compliance with policy; testimony bolsters one of prosectuors' critical contentions in trial, in which government has charged Andersen with obstructio n ofjustice for destroying documents related to its work for Enron; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Phone Sale Delayed
abstract: Czech government delays decision to sell its stake in Ceski Telecom and says it will hold talks with two bidders in effort to raise more money from sale; wants 80 billion korunas ($2.32 billion) for 51 percent stake; further 27 percent stake is for sale from consortium running company, joint venture of Royal KPN and Swisscom (S)

headline: Cyberpets? Shudder
abstract: A C Willment letter on May 2 article finds idea of cyberpets perverse

headline: Hal Riney, Founder Of Agency, to Retire
abstract: Hal Riney will retire as chairman of Publicis & Hal Riney and become chairman emeritus (S)

headline: Banking Mergers Gain Momentum in Europe
abstract: Analysts say bank executives in Europe are re-examining potential for big, cross-border acquisitions with share prices beginning to stabilize; regulators in Britain and Scandinavia have effectively barred further consolidation on domestic front, so bank in those countries will have to look for growth abroad; analysts say France and Germany have too many banks, making consolidation inevitable; add acquisitions are best way for large European banks to follow in footsteps of Citigroup and J P Morgan Chase by offering full financial servies; possible mergers noted; chart (M)

headline: As Crisis Deepens, Mubarak Finds He Is on the Sidelines
abstract: Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak, after more than 20 years of standing alongside American presidents in building peace in Middle East, feels undermined by Washington, upstaged by Saudi Arabia and vulnerable before angry Arab population; is reportedly angered by Pres Bush's approach to Israeli-Palestinian crisis; wants administration to take more muscular and balanced approach; reportedly feels Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon is not partner for peace with Arabs and that it was probably mistake for Arab leaders to have offered Saudi-sponsored peace proposal at recent Arab League summit; is reportedly chafing that his stature in Arab world and in Washington appears to have declined since days not long ago when he played leading role in broader peace effort between Israel and Arab states; photos; anger at Israel spills into streets in Cairo; riot police fire tear gas and water cannons at large numbers of protestors trying to reach Israeli Embassy (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: INDIA: A Warning To Pakistan; INDIA: Support For Embattled Neighbor; HONG KONG: Leader Appoints New Team; KAZAKHSTAN: Law On Political Parties;.

headline: Marvin Honig, An Ad Talent, Is Dead at 66
abstract: Marvin Honig, leading creative talent in advertising in 1960's and 1970's, dies at age 66 (S)

headline: U.S. Cautioned Leader of Plot Against Chávez
abstract: Bush administration acknowledges that Asst Sec Otto J Reich telephoned Pedro Carmona Estanga, briefly Venezuela's president after coup against Hugo Chavez, to plead with him not to dissolve National Assembly because it would provoke outcry; officials cite call as evidence they tried to uphold democratic process, but disclosure raises questions as to whether Reich or others were stage-managing coup; Carmona did shut down Assembly and Supreme Court, igniting popular backlash that restored Chavez; Bush administration, which denies encouraging plotters against leftist president, told members of Congress Chavez had resigned and did not condemn coup until after angry protestoers forced Carmona out; White House spokesman Ari Fleischer insists US 'explicitly' told opposition leaders US would not back coup (M)

headline: Some Thoughts On Airline Security
abstract: Aviation consultant Michael Boyd strongly opposes so-called trusted traveler plan, which would allow passengers who agree to detailed prescreening to carry 'smart card' ID's that would allow them expedited passage through airport security; Boyd says people can go from being acceptable risk to unacceptable one with no trace (S)

headline: Center-Left Leader in Prague Is Asked to Form Government
abstract: Czech Republic Pres Vaclav Havel asks center-left leader Vladimir Spidla to form government as concern grows that center-left coalition might not be strong enough to push through reforms needed to take country into European Union; Spidla's ruling Social Democrats finished first in June 14 parliamentary elections, taking 30 percent of vote and winning 70 seats in 200-seat lower house (M)

headline: Law Firm Merger Is Set for Today
abstract: Bryan Cave and Robinson Silverman Pearce Aronsohn & Berman law firms reportedly plan to merge; combined firm will be known as Bryan Cave/Robinson Silverman in New York and Bryan Cave elsewhere (S)

headline: The Big Board Is Standing Up for Independence
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column welcomes New York Stock Exchange's proposals for how companies whose shares it trades can improve their corporate governance, particularly requirement that independent directors are majority of company's board (M)

headline: Japan, Joining Europeans, Plans To Impose Steel Duties on U.S.
abstract: Japan joins forces with European Union in announcing that it will impose 100 percent duties on some imports of American steel in June; is first time Japanese government has taken such action in trade dispute, and it represents emergence of new coalition of government to combat what is seen as flare-up of protectionism in bush administration; Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development overrules American objections and issues communique urging all nations to resist protectionism and to pursue free trade (M)

headline: Durban Journal; A Hit Song Puts Ethnic Tensions at Center Stage
abstract: Song by Mbongeni Ngema, South Africa's most prominent black playwright, has become hit and is stirring furor, particularly in ethnically diverse city of Durban; song accuses people of Indian ancestry of exploiting and abusing blacks; prominent Indians are calling Ngema racist, Nelson Mandela, country's first black president, has asked him to apologize, and there is growing pressure to ban song from airwaves; but Ngema remains decidely unapologetic, saying uproar only highlights need to address longstanding tensions between blacks and Indians; photos (Durban Journal) (M)

headline: Special Grand Jury Zeroes In on Enron Executives
abstract: Prosecutors open new phase in investigation of collapse of Enron Corp, advancing beyond indictment of its auditor Arthur Andersen to focus on company executives and their activities; convene special grand jury, charged solely with investigating possible crimes related to collapse; are focusing particular attention on deals involving quarter of partnerships known as the Raptors, as well as Southampton Place, which number of Enron insiders used to enrich themselves; are examining other issues, including whether conversations between company executives and Army Sec Thomas E White, former Enron executive, may have led him to sell Enron stock valued at $3 million in October; are examining whether Enron executives perjured themselves while testifying under oath before Congressional committees; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Economy Surged at 5.8% Rate in the First Quarter
abstract: The nation's economy expanded at its fastest rate in more than two years during the first three months of 2002, the government reported today.

headline: Rage Against the Machine (When Any Rage Will Do)
abstract: Game Theory column reviews State of Emergency, developed by Vis, and JSRF: Jet Set Radio Future, developed by Smilebit; both are riot-simulation games; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Convictions In Attack On Foreigners
abstract: Three former skinheads are convicted of attempted murder for throwing firebombs at Rostock, Germany, apartment complex housing asylum seekers 10 years ago; 30 other people have been convicted in attack (S)

headline: Inquiry Into Drug-Sales Practices Is Widened
abstract: US Attorney's office in Boston widens its five-year probe into sales practices of prescription-drug companies, subpoenaing records involving distribution of best-selling drug, Prevacid, made by TAP Pharmaceuticals, joint venture of Abbott Laboratories and Takeda Chemical Industries, and managed care drug distributors Caremark Rx and Express Scripts; Caremark and Express Scripts say subpoenas requested records for Prevacid, ulcer treatment that had $3 billion in 2001 sales, as well as for Lupon, prostate cancer treatment, also made by TAP; three companies say federal investigators told them they are not targets of current phase of investigation;

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Dairy Company Overhaul
abstract: Japan's Snow Brand Milk asks its main creditors for another 50 billion yen in financial aid and announces additional 1,300 job cuts by September; company will sell part of its ice cream and baby foods businesses (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Beverage Profit Up
abstract: Fomento Economico Mexicano, Mexico's largest beverage company, says first-quarter profit rose 29 percent; net income grew to 628 million pesos ($68 million), from 488 million pesos year earlier; sales rose 6 percent, to 11.36 billion pesos (S)

headline: A Lighthearted Candidate in Colombia Gives a Lift to the Left
abstract: Luis Eduardo Garzon, former Communist who has never held public office, is unlikely presidential candidate in Colombia; could finish as high as third in field of nearly dozen candidates; political analysts say he has strong enough showing to carve out niche for left that has been hobbled by assassinations and bitter feuding; Garzon is focusing on uniting disparate and often intolerant left comprising Communist Party members, former rebels, union leaders and what is left of Patriotic Union (M)

headline: Bush Speaks of Heroism and Sacrifice at Cemetery in Normandy
abstract: On the first Memorial Day since Sept. 11, the president recalled "the scale and heroism and sacrifice of the young" who gave their lives during World War II.

headline: Bush Puts Best Face on Mission, Calling Powell Trip Worthwhile
abstract: President Bush today appeared to back off from his statements that Israel must immediately withdraw from the West Bank.

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: Africa NIGERIA: Court Sides With Government On Oil; SUDAN: Cease-fire Monitors.

headline: Hopes for Mideast Send Oil Prices Down
abstract: hopes f

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: U.S. Offers Missiles
abstract: Pentagon offers to supply medium-range missiles to Brazil, marking first time US authorizes sale of weapons in Latin America; action is seen as attempt to gain edge for F-16 jet, although Brazil is believed to favor French-made Mirage (S)

headline: Imports Lift Trade Deficit to $31.5 Billion
abstract: Commerce Department reports US trade deficit grew in February to widest in 10 months as recovering economy fueled demand for imported goods; figures show $31.5 billion trade gap was larger than expected and 11.6 percent wider than $28.2 billion deficit in January; imports of consumer goods rose 4.6 percent, to $24.4 billion, largest since March 2001; value of oil imports fell 17.9 percent, to $4 billion, in February from $4.9 billion in January; US imported 243.5 milion barrels in February, less than 301 million in January, as price rose to $16.56 per barrel from $16.31 (M)

headline: Phone Industry Slump Hurts Canadian Banks
abstract: Slump in telephone business is taking heavy toll on Canada's banks; three of industry's five leaders have reported sharply lower profits in latest quarter, with big hits from their exposure to troubled borrowers in North American telecommunications sector; Bank of Montreal says net income in quarter ended April 30 halved, to 301 million Canadian dollars ($196 million); bank raised its provisions for loan losses 47 percent, to $209 million, with bulk of increase stemming from $91 million write-off of nearly all its loans to Teleglobe, owned by BCE; Toronto-Dominion Bank and Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, known as CIBC, have heaviest exposure to telecommunications sector relative to their size of any banks in North America, with industry accounting for 4 to 5 percent of two banks' loan books; banks with limited exposure to industry, including Royal Bank of Canada and Bank of Nova Scotia, report higher second-quarter earnings; Bank of Nova Scotia says second-quarter earnings rose 11 percent, to 598 million Canadian dollars ($390 million); chart (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: DVD Renter Speeds Delivery
abstract: Netflix, online digital videodisc rental company, says it has 10 new distribution centers operating across country; says because of geographical placement of shipping centers, half of company's 600,000 subscribers will receive DVD deliveries overnight, while other half will receive shipments in two days (S)

headline: G-8 Adopts African Aid Package, With Strict Conditions
abstract: Pres Bush and leaders of major industrial countries end meeting in Canada by committing billions of dollars in aid to African nations that successfully reform economies and governments; leaders pledge to reduce their own farm subsidies, which would help poor countries compete, but only after global trade talks; separately, Europe and Japan agree to provide up to $10 billion for dismantling of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons in Russia and other former Soviet states; US has already committed $10 billion; Bush, meeting with Pres Vladimir Putin, reports positive response from others to his new approach to Mideast; skirts issues of ousting Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat; Russia will host meeting for first time in 2006; photos of Pres Bush with Nigerian Pres Olusegun Obasanjo and with Putin (M)

headline: Inquiry on Canadians' Deaths Says U.S. Pilots Broke Rules
abstract: Military officials say probe found Air National Guard pilot Major Harry Schmidt, who mistakenly dropped bomb on Canadian soldiers conducting nighttime live-fire exercise in Afghanistan in Apr, and pilot of second plane broke procedures by not taking time to assess threat properly; say Schmidt thought he was under attack from ground when he dropped bomb that killed four Canadians and wounded eight; say warning from radar plane that potential frendlies were in area came seconds too late; say inquiry found second pilot, Maj William Umbach, failed to exercise leadership (M)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: ZIMBABWE: Leading Lawyer Arrested ; MADAGASCAR: More Political Clashes.

headline: As Local Voting Nears, Blair Assails French Rightist's 'Racism'
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair attacks 'repellent racism' of Jean-Marie Le Pen, far-right candidate for French presidency, and he urges British politicians to stand up to anti-immigration British National Party in local elections next week; BNP hopes to attract support in balloting for estimated 6,000 local council seats by concentrating on towns and cities where there was rioting last summer against immigrant populations; pollsters predict less than 25 percent of eligible voters will cast ballots, and warn that extremists can have disproportionately large impact in such low-turnout elections (M)

headline: Hard-Liner Elected in Colombia With a Mandate to Crush Rebels
abstract: Alvaro Uribe Velez, hardliner, is elected president of Colombia with 53 percent of vote, or more than 20 percentage points ahead of closest rival Horacio Serpa, Liberal Party populist; wins majority needed to avoid runoff; he pledges uncompromising 'hard hand' against insurgents; quickly receives backing of US and congratuations from Amb Anne Patterson; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Macedonia: Ex-Guerrillas Enter Politics
abstract: Ali Ahmeti, leader of last year's ethnic Albanian insurgency in Macedonia, forms political party to push for enactment of minority rights reforms agreed to in peace deal brokered by West (S)

headline: ABC Is Said To Have Pact On 'Nightline'
abstract: ABC and Ted Koppel strike agreement that ensures that his late-night news program, Nightline, will remain in its 11:35 pm slot for at least two years; deal patches up--for now--strained relations between Koppel and his network, which had threatened future of Nightline and Koppel's career at ABC News; Nightline's future was placed in doubt earlier in year when ABC tried to woo David Letterman away from CBS to start new late-night talk show in time slot that Koppel has held for 22 years (M)

headline: Intimidation of monitors / Corruption stymies crackdown : Illegal logging topples Cambodia's forests
abstract: PHNOM PENH—  Eva Galabru had returned to her office late one night. As she got out of her car several men, at least one of them masked, pushed her to the ground. Then they kicked and beat her.

headline: Japan Is Slow to Accept the Latest Phones
abstract: Japanese consumers are slow to accept so-called third-generation cellular phone service, unwilling to buy costly handsets that are part personal digital assistant and part portable entertainment center; fuzzy reception from consumers may hamper plans to introduce new feature, ability to use phones around globe; photo (M)

headline: Article 2002042491763017622 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //              JOB POSITIONS

headline: WORLDCOM LEADER DEPARTS COMPANY IN TURBULENT TIME
abstract: Bernard J Ebbers resigns as WorldCom chief executive, president and director; owes company over $366 million for loans and loan guarantees to cover his potential losses on his WorldCom stock as share price plunged; company is subject of wide-ranging Securities and Exchange Commission probe of its accounting practics and financial ties to Ebbers; WorldCom says it has enough cash to continue operating indefinitely, despite staggering debts; analysts note two decades of competitive ferment he helped symbolize have radically changed telecommunications landscape; graphs of WorldCom stock price; revenue and income; photo (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Adrienne H. Bills was named to the new posts of Northeast sales manager and director for brand extensions for National Real Estate Investor and Shopping Center World magazines, New York.

headline: COURT APPROVES LIQUIDATION PLAN FOR T.W.A.
abstract: Trans World Airlines, bankrupt carrier bought last year by AMR Corp, wins court approval of its liquidation plan to pay creditors (S)

headline: Suicide Planner Expresses Joy Over His Missions
abstract: Abdel Karim Aweis, leader of Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades now in Israeli custody, gives interview in which he describes sending suicidal attackers to kill Israelis and expresses satisfaction at their success; says he wanted to even score after growing number of Palestinians were killed by Israeli troops in months of intensifying violence and to force Israeli public to demand withdrawal from West Bank and Gaza -- aim he acknowledges has not be achieved; his own role illustrates complex relationship between armed militants of Fatah movement and security orces of Palestinian Authority; photo of Aweis at funeral of his brother in March (M)

headline: A consultant issues a report that looks at how public service ads could be greatly improved.
abstract: Report by independent communications consultant Andy Goodman says public service advertising, at least in print form, is not connecting effectively with consumers, and there are ways it could be better; Starch division of RoperASW, part of NOP World Co, conducted survey and provided data for guidelines (M)

headline: Enron's President Resigns Under Creditors' Pressure
abstract: Jeffrey McMahon resigns as president and chief operating officer of Enron Corp under pressure from some of its creditors, who have questioned his role in financing deals that helped hide losses or inflate profits (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Jean Allen was named a partner to head the new corporate and marketing communications practice at Whitehead Mann, New York, an executive recruiter.

headline: Europe Says Art Auction Houses Fixed Prices
abstract: More than a year after American authorities found that Christie's and Sotheby's had joined in an illegal price-fixing cartel, European antitrust officials leveled essentially the same charge.

headline: Cherished, but for What?
abstract: Ellyn Spragins Love & Money column criticizing prenuptial agreements; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Gold Miner Considers Options
abstract: Australia's AurionGold appears prepared to reject Placer Dome's $1.13 billion takeover bid unless it is raised; graph (S)

headline: SBC AND ECHOSTAR AGREE TO SELL EACH OTHER'S SERVICES
abstract: SBC Communications, which sells local telephone service in Midwest and West, and EchoStar Communications, cable TV provider, agree to sell each other's services to compete with cable TV; financial terms undisclosed; SBC will sell EchoStar's Dish network in its 13-state region starting in May; EchoStar will sell SBC's high-speed Internet access (S)

headline: Tickets Don't Win Oscars
abstract: Halle Berry and Denzel Washington starred in films that together grossed only $96 million by time of Oscars, smallest combined total for best actor and actress Academy Award-winning films since 1996 Oscars; table of grosses of best actor and actress award winners; photo (S)

headline: An Unlikely Couturier From an Unlikely 'Paris'
abstract: Profile of Elie Saab, Lebanese fashion designer whose international stature is growing to include Hollywood stars as well as Persian Gulf princesses; photo (M)

headline: Gays in China Step Out, With One Foot in Closet
abstract: Gays in China's cities no longer live completely closeted lives, but most of them shuttle regularly between gay and straight lives; China effectively decriminalized homosexuality only in 1997, and it came off list of mental illnesses just last year; even though it is now possible to live as gay man in China, norm in gay community is to get married, have children, play it straight at work and visit gay nightclubs and other gay establishments at night; emergence of partly closeted, partly liberated, sexually active gay community at same time that AIDS cases are rising quickly in China has created unique challenges; Chinese doctors are just beginning to investigate and deal with AIDS in this poorly defined high-risk group, whose members are sometimes still unclear about their sexuality and frequently have sexual relations with men and women; photos; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Advertising Slipped In 2001
abstract: Interactive Advertising Bureau says Internet advertising revenue in US fell 7.5 percent in fourth quarter of 2001, to $1.7 billion; marketers spent $7.2 billion on Internet advertising for all of 2001, down 12 percent from 2000 (S)

headline: For Company A, War Is Nearly Over but Many G.I.'s See Afghan Mission as Not Quite Completed
abstract: The soldiers from Alpha Company have been in Afghanistan for six months, and can now count on one page of the calendar the days before they go home.

headline: U.S. Urges Sudan to Divide Oil Income as Step to Peace
abstract: John C Danforth, special US envoy to Sudan, recommends that Sudanese government share its oil revenue with rebels as part of effort to end decades-long civil war; rebels of Sudanese People's Liberation Army, which has been fighting for self-rule for southern part of country, have been attacking oil installations; say oil provides money that pays for Islamic government's military campaigns against mostly Christian and animist south (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  Consumer Price Index: March  Housing Construction: March  Industrial Production: March  Capacity Utilization: March    WEDNESDAY  Balance of Trade: Feb.

headline: NATIONSRENT FILES PLAN TO REORGANIZE AND CUT DEBT
abstract: NationsRent Inc, construction equipment rental company that sought bankruptcy protection in December, files recovery plan that would eliminate more than half company's debt (S)

headline: New Economy; Corporate boards are supposed to represent shareholders. Why aren't they more democratic?
abstract: Steve Lohr column discusses issues of corporate democracy raised by Walter B Hewlett in his unsuccessful bid to block Hewlett-Packard's purchase of Compaq Computer; notes experts in corporate governance say chief executives too often choose so-called outside directors who are likely to back them because they themselves are chief executives or do business with company; drawing (M)

headline: Ivy League or Also-Ran? Does It Matter?
abstract: Within the economics profession, there is a vigorous debate over whether highly selective and highly expensive colleges confer any real benefit in later life.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Rates Increased
abstract: Bank of Korea surprises forecasters by raising its benchmark interest rate one-quarter point, to 4.25 percent (S)

headline: Shooting on the Edge; 4 Innovators Rethink Speed, Light, Color and the Studio
abstract: Photographer Doug Menuez uses high-end Epson printer to produce quality photos for use in advertising; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Suggests, Without Proof, Stock Adviser Knew of 9/11
abstract: Asst US Atty Kenneth Breen says Amr Ibrahim Elgindy, San Diego stock adviser accused of bribing FBI agent Jeffrey A Royer to give him confidential government information, may have had prior knowledge of Sept 11 attacks; says Elgindy tried to sell $300,000 in stock on afternoon of Sept 10 and told his broker that stock market would soon plunge; Elgindy lawyer rejects allegation and says it appears to be motivated by fact that Elgindy is Muslim and was born in Egypt; FBI officials also say they have no evidence that Elgindy has prior knowledge of attacks; Breen asks Judge John A Houston to hold Elgindy without bond, calling he poses serious flight risk; Houston disregards Breen's claims about Elgindy and Sept 11; says there is enough other evidence that Elgindy might flee to justify detaining him at least until June 6 hearing to determine whether he should be moved to New York for trial (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of picture caption accompanying April 7 article on executive compensation trends in Japan

headline: Qwest May Take Up to $30 Billion Charge
abstract: Qwest Communications International says it might take charge of $20 billion to $30 billion this year to write down value of assets; Qwest and Securities and Exchange Commission staff members are recommending that agency take action against company for excluding information on costs associated with US West purchase in June 2000 (M)

headline: U.S. to Use World Meeting To Focus on Terror Finances
abstract: Finance ministers from around world, and protesters, gather in Washington for IMF-World Bank meeting to consider proposals for battling terrorism and poverty at time when links between two problems are increasingly clear; US will call for world to do more to crack down on sources of financing for terrorists; Sec Paul O'Neill also predicts 'testy' exchanges on his proposals to funnel more aid to poor countries as outright grants rather than loans (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: President Rejects Talks With U.S.
abstract: Mohammad Khatami, reformist president of Iran, rejects talks with United States and calls on Parliament to submit to policies decided by supreme religious leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei; says talks cannot be considered while US uses 'bellicose and threatening tone' against Iran; photo (S)

headline: Argentina's Fallen Economic Czar Is Held in Arms Deal
abstract: Domingo Cavallo, Argentina's all-powerful minister of economy in 1990's, is arrested in Buenos Aires and detained on suspicion of involvement in 'aggravated contraband'; accusations stem from his supposed role in illegal arms deals attributed to Argentine government in early 1990's; supporters and independent political analysts contend he is being made scapegoat for Argentina's economic crisis, which forced his resignation in Dec and plunged country into economic and political turmoil; Cavallo has been prohibited from leaving country for last month; his imprisonment order caps startling fall from grace for man who was credited with country's rapid growth in 90's; Pres Eduardo Duhalde and his Peronist government have been pressured by street demonstrators to prosecute political and economic leaders blamed for country's economic debacle; Cavallo is especially unpopular for issuing Dec freeze on bank deposits following 66 percent devaluation of Argentine peso; photo (M)

headline: Auto Union and Honda Dispute Safety Record at Plants in Ohio
abstract: United Automobile Workers says injury rates more than doubled average for American auto industry at Honda Motor Co's four factories in central Ohio that make quality cars and motorcycles that are among most profitable in industry; union compiled injury data from federal records and hopes to use information as cornerstone of its campaign to represent Honda's workers; plans public forum on June 26; federal records show there were 23.5 injuries that caused lost workdays for every 100 workers at Honda's two auto assembly plants in Ohio in 2000, more than double auto industry's average rate of 10.5 such injuries per 100 workers; union attributes injuries to Honda's demanding production rates, its widespread use of temporary workers who have less training than permanent employees and absence of independent safety advocates in Honda plants to help injured workers find suitable jobs; Honda says safety logs, which Labor Department requires companies to maintain, unfairly inflate its injury rates because company aggressively reports even minor injuries and does not rush injured workers back to job; adds company's injury rates will be cut in half under new workplace rules imposed by Bush administration this year; Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has recently questioned injured Honda workers as part of inquiry, though it declines to say for what; some workers comment; chart; photos (M)

headline: Yum Brands Expands Role With BBDO
abstract: Yum Brands, formerly Tricon Global Restaurants, expands its relationship with New York office of BBDO Worldwide by awarding agency broadcast creative account of Long John Silver's restaurant chain, which Yum recently acquired; billings estimated at $25 million to $30 million; Fallon Worldwide was previous ad agency (S)

headline: MediaTalk; The Ad's the Thing In a Newspaper Dispute
abstract: Chicago Sun-Times vice president John Cruickshank denies that meeting with theater owners on why theatergoers pay little attention to paper was effort to press them to do more advertising in paper; owners recall meeting after Sun-Times rebuffs interview proposal from publicist for Goodman Theater, which does little advertising in Sun-Times (S)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for ROBERT D. REISCHAUER; Better Medical Decisions, Not Higher Costs
abstract: Interview with Urban Institute president Robert D Reischauer on Supreme Court ruling that states can insist on independent review for patients whose managed care plans refuse to pay for treatment or drug prescribed by doctor; photo (M)

headline: Adelphia Communications Restating Results for Last 3 Years
abstract: Adelphia Communications says it is restating its financial statements for last three years to include on its books over $1 billion in loans that embattled cable company guaranteed to entities controlled by family of chairman John Rigas; also says that because it delayed filing its annual financial report, it has received notices of default on some agreements with lenders and it is in potential default on others; company has obtained waivers to enable it to file report late and still comply with borrowing requirements (M)

headline: Amtrak and Delta conduct intensive campaigns to lure business passengers.
abstract: Delta Air Lines and Amtrak have begun advertising drives to woo business travelers in Northeast corridor, market that has become more competitive with Amtrak's expansion of its high-speed Acela service; Delta's ads stresses speed, including quick check-in; Amtrak's ads cite its expanded schedule and services; photos (M)

headline: Article 2002042091370609690 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology Paper Version         function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                            International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business             Technology           -      E-Business            -      Circuits            -      Columns               Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Pay Guidelines At Vodafone
abstract: Vodafone Group issues new salary guidelines in response to critics who say company is overpaying top executives even as it reports huge losses; Christopher Gent, chief executive, will receive total compensation in line with executives at top quartile of European companies (S)

headline: Fiat and Banks Move Closer To a Financing Agreement
abstract: Fiat appears to be inching toward accord with its major creditor banks on injection of fresh capital as part of plan to curb its losses and reduce debt (M)

headline: Netanyahu Says Powell Mission 'Won't Amount to Anything' and Urges Arafat's Exile
abstract: Former Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, visiting United States at Prime Min Ariel Sharon's request, says Sec Colin L Powell's peace mission will not succeed; says Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat will eventually have to be expelled from West Bank; calls for disarming Palestinians and creating physical border separating Israel from Palestinian-controlled areas; meets with bipartisan groups of senators and congressmen (M)

headline: Ex-Korean Chief's Daughter Rides Nostalgia Wave
abstract: Park Geun Hye, South Korean congresswoman and daughter of late Pres Park Chung Hee, will announce formation of her own political party, with goal of winning presidency herself; her candidacy could split conservative votes, virtually guaranteeing election of Roh Moo Hyun, former human rights lawyer, whom Park dismisses as 'radical'; with voting still eight months away, many analysts are keeping their options open; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Falls
abstract: Ifo economic research institute's index of western German business confidence declined to 91.3 in June from 91.6 in May; index of future expectations for business fell to 104.9 compared with 106.2 in May (S)

headline: Officers May Gain More Than Investor In Move to Bermuda
abstract: Chief executives could be biggest beneficiaries of rush by corporations to incorporate in Bermuda to reduce their American taxes, despite rationale that move is to increase profits to benefit shareholders; could pocket at minimum millions in additional pay, taking home extra income equal to half of company's tax savings or more; government's loss in taxes is chief executive's gain in form of higher pay, bonuses and profits on sale of stock options; each company's Bermuda strategy differs in details, but chief executives always profit because compensation is based partly on profitability of company or stock price; executives who stand to profit include Nabors Industries chief executive Eugene M Eisenberg, whose pay could rise by tens of millions of dollars each year if shareholders approve plan to incorporate in Bermuda and establish legal residence in Barbados; he has made more than $126 million over past two years, mainly because his contract calls for world's largest operator of land-based oil-drilling rigs to pay him 6 percent of its cash flow; photo (M)

headline: Compressed Data; The Weather Service's Voice Is Changing
abstract: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is updating text-reading software that delivers National Weather Service weather advisories over special radios and over Internet; new technology is meant to create more naturalistic voice and add female speaker to lineup; photo (M)

headline: SOME PLAINTIFFS REJECT SULZER SETTLEMENT
abstract: Federal Judge Kathleen O'Malley gives Sulzer Medica another nine days to persuade plaintiffs to accept its $1 billion settlement of lawsuits over defective hip and knee implants after lawyers say too many people opted out; about 100 plaintiffs have dropped out of settlement to pursue their own claims against company (S)

headline: 3 Ex-Chiefs Discover Perils Of Borrowing and Believing
abstract: Analysis of corporate executives John J Rigas of Adelphia Communications, Stephen C Hilbert of Conseco and Bernard J Ebbers of WorldCom Inc, who must repay huge loans and are out of jobs at companies they helped build because they had too much faith that their businesses would keep climbing; entities owned by Rigas family borrowed $2.3 billion from banks with loans guaranteed by Adelphia; some of that money went to buy cable systems, but it appears that most of it was used to buy Adelphia stock for family; WorldCom founder Ebbers was forced to step down last month and has been given five years to repay his loans; WorldCom discloses that he now owes $408.2 million after it consolidated number of loans, some from banks and some from company; Ebbers's stake in company is worth $19.8 million; Hilbert, who built Conseco into large insurance company, allowed loans to be spread more broadly before he was ousted in spring 2000; other senior executives and even outside directors borrowed tens of millions to buy shares whose price has since collapsed; loans came from Bank of America, but were arranged and guaranteed by Conseco, which is paying interest on them; photos (M)

headline: The Power of a Loaded Desktop And a Touchpad With Extras
abstract: Toshiba's new notebook computer offers touchpad that allows user to call up four handy miniprograms--numeric keypad, calculator, notepad and signature; things created on touchpad can be pasted into other programs; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Dictator's Daughter Forms Party
abstract: Park Geun Hye, daughter of Park Chung Hee, former South Korean dictator, is appointed to lead party she has formed, and many analysts expect her to be candidate in December presidential elections (S)

headline: Seeking Trade, Africans Find Western Barriers
abstract: African leaders, along with some of poverty-fighting advocacy groups that for years have viewed globalization with suspicion if not downright hostility, are increasingly embracing international trade as most powerful tool available for creating jobs, steady incomes, hope and political stability; after concentrating for years on winning relief from crippling debt burdens and lobbying for increases in foreign aid payments, African governments are instead starting to demand reduced tariffs and other changes in trade policies from United States and other rich nations to increase sales of local products; photo of Treasury Sec Paul O'Neill, who is traveling through Africa with Bono, musician (M)

headline: Judge Rejects Perelman Deal To End Dispute on Stock Sale
abstract: Delaware Chancery Court Judge Leo Strine rejects settlement that allowed financier Ronald O Perelman to keep money he received when he arranged for one company he controlled to pay him more than four times market price for stock he owned in another company; M&F Worldwide, controlled by Perelman, paid $17 per share in cash and stock to Perelman for his 83 percent stake in Panavision; Panavision shares traded for $3.95 each just before deal was completed in April 2001; settlement, reached in February, was denounced by some shareholders as inadequate (M)

headline: UBS and Malaysian Utility In Costly Dispute on Bonds
abstract: Tangled closed-door legal dispute over UBS Warburg's decision to help Malaysian utility Tenga Nasional Berhad sell $800 million in bonds in 1997 threatens to cost both companies lot of money; at center of dispute is contention by UBS that Tenaga, which is 78 percent owned by Malaysian government, reneged on little-understood term of deal that gave UBS right to refinance bond deal if rates on US Treasuries fell; UBS sued Tenaga in London early this year, but case attracted no attention until now, when Tenaga issued statement denying any liability and saying that it had countersued in early May; dispute threatens to tarnish UBS Warburg's ability to win new business in Malaysia and Tenaga's standing in international debt markets, raising its borrowing costs (M)

headline: PUBLIC SERVICE ENTERPRISE TO BUY TWO POWER STATIONS
abstract: Public Service Enterprise Group, owner of New Jersey's largest utility, agrees to buy two power stations in Bridgeport and New Haven, Conn, from Wisvest Corp for $220 million; Public Service's generating unit PSEG Power will finance acquisition (S)

headline: Return of the Suit, Tentatively; Some Men Are Dressing Up Again, but Casual Still Lives
abstract: Men are buying more tailored clothing and suits but market research shows that in dollar terms, sales are continuing to decline; men are not investing heavily in expensive new wardrobe; not only are suits less expensive, but early data suggest that men may be trying to take formal edge off their tailored pants and jackets by pairing them with relaxed accessories; photo (M)

headline: With a Word, Israeli-Turkish Strain Surfaces
abstract: Turkish Prime Min Bulent Ecevit's charge that Israeli military raids in West Bank constitute 'genocide' strains usually good relationship that is strategically important to both countries and to US (S)

headline: F.B.I. Is Investigating Kmart For Possible Criminal Violations
abstract: FBI, working with US attorney in Detroit, says it is examining Kmart Corp's records to determine whether any of company's activities warrant criminal charges; US Attorney Jeffrey G Collins says his office is conducting investigation into accounting practices at Kmart (M)

headline: Milosevic Ally Shoots Himself Over Law on Hague Suspects
abstract: Former aide to Slobodan Milosevic, Vlajko Stojiljkovic, shoots himself outside Parliament in Belgrade in defiant protest against law passed hours earlier clearing way for him and other war crimes suspects to be sent to The Hague to stand trial at international tribunal there; he is in critical condition in hospital; he leaves note blaming his 'death' on Pres Vojislav Kostunica, among others; his action is expected to harden public opinion against tribunal in Hague and contentious handing over of suspects for trial; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Irish Guerrillas Sentenced
abstract: London court sentences Declan Rafferty, Fintan O'Farrell and Michael MacDonald, members of renegade Real IRA, to 30 years in jail for trying to buy arms in Slovakia for their program of terror aimed at bringing down Northern Ireland peace plan (S)

headline: F.D.A. Backs Cancer Drug
abstract: Genentech and OSI Pharmaceuticals says Food and Drug Administration has designated cancer treatment Tarceva as fast-track product to expedite its review (S)

headline: BUSINESS TRAVEL: MEMO PAD
abstract: Business Travel Coalition annual survey shows more companies than ever are buying cheaper advance-purchase nonrefundable tickets for business travel, trend that terrifies major airlines (M)

headline: At J.P. Morgan, 2 Contenders Are Relying On Turnaround
abstract: Ability of J P Morgan Chase to recover from string of recent losses rests largely in hands of Geoffrey T Boisi, co-head of J P Morgan's investment bank, and David A Coulter, who runs consumer bussiness, who are looking to restore battered reputations and may be considered for top job someday; Boisi and Coulter run businesses that account for 85 percent of J P Morgan Chase's operting revenue in first quarter; bank has been struggling with lackluster performance since J P Morgan and Chase Manhattan merged at end of 2000; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Peace Talks With Rebels
abstract: Sudanese and rebel leaders gather in Kenya to begin five weeks of talks aimed at ending 18-year civil war; both sides aver commitment to peace (S)

headline: CONAGRA FOODS SAYS QUARTERLY EARNINGS INCREASED 58%
abstract: ConAgra Foods says fourth-quarter earnings rose 58 percent; net income was $192 million, up from $121 million from year earlier; revenue dipped to $6.41 billion from $6.43 billion (S)

headline: Smaller Turnout for Tiananmen Memorial
abstract: The annual candlelight vigil here to remember the protesters killed by the Chinese military in Beijing's Tiananmen Square drew a sparser crowd than usual tonight.

headline: BUNGE IN TALKS TO BUY CEREOL, A FOOD OIL COMPANY
abstract: Bunge Ltd is in exclusive talks to buy control of French food oil company Cereol SA to increase its share of European soybean mqrket; negotiations cover purchase of 55 percent stake in Cereol held by Edison SpA (S)

headline: Sinn Fein Says No to Congressional Probe on Colombia
abstract: Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, turned down a request to testify in Washington on connections between the I.R.A. and Colombian rebels.

headline: Vatican Aims Sharp Rebuke At 'Reprisals' By Israelis
abstract: Vatican sharply criticizes Israel for imposing 'unjust and humiliating conditions' on Palestinians and also condemns all acts of terrorism in Middle East; calls on two sides to respect holy places in Bethlehem, which is under Israeli military occupation; senior Vatican official meets with Israeli and United States ambassadors to Holy See, and summons Arab League's representative for meeting; latest statement from Vatican seems to single out Israel for condemnation; analysts say Vatican is in difficult position with expansion of street fighting into Bethlehem, where Palestinian gunmen and Christian monks and nuns have reportedly been trapped inside Church of the Nativity (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Tobacco Sales Fall
abstract: British American Tobacco says sales volume in early months of 2002 is 'a little below expectations,' leading to drop of 2 percent to 3 percent; chairman Martin Broughton comments; photo (S)

headline: Ex-Andersen Partner Says He Knew Data Would Be Destroyed
abstract: David B Duncan, former Arthur Andersen partner who pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice, testifies at Andersen's criminal trial that he instructed employees last fall to follow Andersen's document retention policies, knowing that move would result in destruction of records related to Enron; Duncan is government's main witness in its obstruction case against firm; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Stable Economic Growth
abstract: Philippine economy expanded 3.8 percent in first quarter of year compared with first quarter of 2001; graph (S)

headline: DELAY IN PSORIASIS DRUG HURTS XOMA AND GENENTECH
abstract: Xoma and Genentech shares fall after companies delay bid for approval of experimental psoriasis drug Xanelim after study fails to show they can make consistent batches of drug; setback leaves companies behind Biogen, which filed application for competing drug in Aug (S)

headline: Article 2002042190217584880 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //              JOB POSITIONS

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ATLANTIC BAKING GROUP INC., Oakbrook, Ill., a maker of store-brand cookies and crackers, said it would buy the Bake-Line Products unit from Kellogg Co., Battle Creek, Mich., the maker of Frosted Flakes and Eggo waffles, and purchase four bakeries from Consolidated Biscuit Co., McComb, Ohio, a baker of cookies and snacks, to add customers and snack products. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Echo Of The Cold War
abstract: Three former East German border guards go on trial for attempted murder in near-fatal shooting of 14-year-old boy in 1962 as he tried to flee to West Germany; dozens of former border guards have been tried on similar charges since fall of Berlin wall in 1989 (S)

headline: Enron Is Seen Having Link With Global
abstract: Executives and traders involved in deal say Enron and Global Crossing used complex swap of fiber optic network capacity and services brokered by Reliant Resources to sidestep accounting rules in Mar 2001 deal; deal helped disguise what was essentially exchange of long-term services and $17 million loan to Global Crossing by Enron; let each company book revenue; sheds light on way two companies operated in formerly frenetic market for trading high-speed communications capacity, market allegedly fraught until recently with so-called roundtrip deals conducted merely to inflate parties' reported revenue and help drive up their stock prices (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Gasoline Price Investigation
abstract: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission raids offices of Caltex Australia, Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Exxon Mobil Corp to search for evidence of price collusion at gasoline stations across Australia; motorists' organizations complained about gasoline price increases around Easter; commission's chairman Allan Fels comments; photo (S)

headline: With Burn-On CD Labels, No Need to Scrawl-and-Stick
abstract: Yamaha's new CD burner allows user to burn title and track list directly onto CD, eliminating need for stick-on labels; photo (M)

headline: Bally, Unilever and Free Product Add Up to a Sampling Campaign
abstract: Through a deal with Unilever, the packaged goods maker, Bally Total Fitness will hand out samples of Dove Body Refreshers as women enter the gym.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Caterer Lowers Outlook
abstract: È

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Opposition Names Candidate
abstract: South Korea's Grand National Party leader Lee Joi Chang wins party's presidential nomination; will face Millennium Democratic Party candidate Noh Muu Hyun, who leads in polls but has been slipping as scandals rock government (S)

headline: Vivendi's Chief Forces Out Its Pay Television Director
abstract: Jean-Marie Messier, chief executive of Vivendi Universal, fires Pierre Lescure, popular director of French pay television unit, Canal Plus, as investor pressure mounts for Messier to shore up Vivendi's depressed share price (M)

headline: Network Formed for Health Accounts
abstract: Network Formed For Health Accounts.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: U.N. Envoy Returns
abstract: Special United Nations envoy Razali Ismail returns to Myanmar for seventh time in 18 months, hoping to nudge forward confidence-building talks between military government and opposition leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, who remains under house arrest (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Federal Reserve Votes To Hold Rates Steady  Faced with corporate scandals, skittish financial markets and an economic recovery that has little traction so far, the Federal Reserve has decided to hold interest rates steady, saying it was not yet clear how soon the outlook would improve.    As it has all year, the Fed said it expected the economy to pick up, and it hinted again that it planned to raise rates eventually. But it acknowledged that the rebound appears to have lost some momentum. [Page C11.]

headline: West Wayne Buys Breathe Interactive
abstract: West Wayne acquires Breathe Interactive, direct and interactive marketing agency with billings estimated at $2 million to $3 million; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: No Cease-Fire Until Withdrawal, Arafat Tells Powell
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell meets with Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat in largely destroyed headquarters in Ramallah, Arafat's first meeting with top American official since Israel declared him irrelevant months ago; Arafat tells Powell no cease-fire is possible until Israel ends military operation in West Bank and withdraws from cities and towns it rcently occupied; Powell reportedly delivers blunt message, warning Arafat of need to make changes in interests of peace; later meets with Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon, who proposes international summit on Middle East along lines of 1991 Madrid conference but without participation of Arafat; presses Pres Bush's request for full Israeli withdrawal; photos; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Industrial Output Rises
abstract: Malaysian industrial production rose 2.9 percent in February compared with year earlier (S)

headline: In Pakistan, U.S. Embraces Friend of a Foe
abstract: South Asia highlights just how murky world of friends and enemies has become since Sept 11; Bush administration has embraced Pakistan as one of its most important allies in campaign against terror, even though it is widely believed that Pakistan obtained most of its present missile ability directly from North Korea, part of Pres Bush's 'axis of evil'; experts say Pakistan has also cooperated closely on its nuclear and missile programs with Iran and Syria, countries Bush administration says could put weapons of mass destruction in hands of terrorists (M)

headline: WHAT THEY'RE READING
abstract: Pamela Forbes Lieberman, 48  Chief executive, Truserv, a wholesale hardware cooperative    BOOK -- ''Primal Leadership: Realizing the Power of Emotional Intelligence'' by Daniel Goleman, Richard E. Boyatzis and Annie McKee (2002)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: IRELAND: Strike Grounds Airline; GERMANY: Setback For Mobilcom Executive; BRITAIN: No Upturn For Aircraft Engines; ITALY: Insurer Acquires Rival; Data Rule Arouses Concern; RUSSIA: Low Price Hurts Oil Concern.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Telecom Profit Rises
abstract: Telefonica Moviles announces 85 percent rise in first-quarter net profit, to 287 million euros ($262 million) on pro forma basis; revenue rose 16.6 percent, to 2.26 billion euros, while earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization rose 22 percent, to 916.6 million euros; operating costs were steady at 61 percent of revenue; graph (S)

headline: DECLINING SALES AT KMART TAKE TOLL ON FOOTSTAR PROFIT
abstract: Footstar, owner of Just for Feet and Footaction chains, says second-quarter profit will be unchanged or less than year earlier because of declining sales at its shoe departments in Kmart stores (S)

headline: Given $300,000, Abductors Refuse to Free 2 Americans
abstract: Philippine and American officials say Abu Sayyaf, Muslim extremist group that is holding two Americans hostage in southern Philippines, refuses to hand them over after being paid $300,000 ransom, and has demanded another $200,000; original ransom money was raised and paid by families of hostages, Martin and Gracia Burnham, with acquiescence of Bush administration; Philippine soldiers and American Special Forces are conducting exercises on island of Basilan, where Burnhams are last known to be held, and Philippine officials now say that military activity may have impeded Burnhams' release (M)

headline: Kashmiri Impelled to Lead by His Father's Death
abstract: Profile of Umar Farooq, Kashmiri Muslim political and spiritual leader, who seeks political settlement of Kashmir crisis; assumed roles from father, assasinated in 1990, and moderate separatist leader Abdul Ghani Lone, assassinated this May; is possible target of Kashmiri militants backed by Pakistani intelligence agency, who favor violent route to independence; Indian government, unwilling to negotiate Kashmir's status, will not talk to him; photo (M)

headline: Investing; Retailers Struggle To Thrive In Toyland
abstract: retailers stru
