headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Micron Shares Drop After Loss Is Posted
abstract: Shares of Micron Technology Inc drop 75 cents, to $19, after it says it will record loss for third quarter (S)

headline: TV's Future: Wide, Thin And Bright
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on new generation of wide-screen television sets by Sharp, Samsung and Panasonic; liquid crystal display flat panel offers much brighter picture and is cheaper to run; difference between plasma and LCD explained; sets are expensive, in range of $7,000; drawing, photos (M)

headline: Korongo Journal; Amid War, 4-Legged Cash and Dreams of Tourism
abstract: Residents of southern Sudan are adopting new ways of doing business, forced by 20 years of civil war that has devastated economy and left country without banking system or currency; goats are currency of choice in money-scarce Korongo, remote village in Nuba Mountains; map; photo (M)

headline: Article 2002042491275589741 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                      International           -      Africa            -      Americas            -    Asia Pacific          -      Europe            -      Middle East               National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business              Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: MAKER OF DISPOSABLE PLATES AND CUPS TAKES GREEN TURN
abstract: MaØ

headline: Defying Crackdown, North Koreans Stream Into China
abstract: Many of 100,000 North Koreans living illegally in China hope to get to South Korea; in last 10 weeks, 38 of them won political asylum in South Korea by jumping over walls or pushing through gates at embassies and consulates in Beijing; four more are now in South Korean Consulate as their passage out is being negotiated; such successes have turned walls of embassies in Beijing into new boundary between divided Koreas; South Korea offers arrivals from North nearly $30,000 in resettlement aid; experts on North Korea predict that desperate dashes will increase, but many people who work with refugees worry that news-making asylum ploys may actually increase harassment for North Koreans who remain illegally in China; photos (M)

headline: Chicago Stadium Ruling
abstract: A Cook County Circuit Court Judge John Madden rejects lawsuit that tried to block Chicago Park District's $606 million redevelopment of Soldier Field stadium used by Chicago Bears; suit questioned legality of using public money and land to benefit team; suit was filed by Landmarks Preservation Council of Illinois and Friends of the Parks (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Settles S.E.C. Charges
abstract: Microsoft Corp settles Securities and Exchange Commission charges that it filed false financial reports stemming from its improper use of up to $900 million in reserves; is not fined; agrees to be subject to stiffer penalties if it commits similar violations in future (M)

headline: Iranian Journalist Gets 8-Year Term
abstract: Iran's hard-line judiciary has sentenced a journalist to eight years in prison, a newspaper report said on Saturday.

headline: In Santa Barbara
abstract: Travel article on Santa Barbara, Calif; highlights noted; photo (M)

headline: Artisanal roots nurture industry built on integration : It all starts with the best textiles
abstract: MILAN—  Highly fragmented, intensely specialized and still largely owned by the same families that started the businesses, Italy's textiles industry remains the most important component in fashion worldwide, supplying top designers with quality materials. But its continuing success may depend on whether it can resist the modern business mantra that says market economics, consolidation and vertical integration are essential to survive in a global marketplace.

headline: Deleting Snapshots, Not Your Air Supply
abstract: Pioneer Research introduces two underwater digital cameras that offer quick-delete capability; photo (M)

headline: With the World Band in Your Hands
abstract: Article on improvements in shortwave radio; includes explanation of how it operates and factors that can affect transmission; test results of models by Grundig, Sony and Sangean noted; photos (M)

headline: Criticism of Ads Spur Their Withdrawal
abstract: Subaru of America drops television commercial for its sport-utility vehicle that showed rabbit being released from captivity after some animal-rights groups complain rabbit is domestic creature that would die in wild; Ikea North America withdraws humorous newspaper ad promoting sale at two Southern California stores that showed two female prison inmates after gay rights groups complain ad reinforces 'harmful stereotypes' (M)

headline: Arafat Condemns Terror; Powell Meeting On
abstract: Sec Colin Powell says he will meet with Yasir Arafat, after Palestinian leader issues statement condemning terrorist acts against civilians and 'especially' suicide bombing that killed six people in Jerusalem; Arafat's statement, demanded by White House as condition for Powell meeting, also rails at length against Israel; Powell to see Arafat in Ramallah compound where he has been sealed up with about 100 other people by Israeli troops; suicide bomber, identified as Andaleeb Taqtaqah, blew herself up outside Mahane Yehuda market in Jerusalem; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Court Sides With Government On Oil
abstract: Nigeria's Supreme Court rules off

headline: Israel Pursues Military Actions as Powell Prepares to Leave
abstract: As Secretary of State Colin L. Powell prepared to end his peace mission, Ariel Sharon made clear that the Israeli dragnet through the West Bank was not over.

headline: Hailing an Old Cry, 'Viva Cuba Libre!'
abstract: Pres Bush's visit to Miami and vow not to lift economic sanctions against Cuba adds weight to political clout of city's Cuban-American residents; some comment; photo (M)

headline: Afghan Cabinet Sworn In Despite a Few Ill Omens
abstract: Pres Hamid Karzai swears in new Afghan cabinet in Kabul with show of unity, despite continued rumblings of dissatisfaction and intimidation; makeup of cabinet, whose 29 members were chosen with laborious attention to representing each of powerful regional and ethnic groups, described; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Congress Defies President
abstract: Argentina's lower house of Congress votes against modifying 'economic subversion' law; International Monetary Fund has made revisions condition for resumption of aid; Pres Eduardo Duhalde threatens to resign unless Congress acts on amendment he submitted (S)

headline: U.S. to Push Harder for Political Solution in Mideast
abstract: Bush administration promises quicker and deeper involvement in searching for political solution in Mideast after intense but contradictory domestic and international pressure for United States to become more engaged; Secretary of State Colin L Powell says for first time that Prime Min Ariel Sharon's campaign against Palestinian Authority should not be open-ended; says his mind is open to meeting next week with those involved in conflict, during his visit to Germany and Spain; until now White House has always deflected questions about sending Powell or any high-level official to work face to face on problem rather than over telephone; Bush administration has steadfastly maintained position that violence must diminish first before first steps toward political negotiations; now Powell says negotiation and political process may have to come first to end violence; Europeans and Arab states have been pressing Pres Bush to give Yasir Arafat incentives to call halt in Palestinian suicide bombings, while many conservatives in America are arguing just the opposite; they want Bush to help Sharon crush Arafat and terrorist groups allied with him; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Fired Before He Could Quit
abstract: Prime Minister Costas Simitis fired Health Minister Alekos Papadopoulos, who said he was planning to leave politics. The statement by Mr. Papadopoulos, one of the Socialist government's most popular members, added to growing disarray in the party and fueled accusations by the opposition that Mr. Simitis is losing hold of his cabinet.   Anthee Carassava (NYT)

headline: Article 2002042093797647450 -- No Title

headline: Verizon Wireless Sues U.S. Over Licenses
abstract: Verizon Wireless Inc sues Federal Communications Commission in effort to cancel $8.7 billion agreement to buy wireless licenses; seeks return of remaining $261 milion of $1.7 billion down payment for licenses and compensation for lost interest while FCC held money; says it may be owed more than $100 million in interest (S)

headline: Private Sector; A Glass Ceiling That Can't Be Missed
abstract: Maurice R Greenberg, introducing his choice of possible successors at American International Group, defends all-male cast; holds that company has fair share of female executives, but that woman would not get same respect routinely accorded male chiefs in some of nations where company operates; photo (S)

headline: PrivateSector; At Nike, Function Over Fashion
abstract: at nike, function over fash

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Interest In Oil Field
abstract: Norway's Statoil will bid to be partner with Venezuela's state oil company in offshore natural gas project that would entail its investing up to $3 billion; Statoil is interested in investing in Deltana Platform project in Caribbean Sea; field is between Venezuela and Trinidad and Tobago (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Military Bills Advance
abstract: Japanese cabinet approves measures to strenghten role of military in national defense, giving government more freedom to respond to threats and national emergencies (S)

headline: $10 Billion Pledged to Ex-Soviets to Dispose of Unconventional Arms
abstract: Japan, Canada and European members of Group of 8 agree at summit meeting in Canada to spend $10 billion over next decade to help Russia and other former Soviet states dispose of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons (S)

headline: CUMMINS SHARES DROP ON GENERATOR SALES CONCERNS
abstract: Shares of Cummins Inc fall 4.5 percent on concern that demand for power generators and truck engines will be lower than expected; Cummins is largest maker of heavy-duty diesel engines (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Ruling In Killing By Colonel
abstract: Military psychiatrists find Col Yuri Budanov suffered from shell shock and shrapnel wounds to head and was insane at time he strangled Chechen woman, 18, he says he suspected was sniper; officials say he will probably be freed and given medical treatment (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   7.00       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   3.50       Federal funds   1.81   1.80   3.50       3-month T-bills   1.70   1.72   4.14       6-month T-bills   1.85   1.85   3.56       10-yr. headline: Early Verdict on Audit: Procedures Ignored
abstract: Analysis of breakdown of internal procedures at Arthur Andersen revealed at firm's trial on obstruction of justice charges involving Enron; breakdown apparently fostered atmosphere of recklessness among some of its accountants that played big part in Enron's collapse (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: HONG KONG: Bank Posts Loss; SINGAPORE: Economy Surges;.

headline: Investing; Do Fund Directors Buy In? The Answers Are Mixed
abstract: Article on new rule instituted by Securities and Exchange Commission requiring mutual fund companies to disclose whether their independent directors are investing money in funds they oversee (M)

headline: HOLDER FILES SUIT TO BLOCK NABORS MOVE TO BERMUDA
abstract: Nabors Industries says shareholder Steven Rosenberg has sued to block company's plan to move its headquarters to Bermuda; suit also seeks monetary damages (S)

headline: In These Convertibles, a Smoother Route to Stocks
abstract: Investing in mutual funds that specialize in convertible securities discussed; convertibles offer some of profits possible in stock market and some of income cushion of bonds; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Opposition To Hynix Purchase
abstract: Union and group of minority shareholders at Hynix Semiconductor say they will fight sale of company's memory chip operations to Micron Technology; shareholders say $4 billion price is too low, and union says that if deal is approved it will call general strike (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Aiming For The Moon
abstract: Report in China Daily says China aims to put man into Earth orbit by 2005 and place astronauts on moon by 2010 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Request To Save Children Ignored
abstract: World Food Program has not received response to urgent appeal to finance nutritional programs in Guatemala, where drought has left 60,000 children under age 5 facing chronic malnutrition (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: South KOREA: Hynix Names Executive.

headline: Cross Media Unit Faces Complaint From the F.T.C.
abstract: Federal Trade Commission files complaint accusing Cross Media Marketing Corp's magazine unit of violating telemarketing rules; says company withheld some information, misrepresented subscription lengths and prices, and billed customers for magazines they did not order or canceled (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Siemens Cuts Jobs
abstract: German electronics and engineering group Siemens will cut 2,000 jobs and sell nonprofitable activities of its industrial services unit, affecting another 5,000 jobs (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: NTL Suspends A Payment
abstract: British cable company NTL suspends $96 million in interest payments due April 1 at request of unofficial committee representing half face value of company's outstanding publicly traded bonds (S)

headline: Banff Memo; In Canada, World's Most Exclusive Summer Camp
abstract: Remoteness of Kananaskis Village, Alberta, keeps antiglobalism demonstrators from bothering Group of Eight meeting; reporters are also kept at bay, and insiders briefing them on meeting liken atmosphere at Delta Lodge to summer camp; photos; map (M)

headline: Losses in Argentina Reduce Citigroup's Earnings
abstract: Citigroup reports first-quarter earnings that fall short of analysts' estimates, in large part because of greater-than-expected losses in Argentina; posts net income of $4.8 billion, up 37 percent from $3.54 billion year earlier; company earned $3.86 billion; results were hurt by $816 million pretax charge related to its corporate and consumer businesses in Argentina; chairman-chief executive Sanford I Weill comments; Bank of America earned $2.18 billion in first quarter, compared with $1.87 billion year earlier; graph; photo (M)

headline: Boeing Meets With Unions On Contract
abstract: Boeing managers, including commercial-airplanes chief Alan Mulally, begin meeting early with company's two largest unions to prepare for contract talks with machinists and engineers (M)

headline: Despite Violence, Settlers Survive and Spread
abstract: Numbers of Israeli settlers on West Bank continue growing despite escalating violence of past 18 months; many continue building homes in middle of Palestinian Hebron and in rocky West Bank hills to pursue vision that blends nationalism, messianism and yearning for good life on what they regard as biblical birthright but what Palestinians dream will be their national home; most Israelis say settlements are not obstacle to peace; identify with settlers, who consider themselves embattled pioneers on behalf of all Jews; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: AFGHANISTAN: Heroin Flow Continues; TURKMENISTAN: Villas For The Needy; INDIA: Killer Elephant Slain After Chase;.

headline: Lenders Are Said to Shut Off Crucial Source of Financing
abstract: Bankers say WorldCom will longer be able to raise money in anticipation of payments from its customers because it is in violation of terms of financing arranged in May; WorldCom raised $1.5 billion in May in financing backed by anticipated customer payments, known as receivables; WorldCom's lenders organize committee of nine banks led by Citigroup and Deutsche Bank; banks will then decide what information to request from WorldCom to consider additional lending to company (M)

headline: 2 Companies Settle Competition Complaint on Hypertension Drug
abstract: Federal Trade Commission reaches settlement with generic drug makers Biovail Corp and Elan Corp, which it accusesyof using licensing agreement to prevent competition and to keep prices higher for nifedipine, generic hypertension drug; settlement is first case of FTC's taking anticompetitive action against two generic drug makers (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Nazi-Era Case Postponed
abstract: Special Supreme Court tribunal in Athens defers ruling on whether it has jurisdiction to try class-action suit by about 60,000 Greeks demanding compensation from Germany for Nazi atrocities in more than 60 Greek villages between 1941 and 1944 (S)

headline: UBS Quarterly Income Falls, But Results Beat Expectations
abstract: UBS says net income fell to $852 million in first three months of 2002, down 14 percent from comparable period year ago (M)

headline: Accountants Are in Demand. Go Figure.
abstract: Job market is tigú

headline: Milosevic Aide Surrenders to War Crimes Tribunal
abstract: Nikola Sainovic, former top aide of Slobodan Milosevic, surrenders to United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague; Sainovic, former deputy prime minister, was indicted along with Milosevic on charges of war crimes committed in Kosovo in 1999; another suspect Momcilo Gruban, Bosnian Serb, also turns himself in; was indicted on charges of committing atrocities at notorious Omarska prison camp; 23 fugitives have been pressed to surrender since Parliament in Belgrade adopted law requiring government cooperation with tribunal (M)

headline: Deal Seen Near To End Impasse In Church Siege
abstract: Palestinian and Israeli officials seeking to end 35-day Israeli siege of Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem report agreement on framework to end impasse; progress follows day of diplomatic maneuvering, in which Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon traveled to Washington to meet with Pres Bush and Egypt's Foreign Min Ahmed Maher visited Yasir Arafat at headquarters in Ramallah in show of solidarity; agreement reportedly calls for dozen Palestinian men Israel considers terrorists to be sent to exile in Italy; as many as 35 others would be removed to Gaza Strip, and rest would go free; Israel would, in turn, withdraw forces; settlement would represent significant compromise by Arafat, who has fiercely resisted notion of exile for any of besieged men; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft and Verizon in D.S.L. Deal
abstract: Verizon Communications says it will begin using Microsoft Corp's content, software and marketing software for its high-speed DSL Internet service and will pay Microsoft's portion of revenue; Microsoft says it offers DSL version of its MSN online service in 70 markets nationwide, representing 90 percent of households that can get DSL service; MSN is buying wholesale DSL access from BellSouth, SBC Communications and Verizon and reselling them with MSN content and software (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Cellphone Subsidies Hurt Vodafone
abstract: Japanese unit of Vodafone Group, J-Phone, starts providing subsidies to retailers for its wireless handsets, reversing earlier pledge to parent company that it would increase profits by reducing subsidies; action sets off sharp decline in Vodafone's share price; stock price graph (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Paper Sues a Web Site Over the Way It Links
abstract: Avi S Adelman, who writes about local Dallas issues on his Web site, rejects bid by Dallas Daily News owner that he remove links to articles within newspaper's Web site and link only to its home page, as specified in site's terms of use; holds site should use software to block incoming links, or accept that being linked is part of being online (S)

headline: Stream Fishing: A Guide to Net Radio
abstract: Internet radio stations work by compressing files to computer in process called streaming; many conventional radio stations are available online, and there are numerous Internet-only stations that cater to specific tastes; some simply provide steady stream of music, while others, usually for annual subscription fee, can be customized; photo (M)

headline: A Greeting Steals Its Way Into Your Hard Drive
abstract: Users of Microsoft's popular Outlook e-mail program are targets of new computer virus, made by new-media artist Mark Daggett, that arrives disguised as electronic greeting card; virus spreads by randomly picking three images from recipient's hard drive and sending them to everyone in victim's Outlook address book; Daggett says program is not true virus because recipients must actively agree to reveal computers' contents; photo (M)

headline: Collection Chronicles A Digital Revolution
abstract: Article discusses Web site devoted to digital camera's place in photographic history; site is developed and maintained by Rodger L Carter; photo (M)

headline: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS AGREES TO BUY GAIN TECHNOLOGY
abstract: Standard Microsystems Corp, maker of integrated circuits, agrees to buy Gain Technology Corp for $34 million in cash and stock to increase sales of circuits to semiconductor companies (S)

abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                      International           -    Africa          -      Americas            -      Asia Pacific            -      Europe            -      Middle East               National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business              Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: Afghan Warlord Muddles Interim Government's Plans
abstract: Afghan warlord Padsha Khan Zadran, still controls large parts of Khost and Pakita Province despite efforts of interim government of Hamid Karzai to oust him; situation has become most glaring example of government's inability to control events outside capital of Kabul; photo (M)

headline: Harvard Team Ranks First In Telling AOL What to Do
abstract: Harvard University students Diane Bourne, Tjada P D'Oyen, Sitella A Glenn and Panya Lei Yarber win $20,000 in Goldman, Sachs & Co-sponsored contest that asked students to examine challenges facing AOL Time Warner and to devise strategy for Richard D Parsons, who is to become chief executive next month (M)

headline: BP Adds to Stake in Russia, Despite Earlier Legal Battle
abstract: BP increases its stake in Russian oil company Sidanko to 25 percent from 10 percent; deal comes little more than two years after BP came close to scrapping its investment in Sidanco altogether during drawn-out legal battle over oil assets with two Russian companies that are now its partners in Sidanko; BP pays $375 million for 15 percent plus one share of Sidanko; transaction leaves BP's local partners, Alfa Group and Access/Renova with reduced, but still majority, stake (M)

headline: NSB HOLDING IS BUYING LIBERTY BANCORP FOR $34.5 MILLION
abstract: NSB Holding Corp is acquiring Liberty Bancorp for about $34.5 million in cash (S)

headline: France Announces Cabinet With a New Security Post
abstract: French Pres Jacques Chirac, under pressure to show results before crucial legislative elections, appoints conservative interim cabinet led by Jean-Pierre Raffarin as prime minister; Francis Mer, chairman of Arcelor steel giant, is unconventional choice for finance minister; conservative hard-liner Nicolas Sarkozy is named to new security ministry; Raffarin is low-key leader of regional council and outsider to Paris political establishment (M)

headline: COURT DISMISSES SOME CROWN CORK ASBESTOS CASES
abstract: Crown Cork and Seal Co says Pennsylvania court has dismissed 376 pending asbestos cases against company related to 1963 acquisition of Mundet Cork Co (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Andersen Verdict Offers Clues for Enron Inquiry  Evidence at the Arthur Andersen trial appears to indicate that a decision promoted by Andrew S. Fastow, Enron's former chief financial officer, was crucial in its downfall. Investigators are exploring the matter, as crucial facts in Enron's collapse continue to emerge.     The jury's Andersen verdict turned solely on the work of Nancy Temple, a lawyer who told a friend that she was taking a job at the accounting firm as a way to get a ''balanced life.'' [Section A.]

headline: Thumbs Down
abstract: Short messaging service, rudimentary form of text messaging available in United States since 1998, has been adopted by fewer than 13 million of nation's 132.8 million wireless phone subscribers; systems used by major wireless carriers have not been compatible until recently; graph; photo (S)

headline: Family-friendly TV, with crucial support of advertisers, wins more time in prime time.
abstract: Family Friendly Programming Forum, consortium of advertisers that funnels seed money to help develop family-oriented television programming, has five shows slated for broadcast networks' coming prime-time schedules; strong showing for consortium-endorsed shows comes as networks are increasingly embracing fare family can watch together; over 20 fall shows seek to appeal to multigenerational audiences; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   8.00       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   4.50       Federal funds   1.75   1.84   4.99       3-month T-bills   1.69   1.68   4.01       6-month T-bills   1.91   1.90   4.00       10-yr. T-infl.   3.13   3.13   3.42       10-yr. T-note   5.19   5.13   5.21       30-yr. T-bond   5.66   5.62   5.66       Telephone bd.   7.78   7.77   7.90       Municipal bds.   5.33   5.34   5.39        (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Article 2002042190905574322 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Job Market Text Version         function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                            International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business              Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: You Kidding Me? How Global Crossing Pursued Tony Soprano
abstract: Current and former Global Crossing employees say company chairman Gary Winnick favored proposed adverting drive that would have used James Gandolfini, actor who plays Mafia leader on Sopranos television series, as tough-speaking company spokesman; Gandolfini aide says he discussed deal but lacked interest; company abandoned effort in face of financial and other woes (M)

headline: In Chicago, a Case of Football vs. Aesthetics
abstract: Plan to renovate Soldier Field by constructing new seating bowl that would accommodate 123 new sky boxes and 8,500 premium 'club' seats has drawn criticism from architects and preservationists and has also led to lawsuit by two civic groups determined to halt $606 million project; lawsuit, which was filed in August by Friends of the Parks and Landmarks Preservation Council of Illinois, questions legality of using public money for benefit of private company, in this case Chicago Bears, which has been primary tenant of stadium since 1971; stadium is owned by Chicago Park District, city agency; Cook County Circuit Court Judge John Madden will hear case on April 25 and is expected to issue ruling shortly thereafter; renovation plan was devised by Lohan Caprile Goettsch and Wood & Zapata; photo (M)

headline: Bush's California Energy Stance Faulted
abstract: Pres Bush and Vice Pres Dick Cheney strongly opposed any government intervention or price controls intended to rein in surging costs of electricity throughout California's energy crisis early last year; Gov Gray Davis and Sen Dianne Feinstein react with anger at release of documents showing that Enron Corp traders used questionable strategies intended to increase company's profits from trading power in state; Davis and Feinstein criticize what they say was Bush administration's failure to heed their suspicions that more than just market forces were to blame for enormous price increases in wholesale electricity in state; they had suspected market manipulation as cause of soaring wholesale power prices that pushed PG&E into bankruptcy and drove Edison International to brink; White House spokeswoman Claire Buchan says Bush had called last May for Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and Federal Trade Commission to be vigilant; White House releases excerpts of comments made by Bush and other administration officials last spring about White House's commitment to investigate illegal price-gouging (M)

headline: Arrests of Teens in Fatal Fire Stirs Internet Debate in China
abstract: There is a growing debate in China about the allegedly harmful effects of youthful addiction to Internet games and cyber cafes.

headline: As Troubles Mount, Chief Quits At Canadian Telecom Giant
abstract: Jean C. Monty resigned today as chairman and chief executive of BCE, Canada's dominant telecommunications company.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Samsung's Profit Soars
abstract: Samsung Electronics reports earnings of $1.46 billion in first quarter, increase of 53 percent; sales rise 15 percent, to $7.6 billion (S)

headline: THE COLLECTIONS / MILAN: Heavy metal, loud and clear
abstract: Milan—  Ticking stripes, cropped pants, low at the crotch, glazed fabrics for suits, Asian prints and all-white outfits have emerged as trends in a quiet Milan menswear season. Accessories for next summer include narrow-toed loafers, the ubiquitous giant tote bags and silver metal chains. The other heavy metal story is zippers which are now used for decoration on jackets or baggy pants, rather than to fasten them.

headline: Tax Treaties With Small Nations Turn Into a New Shield for Profits
abstract: Some large companies, encouraged by top law and accounting firms, are adopting new strategy to cut taxes legally on profits they make in US; technique allows company to transfer profit earned in US to paper company in another country that has special kind of tax treaty with US; treaties, originally intended to serve American economic interests abroad, allow companies through accounting sleight of hand to transform taxable profits into expenses they can deduct on federal tax returns; tax-deductible expenses include interest payments to overseas company, royalties for use of company's logo and fees for management advice; paper company then sends money to US company's worldwide headquarters in Bermuda, which has no income tax and is tax haven of choice for many companies; what were once taxable profits are turned into virtually untaxed dollars for use anywhere in world; large publicly traded companies can use method to reduce taxes on American profits to as little as 11 percent, from average of 21.5 percent; photo; charts (M)

headline: On Eve of Vote, French Papers Rally Voters Against Rightist
abstract: Left- and right-leaning French newspapers are virtually unanimous in running front-page editorials urging voters to reject far-right candidate, Jean-Marie Le Pen, and to give Pres Jacques Chirac landslide victory in May 5 runoff election for President (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Raises Loss Estimate
abstract: Barclays says provisions to cover bad loans in first quarter of 2002 were higher than in quarter year earlier; news sends shares tumbling 4.4 percent (S)

headline: Sharon Ejects Party From Israeli Cabinet
abstract: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel fired ministers from the rigorously Orthodox Shas Party from his cabinet after they voted against an emergency economic package in Parliament.

headline: Farmland Co-op Reports $50 Million Loss
abstract: Farmland Industries Inc reports loss of $50 million in its fiscal second quarter, compared with loss of $1.3 million year earlier; sales fell 33 percent, to $1.6 billion (S)

headline: Article 2002042492360327032 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                       International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business             Technology           -    E-Business          -      Circuits            -      Columns               Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Many creditors are increasingly worried that big banks have conflicting roles as both lenders and advisers.
abstract: Some of nation's biggest banks are being challenged for serving dual roles as lenders and advisers to troubled companies; companies' creditors say situation gives rise to conflicts, adding that it is inevitable result of banks' increasing diverse roles, particularly in two years since legislation eliminated separation between investment banking and commercial lending businesses; some examples cited (Market Place column) (M)

headline: More Black Stock Investors
abstract: Neuwirth Research Inc survey finds number of higher-income American blacks investing in stock market rose sharply in most-recent five year period (S)

headline: Phone Start-Ups Win the Latest Round in Court
abstract: US Supreme Court, 7-1, hands huge victory to start-up telephone companies by broadly affirming rules that permit them to lease equipment from largest phone companies at relatively low costs; pricing regulations are meant to let rivals viably compete with entrenched local phone companies by leasing access to their networks rather than having to build expensive duplicate systems; established telephone companies had argued that rules, which grew out of Telecommunications Act of 1996, forced them to give competitors access to their networks at unfairly low prices; decision has significant implications for competition in local phone markets; rate formula helps determine number of market issues, including which companies will enjoy greater profits, whether smaller local companies are able to survive and effectively compete, and extent to which larger companies are willing to make capital investments; Verizon, SBC Communications, BellSouth and Qwest had argued that standards permit leasing fees that are so low that neither they nor smaller challengers would have financial interest in investing to build and improve their networks; smaller rivals had argued that formulas proposed by incumbents would lead to higher fees that would eviscerate deregulatory goals of Telecommunications Act, driving them out of business and leaving local markets exclusively in hands of monopolists; court's opinion was written by Associate Justice David H Souter (M)

headline: NTL CONTINUES NEGOTIATIONS WITH LENDERS
abstract: NTL, which is restructuring about $10.6 billion in debt by converting it to equity, is continuing to negotiate with its banks (S)

headline: EarthLink Will Acquire Corporate Computer Seller
abstract: PeoplePC will be acquired by EarthLink; EarthLink will pay $10 million to $14.3 million and will be liable for roughly $35 million in services to existing PeoplePC customers (M)

headline: South Korea Finds Fortune By Shunning Japanese Ways
abstract: South Korea, long in Japan's shadow, is blazing new trail for Asian economic development; by encouraging consumers to spend freely on credit, throwing its doors open to foreign investment and introducing American-style freedom to fail, South Korea has pout itself back on track as one of Asia's fastest-growing and most diversified economies; with Seoul's main stock market index nearly doubling since September, foreigners now account for 38 percent of share ownership and two-thirds of daily trades; South Korea has attracted $52 billion in new investment from overseas since 1998, more than double what it pulled in during previous four decades; graph; photo (M)

headline: Another Snag For ImClone And Its Drug For Cancer
abstract: Merck of Germany, in another potential blow to ImClone Systems, company with European rights to ImClone's cancer drug Erbitux, has decided not to modify its clinical trial in some ways that ImClone believes would help drug win approval in US; decision could mean that ImClone and its American marketing partner, Bristol-Myers Squibb, will have to undertake new clinical trial themselves, further delaying approval of Erbitux (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Stagnant Economy
abstract: Hong Kong's economy continued to stagnate in first quarter, with output falling nine-tenths of 1 percent from year earlier; small increase in exports of services, notably jump in tourists from mainland China, failed to offset record unemployment of 7 percent and sinking exports of goods (S)

headline: BBDO Worldwide Is Dropped As Agency for Charles Schwab
abstract: Charles Schwab Corp unexpected dismisses BBDO Worldwide, advertising agency that used celebrities in commercials for brokerage firm; move seen indicative of how ties between ad agency executives and advertisers can fray during tough economic times, particularly in competitive marketing categories like financial services; photo (M)

headline: GILLETTE ORDERED TO PAY $10 MILLION TO SYNDIA
abstract: Jury orders Gillette Co to pay $10 million to Syndia Corp for infringing patents covering method for coating razor blades with diamond-like carbon to make them stronger; Syndia says it may ask court to block Gillette from selling its Mach3, Mach3 Turbo and Venus razor blades because of patent-infringement finding unless Gillette signs licensing agreement (S)

headline: Indonesian Official Urges U.S. to Resume Military Assistance
abstract: Laksamana Sukardi, close adviser to Pres Megawati Sukarnoputri of Indonesia, says United States should drop restrictions imposed three years ago on assistance to Indonesian military and help restore 'tarnished reputation' of his nation's army; since Sept 11 Washington has repeatedly pressed Indonesia to take firmer action against groups and individuals suspected of having ties to Osama bin Laden and his Al Qaeda terrorism network; Sukardi says this is impossible task if military remains discredited in eyes of public; Indonesian Government wants to resume military training in US for its officers; Sukardi stops short of advocating that US help supply military with weapons (M)

headline: China Finds Way to Beat Chip Limits
abstract: China is fast catching up with United States's ability to make advanced semiconductors; two Shanghai plants have ordered equipment from Europe and Japan capable of etching tiny circuitry used in smallest, fastest and most powerful computer chips and could start manufacturing made-to-order chips as early as 2003; US export controls, intended to deny US technology to China's military, have lost their teeth, largely because US does not have monopoly on chip-making technology; technology could help China create streamlined, high-technology military; photo (M)

headline: Allies Exhume 23 Bodies Thought to Be Qaeda Fighters
abstract: Canadian troops and American criminal investigators in Afghanistan's Tora Bora mountains exhume 23 bodies they believe are remains of Al Qaeda fighters, perhaps Osama bin Laden security contingent killed in air strike Dec 15; DNA testing is done before reburial; bin Laden's remains are not found (M)

headline: Why Big Ideas Often Fall Flat
abstract: William J Holstein article discusses details of managing company Lawrence A Bossidy outlines in book Execution: The Discipline of Getting Things Done, which he wrote with Ram Charan and Charles Burck; Bossidy says chief executive must be engaged in people management, strategic development and operations; photo (M)

headline: When the Earth Moves Under the Stock Market
abstract: Jerry Frankel letter points out that stock market crashes, unlike earthquakes, generally result from human problems, not forces of nature

headline: Iran, Back in the Bond Market
abstract: Iran is returning to bond market for first time since 1979 Islamic revolution (S)

headline: Honda Considers Airlift of Steel
abstract: Honda Motor Co is prepared to airlift 2,000 tons of carbon sheet steel to its American and Canadian auto factories if it cannot secure adequate supplies from United States steel producers; steel-import tariffs imposed by Pres Bush prompt Honda's airlift plans (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Andersen Prosecutors Accused of Intimidation  A lawyer for Arthur Andersen accused federal prosecutors of trying to intimidate at least three witnesses by threatening them with indictment and said he would submit an immediate request to the Justice Department for an investigation.    The accusation came after a day of hearings during which prosecutors disclosed that an Andersen partner had told an Enron lawyer in December that he had deleted e-mail messages, an indication that Andersen knew about the destruction of records weeks earlier than previously believed. [Page C2.]

headline: French Arrest More Suspects In Violent Acts Aimed at Jews
abstract: French police officials report arrests of nearly 40 people in connection with attacks on synagogues and other Jewish sites in France in last week; 10 people remain in detention, one has been found guilty and sentenced to three-month prison term; attacks are believed to be have been carried out largely by French Arabs acting in support of Palestinians (S)

headline: U.S. Says a Key Detainee Had Planned More Attacks
abstract: Bush administration officials say Abu Zubaydah, important lieutenant to Osama bin Laden, was organizing new attacks on American targets when he was captured in Pakistan last week; confirm arrest and say he may be taken from undisclosed location to Guantanamo Bay, where he could be first Al Qaeda leader to face US military tribunal; Sec Donald Rumsfeld says Zubaydah is being treated for gunshot wounds suffered during capture (M)

headline: Some U.S. Backers of Israel Boycott Dailies Over Mideast Coverage That They Deplore
abstract: Intense public reaction to coverage of violence of Middle East conflict prompts unusually harsh attacks on several news media outlets and has led to boycotts of The New York Times, The Los Angeles Times and The Washington Post; broadcast news operations, including CNN and National Public Radio, have also been criticized; criticism comes largely from supporters of Israel; swift communications of Internet era help fan intensity of criticism (M)

headline: Units of Grey Global Win and Lose Accounts
abstract: Some account changes at agencies owned by Grey Global Group (S)

headline: A SUCCESSFUL NORTEL STOCK SALE RAISES $1.3 BILLION
abstract: Nortel Networks Corp says sales of shares and equity units gave it net proceeds of $1.3 billion, about 40 percent more than it had planned (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Server Sales Remain Flat
abstract: Dataquest says shipments of computer servers increased 0.6 percent in first quarter, to 1.08 million; Compaq Computer remained number one globally as Dell Computer widened its lead in US (S)

headline: Article 2002042494200959890 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //              JOB POSITIONS

headline: Fickle Bosses Deemed Worst
abstract: No one likes working for a manager or supervisor who consistently criticizes and insults the staff. But a recent study suggests there is a type of boss considered even worse -- the one who will be supportive one day and knock you down the next.    The study, published in the April-May issue of the Academy of Management Journal, examined ''social undermining'' in the workplace. It was based on random interviews with 343 police officers. The study identified ''undermining'' bosses as those who insulted employees, talked behind their backs or gave employees the silent treatment. Examples of support included listening to employees' concerns, acknowledging skills and pitching in to help.

headline: Rough Roads for Women
abstract: Carol Alexander letter seconds May 19 article on indignities suffered by women on business trips

headline: Fox's Wooing of America Brings Him Woes at Home
abstract: Analysis of Mexican Pres Vicente Fox's embrace of United States in his first 18 months in office, ending seven decades of anti-Americanism by old ruling party; says polls suggest majority of his countrymen support him, but younger and better-educated Mexicans who helped elect him fear that he has won little in return for his political investment in American policies and trade practices (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: FRANCE: Economy Grows; BRITAIN: Cruise Acquisition Opposed; BRITAIN: Developer Bought Out; BRITAIN: Lloyd's Drops Buyout; SPAIN: Bank To Write Off Loss.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Moves to Drop Dissident Heir From Its Board
abstract: Hewlett-Packard, stung by lawsuit filed last week by dissident director Walter B Hewlett, announces it will not nominate him for re-election to its board; Hewlett, heir who led determined, costly and nearly successful proxy fight against company's planned purchase of Compaq Computer, condemns move; decision to remove Hewlett is further evidence that hostilities in proxy contest have not ceased, well after votes have been cast; photo (M)

headline: Qwest Said to Get Several Bids for Yellow Pages Unit
abstract: Qwest Communications International receives at least three offers worth more than $8 billion in first round of bidding for its yellow pages business; consortium of firms led by Kohlberg Kravis approaches Qwest with $7.7 billion offer, but offer is rejected as too low; another bid is submitted from team led by Carlyle Group that includes Madison Dearborn Partners and Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe, J P Morgan Chase, Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers; third bid is submitted by Apollo Advisers and Oaktree Capital Management and is backed by Deutsche Bank (M)

headline: Gamble on Connie Chung Is Set to Start
abstract: Connie Chung is set to make debut with nightly news program on CNN, right opposite Bill O'Reilly on Fox News; CNN executives, who hope Chung can help network regain No. 1 position from Fox, believe she will draw audience by standing in serious contrast to opinionated programs on competing channel; photo (M)

headline: Convoy Struck in November Found to Lack U.N. Markings
abstract: United Nations food convoy that was heavily damaged on Nov 10 during American airstrike in Afghanistan was unmarked and had not coordinated its travel with US-led coalition forces, according to investigation by Central Command; convoy was en route to city of Bamian and struck by two bombs that were dropped in effort to block Taliban and Al Qaeda forces; no United Nations employees were hurt in incident; two reports are also released on Afghan detainees who claimed they had been beaten while in custody, but report says injuries are consistent with force necessary to secure them (M)

headline: A Bull Is Taking One Step Back
abstract: Interview with Steve Leuthold, president of Leuthold/Weeden Capital Management and longtime bear who turned bullish on stock markets in Feb 2001; he is currently optimistic regarding equities in several sectors; photo (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Urges Caution On U.S. Role In Philippines
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says he would not be willing to expand American military training mission in Philippines unless top aides justify step, which he says would put Army Special Forces at greater risk and would probably commit Pentagon to longer-term military role there; Deputy Sec Paul D Wolfowitz is believed to be leaning in favor of expanded approach in Philippines (M)

headline: Betting the Farm That Online Trading Isn't Dead
abstract: Market Place column on Ameritrade Holding Corp's decision to acquire rival Datek Online Holdings Corp for $1.29 billion in stock; Ameritrade's chief executive Joseph Moglia is quite optimistic that Nasdaq day-trading boom may come back, agreeing to pay $1,540 a piece for Datek's 837,000 accounts; analysts and investors question whether Ameritrade may have overpaid; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Global Crossing Challenges Bid
abstract: Global Crossing challenges ruling that found it ineligible to provide network for Defense Research and Engineering Agency; Global Crossing won contract in July 2001; contract, valued at up to $400 million over 10 years, was later rescinded by Defense Information Agency over questions about bidding procedure; WorldCom received contract on April 4 (S)

headline: Big Board Issues Its Ideas on Corporate Governance
abstract: New York Stock Exchange issued recommendations intended to tighten corporate governance rules, including requiring that independent directors constitute majority on corporate boards; about 25 percent of 2,800 companies listed on exchange did not have majority of independent directors on their boards in 2001; investors and corporate governance specialists welcome recommendations as first step in restoring confidence in stock market, but say they will not be able to prevent fraud by corporate executives; photo (M)

headline: Here Are Your Pills. Do You Want the Seminar?
abstract: Small but growing number of drugstores are expanding their services to include broader range of health management services; physicians are guardedly supportive of pharmacists entry into patient care (M)

headline: Financial Crisis May Sideline Part of England's Soccer Tradition
abstract: Many of England's much-loved soccer teams face bankruptcy because ITV Digital says it cannot pay $260 million it promised English Football League this year for broadcasting its games; financial crisis does not affect top teams like Manchester United, which easily attract millions of television dollars; it does affect lower-division clubs, and focuses attention on their roles in their communities; many local soccer teams assist programs and projects that were once concerns of unions, business groups and crusading town newspapers; they have recreation programs for thousands of local youths (M)

headline: U.S. Group Is Said to Acquire Irish Company
abstract: Madison Dearborn Partners, private Chicago investment firm, agrees to buy Jefferson Smurfit Group, Irish paper and packaging company, for $3.34 billion (S)

headline: First Wave Of Strikes In Germany Shuts Plants
abstract: Nearly 50,000 German workers go on strike, shutting Mercedes and Porsche plants in Stuttgart, in first of planned series of short strikes that could hit hundreds of companies next few weeks; employers are bracing for what could be long confrontation; IG Metall, union representing 2.7 million factory workers, is officially demanding wage increases of 6.5 percent per year and says it will not settle for anything less than 4 percent; photo (M)

headline: First-Quarter Net Income Declines at Times Company
abstract: New York Times Co says first-quarter net income dropped as continuing advertising slump offset robust growth in circulation revenue; posts net income of $54.5 million, down 11 percent from $61.3 million year earlier; total revenue decreased 5.3 percent, to $737.1 million from $778.2 million year ago as advertising revenue declined 10.2 percent; latest figures reflect aftertax charge of 4 cents per share for cost of eliminating jobs, primarily at Boston Globe; daily circulation rose 3.8 percent, or 43,000 copies, to 1.2 million copies in six-month period ended March 31, while Sunday circulation rose nearly 41,000 copies, or 2.4 percent, to 1.7 million; chief financial officer Leonard P Forman cautiously predicts recovery in second half; chief executive Russell T Lewis notes both 3.7 percent reduction in costs this quarter compared with those in period year earlier and The Times's success in winning record total of seven Pulitzer Prizes this year (M)

headline: Russian Lab Storing Germs Faces Cutoff Of Electricity
abstract: Power supplier threatens to cut off electricity to lab 100 miles south of Moscow that contains 3,000 strains of anthrax, plague and other deadly bacteria, many of them in cryogenic casks cooled with liquid nitrogen and isolated from environment by layered enclosures and oversize air-handling systems that are all dependent on electricity; lab, in Obolensk, wants US and Western countries that have contributed $6 million to its transformation from bioweapons complex to give additional $500,000 a year to pay its electric bills and arrears; situation is another example of how basic capitalist imperative for enterprises to be self-sustaining can conflict with remnants of Soviet weapons systemtems (M)

headline: U.N. Broadens List of Products Iraq Can Import
abstract: Security Council unanimously approves resolution overhauling its economic sanctions against Iraq to dampen their impact on civilians while keeping pressure on Pres Saddam Hussein; measure will allow far more consumer goods and continue to block items that could be used for military purposes; is seen as victory for United States and its allies on Council, laying diplomatic groundwork to oust Hussein, perhaps by force, and blunting any drive to end sanctions; sanctions, which must be renewed every six months, are to stay in place until United Nations weapons inspectors can verify that Iraq has dismantled programs to develop weapons of mass destruction (M)

headline: Business; Looking Far From 7th Ave. to Revive Leslie Fay
abstract: Profile of new Leslie Fay Co chief executive John Short; focuses on challenge he faces in reviving maker of moderately priced dresses; company has been hurt by drop in sales of dresses for work and social occasions, outdated styles, growth of private-label brands and rise of 'cheap chic' separates at some chain stores; photo (M)

headline: Fiat Names Associate Of Founders As Co-Chief
abstract: Fiat names Gabriele Galateri di Genola e Suniglia co-chief executive, fueling speculation that company is preparing to exit auto industry; Galateri will share post with chairman Paolo Fresco; heads holding companies used by Fiat's founding Agnelli family to control sprawling Fiat empire (M)

headline: Elections to Proceed in the Netherlands, Despite Killing
abstract: South Korea's military draft becomes major political issue with refusal of Oh Tae Yang, 28-year-old Buddhist cleric,to serve; Oh has won support of human rights lawyers, and civic and religious groups, overcoming two government requests for arrest warrants and winning court hearing later this year (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Toughening On Migrants
abstract: China demands that South Korea hand over several North Korean migrants holed up in its embassy in Beijing, asserting they have no legal right to asylum (S)

headline: Israeli Armor Units Continue Sweeping Through West Bank
abstract: Israeli tanks and armored vehicles rumble into Nablus, second largest city in West Bank, continuing relentless sweep even as international criticism gathers force and some Israelis themselves begin to question the operation; Israeli Army is now in control of all major Palestinian-ruled centers in West Bank except Hebron; Israeli military operation is running into greater resistance with every advance; Prime Min Ariel Sharon says it will continue until 'infrastructure of terrorism' is rooted out; in Bethlehem, tanks and armored personnel carriers surround Church of the Nativity, where 200 Palestinians have taken refuge; attacks from across northern border with Lebanon raise possibility of Israeli retaliation against Syrian targets, on premise that Hezbollah, militant Islamic movement in Lebanon, would not attack Israel without consent from Syria; demonstration by several hundred Israeli Arabs and leftist peace protesters on road to Ramallah turns nasty when Israeli security forces fire tear gas and beat participants, including three members of Israeli Parliament; this is first protest by Israelis against military operation; photo (L)

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: New rail initiatives, bolstered by sharp increases in business-travel ridership on Amtrak's Northeast Corridor and on other Amtrak rail corridors in Southern California and Pacific Northwest, are moving along; Railway Age magazine editor William C Vantuono says one of most important is fledgling Midwest Regional Rail Initiative, projected $4.1 billion system to develop high-speed corridors linking Chicago, Detroit, St Louis, Milwaukee and other cities in nine Midwest states; Federal Railroad Administration has announced $3 million grant to Florida High-Speed Rail Authority for studies on high-speed rail link from Orlando to Miami; American Express says business travel is booming in China; American Express has opened its joint venture in Beijing with China International Travel Service; Kroll Inc is affiliating one of its businesses with iJet Travel Intelligence, Web and wireless travel intelligence provider for corporate travelers; two companies will leverage their technological and analytical operations to provide travel advisories to combined international customer base of 170 clients; British Airways drops price of ticket on supersonic Concorde from New York to London to $6,999, drop of 45 percent from regular price, for selected travel days through Aug 31; other options noted (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: VISTEON CORP., Dearborn, Mich., a maker of auto parts, said it would spend about $300 million to build a new headquarters on a 265-acre site in Van Buren Township, Mich., to complete its move from Dearborn, the home of its former parent, Ford Motor Company.    IMMUNOMEDICS INC., Morris Plains, N.J., a developer of tests and drugs for cancer and infectious diseases, increased its stake in IBC Pharmaceutical, a cancer therapy venture, to 92 percent by buying the 43 percent stake held by Beckman Coulter Inc., Fullerton, Calif., a designer of laboratory systems, for up to $11.6 million in stock and a warrant for a future stock purchase.

headline: Queen Mother's Coffin Lies in State
abstract: Britain began its formal farewell to the Queen Mother today with a display of pageantry and decorousness.

headline: Horace A. Shepard, 89, Former Chief of TRW
abstract: Horace A Shepard, former chief executive and chairman of TRW, dies at age 89 (S)

headline: An Unhappy Quarterback: Balky Players Are Defying the Bush Game Plan
abstract: News analysis; Pres Bush is clearly irritated at being defied by Israel, Palestinian Authority and Arab states in effort to negotiate cease-fire between Israelis and Palestinians; how he responds to more challenges to his authority over next few days could be fascinating subtext of his entrance to maelstrom of Middle East; photo (M)

headline: Former ImClone Chief Is Charged With Securities Fraud
abstract: Samuel D. Waksal, the former chief executive of ImClone Systems, was arrested today on criminal charges of conspiracy to commit securities fraud in connection with an insider trading scheme.

headline: Internet Radio Criticizes Rate On Royalties
abstract: Federal copyright regulators set critical ground rule for fledgling Internet radio industry, cutting in half proposed royalty rate that Internet companies must pay record labels; adjustment falls short of what many say would be necessary for them to stay in business; radio companies will pay recording industry 0.007 cent each time they play song over Internet; webcasters had hoped that rate would be set at percentage of revenue, move that they argued would allow them time to build new outlet for music; James H Billington, librarian of Congress who ruled in consultation with Copyright Office, says percentage-of-revenue rate would not have been fair to record industry; Recording Industry Association of America criticizes rate as too low (M)

headline: Mexico Bars Its President From Trips Next Week
abstract: Mexican Senate invokes its power to bar Pres Vicente Fox from visiting US and Canada; action arises from heated disputes over foreign policy and Fox's frequent trips at time when critics say he should be working on pressing domestic issues; PRI opponents also say they are skeptical about Fox's close relationship with US (M)

headline: Leading Indexes Post Third Consecutive Losing Week
abstract: Stocks fall, sending Dow Jones to its lowest close since Nov 12; Dow declines 34.97 points, to 9,589.67; S&P 500 falls 1.62 points, to 1,027.53; Nasdaq composite index sheds 19.40 points, to 1,535.48; Treasury prices fall; 10-year note yield rises to 5.07 percent; 30-year bond yield rises to 5.66 percent; tables; graph (M)

headline: Vivendi Likely to Give Up Its Effort to Overturn Vote
abstract: Vivendi Universals's board is scheduled to meet in Manhattan to try to resolve some of uncertainties facing company; board's most definitive action is expected to come in rejecting idea of holding another shareholder meeting this year; in April, Vivendi said electronic voting system used at its annual meeting in Paris had been tampered with, leading to defeat of two important shareholder resolutions; chairman Jean-Marie Messier is expected to present options on disposition of Vivendi's water treatment business (M)

headline: KMART SPENT UP TO $1 BILLION ON CLOSING OF STORES
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission filing shows Kmart Corp spent as much as $1.05 billion in first quarter to prepare to close hundreds of stores; says company spent $600 million to $800 million in quarter ended May 1 for planned closing of 283 stores; adds Kmart had additional $250 million in expenses from discounting merchandise sold at going-out-of-business sales (S)

headline: S.E.C. BEGINS FORMAL INVESTIGATION INTO ALPHARMA
abstract: SEC probes Alpharma Inc's its methods for recognizing revenue in connection with earnings restatement company reported in November (S)

headline: Questions Linger in Calm but Scarred Caracas
abstract: Caracas, Venezuela, begins returning to normal work routines after weekend of political turmoil in which Pres Hugo Chavez was deposed in coup and later returned to power; calm returns to slums ringing capital; questions linger in minds of many about those who died; government officials and human rights investigators differ on number of deaths, with figures ranging from 15 to 40; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: In a Surprise, Celera Picks A President From Within  Celera Genomics named one of its own executives, Kathy Ordoñez, as president, succeeding J. Craig Venter, its founder, who left under pressure in January.    The move was a surprise because Celera had said it was looking for an experienced pharmaceutical executive to transform the company from a provider of genetic information into a drug company. But Ms. Ordoñez, who now runs Celera's diagnostics business, has little experience in drug development. [Page C2.]

headline: Saudi to Warn Bush of Rupture Over Israel Policy
abstract: Crown Prince Abdullah is expected to tell Pres Bush that strategic relationship between Saudi Arabia and US will be threatened if Bush does not moderate his support for Israel's military policies; two will meet on Apr 25; Saudi family has reportedly discussed using 'oil weapon' against US, or demanding that US leave strategic military bases in region; there is also warning of general drift by Arab leaders toward radical politics that have been building in Arab street; Saudi message contains undeniable brinkmanship intended to put pressure on Bush to take much larger political gamble by imposing peace settlement on Israelis and Palestinians; Abdullah is thought to represent not just Saudi Arabia but also broader voice of Arab world; his delegation's strong sense of alarm and crisis are being heard in other Arab capitals; Abdullah believes Bush has lost credibility by failing to follow through on his demand two weeks ago that Prime Min Ariel Sharon withdraw Israeli troops from West Bank and end sieges of Yasir Arafat's compound in Ramallah and of Church of Nativity in Bethlehem (M)

headline: Sentence for Stock Manipulation
abstract: Victor Wang, former chairman of Duke & Co, brokerage firm that became criminal enterprise under his direction until it closed in 1998, is sentenced to serve 7 1/2 years to 22 1/2 years in New York State prison; Wang pleaded guilty in August 1999 to charges of enterprise corruption (M)

headline: Visiting Synagogue, Bush Praises Russian Religious Tolerance
abstract: Pres Bush visits Grand Choral Synagogue in St Petersburg and leaves saying he believes officialy-sanctioned anti-Semitism of Soviet times is thing of past; photo with Brooklyn-born Rabbi Menahem-Mendel Pevzner; Pres Vlaidmir Putin, who has given leadership role to Lubavitcher Hasidism, arranged visit to show that Jews are free of harassment; he has urged Bush to reverse 1974 Jackson-Vanik amendment aimed at helping Soviet Jews get freedom to emigrate (M)

headline: Spanish Judge to Study Bank's Offshore Accounts
abstract: Judge Baltasar Garzon opens investigation into secret funds held offshore by senior executives at Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, Spain's second-largest bank, which is suspected of laundering money, illicitly financing political campaigns and falsifying accounts; asks Bank of Spain to suspend its civil inquiry into secret accounts because of 'possible penal responsibilities' facing 16 current and former executives named in inquiry; offshore accounts were apparently set up by Banco Bilbao Vizcaya under leadership of Emilio Ybarra before 1999 merger with Argentaria that created Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, and came to light when chairman of combined bank, Francisco Gonzalez, balked at signing bank's 2000 financial statements unless Ybarra, who became co-chairman after merger, informed Bank of Spain about them (M)

headline: As Pressure Grows, Option Costs Come Out of Hiding
abstract: Investors are more intent than ever on exposing titantic transfers of shareholder wealth to executives and employees that options represent at many companies; Standard & Poor's plan to deduct expense of stock options from its calculations of companies' core earnings means investors will be able to grasp option costs even if companies keep burying them in footnotes; Bear Stearns analyst Patricia McConnell says dilutive effect of options on earnings in 2001 will be far greater than in 2000, when she found earnings would have dropped 9 percent over all if options were deducted as expense (M)

headline: North Korea Agrees to Receive American Envoy to Renew Talks
abstract: South Korea says its special envoy, Lim Dong Won, has secured North Korea's agreement to receive American envoy, Jack Pritchard, to re-start talks stalled for months; sudden burst of diplomatic activity, after months of worsening ties, sets off debate in South Korea and United States over whether North Korea is resuming engagement because of Bush administration's hard line or efforts of Pres Kim Dae Jung (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Latin America: Mexico: Interest Rate Eased
abstract: Mexico's central bank moves to cut interest rates by making more credit available to commercial banks; is convinced inflationary pressures have eased enough to have economic growth without surge in prices (S)

headline: A Little Bit Of Inflation Could Go A Long Way
abstract: EVERYBODY knows it's possible to have too much of a good thing. Too much rich food leads to indigestion; too many e-mail messages can drive you to the delete button.    The same is true of the Federal Reserve's long crusade to eliminate inflation from the American economy. That campaign, begun courageously by Paul Volcker in 1979 when prices were spiraling higher at double-digit rates and carried on brilliantly by Alan Greenspan over the last 15 years, is one of the great success stories of economic policy, helping to lay the foundation for much of the prosperity of recent years.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Europe-Asia Meeting On Migrants
abstract: Officials from European Union, China and 9 other Asian nations are meeting in Canary Islands, favored destination for boatloads of illegal immigrants seeking better life in Europe, to discuss migration issues; will try to trace routes used to smuggle migrants to Europe and devise plans to stop traffic (S)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: MEXICO: Judge Orders Arrest Of Former Oil Chief; Costa RICA: New President Sworn In

headline: Vermont to Require Drug Makers To Disclose Payments to Doctors
abstract: Vermont, amid rising concern about cost of prescription drugs, is expected to become first state in nation to require pharmaceutical companies to disclose their gifts and cash payments to doctors, hospitals and other health care providers; Vermont Gov Howard Dean says drug companies are giving doctors free dinners and flying them to Flordia for vacation; Dean plans to sign disclosure bill; adds such gifts could influence physicians to prescribe certain drugs, often most expensive ones; Vermont legislation is part of growing effort by state and federal lawmakers to rein in drug companies' marketing practices; chart lists some bills that have been or are being considered in other states; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | North America: Canada: Jobless Rate Declines
abstract: Statistics Canada reports Canada's unemployment rate fell to 7.6 percent in April because of surge in full-time jobs (S)

headline: Wall Street Journal Is Set to Loosen Its Collar
abstract: Wall Street Journal plans first page redesign that includes use of pastel colors, fancy boxes and main headlines occasionally spanning two or three columns; seeks to reposition its journalism and business with changes and introduction of fourth daily inside section, Personal Journal; move comes at time of falling advertising revenues; Journal seeks to entice new readers, particularly women, and expand beyond aging core of existing subscribers; is committing more resources to consumer-oriented reporting believed to be magnet for advertising; front-page changes will make room for fast-breaking exclusives; photos (M)

headline: Procter Is Suing Coca-Cola On Calcium Drinks Patent
abstract: Procter & Gamble files lawsuit against Coca-Cola Co, asserting that Coke's Minute Maid division violated Procter's patent for adding calcium to fruit drinks; lawsuit accuses Minute Maid of using Procter's calcium technology; seeks injunction to stop Minute Maid from making products in their current form and unspecified amount of damages (M)

headline: As Arafat Critics Close In, Deputies Vie in the Wings
abstract: Article focuses on political future of Yasir Arafat; Palestinian political analysts and Israeli intelligence officials say Arafat, for decades very personification of Palestinian aspirations, is in deep trouble with his own people; see his authority challenged by younger generation of street leaders who grew up fighting Israeli occupation; say Arafat will likely remain at helm in weakened state since there is now no alternative, but that potentially violent power struggle is building, pitting different generations of Palestinian fighters against each other and also setting at odds rival security chiefs in West Bank and Gaza Strip; effect of Israel's military invasion in dampening his popularity discussed; what he envisioned as triumphal appearances after release from siege have drawn only perfunctory crowds, and his promises of pending reform are being greeted with cynicism not only by Israelis but by many Palestinians; photo (M)

headline: Dollar Hits A 2-Year Low Against Euro
abstract: US dollar, after rising sharply in value for years in reflection of American economic might, is weakening markedly, mirroring concern about fragility of economic recovery and nation's financial conditions; dollar falls to two-year low against euro and also edges down against Japanese yen; decline comes after new data show US trade deficit widened to what some economists say is worrisome level; Commerce Department reports monthly trade deficit rose in April to record $35.9 billion; current account balance also posted record deficit $112.5 billion for first quarter; euro trades at 96.52 cents, up from 95.67 cents day earlier; dollar is worth 123.37 yen, down from 123.82 yen; graph (M)

headline: Senegalese Loner Works to Build Africa, His Way
abstract: Senegal Pres Abdoulaye Wade, elected two years ago after struggling in opposition for 26 years, has emerged through force of ideas and personality as one of sub-Saharan Africa's leading spokesman; 76-year-old Wade explains his refusal to go along with Robert Mugabe's stolen election in Zimbabwe; interview; photo; map (M)

headline: Generic Drug Maker Challenges AstraZeneca Patent for Prilosec
abstract: AstraZeneca, maker of Prilosec, is battling generic drug makers that want to make lost-cost versions of drug, heartburn and ulcer treatment with $3.7 billion in sales in US in 2001; AstraZeneca contends generic drug makers are infringing its patents on process for making drug; generic drug maker Andrx Corp has accused AstraZeneca of concealing information in patent application for drug; contends that foreign patent records show that AstraZeneca applied for US patent on Prilosec without telling American patent examiners that similar, prior patent for making drug was already pending in Korea; if Andrx's arguments are upheld in court, it could mean that generic versions of drug could be manufactured, potentially causing major erosion in sales for AstraZeneca but saving consumers and insurers millions of dollars; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; A Booster for Virtual Diplomas
abstract: Jones International University, first university to exist entirely online, says Mexican Pres Vicente Fox will deliverkeynote commencement speech, which will be shown in streaming video on school's Web site; about 100 of school's 2,000 students are from Mexico; photo (M)

headline: Major Central Banks Sell Yen To Try to Stem Recent Rise
abstract: Federal Reserve, European Central Bank and Bank of Japan sell yen for dollars in bid to stem rise in yen's value that threatens to hamper Japan's economic recovery; moves depress yen's value only briefly; graphs (M)

headline: Animosities Flare In the Struggle Over Adelphia
abstract: Behind-the-scenes battle that has been raging for several days between Adelphia Communications Inc's largest shareholder Leonard Tow and company's board culminates in angry exchange of letters between Tow and interim chief executive Erland E Kailbourne; Tow, who has support of group of large institutional investors, met with board member Leslie Gelber on May 29 and asked to be named chairman; Tow has already secured two board seats; board refused request and Tow sent letter to Kailbourne protesting company's plan to sell 'valuable' cable assets as soon as May 31, contending it is being done in 'atmosphere of desperation'; Kailbourne sends letter to Tow, telling him that his efforts should be 'directed toward what will benefit all of the company's shareholders and not in pursuit of a separate agenda'; exchange comes as Nasdaq says it will delist company's stock because company has not yet filed its 2001 financial report with Securities and Exchange Commission (M)

headline: Barnes Group Cuts Jobs
abstract: Barnes Group, maker of parts used in automobiles and aircraft, eliminated 150 positions in first quarter, and profit fell 7.5 percent during period; net income fell to $6.77 million from $7.31 million year earlier; revenue fell 2.5 percent, to $194.2 million from $199.3 million; job cuts at Barnes Aerospace accounted for about 2.8 percent of company's work force (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Officials Quit After Air Crash
abstract: All nine senior officials at the China Aviation Development Foundation, a quasi-governmental group that owns 71 percent of China Airlines, resigned to take responsibility for the crash last Saturday of a China Airlines Boeing 747 into the Taiwan Strait. all 225 aboard died. Rough seas and powerful currents have prevented the recovery of the aircraft's data and cockpit voice recorders and most of the wreckage.   Keith Bradsher (NYT)

headline: A Bittersweet Homecoming
abstract: Salah Ajarma's return home after 39 days in the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem was a bittersweet affair.

headline: MeriStar to Miss Estimates
