abstract: MeriStar Hospitality Corp, owner of some Hilton and Marriott hotels, decreases estimate of second-quarter profits (S)

headline: SUNGARD TO BUY A RIVAL DATA-RECOVERY COMPANY
abstract: SunGard Data Systems, which makes software to handle stock and bond trades, agrees to buy unprofitable rival, Guardian iT, for 56 million pounds ($81.5 million) (S)

headline: Z-TEL TECHNOLOGIES LAYS OFF 350 AS IT CLOSES AN OFFICE
abstract: Z-Tel Technologies lays off about 350 employees, or 27 percent of its staff, as it closes customer service center in Minot, ND; will move customer service to office in Atmore, Ala (S)

headline: Europe Seeks Fast Action In Steel Fight
abstract: European Commission is gathering support among 15 European Union states for imposing retaliatory trade sanctions within next two months on imports of steel products from US; commission has already listed wide range of products on which it plans to impose sanctions in response to tariffs of up to 30 percent that Bush administration imposed on some steel imports into US last month (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: BCE Executive Is Named
abstract: BCE Emergis names Pierre Blouin as chief executive, succeeding Brian Edwards (S)

headline: Praising the President For Seeking Balance
abstract: Pres Bush's decision to put his administration at center of new Middle East negotiations wins wide praise from members of Congress across political spectrum, who say escalating violence threatens vital American interests in region (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WorldCom Overstated $3.8 Billion in Cash Flow  WorldCom, the second-largest long-distance carrier, said that it had overstated its cash flow by more than $3.8 billion in the last five quarters in what appears to be one of the largest cases of questionable bookkeeping yet.    The move throws the survival of WorldCom and MCI, which it acquired in 1999, into doubt. The company has been struggling to refinance $30 billion in debt. [Page A1.]    Enron Inquiry Turns to Bankers  Prosecutors are investigating whether individual bankers illegally benefited from deals involving Enron-related entities, potentially at the expense of their employers, people involved in the case said. [A1.]

headline: Russia Says It Has Uncovered an American-Run Espionage Ring
abstract: Russia's counterintelligence agency reports breaking American-run espionage ring its says used mind-altering drug in bid to recruit expert from top-secret military plant; says plot was aimed at arms projects and military work for former Soviet nations; Interfax news agency says female CIA officer working as diplomat has been forced to leave Moscow; says Russian expert worked as double agent and disclosed no secrets (M)

headline: Executive Pay: A Special Report; Perks Make Life Comfortable, Even in Retirement
abstract: Article in special report on executive pay focuses on chief executive perks that are increasingly being extended well into executives' retirement; company officials say continuing benefits help them recruit executives and are often use to reward outgoing executives for successful tenure; critics score life-time benefits; photo (M)/

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Oak Technology Shares Fall
abstract: Shares of Oak Technology plunge 54 percent after company cuts its fourth-quarter sales forecast and says it will report loss (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bell Canada Stake Bought
abstract: BCE Inc will regain full ownership of Bell Canada by buying out SBC Communications' 20 percent stake for $4.2 billion; photo (S)

headline: Martha Stewart Questions Widen, Punishing the Stock
abstract: Shares of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia fall $3.20, to record low of $10.40, as new questions emerge about her sale of stock in ImClone Systems; shares fall as concern grows that federal investigation of Martha Stewart is intensifying and that witness questioned Stewart's account of her sale of 4,000 shares of ImClone stock, which occurred one day before company announced regulatory setback that sent shares down sharply; Douglas Faneuil, assistant to Stewart's broker Peter Bacanovic, has told Merrill Lynch's lawyers that he was unaware of any agreement to sell Stewart's ImClone shares if they fell to certain price; Faneuil initially told Merrill that there was such agreement, but he is now saying he was pressed by Bacanovic; Wall Street Journal, citing unidentified person, says government has widened its investigation of Stewart beyond insider trading to possible obstruction of justice and making false statements (M)

headline: U.S.-Style Conservative Runs as Outsider in France
abstract: Interview with Alain Madelin, US-style conservative candidate in France's presidential election who is not expected to do well; his ideas of less government worry many French voters, who fear what they see as economic model that erodes social benefits and eliminates protectionism; photo (M)

headline: A Talent Stable That's Huge In TV News. Is It Too Big?
abstract: Richard Leibner, whose N S Bienstock talent agency represents about 600 television news anchors, correspondents and producers, is central figure in much of wheeling and dealing that is going on as broadcast news divisions begin handing reins to new generation and as cable news networks engage in race for big-name anchors; his concentration of talent has prompted some to ask whether his firm can fairly represent interests of all its clients; others wonder whether he has too much sway within networks themselves; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Wireless Merger
abstract: Parthus Technologies, microchip designer, to merge with DSP Group unit; deal gives DSP shareholders 50.1 percent of new company, to be called ParthusCeva; Parthus shareholders will own rest and get $60 million in cash (S)

headline: Sir Peter Shepheard, Architect And Landscape Designer, 88
abstract: Sir Peter Shepeard, British architect, planner and landscape designer, dies at age 88; photos (M)

headline: Article 2002042191032501951 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                       International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics             Business           -      Media & Advertising            -      World Business            -      Your Money            -      Markets            -      Company Research            -      Mutual Funds            -      Stock Portfolio            -      Columns               Technology              Science              Health              Sports              Winter Olympics              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: Kinshasa Journal; Suspects by the Score and, Oh, Such Digressions!
abstract: Kinshasha Journal on mass military trial of 135 suspects that has so far shed no light on who was behind murder of Laurent D Kabila, former president who was gunned down in his palace last year; photos; map (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: MONDAYNone.

headline: Angolans Cheer the Peace and Hope It Will Stay Awhile
abstract: Angola's warring generals sign cease-fire to silence guns that have savaged country for more than two decades; Pres Jose Eduardo dos Santos and new rebel leader Paulo Lukamba attend signing ceremony in Parliament building in Luanda; ceremony comes six weeks after death of longtime guerrilla leader Jonas Savimbi; diplomats and officials say that without him, Unita rebels quickly lost will to fight; hope ripples through nation when Gen Abreu Kamorteiro, Unita commander, embraces government counterpart Gen Armando da Cruz Neto after signing peace accord; photos (M)

headline: Private Sector; A Texas Schoolyard Business Brawl
abstract: Five prominent business executives, including Jeff Sandefer and Jack Long, cut their ties to University of Texas at Austin because it took aim at popular entrepreneurship program in which they teach; school, eager to replace some of part-timers with full-time, research-oriented professors, opposed insistence by original group of executives that teacher with worst student evaluations each year resign from program unless every member of group scored in top 25 percent of school (S)

headline: Bush Palestinian Plan
abstract: President Bush indicated in a meeting with the Saudi foreign minister that he had a plan to support the creation of a Palestinian state in order to give some immediate hope to Palestinians living under Israeli occupation, officials said.     Article, Page A18.

headline: Charles Mullen, 74, Former Chief Of American Tobacco Company
abstract: Charles H Mullen, former chairman and chief executive of American Tobacco Co, dies at age 74 (S)

headline: Clues on Italy's Role at Nativity Church
abstract: Italy says accepting Palestinian militants now holed up in Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem 'cannot even be considered,' which raises question of how Israeli, Palestinian and international negotiators could have gone so far on deportation plan without consulting Italy; role of Italian priests in talks noted; Vatican is pushing for solution that involves Italy, but Italian officials note church has no right to assume consent (M)

headline: In Hong Kong
abstract: Travel article on Hong Kong; highlights noted; photo (M)

headline: Britain and Spain Seek Backing for European Policy on Migrants
abstract: Migration and ensuing social problems move to center of political debate in almost all 15 countries in European Union, and in many of former Communist countries that wish to join EU and often serve as transit lands for illegal migrants; Prime Ministers Tony Blair of Britain and Jose Maria Aznar of Spain agree to call for Europe-wide policy to get tough on illegal migrants at EU summit meeting June 21-22 in Spain, where Aznar will have strong voice in drawing up agenda; two men are considering proposal to withhold aid to countries that fail to restrict flow of migrants or do not crack down on so-called people traffickers; they agree that EU should draw up common immigration and asylum policy to offset tough measures they are proposing (M)

headline: How Enron Got California To Buy Power It Didn't Need
abstract: Enron Corp traders gave code names to complex trading strategies they employed in 2000 and 2001 to maximize gains in California's wholesale electricity market; Enron is no longer in trading business, and interim chairman Norman P Blake Jr condemns company's old tactics as 'seemingly gaming the business' and 'very offensive,' in testimony before Senate panel; documents released this week by federal regulators and interviews with California officials indicate that when Enron was flying high, its trading tactics exploited weaknesses in state's energy markets to hilt; one set of strategies, which traders called Death Star and Load Shift, involved creating appearance of congestion on California's power grid and then arranging for state to pay Enron to relieve congestion; Sen Barbara Boxer criticizes Enron for tampering with state's wholesale energy market after deregulation; diagram; photos of Gov Gray Davis and Boxer (M)

headline: Debt Issues for Sale During the Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills; a four-week bill on Tuesday and a two-year note on Thursday.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.69 percent; on the six-month issue 1.84 percent and on the four-week bill 1.64 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 3.39 percent.

headline: DYNEGY'S CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER QUITS
abstract: Rob Doty resigns as chief financial officer of Dynegy Inc (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: Europe BELGIUM: Inquiry In Killing Of Immigrants ; IRELAND: Investigation Of Bombing Tip; BRITAIN: Gurkhas Sue For Equal Treatment ; LATVIA: Language Law Dropped.

headline: I.W. Burnham II, a Baron of Wall Street, Is Dead at 93
abstract: I W Burnham II, Wall Street financier, dies at age 93; photo (M)

headline: WEYERHAEUSER TO CLOSE PLANTS AND CUT 206 JOBS
abstract: Weyerhaeuser Co will eliminate 206 jobs as it closes lumber and paper plants in three states (S)

headline: Germany Braces for Strikes As Union Takes Off Gloves
abstract: Germany is bracing for most combative confrontation between unions and manufacturers in at least seven years; powerful metalworkers' union plans to start wave of strikes on May 6 that will move from factory to factory through country's industrial heartland; strikes could make it harder for Germany to bounce back from severe economic slowdown; union is demanding wage increases of 6.5 percent, about three times current inflation rate; industry leaders are openly warning about factory lockouts that would keep nonstriking workers from reporting for duty at factories where supplies had been disrupted by strikes at other companies; strikes pose serious political risk for German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, who pleaded in vain last week for agreement; Schroder's Social Democratic Party relies heavily on union support, but debilitating strike could cost party dearly in national elections this fall; graph; photo (M)

headline: Chief UN chemical weapons inspector hits back at U.S. criticism
abstract: PARIS:—  The head of the international chemical weapons watchdog agency, Jose Bustani, accused U.S. "hawks" Wednesday of undermining multilateral diplomacy by seeking to fire him and suggested that Washington saw his agency as an obstacle to its campaign against the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein.

headline: Executives Take On New Assignments
abstract: Leo Burnett Worldwide is opening ad agency in London named Made; Made is being led by Joakim Jonason and Simon Moore; Tim McHale and Tom Hespos are opening agency in New York called Underscore Marketing (S)

headline: KENNAMETAL AGREES TO BUY TOOL UNITS FROM MILACRON
abstract: Kennametal acquires Milacron's Indian and European metal-cutting tool units, Widia and Werko, for about $170 million (S)

headline: Protests Over Le Pen's Success Grow Across a Shocked France
abstract: Thousands took to the streets today to protest the unexpected success of the extreme rightist Jean-Marie Le Pen in qualifying for the presidential elections next month.

headline: Private Sector; It's a New Legal Jungle Out There
abstract: Tower C Snow, former chairman of prominent law firm Brobeck, Phleger & Harrison, will start new office for Clifford Chance Rogers & Wells and continue influencing evolution of consolidating legal industry (S)

headline: China Demands South Koreans Hand Over Refugees in Embassy
abstract: In an apparent hardening of its stance, the Chinese government demanded today that South Korea hand over several North Korean migrants who are holed up in its embassy in Beijing.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Anthem to Pay $4 Billion For Managed Care Company  Anthem, a large Blue Cross and Blue Shield company, announced that it was buying Trigon Healthcare, a managed care company in Virginia, for about $4 billion.    The deal is the latest in a wave of consolidations in the national federation of 43 Blue Cross plans. Analysts said Anthem paid a relatively high price, probably to pre-empt competing bids. Shares of Trigon surged. [Page C4.]    Andersen Steps Up Talks on Unit  Arthur Andersen is nearing a deal to sell its consulting business to KPMG Consulting, partners at Andersen said. [C2.]

headline: In Czar Peter's Capital, Putin Is Not as Great
abstract: Pres Bush will travel to Moscow for first summit in Russia with Pres Boris Yeltsin for what advisers describe as historic start to Russia's integration with West; will spend weekend with Putin in city of St Petersburg, founded by Russia's great Westernizer and first imperial czar Peter the Great, where many Russians say importance of meeting is not Russia's romance with West but shotgun nature of current courtship; meeting strips away notion of past summits that both countries were equals, since agenda will be overwhelmingly American; while Putin is not in complete agreement with agenda, his unassailably clear desire to lash Russia's fortunes to Europe leaves him little choice but to accept it; photos (M)

headline: Economists Push for Microsoft Penalties
abstract: Group of six leading antitrust economists, six days before closing arguments are scheduled in Microsoft Corp antitrust trial, file last-minute brief urging Federal Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly, who is presiding over case, to impose tough penalties on company; Microsoft argues that brief should be rejected, in part because economists Timothy Bresnahan and Daniel Rubinfeld worked for Justice Department while is was pursuing its case against Microsoft; other economists are Richard Gilbert, George Hay, Bruce Owen and Lawrence White (M)

headline: Canadian Unit To Join Deloitte
abstract: Arthur Andersen's partners and staff in Canada agree to join Deloitte & Touche; combined company in Canada will be led by Deloitte managing partner Colin Taylor; some Andersen partners will join board; Andersen Canada move is setback for Andersen Worldwide, which had hoped to merge all its operations outside United States with KPMG (M)

headline: CIRCUIT CITY TO DROP VHS MOVIES TO CLEAR WAY FOR DVD'S
abstract: Circuit City Group is eliminating VHS movies from its stores to make room for faster-selling DVD's; company has removed videocassette movies at some of its 622 stores and plans to stop selling them at other stores (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Mar 31 article on Ian M Russell: New York City parade his Scottish Power helped sponsor was National Tarday Day Parade; parade is not named for St Andrew's Day

headline: Article 2002042090438609490 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                       International              National              Nation Challenged              Politics             Business           -    Media & Advertising          -      World Business            -      Your Money            -      Markets            -      Company Research            -      Mutual Funds            -      Stock Portfolio            -      Columns               Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: An Ethics Code Can't Replace a Backbone
abstract: Jeffrey L Seglin column focuses on ethics code Harvard Business Review has adopted in wake of Suzy Wetlaufer's resignation as editor in chief in dispute over personal relationship she formed with Jack Welch while interviewing him for feature article; column holds companies writing such codes risk being seen as merely trying to brush aside past events and must convince employees that codes reflect true corporate values; drawing (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Salvatore DeMicco was named to the new post of marketing research analyst for the Organic Living Group at the New York office of Rodale Inc.

headline: Chirac and Le Pen Embark On Election's Final Round
abstract: Pres Jacques Chirac and Jean-Marie Le Pen begin campaigns for second round of French elections, Chirac denouncing rightist as outside respectable politics and Le Pen accusing president of flouting rules of democracy; tensions remain high as tens of thousands of demonstrators denounce Le Pen; Chirac, in Rennes, urges voters to wipe out embarrassment of Le Pen's success in first round (M)

headline: More Choices For Cheap Tickets
abstract: Online travel-booking site Expedia has announced that it will offer many of special Web fares of American Airlines, United Airlines and Delta Air Lines that until now had largely been restricted to Orbitz; Orbitz is rival Web site owned by five airlines--those three and Continental Airlines and Northwest Airlines (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Airline Merger Approved; JAPAN: Write-off At Softbank.

headline: AMERICAN AIRLINES PILOTS SEEK MEDIATION
abstract: Allied Pilots Association at American Airlines is expected to ask National Mediation Board to act as middleman in contract negotiations (S)

headline: U.S. Threatens Energy Traders With Limits On Pricing
abstract: Federal Energy Regulatory Commission threatens to strip four large energy traders of their ability to charge unregulated rates for electricity because of their responses to inquiries about whether they manipulated trading in California during 2000-01 power crisis; says El Paso Electric, Avista Corp and Portland General Electric, Enron unit, seem to have submitted false data, while Williams Cos has refused to answer key question; companies say they will quickly provide new data; Comr Nora Brownell says she expects companies to provide satisfactory explanations and retain rate authority, interview; White House gives Senate committee over 2,000 pages of documents detailing Enron-related contacts; plans to turn over more data later; expresses concern that panel will not agree to handle data in secure manner; Sen Joseph I Lieberman says documents will be kept in locked room and reviewed only by few staff members; says he or Sen Fred Thompson could make them public; Thompson favors tighter standards for releasing data (M)

headline: 10 Pakistani Soldiers Are Killed in Fight With Al Qaeda Suspects
abstract: Ten Pakistani soldiers were killed today in a gun battle, marking the deadliest encounter yet in the hunt for terrorists on the Pakistani side of the Afghan border.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN BREWER CONFIRMS IT IS IN TALKS FOR MILLER
abstract: South African Breweries confirms it is in preliminary talks to buy Miller Brewing from Philip Morris Companies (S)

headline: Prizes Given For Coverage Of Business
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson of New York Times and Rebecca Smith and John Emshwiller of Wall Street Journal are among winners of Gerald Loeb Awards for Distinguished Business and Financial Journalism; awards, which are administered by Anderson School at University of California at Los Angeles, honor print and broadcast journalists; among other winners are Paul E Steiger of Wall Street Journal, Duff Wilson and David Heath of Seattle Times, Jeffrey Meitrodt, Mark Schleifstein, Pamela Coyle and Ronette King of Times-Picayune, Janet Patton of Lexington Herald-Leader, David Henry and Nanette Byrnes of Business Week and Allan Dodds Frank and Lisa Slow of Cable News Network/CNNfn (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Apr 21 articr

headline: In Silicon Valley
abstract: Travel article on Silicon Valley, Calif, suggesting where to stay, where to eat and things to do; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Swissair Is Investigated
abstract: Criminal inquiry begins into financial underpinnings of collapsed Swiss national carrier, Swissair (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: U.N. Worker Freed
abstract: Mohamed Ali Abukar, UN worker kidnapped in Somalia, is released after almost month in captivity (S)

headline: Honeywell Says Asbestos Verdict Was More Than It Had Disclosed
abstract: Honeywell International appears to have misinformed analysts and shareholders about how much of $53.5 million verdict it is responsible for paying in case of Stephen Brown, who died of cancer caused by asbestos; Honeywell's stock dropped as much as 11 percent on Feb 8 when judgment was announced, shaving $3 billion off its market value; shares quickly rebounded after company said it has been found liable for less than $1.1 million of verdict; lawyers, who included both plaintiff and defense attorneys, said company's true responsibility was much greater; Honeywell now says it must pay at least $11 million of judgment; Honeywell's general counsel Peter M Kreindler says company plans to appeal verdict and has not misled investors about its size; adds company does not face financially significant liability from asbestos cases and has $2 billion in asbestos insurance; graph (M)

headline: Text of Merrill Lynch Statement
abstract: The following statement was issued by Merrill Lynch on Tuesday morning. /

headline: Drugs, Terror and Tuna: How Goals Clash
abstract: Bill to change import taxes on canned tuna illustrates how America's various strategic aims in wars on drugs and terrorism can clash, alienating important allies engaged in battling terrorism; bill includes provision to eliminate steep import taxes from Andean nations, in hope of creating jobs in Ecuador and Colombia as alternative to drug trade, but bill would keep taxes in place for countries like Philippines, where tuna is important industry and where 600 American soldiers are helping Philippine Army track Abu Sayyaf Muslim insurgents in fight against terrorism; officials in General Santos in Philippines warn that bill could wipe out its tuna industry, which employs thousands of people; Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo of Philippines, who has staked much political capital on helping US fight terrorism, says passage of trade provision would deal severe blow to economy there while handing propaganda victory to Abu Sayyaf movement; says this might create heavy domestic pressure for Philippines to retreat from its active support for American war on terrorism; Senate is considering trade bill; photo; map (M)

headline: Declines on Homes And Durable Goods
abstract: Commerce Department reports orders for durable goods declined 0.6 percent in March, to $173.4 billion, after 2.7 percent increase in February; says purchases of new single-family homes fell 3.1 percent, to annual pace of 878,000 (S)

headline: Reading Made Easier With Twice the Screen
abstract: New 2-VU laptop by Estari folds out to reveal two screens; user can view two full-page documents simultaneously; photo (M)

headline: After Ferocious Fighting, Sri Lanka Struggles With Peace
abstract: Reclusive Tamil rebel leader, Velupillai Prabhakaran, will meet hold news conference on April 10 for first time in more than decade, move regarded as most remarkable sign that peace process is gaining momentum on Sri Lanka; feels comfortable to surface without fear of government arrest because of cease-fire signed in late February; first face-to-face peace talks in seven years between rebels and government are expected to begin in May or June; photo (M)

headline: In a Paradise Torn by Feuding, Kashmiris Long for Independence
abstract: Most Kashmiris are disgusted with Pakistan and India, and want independence; in Srinagar, region of towering mountains and exquisite natural beauty has become war zone, with soldiers in full combat gear everywhere; residents fear to go out at night, and tourists shun the place; war, fear, death and destruction have taken heavy psychological toll; hospital doctors say major illlneses are depression and post-traumatic stress disorder; say suicide rates are climbing, primarily among teenagers; photo; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: New Microsoft Offices
abstract: Microsoft Corp will occupy two floors of Hong Kong's Cyberport, struggling project that is supposed to create campuslike setting for information technology businesses (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: Annan Pushes Reunification
abstract: United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan, visiting Cyprus, seeks to jump-start flagging reunification talks between rival Greek and Turkish communities; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Adds To Sales Force
abstract: Microsoft Corp is making largest addition to its sales force in decade, hiring 450 people as revenue growth slows (S)

headline: Scoring Credit Scorers
abstract: Gary Stevens letter on Apr 21 article holds credit scoring companies do a lot of damage

headline: COCA-COLA EXPANDS BEVERAGE PACT WITH DELTA AIR LINES
abstract: Coca-Cola Co expands its beverage agreement with Delta Air Lines Inc to include five international carries affiliated with Delta--Alitalia, Korean Air Co, Aeromexico, CSA Czech Airlines and Air France; carriers agree to stop selling PepsiCo for five years (S)

headline: U.S. Asks Caremark Rx for Documents
abstract: Caremark RX says United States attorney's office seeks documents about its relationship with TAP Pharmaceutical Products that focus on TAP's cancer drug Lupron and its ulcer drug Prevacid; says it is not target of probe and cooperates with government (S)

headline: TURKEY INFLUENZA CONTRIBUTES TO LOSS AT PILGRIM'S PRIDE
abstract: Pilgrim's Pride Corp will report loss in its most recent quarter because of disease in its turkey flock and weaker chicken prices (S)

headline: India to Ease Limits on Foreign Ownership in Media and Tea
abstract: India will relax restrictions on foreign ownership in print media and tea industries in effort to offset swelling current-account deficit; foreign owners could acquire stakes of up to 74 percent in technical journals and other nonnews publications, and up to 26 percent in newspapers and current-affairs periodicals; ban was imposed in 1955; editorial and management control would have to remain in Indian hands and in case of news publications, foreigners could not be largest shareholders; each deal and each foreign owner would have to obtain clearance from government; government also decides to allow 100 percent foreign direct ownership of tea plantations and other parts of tea industry (M)

headline: Arab Rakes Israeli Yeshiva With Gunfire; 3 Students Die
abstract: Palestinian gunman fires on Israeli settlement near Nablus, killing three young yeshiva students before being shot and killed; Israel dies in road ambush near Ramallah; attacks follow five suicide bombings in less than week; compound evidence that recent major Israeli military offensive did little to blunt Palestinian attacks; Israeli raids in Jenin, Hebron, Beit Jala and Qalqilya in West Bank leads to arrests of 14 Palestinians; Army remains in control of Bethlehem; map; photo (M)

headline: REVLON HIRES CLAIROL EXECUTIVE TO OVERSEE MAKEUP LINE
abstract: Revlon hires Debra Leipman-Yale, who was president of Clairol's international unit, as executive vice president and global general manager, replacing Cheryl Vitali, who resigned in February (S)

headline: Article 2002042590265378160 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //              JOB POSITIONS

headline: HALLIBURTON LOSES PATENT SUIT TO BJ SERVICES
abstract: BJ Services Co wins $98.1 million judgment for patent infringement against Halliburton Co, rival oil field services company, in case involving hydraulic fracturing method; Halliburton to appeal (S)

headline: The Workaround: 32 Steps to Frustration
abstract: Software companies issue what are known as workarounds, jury-rigged measures that call for users to 'work around' software bug; for example, certain versions of Microsoft's Outlook Express mangle e-mail messages that start with word 'begin'; proposed workaround posted on Microsoft's Web site advises people to use 'different word'; review of other software developers' posted workarounds; drawing (M)

headline: I.R.A.'s Illegal Arsenal Reduced In a 2nd Act of Disarmament
abstract: International commission charged with disarming Irish Republican Army says organization has for second time removed batch of weapons, ammunition and explosives from its illegal arsenal (M)

headline: Article 2002042194187222230 -- No Title
abstract: function pop_me_up(pURL, features){new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features);new_window.focus();}  function changeImage(image_name,image_src) {document.images[image_name].src = image_src;}  function MM_jumpMenu(targ,selObj,restore){ //v3.0eval(targ+".location='"+selObj.options[selObj.selectedIndex].value+"'"); if(restore) selObj.selectedIndex=0; } //                                                                                                                      International           -      Africa            -    Americas          -      Asia Pacific            -      Europe            -      Middle East               National              Nation Challenged              Politics              Business              Technology              Science              Health              Sports              New York Region              Education              Weather              Obituaries              NYT Front Page              Corrections                   Editorials/Op-Ed              Readers' Opinions

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: The Advertising Council, New York, elected 13 members to its board.

headline: Gates Says Court Ruling Could Doom Windows System
abstract: Microsoft Corp chairman Bill Gates insists in court that company will have to remove its Windows operating system from market if court adopts crucial proposal of states seeking tougher antitrust penalties against it; states want Microsoft to sell version of Windows that allows computer makers to replace Internet Explorer Web browser and several other components with software produced by rivals; proposal says stripped-down Windows must function without degradation (M)

headline: The ratings gap may widen, but CNN is still the ad revenue leader.
abstract: Fox News Channel widens its ratings lead over CNN in first three months of 2002 despite being available in eight million fewer homes; leads among viewers between ages 25 to 54, and O'Reilly Factor on Fox has largest audience of all cable news shows, beating CNN's top-rated Larry King Live; CNN viewership is up 55 percent from first quarter of 2001, and CNN still leads Fox in advertising revenues; MSNBC lags far behind in ratings, followed by CNBC; photo (M)

headline: With an industry convention drawing near, agencies try to accentuate the positive.
abstract: Omnicom Group substantially remakes its board to give greater weight to outside, independent directors as seven inside directors leave (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; The three big Internet portals begin to distinguish among themselves as shopping malls.
abstract: Forrester Research report advises retailers to advertise on only one of three main Internet shopping portals, Yahoo, MSN and America Online, and start appearing on more shopping-specific sites like Amazon and eBay; notes so-called big three attract same types of people; three plan new versions of their shopping areas to distinguish themselves from one another; Forrester analyst Carrie A Johnson notes online retailers that advertise with portals credit them with delivering 26 percent of their visitors and 19 percent of sales in 2001; photo (M)

headline: Powell, in His Comments, Outlines a 3-Point Strategy
abstract: Excerpts from news conference held by Secretary of State Colin L Powell in Jerusalem, on conclusion of his Middle East trip (M)

headline: Suit Against Hewlett Deal Is Dismissed
abstract: Fight over future of Hewlett-Packard Co appears to have all but ended, after Delaware Court Chancellor William B Chandler 3d dismises suit by Walter B Hewlett; door appears open to completing Hewlett-Packard's merger with Compaq Computer with Mr Hewlett's court challenge thrown out; Hewlett says he will not appeal to Delaware Supreme Court and will now back merger (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Accounting Issue
abstract: Royal Ahold sets conference call with analysts to clarify accounting issue that cause stock to drop sharply; Ahold's annual report noted that its 2001 earnings, prepared in accordance with United States accounting rules, would be 90 percent less than when prepared under Dutch standards; graph (S)

headline: Possibility Of Big Spinoff Seen at Sony
abstract: Sony of America chief financial officer Robert S Wiesenthal estimates Sony's entertainment businesses are worth $14 billion to $19 billion, meeting with analysts; meeting spurs speculation that Sony plans to sell stock in businesses (M)

headline: Big Companies With WorldCom Exposure Plan Write-Offs
abstract: American Express Co, General Electric and ProAssurance are among companies that plan huge write-offs in second quarter because of exposure to WorldCom; American Express will write down about $90 million; General Electric write off $110 million (M)

headline: BUSH IS CRITICIZED ON MIDEAST ROLE
abstract: Pres Bush, under rising criticism for handling of growing violence in Middle East, expresses frustration that Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat has failed to denounce suicide bombings; testily rebuts assertions during news conference that he has remained too detached from conflict; has not spoken directly to either Arafat or Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon in recent days, despite protestations that he has immersed himself in search for end to bloodletting; again urges Sharon to keep path to peace open, but makes no mention of UN resolution calling for withdrawal of Israeli forces from Ramallah which was backed by US; criticisms of his Mideast role by some members of Congress noted; Sec of State Colin Powell urges Sharon to think carefully about consequences of Israeli military action and wisdom of isolating Arafat; says Gen Anthony C Zinni, special envoy, will remain in region to help work toward cease-fire (M)

headline: Andersen Sends New Proposal For Settlement To Government
abstract: Lawyers for Arthur Andersen & Co, in effort to head off impending trial, submit proposed settlement of its criminal case to government, offering fewer concessions than prosecutors were seeking last week when talks collapsed; seeking last week when talks collapsed; settlement proposal is made in letter to Leslie Caldwell, head of Justice Department's Enron task force; Andersen reiterates its commitment to acknowledge wrongdoing as part of deferred-prosecution agreement but declines certain other provisions that government has sought; civil settlement talks between Andersen and creditors and shareholders of Enron are on brink of collapse; Andersen reaches tentative agreement to sell its risk management business to Robert Half International, human resources firm that specializes in providing professional staff like lawyers and accountants; deal is another sign of Andersen's efforts to sell business lines and move closer to audit-only model of accounting firm; managing partner C E Andrews comments; photo (M)

headline: Pace of New Factory Orders Is Reported as Fastest in 14 Years
abstract: Institute for Supply Management says its factory index rose to 55.6 in March from 54.7 in February; production index fell to 57.8 from 61.2; new-orders index rose to 65.3 from 62.8 in February; Commerce Department says construction spending rose in February at fastest pace in year; 1.1 percent increase in spending, to $879.4 billion at annual rate, was led by new homes; graph (M)

headline: A Leftist Surges in Brazil's Turbulent Presidential Election
abstract: Corruption accusations have thrown Brazilian presidential race into turmoil; polls show left-wing opposition challenger Luiz Inacio da Silva charging ahead of Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso's chosen candidate Jose Serra; vote is not until Oct, but surge of da Silva in his fourth run for presidency unnerves markets in Brazil and abroad; Serra's support drops sharply after corruption charges involving former campaign manager are made public; chart (M)

headline: The Navy and the Marines join forces for a campaign with Madison Avenue.
abstract: Pentagon has been promoting Navy and Marine Corps together in television and print ads since February; ad agency is J Walter Thompson; photo (M)

headline: Arts Festivals Buzz With Digital Deviltry
abstract: As computer technology takes hold in arts, multimedia works and high-tech performances are rapidly spreading across arts festival schedules; sound artist Liz Phillips will turn pulse of summer into sound with new interactive installation that will open in July at Lincoln Center Festival; sensors responding to changes in light and motion of passers-by trigger electronic devices that cause metallic bowls and other containers to emit sound as if they were loudspeakers; other digitally driven works described (M)

headline: Big Korean Chip Maker Fires Top Executives and Salomon
abstract: Hynix Semiconductor fired about one-third of its 60 senior executives today and discharged Salomon Smith Barney.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Unemployment Rises
abstract: German unemployment rises at fastest pace infive years in May, as companies continue to cut jobs to counter losses stemming from last year's economic slump; number of people out of work rises seasonally adjusted 60,000 (S)

headline: S.E.C. Is Investigating Adelphia Loans
abstract: Adelphia Communications, subject of several shareholder lawsuits, says Securities and Exchange Commission has opened formal inquiry into $2.3 billion in loans it backed to partnerships owned by family of chairman John Rigas; SEC is conducting informal inquiry into whether Adelphia adequately disclosed debt (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   8.00        Discount rate   1.25   1.25   4.50        Federal funds   1.75   1.68   4.67        3-month T-bills   1.67   1.69   3.79        6-month T-bills   1.87   1.91   3.79        10-yr. T-infl.   3.12   3.13   3.32        10-yr. T-note   5.23   5.19   5.15        30-yr. T-bond   5.73   5.66   5.66        Telephone bd.   7.80   7.78   7.95        Municipal bds.   5.35   5.33   5.42          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: MERRILL TO QUIT ONLINE JOINT VENTURE WITH HSBC
abstract: Merri

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: A Call For Inflation
abstract: International Monetary Fund senior adviser David Robinson says Japan's central bank should consider setting inflation target to end two and a half years of sliding prices (S)

headline: Wage Pact Reached By German Workers
abstract: German metal workers in Berlin and Brandenburg region adopt wage accord, suggesting series of strikes are near end; will get 4 percent raise in first year and 3.1 percent more in second; executives and economists say raises could lead to layoffs

headline: Egypt Assails The Lumping Of U.S. War With Israel's
abstract: Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak scores United States for letting Israel lump Palestinian struggle to end occupation into same category as war on terrorism in Afghanistan, televised speech; echoes impatience of other Arab officials with lack of peace initiatives from US, warning it undermines credibility of war on terrorism in Arab and Muslim worlds (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Personal Income: March    TUESDAY  Consumer Confidence: April

headline: BFMA SAYS IT IS CONSIDERING ANOTHER BID FOR MORTON'S
abstract: BFMA Holding Corp is considering another bid for Morton's Restaurant Group; urges Morton's shareholders to reject buyout offer from Castle Harlan (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Russians Pull Out Of Old U.S. Base
abstract: Russia pulls out of huge American-built port at Cam Ranh, Vietnam, where it has operated rent-free since 1979; foreign ministry spokeswoman rejects United States suggestion that port be opend to warships of all countries (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Tower Records Unit Sold
abstract: Tower Records Inc sells its Japanese unit to Nikko Cordial's Nikko Principal Investments Japan Ltd unit and Japanese unit's managers for $114 million; Keith Cahoon will continue to run Japanese unit (S)

headline: Diplomatic Memo; A Wider Atlantic: Europe Sees a Grotesque U.S.
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell encounters grumbling from European allies about various American policies and actions at meeting of North Atlantic Treaty Orgn foreign ministers in Reykjavik, Iceland; much of back talk is just that, but there is also real and deep European concern about everything from sharp differences over social policy on various issues to Bush administration's insistence that it will pursue its own course in Iraq; Pentagon and vast military machine at its command tend to intimidate Europeans, and Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld's brisk presentation of war in Afghanistan has often antagonized Europeans who dwell on American bombing mistakes and victims; many diplomats praise Powell, who is administration's chief representative of softer-edged, multilateralist, talk-it-over side of American foreign policy, and who spends more time than most of his colleagues in Washington consulting, reassuring and working with allies (M)

headline: Russia and China Called Top Business Bribers
abstract: Transparency International,independent anticorruption organization, says Russian and Chinese companies are considered most flagrant bribe-payers in richer nations seeking contracts by 800 business experts in 15 emerging-market countries; says Taiwan and South Korea are close behind; says there is perception that anti-bribery laws in United States and other industrial nations are not deterring bribe-payers from multinational companies based in West and Japan; Transparency International introduced 'bribe payers' index' in 1999; chart (M)

headline: DataBank; In a Losing Week, Technology Suffers Most
abstract: Stocks lost ground in week ending Apr 5, with technology stocks battered for much of week; graphs (S)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: DEALS AGERE TO SELL CHIP UNIT Agere Systems, the maker of communications chips that was spun off from Lucent Technologies, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a unit that makes chips for directing voice traffic on networks to Legerity for $70 million. Agere will transfer all 50 employees of the unit to Legerity, a former unit of Advanced Micro Devices that is majority owned by the buyout firm Francisco Partners.   (Bloomberg News) LIBERTY TO BUY WINK Liberty Media, the cable television company, said yesterday that its broadband unit had agreed to buy Wink Communications, an interactive television company, for $99.9 million. Wink shareholders will get $3 a share in cash, the companies said. The offer from Liberty is 76 percent more than Wink's closing price of $1.70 on Friday. Wink, based in Alameda, Calif., allows TV viewers to use a remote control to get facts about advertised products or to buy them.   (Bloomberg News) E-COMMERCE AMAZON TO WORK WITH VIRGIN ENTERTAINMENT The Virgin Entertainment Group said yesterday that it would give Amazon.com day-to-day control of its e-commerce operation. Users who type in the address of Virgin's Web site are now taken to an Amazon site, where they can buy the same range of music, videos and books available on Amazon's main site, but with entertainment news, gossip and other information from Virgin's staff. Virgin will receive an undisclosed commission on each sale.   Bob Tedeschi (NYT) HARDWARE OUTLOOK EVEN FOR I.B.M. I.B.M.'s effort to cut costs and drop losing businesses will make up for most of the slowing in its sales this year, a Goldman Sachs & Company analyst said yesterday. Though she cut profit estimates, the analyst, Laura Conigliaro, wrote that restrained spending by I.B.M. customers and recent cost cuts

headline: Lawmakers Reaffirm Israel Support
abstract: American Israel Public Affairs Committee holds annual meeting and hears raft of Bush administration and members of Congress reaffirm support for Israel; speakers include Sen leader Tom Daschle and Republican whip Tom DeLay (S)

headline: Market Place; A Family Affair at Adelphia Communications
abstract: Many investors may have been surprised by recent financial revelations from Adelphia Communications, nation's sixth-largest cable television company; last week's disclosure--that Rigas family, which controls company, borrowed at least $2.3 billion from banks in which Adelphia guaranteed loans without recording that fact on books--should not have come as shock; Oren Cohen, debt analyst at Merrill Lynch, says Rigases, who run their empire from Coudersport, Pa, have long history of 'being extremely aggressive in pursuing their own interests'; company's shares fall to their lowest level since 1997 as Adelphia acknowledges that its bookkeeping has become focus of Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry; stock has plunged 45.8 percent sine last week's disclosure; shares, which end trading day at $11.04, down 79 cents, were worth $43 as recently as last June; Rigas family owns about 60 million shares, or about 24 percent of company; shares were worth about $1.2 billion before disclosure and are now worth $660 million; graph; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Confirms U.S. Cooperation in Investigating Canadian Deaths
abstract: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld reiterated today that the United States will cooperate fully with Canada in investigating the accidental killing of four Canadian soldiers in Afghanistan.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Bosnian Serb Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: Drako Mrdja, former Bosnian Serb police commander, pleads not guilty to war crimes charges at trial in The Hague; is accused of participating in massacre of Bosnian Muslim prisoners in 1992 (S)

headline: Awaiting an Inventor
abstract: Vincent Restivo letter on Mar 28 article offers additional suggestion for wish list of inventions

headline: Airport Improvements Are Adrift After Sept. 11
abstract: Many airport improvement projects are being delayed or scaled back because airports are using funds to focus on security measures; Jayne M O'Donnell, vice president of Turner Construction charged with overseeing company's aviation group, counts $6 billion in current projects, reduction of $5.95 billion from what was in works before pojects were halted after terrorist attacks; photo (M)

headline: Officials Got a Windfall Before Enron's Collapse
abstract: Documents filed in bankruptcy court show year before Enron Corp collapsed last December, about 100 executives and energy traders collected more than $300 million in cash payments from company; more than $100 million went to former chairman-chief executive Kenneth L Lay; majority of cash payments went to employees at units whose profitability has been called into question since company's collapse; John J Lavorato, top executive at Enron's energy-trading unit, and gas trader John D Arnold each received cash bonuses of $8 million to keep them from leaving Enron last fall; former chief executive Jeffrey K Skilling received $7.5 million in cash bonuses and incentive pay; Lay got $10.6 million in similar payments; former Enron Energy Services executive David W Delainey received $4.2 million; Senate Finance Committee says it is looking into whether top executives at Enron placed their bonuses in offshore accounts and had later withdrawn that money without paying taxes; chart (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Take 2 Posts Profit, But Shares Fall
abstract: Take 2 Interactive Software reports profit of $9.64 million in second quarter, in contrast to loss of $11.5 million a year earlier; sales rise to $88.2 million from $170.3 million (S)

headline: U.S. Is Said to Be Closer To a Deal With Andersen
abstract: Talks between Arthur Andersen and federal prosecutors continue, with both sides edging closer to settlement of criminal charges against Andersen in Enron case; two sides reportedly squabble over wording of draft plea accord; signs are emerging that other Andersen problems might play role in talks; Arizona Atty Gen Janet A Napolitano, who has been negotiating with Andersen to settle potential charges related to collapse of another Andersen client, Baptist Foundation of Arizona, urges Atty Gen John Ashcroft to ensure that any fines Andersen might pay to settle Enron charges go to Andersen's victims (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Costa Rica: Loser In Election Attacked
abstract: Abel Pacheco wins Costa Rican presidential runoff election, with 58 percent of vote; photo; loser, Rolando Araya, is hospitalized after Pacheco supporters beat him with stick (S)

headline: In New Rebuff to U.S., Sharon Pushes Military Sweep
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon, rebuffing United States demand for withdrawal, vows to continue Israeli's military sweep through West Bank; Israel's security cabinet decides on move after Palestinian suicide bomber attacks bus, near Haifa, killing eight passengers; Sharon holds US and other nations should not press Israel; Israel says up to 200 Palestinians, mostly armed men, have been killed Jenin; Palestinian resistance in city, fiercest Israelis have faced, seems to be ebbing; Israeli forces withdraw from three villages, but continue hunting suspected militants in major cities and towns and some other villages; more missiles and mortars are fired at northern Israel from Lebanon despite US efforts to persuade Syria to curb Hezbollah militants; map; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Dealing With Cable Debts Ntl, BRITAIN: Shell's Profit Falls; SWITZERLAND: Interest Rate Cut; IRELAND: Drug Maker's Profit Is Down.
